DOC.TEXT: -Hogares CREA gradua mas de quinientos jovenes reeducados
-Departamento de Comercio no descarta privatizar Plaza del Mercado de Ponce
-Sostienen desempleo y criminalidad van de la mano
-Adolescente palestina muerta por disparos del ejercito y de colonizadores judios
-Walesa consulta sobre nuevo gobierno; tyminski sale de polonia
CREA-GRADUACION

El Comite Timon Central de Hogares CREA informo que este mes se graduan de esa institucion mas de quinientos jovenes que fueron reeducados en los programas y que se reintegran a la comunidad como ciudadanos utiles a la misma. Jose Juan Garcia, presidente de Hogares CREA se mostro orgulloso con los logros obtenidos por esa institucion hasta ahora y aprovecho la ocasion para felicitar a los miles de hombres y mujeres que colaboran con la obra que se lleva a cabo en unos 73 centros de rehabilitacion. No obstante, Garcia hizo un llamado a la comunidad puertorriquena, especialmente a los comerciantes e industriales a ofrecerle su respaldo a los jovenes que se graduan este mes de manera que puedan lograr un empleo que les permita alcanzar sus metas y objetivos en su proceso de reintegracion a la sociedad. Garcia aseguro que la experiencia habida hasta ahora en las empresas privadas con las personas reeducadas en Hogares CREA ha sido muy buena, al extremo que los empresarios que han empleado a jovenes egbresados de esa institucion asi lo han manifestado y brindan ayuda a la institucion para seguir con los programas de rehabilitacion.
GOBIERNO-COMERCIO

La moderna Plaza del Mercado de Ponce, que funciona aqui hace anos con serias dificultades economicas podria ser privatizada, si el gobierno consigue inversionistas que se hagan cargo de la estructura, reconocio hoy el Secretario del Departamento de Comercio, Jorge R. Santiago. El funcionario anuncio que la instalacion, que cubre una manzana en el centro tradicional de Ponce, pierde un millon de dolares al ano en su operacion y reconocio que esta cifra debe ser absorbida por su agencia. Santiago dijo que la enorme estructura tiene amplios costos que elevan sus perdidas, entre ellas un sistema de aire acondicionado central y modernas faciliadades de elevadores y escaleras electricas. ``Esto se planifico asi y hay que bregar con eso'', dijo Santiago al hablar con periodistas, cuando se le pregunto si las perdidas de la facilidad son producto de una mala planificacion. Santiago reconocio ademas que han fracasado en el pasado intentos de que companias privadas se encarguen de la operacion de la plaza, donde operan decenas de pequenos comercios.
GOBIERNO-CRIMINALIDAD

El presidente de la Junta de Libertad Bajo Palabra, Lorenzo Villalba, anuncio que el proximo ano tratara de implementar un plan con la Administracion del Derecho al Trabajo (ADT) para conseguirle empleos a los reclusos que se acojan a los beneficios de libertad bajo palabra. Sostuvo que gran parte del problema de la criminalidad en el pais se debe al desempleo, al punto de que se requiere que los reclusos que en el futuro saldran a la calle puedan tener un trabajo antes de disfrutar de la libertad. ``Tenemos un gran ejercito de personas en la calle que estan empleados en la economia subterranea'', dijo Villalba al anunciar que ya se reunio con la direccion de ADT para tratar de resolver el problema de falta de trabajo para los reclusos que se acogen a los beneficios de libertad bajo palabra de esa agencia. Se espera que el proximo ano ADT inicie un plan piloto para conseguir empleo a las personas liberados bajo los beneficios de la Junta de Libertad Bajo Palabra.
Israel-palestinos

Jerusalen (ap) - una palestina de 13 anos fue muerta hoy a tiros cuando los soldados y colonizadores judios dispararon contra estudiantes arabes que apedrearon vehiculos israelies en la ocupada margen occidental del rio jordan, dijeron fuentes oficiales y arabes. El ejercito confirmo la muerte y dijo que investiga las circunstancias. El tiroteo ocurrio dos dias despues que el ministro de defensa moshe arens lanzo una nueva ofensiva contra los palestinos apedreadores, y coloco tiradores especializados en cruces carreteros importantes en la margen occidental con ordenes de disparar, ademas de pedir penas mas severas para quienes sean convictos de las pedreas.
polonia-politica

Varsovia (ap) - el presidente electo lech walesa renuncio hoy a la presidencia del movimiento solidaridad, y pidio apoyo al gremio independiente para sus reformas orientadas hacia una economia de mercado libre. Su rival derrotado, el hombre de negocios stanislaw tyminski, salio hoy de polonia rumbo a canada para depositar una fianza de 100.000 Dolares para asegurar su regreso para responder a cargos de calumnias. ''Deseo agradecerles su colaboracion en nuestro esfuerzo'', dijo walesa a la comision nacional de solidaridad, reunida en gdansk. ''Ello representa un honor, y al mismo tiempo una enorme responsabilidad'', agrego. ''Espero que ustedes respalden las reformas polacas'', agrego. El dirigente insto a solidaridad a mantenerse activa en las eleccione parlamentarias libres del segundo trimestre de 1991, y construir asi la base necesaria para respaldar su gestion al frente del pais en el dificil momento de la transicion del comunismo al capitalismo.

Autoridades detienen sujeto disparo contra anciana

Por Frank Gaud
MAYAGUEZ (AP) - Un sujeto de 20 anos de edad fue detenido hoy y acusado en relacion con un incidente donde resulto herida de bala una mujer de 75 anos de edad que se encontraba en un salon de belleza en la calle Ramos Anotonini, en el centro de Mayaguez. El agente Jose Pantoja, de la Seccion de Delitos contra la Persona del Cuerpo de Investigaciones Criminales (CIC) de la Policia identifico al detenido como Jose R. Justiniano Ramos, un celador del estacionamiento del Centro Medico de Mayaguez. Segun la investigacion de la POlicia, Justiciano Ramos, quien reside en la misma Calle Ramos Antonini, donde ocurrieron los hechos, supuestamente jugaba con una pistola junto a otro amigo y se le escapo un disparo que hirio a Eugenia Ortiz, quien reside en la calle Arroyo Mestre, de esta ciudad. La mujer permencia hoy en el Centro Medico de Mayaguez en ``estado de cuidado'' mientras que el sujeto detenido fue ingresado en la carcel de Guayama con 17,500 dolares de fianza que le impuso el juez municipal Miguel Magranel Lizzardi, por cargos de tentativa de asesinato y violacion a la ley de armas, dijo la Policia. El arma que alegadamente utilizo el sospechoso no fue ocupada pero el agente Santos Gonzalez, director de la Seccion de Homicicios del CIC local, explico que se habia ocupado una caja de bala. Gonzalez describio al detenido como ``una persona que ya habia cumplido carcel por violacion a la ley de armas''. Por otro lado, el agente Nelson Santana, tambien del CIC de Mayaguez, dijo que se busca al sujeto Jose Quintana Bermudez por su presunta relacion con el asalto a una estacion de gasolina del barrio Mani, tambien de Mayaguez. El juez municipal Rafael Lugo Rodriguez le fijo en ausencia una fianza de 42 mil dolares por los hechos ocurridos el 3 de diciembre pasado cuando David Santiago, empleado de una estacion de gasolina, afirma que Quintana Bermudez lo asalto y le llevo unos 600 dolares luego de amenazarlo con un arma de fuego.

DOC.HEAD: East Europe Revolution Can't Change Geography, Economics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Europe generally turned its back on the Soviet Union after the region's Communist rulers bowed to popular revolt a year ago, but trade and geography make the huge neighbor impossible to ignore. New governments must balance the lingering emotion of revolution with economic and political reality. They rejoice over the departure of Soviet soldiers and the Warsaw Pact's impending demise, but warily watch the floundering giant that supplies most of their oil and much of the electricity, natural gas and timber, and buys their mediocre consumer goods. Some East Europeans wonder whether they are trading one form of domination for another. ``It is well known that Hungary's energy supplies are largely based on Soviet raw materials,'' Laszlo Lengyel, an economist and political scientist, wrote in the Hungarian labor daily Nepszava. ``There is no need for tanks to maintain their influence in the region.'' Anger and distrust toward the Soviet Union are evident among ordinary people throughout the region. In Bulgaria, once the Kremlin's closest ally in the Soviet bloc, only 30 percent of those polled favored close ties with Moscow and 75 percent were against celebrating Nov. 7, the Soviet Union's Revolution Day. In countries where the study of Russian was required for generations, hardly anyone seems to understand it. People are learning English and German instead. Statues of Lenin have come down and places named for Soviet heroes and their local cohorts have been rechristened. Andras Hegedues of Hungary, the only living signer of the Warsaw Pact, feels Eastern Europeans always must keep their powerful neighbor in mind. Even if the Soviet Union disintegrates, Russia, its largest republic, ``will remain a military power,'' he said. Richard Sumann, director of Czechoslovakia's Foreign Investment Agency, said: ``We must prepare for a situation where the Soviet republics are independent, or more independent.'' Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Romania border the Soviet Union. Bulgaria is tied to the eastern Slavs by language and custom. The Soviet Union says the close ties of four decades were forged by more than Soviet military might. ``Eastern Europe is Eastern Europe, and it will exist as Eastern Europe forever,'' said Oleg A. Grinevsky, the Soviet delegate to talks on reducing conventional weapons in Europe. ``We have historic, economic, and political ties, and it is impossible to exclude them from everyday life.'' In addition to most of its oil, Hungary gets about one-third of its electricity from the Soviet Union. Other Eastern European countries are equally dependent on the Soviets, with little opportunity to change. Cheap and reliable energy supplies are disappearing along with Soviet political domination. Beginning in 1991, the Soviets will demand the market price in dollars for oil delivered to East European countries instead of the much lower prices by complex agreements within the Comecon economic alliance. Several former Soviet bloc nations sought oil supplies from Iraq, then the Persian Gulf crisis tightened supplies and drove prices up. Eastern European countries have pledged to obey the U.N. sanctions on Iraq. Soviet oil supplies to Czechoslovakia this year will be at least 18 million barrels short of the 116 million promised. Poland is expected to get only 70 million barrels, nearly 20 million less than expected. Hungary and Romania have reeived less electricity from the Soviet Union than anticipated. The Soviet economy is in such chaos that Moscow could not even promise supplies of chemicals, coal, timber, cellulose, paper products and consumer goods, said Laszlo Timar, who oversees Hungary's trade with the Soviet Union. ``Their problems and troubles are very big, and we cannot rely on these problems being solved in a short period,'' Timar said. Germany is replacing the Soviet Union as Hungary's main trade partner, but the Soviets are not likely to fall below second or third, he said. That is a matter of geography. According to Timar, when Hungary and the others begin paying the world price for Soviet oil, the Soviets probably will prefer them as customers because pipelines exist to deliver it. When Hungary imposed stiff gasoline price increases in October, taxi drivers and truckers blocked roads for a weekend, virtually shutting down the country. The government struck a deal with the protesters after threatening police or military action. Hegedues, who was premier of Hungary at the time of the 1956 uprising against Stalinism, said he felt ``civil war was in the air'' during the price protests. Gasoline price increases in Czechoslovakia set off two rounds of hoarding this year. Czechoslovak officials used looser rules within the Soviet Union to augment their oil supply. They cut through the Moscow bureaucracy to swap trucks, buses, bulldozers, cranes and consumer goods for 3.5 million barrels of oil from the Tyumen region of Siberia. Timar said Hungary was close to an agreement to trade its Ikarus buses for oil. The Soviet Union is a huge, hungry market for machinery, manufactured items and consumer goods produced in Eastern Europe. Beginning Jan. 1, that trade also will be conducted primarily in hard currency. Many of the products canno be sold in the West, but East European countries need to earn convertible currency from them. Timar estimated Hungary will lose 20 to 40 percent of its Soviet business next year, including half of its machinery market, because Soviet customers will be freer to buy from the West. He predicted Hungary will remain a major supplier to the Soviet Union because ``our products are well known there. We think that slowly, slowly, our exports will be increased, but they will be tragically cut back for the time being.'' Even though Hungarians look west, business will draw them east, he said: ``There is more personal interest in the West now, but to make money they will travel to Moscow.''

DOC.HEAD: Gotti Indictment: The Son Also Rises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Law enforcers say John J. Gotti's indictment could mean a promotion for his son John, whom they describe as a quick-fisted, barrel-chested Mafia prince with more brawn than brains. Because most of the top men in the Gambino crime family are under indictment, behind bars, or both, Gotti ``could very well try to run the family through his son,'' Jules Bonalovonta, the FBI's organized crime expert in New York, said in an interview last month. ``Well, nothing could please us more,'' he said. ``You're not talking about a brain surgeon.'' Bonalovonta said Gotti recently elevated his 26-year-old son - known universally as ``Junior'' - to the rank of capo, or captain. The father was indicted Wednesday on charges that he ordered the murder of his predecessor, and could be held without bail until his trial. Born Feb. 14, 1964, John A. Gotti was the first child of John J. and Victoria Gotti. After graduating from a military high school outside New York City in 1982, he apparently went right into the family business. In 1985, the younger Gotti allegedly slugged an off-duty policeman who was telephoning for help to break up a fight at a Queens diner, authorities said. In 1986, his driver's license was suspended after he ignored numerous traffic summonses, authorities said. In 1989, he was arrested for beating up three people outside a Long Island nightclub - one of several such brawls in which he has been embroiled, usually because one of his friends insulted or accosted a woman, authorities said. But Gotti seemingly inherited his father's talent for dodging prosecutorial bullets. He was found innocent of the diner assault after a man he allegedly threatened with a knife claimed to have kept his eyes closed throughout the fight. In the nightclub case, a grand jury refused to indict Gotti after witnesses said they could not identify any of the assailants. The younger Gotti describes himself as president of a Brooklyn trucking company, but investigators say he has his own crime ``crew'' involved in construction extortion, auto theft, loansharking and narcotics. ``Junior is treated with respect by the other (Mafia) crew leaders,'' an unidentified law enforcement source told the Daily News a year ago. ``They kiss him on the cheek like he's somebody special.'' But Junior takes orders, too. In a conversation recorded by investigators, John Gotti complained to his son that one of the son's friends had dropped Gotti's name in a telephone conversation about a criminal scheme. Gotti told his son the friend should desist or enter the hospital. ``Before you do anything,'' he said, ``you tell me first. ... Now make sure you see me tomorrow and I'll tell you what I want you to do there.'' ``All right,'' the son replied. The elder Gotti's lawyer, Bruce Cutler, describes Junior as an honors student, devoted son and ``health nut'' who has no social life because he works 14 hours a day as ``a totally legitimate businessman.'' As for drugs, Cutler says young Gotti ``won't even take an aspirin.'' Although he dresses as flamboyantly as his father, the 5-foot-9-inch Gotti is best known for his muscular physique, the product of many hours in the weight rooms of various Long Island health clubs. Earlier this year he married Kim Albanese, the daughter of a carpet installer with no apparent mob ties. His father stayed away from the ceremony in a successful attempt to make sure journalists did the same. Two months later the new Mrs. Gotti gave birth to a son, John A. Jr., John J. Gotti's first grandson. The family lives in a split level house in an expensive waterfront section of the Long Island suburb of Massapequa. Whatever his shortcomings, young Gotti apparently has some sense of duty. He helps out at his father's annual Fourth of July party for neighbors of the Gotti crew's Queens clubhouse. ``We don't do this for ourselves,'' he told a reporter last year. ``I got a house in the Poconos I'd rather be at.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll in Interstate Pileup Lowered to 13
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to move up reference to investigators looking at paper mill as possible contributor to fog. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `The lead...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Train Collision, Bjt
LaserPhoto CG1
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators studying a huge highway pileup reduced the death count from 15 to 13 on Wednesday, and said it was possible a paper mill added to the dense fog blamed for the 83-car wreck. The confusion over the number of people killed in Tuesday's crash on Interstate 75 stemmed from problems identifying the victims, said Robert Barlett, who heads the National Transportation Safety Board probe. More than 50 people were injured in the pileup about 40 miles north of Chattanooga. Federal investigators did not expect to find more victims, Barlett said at a news conference in nearby Cleveland. The pileup was caused by two separate chain-reaction crashes in the same spot of the interstate. Investigators first estimated 75 vehicles were involved, and raised the count to 83 on Wednesday. The lead vehicle in the accident on the southbound side of the road apparently was a truck that had slowed down and was rear-ended by another truck, said Barlett. A car apparently was the lead vehicle in the crash on the northbound side, he said. ``This was a most unusual fog, very intense, very difficult to see through,'' said Barlett. He said a fog warning light had been turned on for southbound lanes but not for northbound traffic. Investigators planned to conduct more interviews Thursday, said Barlett. He said videotapes and computers would be used to help reconstruct the crash. NTSB Vice Chairman Susan Coughlin said earlier that investigators would be looking at weather, highway design, driver response and environmental factors. Workers removed the last of the wreckage from the scene Wednesday but the southbound lanes remained closed. The rolling stretch of highway has a history of fog-related accidents and is just north of the Hiwassee River, where Bowater Southern Industries operates a paper mill east of the highway. Ms. Coughlin said investigators would talk to officials at Bowater and other plants about industry's possible contribution to the fog. But she emphasized that the query was just one part of the agency's investigation, which she said would take six to nine months to complete. ``To even speculate on anyone's involvement at this point would simply be prejudicial,'' Ms. Coughlin said. A 1978 study done by the University of Tennessee after a similar accident involving 62 vehicles concluded that the ``primary source of fog ... appeared to be the Bowater paper plant.'' Wayne Davis, a civil engineer who directed the study, said Wednesday that a paper plant by its nature contributes to fog problems. ``A paper plant is a process where you take wood, cook it and evaporate the water to make paper,'' Davis said. ``A tremendous amount of water is converted into steam. If you look around the nation, you will always find the potential for dense fog around paper plants.'' Bowater spokeswoman Astrid Sheil said Bowater considered that study flawed and that Tuesday morning's weather conditions could have occurred whether the paper plant was nearby or not. ``The weather conditions, with the inversion from the hot air during the day time and the cold ground, trapped the fog in,'' said Ms. Sheil. ``That is well documented and that's a natural phenomenon that happens at this time of year, especially in these areas. At least 51 people were taken to hospitals after the crash, and the Tennessee Emergency Management Agency treated others at the scene. Six people remained in critical condition Wednesday night. ``For three minutes after I stopped, cars kept hitting each other,'' Virgil Metts, who escaped serious injury, told the Chattanooga News-Free Press. ``They kept driving into the fog at 60 mph. ``It was deadly silent - a real eerie silence. You couldn't see anything because of the fog, and all you heard was exploding gas tanks.'' George and Margaret Dawson were in the southbound lanes Tuesday in a van packed with valuables for their retirement move from Michigan to Florida. Seconds later, those valuables were scattered across the highway. ``The whole back of the van is gone.'' Mrs. Dawson said. ``But after seeing some of the other people, we consider ourselves lucky. What a way to start retirement.''

DOC.HEAD: Planetary Alignment Will Interfere With Contact With Magellan
DOC.TEXT: An alignment of the planets will interfere with the Magellan spacecraft's ability to send pictures of Venus back to Earth for the next six weeks beginning Sunday, NASA says. During late October and early November, the sun was between Venus and Earth, forcing a two-week halt to Magellan's $744 million mission to use radar to map the surface of cloud-shrouded Venus. ``This time, Venus itself gets in the way,'' although mapping can continue, said Steve Wall, Magellan experiment representative at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Because of the relative positions of Earth and Venus as they orbit the sun, ``a straight line drawn from the spacecraft to the Earth goes straight through Venus'' for part of each day during the 42-day period, Wall said Wednesday. Magellan has already shown Venus is marked by quake faults, gargantuan flows of solidified lava and countless volcanoes, some of which may be erupting now.

DOC.HEAD: Writers Guild Agrees to Three-Year Contract Extension
DOC.TEXT: The Writers Guild of America has tentatively agreed to a three-year extension of its contract with movie and TV producers. ``I never thought it would happen in my lifetime. It means peace for five more years,'' George Kirgo, president of the guild's West Coast branch, said Wednesday. The agreement, which must be ratified by the guild's 10,500 members, calls for annual contract adjustment meetings. The guild staged a 22-week strike in 1988, virtually halting new projects until writers accepted a contract that was due to expire in May 1992. With the extension, the contract will run until May 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Two Freed Oil Men Trapped by Fate, Sustained by Faith, Families
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report. ^By LESLIE DREYFOUS
DOC.TEXT: Donald G. Whatley arrived in Kuwait on Aug. 1 at 10:30 p.m. He was at the Iraqi border by around 1 a.m., had a sandwich and was soon after in bed. By 3:45 a.m., ``the sky was saturated with helicopters, missile fire was showering down over my head.'' He never got a chance to relieve Charlie Amos, another American oil worker who was to have headed home Aug. 2. ``About 25 soldiers drove up (to the oil rig site) and they had guns,'' Amos said from his home in Gilmer, Texas. ``It was tense. We were taken into custody at 5:30 a.m. By 6:30 a.m., we were in Iraq.'' Among Saddam Hussein's earliest captives, both men by dawn had spent the first of many sleepless nights. Four months would pass before their vigil ended last week with the Iraqi leader's decision to free his ``foreign guests.'' It wasn't until Tuesday that Amos and Whatley let down. It wasn't until they'd finally collapsed into the arms of family, gathered around the kitchen table or nestled deep into familiar blankets that they truly knew rest. ``I've had four or five hours of sleep now and feel real fine,'' Whatley said from Shreveport, La. ``But the willpower's gone. All during it, I wouldn't let the Iraqis get into my head and break my mind. ... Now I'm exhausted.'' Whatley and Amos spoke in whispers, drained by their long journeys home from Iraq; numbed by the suddeness of Saddam's turnaround. All at once the monotony was broken, the fear shaken out of them like a bad dream. ``It's been such a long trip,'' Whatley, 48, said before joining his wife for breakfast, bacon and eggs like on just about any day. Amos said he was perhaps most stunned by an unexpected shock of sympathy for the guards left behind. After praying day and night for his freedom, ``It was actually rather emotional saying goodbye.'' Amos and Whatley were separated at the Baghdad hotel where they were taken shortly after the invasion. During Amos' stay at a barren site near Syria, Iraqi guards played pool with their captives and scared up a few old spy novels. If he wanted a little exercise, Saddam's men went along for the run. ``It was a group activity ... they were actually friendly,'' said Amos, 60, who with Whatley works for Santa Fe Drilling Co. ``They didn't like what they were doing any better than we did.'' Guards told Amos, who has been drilling oil in the Middle East for the better part of 20 years, that he was being held at an abandoned phosphates mine. But, he said haltingly, ``It didn't look like that.'' The site, he said, looked more like a military or chemical installation. ``I tried not to think about it,'' Amos said before going to sleep for the first time since leaving Baghdad for home Sunday via Germany. Whatley said his Iraqi guards never called him a ``human shield.'' But he, like Amos, could guess at his part in Saddam's strategy by looking at the series of power plants and satellite centers that were his home over the weeks. ``We were meant to deter attacks,'' Whatley said. It was perhaps that threat of death that bound captor and captive: ``The installation where we were, we'd have been the first to die,'' Whatley said. While living in the shadow of that knowledge, Whatley had nothing to go on but the wife and family he holds so close. ``Hope is what I held on to,'' said the oil worker, who received two letters from his wife while in captivity. Doris Whatley, meanwhile, heard nothing at all. Like relatives of so many of the 900 U.S.hostages, she spent 4{ months as a human barometer. Their emotions have risen and receded depending on the threat of war. Sarrah Amos slept on a couch in the living room, bathed in the television's bluish light and ear cocked to the telephone always somewhere near at hand. ``I know emotionally our families had it worse than we did,'' Amos said. ``We knew where our families were located and their conditions. They knew nothing.'' Until Sarrah Amos and Doris Whatley awoke last Thursday to the news, they'd given up hoping for anytime soon: their husbands were coming home. ``It came as a surprise for us, too,'' said Amos, the father of three adult children. ``It came as such as glorious surprise.''

DOC.HEAD: Gruesome Child-Abuse Case Brings New Criticism of Florida System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report. ^By DAN SEWELL
DOC.TEXT: The case of a badly beaten 3-year-old boy who died after being dumped near a bayfront home has generated new alarm about Florida's child-protection system. The state passed child-abuse reforms and boosted spending after last year's widely publicized death of 2-year-old Bradley McGee, who was under state supervision but was returned home in spite of reports of abuse. He died from being dunked repeatedly into a toilet because he had soiled his pants. Four state social services workers were charged in that case. One was convicted of felony child abuse for negligence and placed on three years' probation. The latest case involved a boy who was returned to his mother's custody after she left him with a sitter for three months. Chief Dade Juvenile Judge William Gladstone summoned state social services officials to a hearing Friday to find out what happened to the boy, initially known as ``Baby Lollipops.'' He was told of a lack of training and crushing caseloads - the boy's caseworker had 50 children, compared with a national standard of 12 per child-protection caseworker. ``This case is my failure, too,'' Gladstone said, his eyes tearing. ``We all failed. Somehow, this child was killed, and he was killed by every person in this state.'' Baby Lollipops was found Nov. 2 beside a wall around a bayfront Miami Beach home. The extensive injuries and severe neglect, including a days-old diaper held with packing tape, were ``incomprehensible,'' said police detective Tom Hoolahan. Before the boy's identity was determined, officers named the victim after the lollipops on his T-shirt. Dade County's medical examiner, Dr. Joseph Davis, said Monday it was the worst case of child abuse he has ever seen in 34 years in the office. The boy's mother and her female lover were arrested Dec. 5 on first-degree murder charges. Police said the mother, Ana Marie Cardona, admitted she and girlfriend Olivia Gonzalez, 24, left the boy in a yard in an upscale neighborhood, hoping he would be found by a wealthy family. They fled with two other children to the Orlando area. The boy wasn't found for four days. It turned out the boy was Lazaro Figueroa, who with his sister had been placed under state supervision two years earlier. That was after their mother left them with a baby sitter and didn't return for three months, authorities said. Lazaro's father was a drug dealer killed four weeks before his birth. The children were returned to Ms. Cardona, now 29, because there was no evidence of abuse, the state Health and Rehabilitative Services Department said. However, Ms. Cardona and her three children - the department wasn't aware of the third - subsequently moved and the agency lost track. The caseworker didn't report Ms. Cardona's disappearance to the court for four months. The caseworker has not been charged. Department spokesman Steve Konicki said criticism of the caseworker was unfair because at the time she was hired the state had no training for child-protection workers. The worker wasn't aware at the time the mother moved that she should go to court and seek a police pick-up order. The caseworker tried diligently on her own to locate the family, Konicki said, but simply hadn't been properly trained. She had been since, he said. ``This is a case that proves why we need what we have now,'' Konicki said. There also have been reforms in the department's background checks, computerization of records, and tightening of standards on separating children from abusive parents. State Rep. Mike Abrams, a legislative leader on children's issues, said the case could bring more reforms. Abrams said caseworkers are still ``underpaid, undertrained, overwhelmed by their caseload.'' Starting pay for workers is $16,000 to $20,000 a year, and 42 percent quit in their first year. Jack Levine, executive director of the advocacy group Center for Children and Youth, said the wonder is there aren't more such tragedies. ``The only children's program in Florida without a waiting list is the morgue,'' Levine said.

DOC.HEAD: Wilson Clamps Tight Secrecy Lid on Appointment of Successor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report. ^By DOUG WILLIS
DOC.TEXT: Gov.-elect Pete Wilson is giving no clues about who he'll pick as his successor in the U.S. Senate. The possibilities include Sonny Bono, Peter Ueberroth and National Security Council aide Condoleezza Rice. ``We neither confirm nor deny any names. The senator is not talking about it,'' Wilson spokesman Bill Livingstone said. ``There's no set timetable on when he's going to make a decision,'' Livingstone added. He said Wilson's first priority is preparing the budget message he will deliver three days after taking office, and that a Senate successor probably won't be named for several more weeks. Wilson's selection of his successor could be one of his toughest political decisions. The California Republican Party is sharply divided between anti-abortion and pro-choice advocates and between conservatives and moderates on fiscal and environmental issues. Wilson, who narrowly won the gubernatorial election last month, must resign his Senate seat before taking his oath of office Jan. 7. Under state law, his appointee will assume Wilson's U.S. Senate seat without any confirmation until California's next general election in 1992, when the new senator must stand election for what then will be the remaining two years on Wilson's term. California's senior senator, Democrat Alan Cranston, has announced he will retire when his term ends in 1992, so both Senate seats will be on the same ballot. Since the winner of Cranston's seat gets a full six-year term, it is viewed as the greater prize. But so far, most potential candidates in both parties are waiting for Wilson's appointment before committing themselves to either race. Wilson and his staff have refused comment on all speculation except to confirm when a rumored contender has asked to be eliminated from consideration. So far, three people have done so, including U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. Bono, the singer-turned-mayor of Palm Springs, has said repeatedly that he is interested in running. It is not clear whether Republican power brokers take him seriously, but he has wide name recognition and presumably could tap wealthy entertainment interests for campaign contributions. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner who made millions in the travel agency business, has been considered a major contender for public office since he organized the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles and turned the games into a major money-maker. He has been linked most commonly to running for the U.S. Senate and in 1986 and 1988 was seen as a possible candidate by some Republicans. But he was also talked about as a successor to retiring Gov. George Deukmejian. Other rumored prospects include Rice, a National Security Council adviser who is the highest ranking black woman in President Bush's administration; U.S. Reps. Tom Campbell, David Dreier, Jerry Lewis and Robert Dornan; state Sens. Marian Bergeson and Ken Maddy; and Orange County Supervisor Gaddi Vazquez, one of California's highest ranking Hispanic Republicans. Wilson has said he is looking for someone who agrees with his moderate GOP views. ``I'll try to find someone who s as nearly like myself as possible,'' Wilson said. But he hasn't commented on what weight he would give to which of his political priorities, which include a pro-choice abortion stand, sympathy with environmental causes and conservative stands on the death penalty. Livingstone says the only people Wilson is confiding in are his wife, Gayle, and his longtime chief of staff, Bob White. They both refuse to comment. ``There's no structure like you have in a judicial selection, where you have an advisory group,'' Livingstone said. ``There is no front-runner that I know of. The (eventual) nominee may not even be on that list.''

DOC.HEAD: Historian Named to NYU Presidency
DOC.TEXT: L. Jay Oliva, a scholar of Russian history who lives with his wife in a student dormitory at New York University, has been named the next president of NYU. Oliva, who is chancellor of NYU, was designated by the board of trustees Tuesday to succeed John Brademas as president of the nation's largest private university in 1992. Brademas announced last summer his plans to step down at age 65. Oliva, 57, is the first NYU faculty member selected to lead the university in its 159-year history. The university has 44,000 students. He has been at the university since 1960, starting in the history department before moving into the administrative ranks as dean, vice president, provost and chancellor. His books include ``Russia in the Era of Peter the Great,'' published in 1969. Oliva still teaches a class in Russian history and said in an interview that he plans to continue. In keeping with an accessible, easygoing style that made him the odds-on favorite for the presidency, Oliva added that he and his wife plan to stay in student housing after he takes office. Brademas, a former 11-term Indiana congressman, served as NYU president since 1981. He was considered a formidable fund-raiser - more than $800 million in a decade - and helped move NYU's fine arts, accounting and business schools into the front ranks nationally. The school also became one of the nation's most expensive. Fixed charges this fall came to $21,400. ``The momentum NYU has achieved provides us the opoortunity over the next decade to move to the front ranks of the nation's premier urban research universities,'' Oliva said.

DOC.HEAD: Darman Draws Heat in Policy Dispute With Administration Colleague
DOC.TEXT: Budget director Richard G. Darman, whose tax and budget maneuvering drew criticism from both parties, is again in the eye of a policy storm as he wages an unusual battle against a junior colleague. As he works on what some associates say may be his final budget, Darman seems to be losing the contest. The inveterate gamesman and prankster, who once donned a gorilla suit to delight President Bush, is finding little to clown about these days in his snit with James P. Pinkerton, Bush's deputy assistant for policy planning. Darman's decision to go after a junior aide has baffled other senior administration officials. And conservatives, many of whom still blame Darman for Bush's shift on taxes, are using the flap as ammunition in a new get-Darman effort. Will the director of the Office of Management and Budget, now working on the president's budget for fiscal 1992, survive the latest onslaught? Many insiders say they expect him to leave soon after the new budget proposal goes to Congress in early February. Furthermore, what prompted Darman's scorn - Pinkerton's proposal for a range of self-help programs for the poor - seems to be finding support from Bush, the man who counts. In fact, the president may incorporate some of them in his State of the Union address in January. It all began last month, when Darman gave a speech attacking the ``empowerment'' agenda that Pinkerton prepared for Bush's consideration. The package includes programs like tenant ownership of public housing and tax breaks for businesses that locate in inner cities. Darman mocked the plan as ``too pretentious'' and mere ``sloganeering'' and said it was a throwback to ideas that failed in the 1960s war on poverty. The budget director also took a slap at the phrase Pinkerton chose to describe the programs, ``new paradigm,'' or new model. Darman called that ``neo-neo-ism,'' and also ``neo-Newt-ism,'' a stab at House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., an outspoken supporter of the concept. Just as Darman touched off Democratic criticism last winter by comparing the federal budget to a ``cookie monster'' and a ``Pac Man'' that gobbles up resources, his mocking attack on Pinkerton's work generated heat among conservatives. ``There are a lot of phrases going around like empowerment and new paradigm ... The fact is they all come down to that fundamental approach of not having a movement toward an overall centralized process,'' said White House chief of staff John Sununu. Gingrich called for Darman's resignation, accusing him of ``an assault on members of his own party.'' Vice President Dan Quayle, Housing Secretary Jack Kemp and William Bennett, President Bush's choice to be the new Republican National Committee chairman, also quickly made their support known for an empowerment agenda. Quayle told a gathering of GOP governors: ``There is nothing wrong with a battle of ideas. But once the president decides, it will not be Republicans vs. Republicans but Republicans vs. Democrats.'' Bush himself championed some of Pinkerton's ``new paradigm'' proposals in a speech last spring. And at a Rose Garden ceremony last week, the president praised the concept anew, calling ``this idea of empowering people, not bureaucracies'' a cornerstone of his effort ``to reduce the heavy hand of government.'' Neither Darman nor anyone at the budget office would comment on the dispute, despite repeated attempts to elicit his views. Pinkerton isn't eager to discuss the disagreement either. But he said, ``I'm just happy the ideas are getting a thorough discussion.'' Pinkerton, 32, who was Bush's chief issues researcher during the 1988 campaign, says he knows some people find ``new paradigm'' something of a mouthful. As the president and other administration officials put forth their agenda ``they'll use their own rhetoric,'' he added. The 48-year-old Darman, who served in six different agencies under three Republican presidents before getting one of his own to head, remains the White House aide conservatives love to hate. His work in negotiating the $500 billion, five-year package of tax increases and spending cuts angered many Republicans who saw it as a big election-year liability. Many members of Congress of both parties accused Darman and Sununu of being heavy-handed and abrasive in negotiating for the president. Gary Bass, director of OMB Watch, a public policy group of former budget officials that monitors the agency's performance, said Darman has justly earned a reputation for ``brilliance in developing schemes. He's always five steps ahead of everyone else.'' ``But he is also arrogant. And I think people on Capitol Hill resent that,'' Bass added. He said ``the real issue'' in the Darman-Pinkerton dust-up has little to do with Pinkerton, but is a ``battle to see who controls the administration's agenda'' - whether conservatives like Kemp, Bennett and Gingrich or more establishment-oriented politicians like Darman.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead, 40 Injured in Brazilian Squatter Riot
DOC.TEXT: At least two people were killed and 40 injured in a fight between riot police and thousands of squatters who refused to obey a court order to abandon private land in a Sao Paulo suburb, authorities say. The struggle occurred Tuesday in Diadema, an industrial suburb of this city of 7 million people, South America's largest. Scenes aired by TV Globo, Brazil's largest network, showed hundreds of helmeted riot troopers, some on horseback, charging into the squatters. The police, using shields and armed with rubber truncheons, hurled tear gas canisters into a crowd of approximately 3,000 people. The squatters fought back with rocks, wooden clubs and Molotov cocktails. A Diadema police officer, who asked that his name not be used, said by telephone that two squatters were killed during the violence, which lasted 35 minutes. He said it was still unclear how they were killed. The officer also said 25 officers and policemen were injured, and that more than 20 people were arrested. The squatters had refused to heed a court order and abandon the 62 acres of privately-owned land. ``We surrounded the place in the morning and tried to convince them to leave peacefully. Instead, they hurled rocks and Molotov cocktails at us. e had no choice. We had to resort to violence,'' the police officer said. He said a local municipal councilman defending the squatters had his right hand blown off by a Molotov cocktail. The squatters occupied the land in September but the order to leave it was only issued on Tuesday. TV Globo showed several Molotov cocktails, clubs and hatchets inside one of the many wooden shacks built by the squatters. It also showed tractors destroying the shacks.

DOC.HEAD: At 99, `Father of PR' Still Promoting
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: At 99, the ``father of public relations'' is still promoting clients - and himself. Edward Bernays showed signs of outlasting his listeners Tuesday as he made a whirlwind tour of the University of Massachusetts. ``At 99, I work 12 hours a day just as I did before, and if a client comes in - we make no bones about it - he pays $1,000 an hour for advice,'' Bernays said during three hours of gab about his career promoting such clients as Sigmund Freud, Enrico Caruso, Vaslav Nijinsky, Calvin Coolidge and other presidents. In 1923, Bernays taught the first college course in public relations at New York University. His 1923 book ``Crystallizing Public Opinion'' is considered the bible of the business. Bernays, who lives in Cambridge, dismissed retirement at age 65 as a ``cockeyed idea.'' He said his theory that work keeps him young was supported during a doctor's visit at 94, when tests showed he had the body of a 62-year-old. ``He made the 16 tests again when I was 95 and I found I was 61,'' Bernays said. Colleagues marvel at his ability to captivate the public and his mastery of getting clients stories into newsprint and onto broadcasting airwaves. ``He is absolutely indefatigable,'' said Scott M. Cutlip, dean emeritus at the University of Georgia and co-author of a widely used public relations text. Cutlip credited Bernays with establishing two-way communication between clients and news media, rather than simply distributing news releases or waiting for reporters to come to the client. Another of his principles involves staging the kind of demonstrations that have since become the norm worldwide. ``Actions speak louder than words,'' Bernays said, giving as an example his efforts on behalf of the tobacco industry decades ago to make it acceptable for women to smoke in public. He said he helped engineer the change in attitudes with the help of debutante friends who lit cigarettes as so-called ``torches of freedom'' during Easter Day parades. About 30 years later, when the Surgeon General revealed the hazards of smoking, Bernays said he campaigned to get tobacco advertising off the airwaves in atonement. His contact with Freud, a maternal uncle, resulted in the American publication of ``Introductory Lectures in Psychoanalysis,'' which previously had been published only in Europe. And there were efforts to revamp Coolidge's sourpuss image. Trying to erase the image created by the frequent sarcastic comment that ``Calvin Coolidge was weaned on a pickle,'' Bernays said he promoted a White House breakfast visit by a group of actors, who were considered slightly raffish in those days. Newspapers all over the country carried the story. ``I recall The New York Times, they had a story that had about five subheads ... and the fourth headline in the New York Times was, `President nearly laughed,''' Bernays said.

DOC.HEAD: A New Mecca For Frustrated Inventors
DOC.TEXT: Haven't you ever wished somebody would invent a doohickey that fastens on the bathtub and holds your book while you wash? How about a gadget that opens and closes toilet lids, no hands? Or a box that creates your own subliminal advertising - injecting microsecond-long messages into your TV, which could help you kick a cigarette or other drug habit. Well they exist, on display at Toronto's New Product Store - a home for the mad scientist and crazy inventor. The business was founded a year ago by Brian Gray, his brother Joseph, and Ed Zwolinski. ``Brian Gray was a frustrated inventor,'' says Zwolinski, who manages the place. ``He had a line of hardware products - a radon gas detector, a disco music light box, custom construction hard hats - and was frustrated by all the doors closed to him, being told to buzz off.'' He says the biggest problem for inventors is skepticism. ``It's so hard to get attention. You really have to have a lot of clout behind you. One person alone doesn't have that.'' The New Products Store can't offer much in the way of clout. But it can offer exposure, both in shelf space in the store and via the publicity it has generated. It also offers professional evaluation from its board of engineers and lawyers, distribution leads, contacts with retailers and a sympathetic ear. The typical inventor usually follows a path like this: He gets an idea, becomes obsessed with it, creates a product and produces it. At that point, the honeymoon is over because he then has to sell it. ``That's where we come in,'' says Zwolinski. ``We offer them a start in the market. There is no way an inventor can know how good his product is without public exposure.'' The store is not very large, but it is located in one of Toronto's most fashionable shopping districts. The store manager can judge customer response to products, even browser response. Robert Dubeck invented the device for reader-bathers, an obsession that has consumed nine years of his life. ``No one thought this was going to go,'' says Dubeck. ``Everyone wanted me to give up the dream, just keep working. I was put down by friends and family. They basically said work for a living, don't come up with a dream to better yourself.'' The secret is getting the big stores and chains to buy and stock the item. And, according to Dubeck, buyers in these recessionary times are not given to speculating on unproven products. ``Our main concern is marketing, publicity and distribution,'' says Zwolinski. ``We're publishing a distribution catalog in December, sending it to 10,000 distributors in Canada and the United States. In it, potential customers will find such items as the Leisure Reader for the bathtub; a lapel or blouse pin for holding eyeglasses; the Bathroom Butler that opens and closes toilet lids; erase protection tabs for computer disks; or the box that creates those microsecond positive affirmation messages for your TV as a means of changing behavior. Some of the stuff, Zwolinski admits, is novelty, such as the floating toilet bowl posters, but a lot of it is genuinely practical. About 40 percent of the inventors represented in the store are American. ``It's really good working with Americans because they are more risk- oriented and more willing to take a chance,'' says Zwolinski.

DOC.HEAD: Majority of Stranded Whales Dead, Dying, Despite Rescue Struggle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 10th graf pvs, `The whales...,' to ADD volunteers' comments. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `Two freed...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HYS1
DOC.TEXT: Fifty-five pilot whales beached themselves near the Kennedy family compound Tuesday, and rescuers managed to get fewer than 10 headed out to sea before deciding to kill many of he mammals to end their suffering. Volunteers struggled throughout the day to save the creatures - most of them mothers and calves - with little success. They splashed the beached whales with water and soothed them with wet towels. The whales - up to 20 feet long and 3,000 pounds - were listless, with eyes closed, making squeaking and whistling sounds and occasionally twitching. ``I'm offering a little comfort,'' said one volunteer, Karen Kelly. ``They respond to your touch and your voice. They are scared and they don't know what's going on. ``Say a prayer,'' she added. By midnight, two whales had been moved to an aquarium, eight or nine had been seen swimming away and the rest were either drowning as the tide rose or being injected with a lethal chemical. The volunteers were sent home, and the would-be rescuers expected all the whales to be dead by morning, either from drowning or the lethal injections. Scientists decided on euthanasia becuase the air-breathing animals were too weak to swim away on the rising tide and drowned as they submerged. The whales' suffering was worsened because without being immersed in cooling water, their body temperatures rose. Experts were unable to explain why the whales beached themselves. About 100 volunteers endured high wind and 35-degree temperatures in the futile effort to save the whales. They used stretchers to return nine of the whales to open water, but one was believed to have beached itself again. The whales got stuck in shallow pools at low tide at Squaw Island, said Ian McMillan, associate director of the Cape Cod Aquarium. On the beach, a few floodlights and car headlights illuminated the moonless night. Ruben Baker, a volunteer, said the sub-freezing temperatures didn't spoil his enthusiasm for the task. ``You get a really neat feeling from the whales,'' Baker said. ``These whales could pick you up and throw you through the air. But it feels like they know we're trying to help them.'' ``They're sort of flopping around,'' said Roger Cadrin, a lieutenant with the Hyannis Fire Department who helped free a few of the animals. ``We named ours Betsy, and there was Bob, Scraps, a few others. When we let them go, they were all pointing in the same direction. They were all anxious to go. They were happy to get moving.'' Two freed whales have radio transmitters attached to their tails and were followed by marine experts in an inflatable boat. They also have luminescent tags attached to their fins so they can be seen at night. McMillan said it was unusual for whales to beach on the southern side of Cape Cod. ``Historically it's been on the other side,'' he said. ``There are certain areas where they seem to strand time and time again.'' Dave Wiley of the International Wildlife Coalition, which assisted in the rescue, said the test for the freed whales was whether they remain at sea or beach themselves again. The rescue effort was the first test of a 600-person volunteer whale rescue program set up by the New England Aquarium two years ago, McMillan said. It was the first mass beaching in the area since 70 pilot whales, a small type of whale, beached at several spots four years ago. Three young whales that beached on the Cape three years ago were rescued and returned to the sea. Some scientists speculate that the beachings occur when the pod, or group, of whales follows a sick leader ashore, or that the mammals become disoriented by magnetic variations along geological faults. McMillan said aquarium scientists are working on a theory that high tides can cause beachings. Planetary alignments last week caused the highest tides in 60 years. ``Whales may use current flows to navigate, and they may get confused by a change in the flow that you only see in very high tides,'' McMillan said. Whales give out heat in only three places - the dorsal fin, the tail and around the flippers. The system is designed to conserve body heat in the water, so when they come onto land the whales cook inside. ``Some of their extremities could be freezing because of the cold weather and at they same time they overheat internally,'' McMillan said. ``When this happens their body chemistry goes beyond any limits that are considered treatable or recoverable.''

DOC.HEAD: Reputed Mafia Boss Arrested by FBI
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to RESTORE last name, Locasio.
DOC.TEXT:
Reputed mafia boss John Gotti was arrested Tuesday night, reportedly on an indictment that accuses him of killing the man he allegedly succeeded as head of the nation's most powerful crime family. Gotti was arrested without incident by FBI agents and city police at the Ravenite social club in Manhattan's Little Italy neighborhood, along with two other alleged members of the Gambino crime family. Charges against the men were sealed, said FBI spokesman Joseph Valiquette. The New York Times reported Wednesday that Gotti, 50, is the subject of a wide-ranging indictment accusing him of running the Gambino crime family since 1986. The paper, quoting officials it didn't name, said the indictment is being brought under the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Law, or RICO. The indictment accuses Gotti of ordering the killing of the previous Gambino boss, Paul Castellano, who was gunned down outside Sparks Steakhouse on East 46th Street in December 1985, officials told the newspaper. Castellano's death enabled Gotti to take control of the crime family. Gotti was taken into custody without incident along with two associates, Salvatore ``The Bull'' Gravano and Frank ``Locks'' Locasio, the FBI said. A fourth man, Thomas Gambino, an alleged boss in the Gambino family, was arrested at an undisclosed location Tuesday night. Gambino is believed by authorities to be the richest of the reputed Mafia members in New York City. The four men were to arraigned Wednesday morning at Brooklyn's federal court, Valiquette said. They were being held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center after being fingerprinted and photographed at FBI offices in Manhattan, Valiquette said. A police spokesman, Officer Scott Bloch, said details about the arrests would be revealed at a news conference likely to be held Wednesday. No other details were immediately available. Gotti's attorney, Bruce Cutler, did not immediately return a call left on his answering service. Gotti has been under investigation in the slaying of Castellano since the shooting, but never has been charged. Evidence against Gotti and his co-defendants came from hidden eavesdropping devices placed with court authorization at the Ravenite Club, the Times quoted the officials as saying.
Gotti was found innocent in February of state charges related to the shooting of a union official. It was the third time that he had been acquitted in recent years of major state or federal charges. Jules Bonalovonta, in charge of the FBI's organized crime office in New York, recently described Gotti as ``the No. 1 target of law enforcement'' and added, ``It's just a matter of time. He's going to go.'' Three times Gotti has appeared in New York City courts on other charges, and three times he has walked out a free man, earning the nickname ``The Teflon Don.'' The acquittals, combined with his reputation for violence and fine clothing, have given Gotti national notoriety. Gotti's attorney recently noted that his client is often linked to the Castellano slaying, but asserted Gotti's innocence. ``Take this poor Mr. Castellano who was killed,'' Cutler said. ``How many times have the newspapers said my client had something to do with this? He didn't.'' Bonavolonta also alleged recently that Gotti has increased the number of Gambino family members since taking over the crime family, and most of the new members deal in drugs. The Gambinos' other sources of income allegedly are gambling, extortion, loan-sharking, union control, airport rip-offs and dominance of the garment district. Thomas Gambino, who allegedly runs a multimillion dollar garment center trucking operation, faces other charges by the Manhattan district attorney's for allegedly controlling the garment district through extortion and coercion.

DOC.HEAD: A Year After His Death, The Dissident's Influence Is Strong
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party used to advertise itself as the ``conscience of the nation.'' By the time Andrei Sakharov died, that title was more commonly accorded to him. Since the physicist and political activist's death a year ago this Friday, friends and colleagues in the human rights movement have battled for Sakharov's cause. But they say no one has emerged to take his place. ``The conscience of the nation - that has remained a vacant position,'' said Sergei Grigoryants, editor of the unofficial journal Glasnost and one of many former political prisoners who Sakharov pressured the government to free. Since Sakharov died of heart failure at age 68, public esteem has continued to climb for the man who helped invent the Soviet hydrogen bomb and later won the Nobel Peace Prize. He campaigned tirelessly for justice for Stalin's victims, nuclear disarmament, freedom of emigration and above all democracy. In a poll published last week by the Moscow News, Soviets were asked ``which of the following names will have great meaning for the people of the U.S.S.R. in the year 2,000: Jesus Christ, Lenin, Stalin, Gorbachev and Sakharov.'' Sakharov finished second to Jesus - but well ahead of Lenin, Stalin and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Moscow News, a reformist weekly, also published an unusual confession, admitting that it had ``shortened'' and ``corrected'' - effectively censored - articles by Sakharov as recently as 1988. ``If we had listened to him, our road to the truth would have been shorter and less tortured. But we shortened and corrected him; we did not listen or pretended that we did not hear,'' the newspaper said. ``I don't know whether he forgave us, but we cannot forgive ourselves,'' it said. A decade ago, Sakharov was denounced in the official press as an ``utterly ignorant person'' and banished to the industrial city of Gorky for criticizing the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. He spent seven years in internal exile before being recalled to Moscow by Gorbachev in December 1986. Soviet troops withdrew from Afghanistan last year; that war now is viewed by Soviets as a national disaster. Sakharov's former apartment in Gorky is being turned into a museum. His memoirs are being serialized by Znamya, a literary journal with a circulation of 1 million. And both his grave in southwest Moscow and his apartment building on the city's Ring Road have become unofficial shrines, decorated daily with flowers by visitors. Sakharov's name frequently serves as a rallying cry for reformers, including Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, and Moscow Mayor Gavril Popov, his comrades in the national legislature. But idolatry of Sakharov annoys his widow, Yelena Bonner. ``Why are we so inclined to create cults ... out of Sakharov, out of me?'' the magazine Ogonyok quoted her as saying last month. ``I think it is absolutely unbearable when people who are trying to develop a democratic consciousness so easily create a cult o new heroes,'' she added. Bonner was to commemorate Sakharov's death at a memorial concert today in Strasbourg, France. She was then to fly to New York, where the second volume of his memoirs, ``Moscow and Beyond,'' is to be published in January. In Moscow, Sakharov's friends and colleagues said they were dismayed that some organizations and political movements have taken his name without embracing his ideals. At least one of the groups - the ``Sakharov Union of Democratic Forces,'' which recently called for a national state of emergency - is far from his political views, said Larisa Bogoraz, a human rights campaigner and widow of dissident Anatoly Marchenko. Grigoryants, Ms. Bogoraz and others said they believed Sakharov would be embarrassed and upset at becoming a larger-than-life character, a symbol freely appropriated by politicians and movements of varying stripes. But they also said he would be pleased by some events of the past year. At the time of his death, Sakharov was pushing for elimination of Article 6 of the Soviet Constitution, which accorded the Communist Party a ``leading role'' in society. Less than four months later, the party agreed to surrender its constitutional monopoly on power. Sakharov's proposed draft of a new constitution was rejected by the Communist Party Central Committee little more than a year ago. Today, his vision of truly sovereign republics joining in a voluntary union is widely embraced as the only way to hold the country together. ``Only now are people beginning to realize how right he was on the nationalities question and many other issues,'' Ms. Bogoraz said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Hard to be Upbeat About Threats of War and Recession
DOC.TEXT: President Bush may have a hard time saying anything reassuring about the State of the Union next month. After all, it's hard to be upbeat about the twin threats of war and recession. Finding applause lines for an audience sure to be anxious and skeptical is bound to present new challenges to the president's speech writers, who haven't won many plaudits lately. Even so, White House advisers are working on a series of ideas, new policy initiatives and lofty language for Bush's second formal address to a joint session of Congress on the nation's well-being. In what may be a portent of rocky times ahead, chief of staff John H. Sununu usurped a traditional prerogative of the House speaker Tuesday by announcing the date of the spech himself - Jan. 29. That's two weeks after the United Nations Security Council's deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face military action. The president has said military action will not necessarily be launched on Jan. 15 if Saddam Hussein continues to defy the U.N. resolutions. But by State of the Union time, the whole world should know which side blinked first. Congress, which is usually sluggish when it reconvenes after the holidays to hear the president's annual address, is sure to be wide awake and combative this year - particularly if Bush has taken military action without first getting its consent. Beyond the issue of whether the nation will be at war by late January is the current sharp economic downturn, already pronounced a recession by many private economists. Less than a week after Bush gives his State of the Union address, he must submit his budget for fiscal 1992. The economic downturn will make it even harder to meet new deficit-reduction targets approved by Congress as part of October's $500 billion, five-year package of tax increases and spending cuts. Furthermore, the Desert Shield military operation threatens to cost tens of billions of dollars in additional federal spending. The breakdown of international trade talks in Geneva this week over the issue of farm subsidies - which the United States wants to eliminate but Europe doesn't - could take another big bite out of federal spending. Under a newly enacted trade retaliation provision, the administration must boost spending on U.S. export subsidies by $1 billion a year if no international agreement is reached to cut such subsidies. That all adds up to a pretty bleak budget outlook. White House aides said they haven't started drafting a State of the Union message, although there are plenty of suggestions on what it should include. But don't look for much soaring language this time. John Kennedy had his ``New Frontier,'' Lyndon Johnson had his ``Great Society,'' Richard Nixon his ``silent majority,'' and Ronald Reagan talked of ``morning in America.'' Even Bush promised a ``kinder and gentler nation'' in his campaign and spoke of the ``winds of change'' in his inaugural address. But so far, about the only new catch-phrase being tossed about is ``the new paradigm.'' That term has been trumpeted by Bush's deputy assistant for policy planning, James P. Pinkerton, who says it means a new model, or a new way of looking at an old problem. It includes a range of self-help programs for the poor, including tenant ownership of public housing and tax incentives for businesses that locate in inner cities. It has won the backing of many conservatives - if not budget director Richard Darman, who has ridiculed the phrase as mere sloganeering and ``neo-neo-ism.'' What does Darman suggest instead? How about ``new balance,'' he offered in a recent speech, although he quickly added: ``I should make clear that there is absolutely no threat of a `new balance' slogan sweeping the nation.'' For his part, Pinkerton said he knows that ``new paradigm'' may seem a bit unwieldy. But he said he likes it anyway. ``I'll probably stick with it even if nobody else does,'' he said. Aides said they expect Bush to propose major changes in bank regulation and limits on congressional terms in his speech. But, with so many uncertainties remaining in the Persian Gulf, they concede that domestic initiatives could easily be overshadowed. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Cranston Aide Says She Acted on Own to Aid Keating
DOC.NOTE: EDS: May stand; committee meets in closed session
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Cranston's banking aide contends she was acting on her own when she took steps that helped savings and loan owner Charles H. Keating Jr. in his disputes with federal regulators. Among the actions for which Carolyn Jordan took responsibility was placing a statement in the Congressional Record in Cranston's name that supported Keating's position in a lawsuit challenging federal regulators. But Jordan, testifying before the Senate Ethics Committee on Tuesday, said repeatedly that she could not recall events or conversations she had on behalf of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in Irvine, Calif. Her assertions drew skeptical comments from some members of the ethics panel, and her faulty recall prompted demands for clearer answers. ``The witness obviously has very good recollection about some things and very poor recollection about others,' said Sen. Warren Rudman of New Hampshire, the ranking Republican on the ethics panel. ``I think we've got to guard against just getting totally meaningless answers.'' Jordan testified in the 16th day of hearings into the so-called Keating Five case. The committee planned to begin closed-door questioning today of James Grogan, Keating's former lobbyist and top aide, who is being given immunity from prosecution based on his testimony. Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala., said the panel would announce later when it would meet in public again. Committee sources said Grogan may not appear in public until early January. Cranston, D-Calif., is one offfive senators under investigation by the ethics panel. They face allegations of improperly intervening with regulators on behalf of Keating, a major financial contributor who with associates provided $1.3 million for the campaigns and causes of the five senators. The others are Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio; and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. Jordan denied applying pressure on staff members at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in May 1988 to ease a decision tightening regulatory control on Keating's troubled thrift. She said Cranston did not ask her to make the call, although she described it in a memo to him afterward. She said the impetus came from Keating's lobbyist, James Grogan, who called her immediately after the bank board met to complain about its action. Federal regulator William K. Black testified last week that the reversal by the bank board two weeks later delayed the ultimate seizure and permitted Lincoln to sell more junk bonds, in which investors lost millions of dollars when the thrift collapsed. The government seized Lincoln on April 14, 1989, and the cost to taxpayers is expected to exceed $2 billion. Jordan also asserted she was acting on her own when a prepared statement in Cranston's name was placed in the Congressional Record on March 27, 1987. Her assertion that Cranston didn't know of the statement in his own name provoked skeptical comments by Rudman and Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., another panel member. ``Now, what is the story? Did he approve that going in the Record?'' Helms asked. ``No, he did not,'' Jordan replied. Helms: ``So just staff members put it in without his knowledge?'' Jordan: ``That is correct.'' The statement in Cranston's name directly contradicted a statement the day before by William Proxmire, D-Wis., then the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. Proxmire had agreed to drop proposed amendments from savings-and-loan legislation specifically giving the bank board authority to limit direct investments, but had inserted in the Congressional Record a statement saying it was Congress' intent that the board already had that power. The statement published the next day under Cranston's name said the board did not have that authority over state-chartered institutions such as Lincoln. That was in line with the position Keating was taking in a suit against the bank board.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Prices Expected to Stay Depressed
DOC.TEXT: Wheat farmers have seen prices drop sharply from a year or two ago, and a new supply-and-demand report by the Agriculture Department doesn't find much improvement in sight. Overall, 1990-91 global wheat production forecasts increased from a month ago, with gains in Canada, China and Mexico more than offsetting reduced prospects in Brazil, the European Community and South Africa. The projected average U.S. market price was reduced 5 cents a bushel from November to a range of $2.50 to $2.70 for the marketing year that began on June 1. In the previous two years, the farm price of wheat was $3.72 per bushel. According to the report issued Tuesday, exports are still expected to be 1.075 billion bushels in 1990-91, down from 1.233 billion last year. The U.S. wheat stockpile carried over next June 1 into the new harvest and marketing year was projected at 937 million bushels, down slightly from the November outlook but still much larger than the 536 million bushels carried forward last June 1. Looking at corn and other coarse grains, the report showed global production in 1990-91 and the year-ending stockpile to be up slightly from last month. ``Although prolonged dry conditions have cut corn planting in South Africa ... gains in the EC, Canada and Turkey are more than offsetting,'' the report said. ``The smaller crop likely will eliminate corn exports by South Africa during their 1990-91 marketing year.'' As with wheat, farmers harvested a bumper corn crop this year. However, unlike wheat, total corn use is expected to exceed output, meaning some reduction in the stockpile during the 1990-91 marketing year that began on Sept. 1. Consequently, corn prices at the farm are projected to average $2.20 to $2.50 per bushel this season, compared with $2.36 in 1989-90. The corn stockpile next Sept. 1 was projected at 1.236 billion bushels, down from 1.344 billion estimated this Sept. 1. World oilseed production, including U.S. soybeans, also is forecast at a record level in 1990-91, up 2 percent from last year. The U.S. soybean carryover next Sept. 1 was projected at 265 million bushels, up 10 million from the November forecast. The soybean inventory this Sept. 1 was 239 million bushels. Farm prices of soybeans were projected to average $5.25 to $6.25 per bushel in 1990-91, down 10 cents on both ends of the range from November. Last season soybeans averaged $5.70 per bushel nationally at the farm. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department has pushed up its estimate of 1990 cotton production to almost 15.4 million bales, up 3 percent from prospects a month ago. ``Harvest proceeded with little interruption during November,'' the department's Agricultural Statistics Board reported Tuesday. ``Yields and grades in the High Plains were good to excellent, and Louisiana's production is a record high level.'' The latest forecast, based on Dec. 1 indications, is up 26 percent from last year's cotton output of less than 12.2 million bales. Upland cotton accounted for 15.01 million bales of the Dec. 1 estimate, and American-Pima, or extra-long staple, 395,900 bales, the report said. The indicted 1990 production of upland cotton as of Dec. 1, included: Alabama, 400,000 bales this year and 383,000 last year. Arizona, 800,000 and 649,000. Arkansas, 1,100,000 and 851,000. California, 2,800,000 and 2,661,000. Florida, 46,100 and 29,000 (carried over from previous forecast.) Georgia, 380,000 and 342,000. Louisiana, 1,200,000 and 868,000. Mississippi, 1,850,000 and 1,555,000. Missouri, 305,000 and 269,000. New Mexico, 80,000 and 80,000. North Carolina, 260,000 and 141,000. Oklahoma, 350,000 and 173,000. South Carolina, 145,000 and 154,000. Tennessee, 490,000 and 476,000. Texas, 4,800,000 and 2,870,000. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Germany and Japan are potentially lucrative markets for American popcorn farmers, the Agriculture Department says. In Germany, popcorn has become ``one of the most recognized U.S. food products,'' the department's Foreign Agricultural Service said Tuesday. And In Japan, it's rapidly overtaking sun-dried squid as the snack of choice. But home-popping is limited in both Germany and Japan, the report said. That may change, however, as microwave ovens become more popular. Per capita popcorn consumption is still relatively low. In Germany, for example, consumption averages about two quarts of popped corn, compared with 56 quarts consumed in the United States, on a per capita basis.

DOC.HEAD: Influx Of Soviet Jews Disrupts Israeli Life
DOC.TEXT: The influx of Soviet Jewish immigrants is beginning to hit Israelis in their paychecks and is showing signs of straining Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's fragile coalition government. While public support remains generally high, the sheer magnitude of the task ahead - housing, employing and educating 1,000 newcomers a day - is becoming increasingly daunting. The impact of the immigration flood - 150,000 so far this year; an estimated 1 million by the end of 1992 - is now felt throughout this country of about 4.4 million people. Some people are voicing doubts about whether Israel can take the strain. ``There is an atmosphere of panic among the politicians. Absorbing an immigration wave of the scope we are now facing ... is a mission beyond Israel's capability,'' warned the respected Haaretz newspaper. But to do anything to stem the flow would negate Israel's very reason for existing. As Haaretz pointed out, ``this is a Zionist state. Taking in Jews is its aim and essence, so nobody dares to say it out loud.'' The 1991 state budget for the first time allocates more to immigrant absorption than to defense. The military lost its fight for a budget increase and had to cancel an order for two German-built submarines. The budget is also stretching Israelis' ability to pay. Last month, the Cabinet approved a hike in the value-added tax, a rough equivalent of a sales tax, from 16 percent to 18 percent. It also endorsed an ``immigration tax,'' a 5 percent income tax levy for the next three years. An attempt to lower the minimum wage and tax pensions was thwarted by the Histadrut, the trade union federation, which held a two-day general strike last month. On Tuesday, two government ministers traded accusations on television over immigration. Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz, whose ministry sees to the needs of immigrants, claimed that at a meeting Sunday of the Cabinet immigration committee, chairman Ariel Sharon behaved ``like a dictator.'' ``He roughly attacked the director general of my ministry. He was banging his fist with full force on the table and shouting,'' Peretz complained. Sharon, the tough-talking former general who heads the Housing Ministry, retorted angrily in a separate interview. Peretz, a rabbi supported by the Orthodox Shas faction in the coalition, tacitly threatened to bring down the government over Sharon's behavior. Interviewed separately, Sharon implied that Peretz's ministry wasn't pulling its weight. ``The Housing Ministry works 18 hours a day and the Absorption Ministry has to work too,'' he said. ``When I hold meetings ... at midnight, is that dictatorship? When I, in my capacity as the head of the coordinating committee, demand that a ministry submit a certain plan, is that dictatorship?'' Sharon also alluded to another issue that is bedeviling the immigration flow: Peretz's controversial claim that up to 30 percent of the immigrants are not Jewish and therefore not entitled to automatic entry into Israel. Sharon was also reported to have chewed out the army for demanding payment for putting up immigrants at its bases, saying it was their job to follow orders, not first ask for payment.
