Nevertheless, the Israeli public remains broadly upbeat. Schools proudly display what they are doing for the immigrants. Radio stations run programs designed to bring newcomers and old-timers together. It is a social must for well-established families to ``adopt'' an immigrant family. The immigration wave is also a morale boost at a time when the Persian Gulf crisis has forced the distribution of gas masks and the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories enters its fourth year looking more violent than ever. Absorption Ministry officials recently returned to work after a two-week strike over pay and hours and found long lines of immigrants outside their offices. Many immigrants had arrived before dawn and scuffles broke out. The strike had deprived many of their only income - the government stipend of $9,000 a year for a family of three.

DOC.HEAD: Holiday Shopping Blues? Consider the Pentagon's List
DOC.TEXT: Meals are being shipped by the millions, but rivets are scarce. New uniforms and desert boots are in production - and in demand. Four months after President Bush ordered U.S. troops to the Persian Gulf, sustaining the still-growing deployment is proving to be an extremely complex, and costly, endeavor. More than $1.2 billion has been spent on food, clothing and medical supplies alone, never mind the millions more on weapons, parts and other materiel needed for the desert deployment. The operation is providing at least a temporary boom to many suppliers who were expecting less military business this year. Instead of closing plants or cutting shifts, several food and clothing suppliers are adding workers or offering overtime to meet Pentagon pleas for quick delivery. A sampling of the orders: -113 million meals, including 74.4 million Meals Ready-to-Eat, the basic field ration, 10.8 new entrees, including pot roast and beef sukiyaki, and 14 million new ``lunch bucket'' entrees to add chili and macaroni and cheese to the menu. -4.8 million pounds of sugar, 3.2 million pounds of flour and 1.4 million pounds of coffee, contracts worth a combined $5.6 million. -547,000 sundry packs, at a cost of $194 million, to supply the troops with razors, shaving cream, toothpaste and the like. -1.5 million tubes of lip balm, costing $278,000. -796,008 pairs of desert and hot weather boots, a $31.6 million deal. -379,375 cans of foot powder; 165,000 pairs of sunglasses; 371,000 wool sweaters; and 3.3 million desert camouflage uniforms, just one of several big-ticket clothing buys. -More than 600,000 armor-piercing rounds for the Army's Bradley Fighting Vehicles, a contract worth $14.3 million to GenCorp's Aerojet Ordnance Division. And buying is just half the task - the Pentagon has to get the goods 7,000 miles to Saudi Arabia and other Mideast points as it masses a 60-day or better supply cushion. The scope of the supply effort is giving pause to some military planners, who worry the inevitability of sustainment problems will be used to advance arguments for early use of force if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ignores a Jan. 15 deadline to end his occupation of Kuwait. The operation is also expensive, and getting more costly by the week as stocks now filling Desert Shield requisitions run low, forcing the Pentagon to issue new contracts. So far, there have been only isolated shortages, officials say. Roughly 90 percent of parts orders are being filled from existing stocks, according to Defense Department figures. Scarce items rush-ordered from suppliers include rivets, electrical cable and strapping used to hold down pallets on military transport planes. Most orders are shipped by sea, but if a unit in the Mideast needs something in a hurry, it can turn to ``Desert Express'' - an emergency next-day delivery service the Air Force is running to Saudi Arabia from two U.S. bases. To date, ``Desert Express'' cargo has mostly been parts in short supply for tanks and planes, particularly Vietnam-era F4-G ``Wild Weasel'' anti-radar jets. The overall air leg of the supply line, operated by the Military Airlift Command, has made nearly 7,000 missions to the Mideast since August, carrying more than 200,000 passengers and 480 million pounds of cargo. The Navy's Sealift Command has delivered 28 billion pounds of dry cargo and nearly 6 billion pounds of fuel. As it orders more food, the Pentagon is trying to spice up the menu as a morale booster. That initiative meant a $44.6 million contract to George A. Hormel and Co. for sukiyaki, pot roast, spaghetti, lasagna and other dinners, and a $20.8 million deal for Dial Corp. for beef stew, chili, macaroni and cheese and other lunches. Other big beneficiaries are the Pentagon's clothing suppliers, who are rushing production of uniforms, the new line of desert boots and chemical protective clothing. Overall, more than 83,000 requisitions for $411 million in clothing have been processed for Operation Desert Shield.

DOC.HEAD: Monetary Fund Cuts Interest Rate
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund is cutting its loan interest rate in a move that could save debtor countries about $100 million a year, sources say. At the end of October the fund had about $30 billion worth of loans outstanding. Mexico, Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela are the biggest debtors among 78 borrowing countries. The fund, with headquarters in Washington, is owned by 154 countries, with the United States the largest contributor. The interest that the fund charges is based on rates that five major governments - the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain and France - pay on the short-term bonds they sell to the public. The fund has been charging 91.3 percent of this rate, which it calculates every week. One source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the fund's Board of Executive Directors decided Monday to cut the proportion to 87.8 percent, retroactive to Nov. 1. The directors met behind closed doors and did not announce the change. They review the formula every three months. For the week of Dec. 3, the interest the fund charges to debtors had worked out to an annual 8.27 percent. The decision to change the formula reduces that by 32 basis points, or 32-100ths of one percent, to 7.95 percent. On loans of $30 billion, such a cut would amount to $100 million in savings to debtors if the reduction is maintained for a year. In recent years, the IMF has lent largely to Third World countries in financial trouble. To get a loan, a government promises to change its policies and put itself in better condition to repay. This involves devaluings its currency, reducing subsidies on basic goods and cutting spending, in many cases. Critics say the price of the promises can be too high: greatly increased prices and many lost jobs in the borrowing country. Such effects have repeatedly led to bloody riots, including in the Dominican Republic last month. The IMF maintains that the pain will be worse if changes are delayed. An arrangement with the fund has often been the ``seal of approval'' that private banks want to see before making much bigger loans of their own.

DOC.HEAD: Numbers Problem Stalls Conventional Forces Treaty Ratification
DOC.TEXT: Major discrepancies in the count of Soviet weapons will delay Senate approval of a new treaty slashing non-nuclear armaments in Europe by at least two months, congressional sources say. The Kremlin figures understate the total numbers of tanks, artillery and other conventional weapons the Soviets would have to destroy under the agreement by tens of thousands, the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday. Although the differences involve several weapons, the largest problem involves tanks. The Kremlin has been gradually moving tanks out of Central Europe, the area controlled by the treaty, and basing them east of the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union. Some in Congress fear that instead of dismantling 10,000 to 20,000 tanks, as the pact requires, the Soviets would have to destroy few or none. In a letter to President Bush, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., the senior GOP member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, complained about the wholesale differences in the Soviet figures. The Soviets ``may, in fact, be defeating the object and purpose (of the treaty) from the outset,'' Helms wrote. The precise numbers of weapons in eac category held by each side, although they are part of the treaty, remain secret. Leaders of the 16-member North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the six-nation Warsaw Pact signed the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty in Paris on Nov. 19. Bush praised the pact then for reducing ``to practically nil the tensions that have existed.'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said, ``Instead of military force, our world order will be based on equitable dialogue.'' At the same time, the U.S. envoy to the negotiations hinted of problems underlying the treaty, but congressional officials said they were not expected to be this large. ``We expect and have expected all along, with an unprecedented data exchange of this sort for there to be mistakes, inaccuracies, incomplete pieces of information,'' said Ambassador James Woolsey. The problems were spelled out on Monday in a briefing for congressional aides by the State and Defense departments, the CIA and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. They also were the subject of discussions between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Houston, a White House source said. Several Democratic staff sources said the problems are correctable and should not derail eventual Senate approval of the treaty, which had been planned to be one of the first items of business when the new Congress convenes in January. The discrepancies occur at a time when the United States and the Soviet Union are enjoying their warmest relations in four decades. Under the treaty's terms, each side has 90 days - until Feb. 19 - to correct inaccurate data. Now, a Republican source said, the administration will not submit the treaty for ratification until March because of the accounting problems. In addition to the undercounting of tanks, the Soviet data understate numbers of armored personnel carriers by 12,000, artillery pieces by 10,000 and combat aircraft by about 3,000, according to administration calculations. One Democratic source said the problem arose in part because U.S. negotiators had been working from 1989 weapons lists provided by the Soviets. Between the time the lists were provided and the treaty was put in final form, the Soviets already had withdrawn as many as 20,000 tanks from the area governed by the treaty to east of the Ural Mountains. The senior Democratic aide said the situation was viewed as ``an accounting problem'' and that such numbers discrepancies are not unusual in the field of arms control. Last year as U.S. negotiators prepared their own numbers, they discovered 900 tanks they didn't know the United States had in Europe, the source said. Some 750 of those excess tanks have since been transferred to Egypt in a move not unlike what the Soviets apparently have done, he said. The 160-page treaty limits each side to 20,000 main battle tanks, 30,000 armored combat vehicles, 20,000 artillery pieces, 6,800 fighter planes and 2,000 combat helicopters. Each side has 40 months to reduce its armaments to the ceilings spelled out in the treaty, which covers a 2.5 million square mile area stretching from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains.

DOC.HEAD: Pilobolus Opens 20th Anniversary Season
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: Pilobolus Dance Theater, formed in 1970 for communal choreography, opened a month-long 20th anniversary season at the Joyce Theater with the most interesting dance being the newest one. ``The Particle Zoo,'' danced at Tuesday's opening night, had its premiere in January in Pittsburgh. It was commissioned by the Pittsburgh Dance Council. It was danced by four men and choreographed by seven people - three of the company's five artistic directors and four dancers. Recorded music by 10 composers is used. One of the four performers is an outsider. Two face each other and clasp hands, supporting a third. When the third leaves and the outsider jumps onto their hands, they let go and he falls. Sometimes they catch him then drop him. They leapfrog, two jumping over each other from side to side, while one rolls along the floor. The outsider gets into the game in the ``wrong'' rhythm making the dance fast, hilarious and dangerous looking. It's a fairly long dance with many parts - whirling each other, diving onto the floor, etc. It's interesting right up to its trick ending. Carol Parker performed the solo ``Moonblind'' from 1978, to spacey music by Jane Ira Bloom. Once, sitting on the floor, she extended one leg and turned her foot out at an extreme angle. It looked impossible. The audience laughed and, when the dancer stared in disbelief, laughed more. Once she spun like a comedian pretending to be a mad top. It had all begun with her looking like a distraught housewife. ``Televisitation'' from 1985 had Kent Lindemer being visited by Jude Woodcock, who came out of his TV set which he slept and stood on his chest. She stands on him through much of the dance, on his legs when he turns over, on his shoulders when he's sitting. Standing, he lifts her gracefully and twirls her around. She responds by getting his neck in a hammerlock. He also lifts her with a hand on the back of her head and a hand on her face. And he swings her so her feet are higher than their heads. She takes bows like a mechanical doll then throws him over her shoulder. After those three amusing pieces, the final dance, ``Debut C'' from 1988 to Debussy music, took itself very seriously. Six lightly clad dancers were aiming for sensuousness and it struck this viewer as mostly pretentious and silly. It is very difficult to loll around to Debussy music and make the motions look like that translucent music sounds. We can remember when Pilobolus dances had dancers come out melded together like spoons in a drawer then tumble in ways that pretty much kept their bodies together. The company has gone in new directions. But Pilobolus still doesn't look like any other dance company around.

DOC.HEAD: Unapologetic Bush Aide Says He's a `Political Counterpuncher'
DOC.TEXT: John Sununu says he has no apologies to make for his pugnacious performance as White House chief of staff, and furthermore wants it known that he never lands the first blow. ``I merely put myself down as a political counterpuncher,'' Sununu said in a vintage performance for an overflow audience at a National Press Club luncheon Tuesday. He lambasted the Democrats, accusing them of forcing President Bush to raise taxes by holding the economy ``hostage'' and forecasting more party strife in the next two years. He also suggested the Democrats were looking at the Persian Gulf crisis as an excuse to raise taxes. He defended the much maligned budget deal and his own contentious role in shaping it, which drew brickbats from Democrats and Republicans alike. Sununu, who called a GOP senator, Trent Lott of Mississippi, ``insignificant'' at one stage of the negotiations, said: ``When push comes to shove, Republicans will work with Republicans to make sure this country continues to grow and thrive.'' It has been a rocky past few months for the abrasive former governor of New Hampshire with a storied temper and capacity for political invective. Sununu denied that he has damaged White House relations with Congress or that he was becoming, as one questioner put it, ``the Don Rickles of Washington politics.'' ``When someone takes a shot at the president of the United States in a gratuitous manner, I will respond,'' Sununu said in defense of his truculent style. ``I believe it is part of my job. ``I guarantee you that, contrary to the legend, any strong statements on my part are both controlled, deliberate and designed to achieve an effect,'' Sununu said. ``There is no random outburst. ``I merely put myself down as a political counterpuncher. You've never seen me initiate an attack,'' he said. Sununu blamed the Democrats for a six-month delay in getting the $500 billion deficit-reduction deal passed, and said that delay will make it tougher ``to keep this country moving rather than floundering.'' Sununu said Bush will not bend again on taxes. The president ``was forced to pay the tax ransom once in order to save the economy. He will not be forced to pay that tax ransom again,'' the chief of staff declared. Bush only gave in on raising taxes this year ``because our nation's economy was held political hostage by those that control Congress,'' he said. He signaled that Bush will try again in the new year for a cut in the capital gains tax. Sununu said the Democrats ``are already looking for a reason to raise taxes.'' ``They're looking for a bumper sticker that justifies it, whether it's a bumper sticker called `Tax the rich,' or they're looking for a cause to justify it, whether it is a surtax on the war,'' said Sununu. The Democratic chairmen of the Senate and House Budget committees, Sen. James Sasser of Tennessee and Rep. Leon Panetta of California, have raised the possibility of a surtax on income if America goes to war against Iraq. Sasser has suggested it might be necessary to raise income taxes by 5-to-10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: In Washington State Capital, STORM Doesn't Mean SNOW
DOC.TEXT: FAT doesn't mean fat in the Washington state capital. And SNOW is no word for flaky rain. Here, in a place that could be nicknamed Acronym City, the government has created thousands of acronyms - 3,187 by one legislator's count - for various agencies, situations, conditions and crimes. With many of the acronyms spelling out words of their own, the speech spoken around the statehouse can often be confusing. SURF and WAVE, for example, don't mean fun at the beach, and SMART isn't the opposite of dumb. We're talking FAT as in Fish Agencies and Tribes, SNOW as in School Nurses of Washington, SURF as in Simple Update Reference File, WAVE as in Washington Award for Vocational Excellence and SMART as in Summer Motivation and Academic Residential Training. All of these can be found in the second edition of the Dictionary of State Government Acronyms, a fat - er make that thick - list that has grown from 1,972 acronyms in 1985 to 3,187 in 1990. The book, like its predecessor, is the work of Rep. Steve Van Luven and helpers Monica Tracey and Barry Weiss. The Republican legislator from Bellevue said the team of acronym-busters labored long and hard to compile the list. His BF, or ``biggest fear,'' he said, was E&0. That's ``errors and omissions.'' The legislator said he paid for much of the work from his own pocket after the House clerk refused to handle the cost. He is giving the book away to other legislators and interested constituents. For the future, he suggests that an ``ADA (Acronym Designation Agency)'' to professionalize the endeavor may be in order. While we're waiting for that to happen, how about a pop quiz of randomly selected acronyms? TARMVWOP, ARMS, CARS, HERO, FONSI, POSSLQ, TOE and SOP. Answers, respectively: Taking a Ride in a Motor Vehicle Without Owner's Permission; Automated Register Maintenance System; Computerized Activity Reporting System; Home-Economic Related Occupations; Finding of No Significant Impact; Persons of Opposite Sex Sharing Living Quarters; Try-Out Employment, and Sex Offender Program. Ready for more? How about STORM, PAW, SP, WOP, AP, WARF and CAB. Answers: State Office of Risk Management; Planning Association of Washington; Sexual Predator; Work Orientation Program; Attending Physician; Washington Association of Rehabilitation Facilities, and Taxi-Cab (honest!). Before you smug few who scored well go forth to master all 3,187 acronyms, remember this: Some with the same spellings or sounds have more than one meaning. MI refers not only to Mentally Ill but also to Manifest Injustice. LOS stands for Length of Stay, but LOSS means Large On-Site Sewage System. Aw, HEC (Higher Education Coordinating Board). Maybe it's time to STOP (Social Treatment Opportunity Program).

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Burt Lancaster is working with therapists to recover speech and other skills damaged by a stroke, his agent says. The 77-year-old actor remains in serious condition, and his wife has taken a room at Los Alamitos Medical Center to be near him, Ben Benjamin said Tuesday. ``He's still in intensive care and he's undergoing extensive physical therapy and speech therapy,'' the agent said. Lancaster, who has starred in more than 70 movies and won an Oscar in 1960 for his portrayal of an evangelist in ``Elmer Gantry,'' suffered a stroke Nov. 30 that left his right side partially paralyzed. --- CORAOPOLIS, Pa. (AP) - Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Jason Miller was fined $700 for being drunk and disorderly aboard a plane in October. Miller was fined Tuesday after pleading guilty. In exchange, charges of marijuana possession and making terroristic threats were dropped. Miller, 51, won the Pulitzer in 1973 for ``That Championship Season.'' He also was nominated for an Academy Award that year for his portrayal of Father Karras in the film ``The Exorcist.'' Police said Miller was returning home to Scranton from a Notre Dame football game in South Bend, Ind., on Oct. 20 when he began causing trouble. He was arrested during a stopover in Pittsburgh. --- LONDON (AP) - Lynn and Vanessa Redgrave are carrying on a family tradition on the British stage as stars of Chekhov's ``Three Sisters.'' The Redgrave sisters and their niece, Jemma Redgrave, star in the play about siblings who long to return from a remote Russian village to Moscow. Sir Michael Redgrave, father of Lynn, Vanessa and their brother Corin, Jemma's father, appeared in the play at the Queen's Theater in 1936. The current version, which opened at the same theater Tuesday, marks Lynn Redgrave's first appearance on the British stage since 1973. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Former gymnastics star Cathy Rigby says making her Broadway debut in ``Peter Pan'' is like old times. ``This is like the Olympics of theater,'' Rigby said in an interview Tuesday. ``You have all those same feelings of excitement.'' Rigby, who won a silver medal at the World Gymnastics Championships in 1970, took up acting and singing after retiring from competition. The 36-year-old mother of four has been on the road for a year in the revival of the musical about the boy who refuses to grow up. The show opens on Broadway on Thursday. ``This is not just children's theater,'' she said. ``It's lasted all these years because it has great depth, it's a wonderful story and it touches children of all ages.'' --- HIALEAH, Fla. (AP) - City officials are trying to close a nightclub owned by rapper Luther Campbell of 2 Live Crew after a man was killed and another wounded there in a weekend gunfight. City Attorney Alex Vilarello filed court papers Tuesday seeking an injunction closing the Strawberry Too club. A hearing wasn't expected before Friday. Campbell, who has owned the club for two years, was acquitted of obscenity in October along with other members of the group. They were arrested for a concert featuring songs from his group's album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' Campbell said police were to blame for violence at the club because they failed to control crowds outside. ``I think the city of Hialeah is full of it, personally, because every club in the city of Miami, Miami Beach, all over the county, has police outside of the club,'' Campbell said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Renominates Clarke as Comptroller of Currency
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is renominating a banking regulator who has been criticized for creating a credit shortage by cracking down too hard on institutions with sour real estate loans. The White House said Tuesday that Bush planned to appoint Robert L. Clarke to a second five-year term as comptroller of the currency, the regulator of nationally chartered banks. He must be confirmed by the Senate. According to government and industry sources who spoke anonymously last week, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu had sought to block the nomination. Sununu's home state of New Hampshire, where he served as governor, has been particularly hard hit by the so-called credit crunch. According to a government source, White House aides last week began soliciting criticism of Clarke from bank and business executives after receiving a letter of complaint from major Republican contributors. Bankers and borrowers in the Northeast have been saying for a year that Clarke's examiners have overreacted to the savings and loan crisis, discouraging bankers from making even sound loans. However, Clarke and other regulators maintained that they have not tightened standards inappropriately. They blame banks' reluctance to lend on deteriorating real estate markets and on a lack of loan demand resulting from the sluggish economy. Clarke had the backing of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, a longtime friend of the president. The secretary is the comptroller's boss, but in practice the comptroller has considerable independence. After reports of Sununu's opposition were published, Democratic and Republican members of the House Banking Committee rushed to Clarke's defense. They warned that the White House would be sending the wrong signal to regulators if they failed to reappoint a regulator for being too tough. Although Clarke jokingly embraced the nickname ``regulator from hell,'' he has since moderated his public remarks. In a statement thanking Bush for the reappointment, he said, ``We can work through the current problems if lenders assume their responsibility to make loans and take reasonable risks, and if regulators follow a responsive, balanced approach that takes into account ... the very significant national interest in not unnecessarily depressing credit availability.'' ``I believe that now is a time for the application of common sense, a time when neither lenders nor regulators should overreact or be unresponsive,'' he said. National banks, which are chartered by the federal government, are about a third of the nation's commercial banks. The rest are chartered by the states. National banks tend to be larger, and together account for more than half of commercial bank assets.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Doesn't `Have All the Wisdom' on Gulf Policy, Lawmakers Say
DOC.TEXT: Though the Bush administration is pressing congressional Democrats to stop sniping at White House policy in the Persian Gulf, leaders on Capitol Hill say it's their duty to raise questions. ``I don't accept the premise that they have all the wisdom,'' said Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Middle East subcommittee. ``Their job is to present their policy, and ours is to test it, probe it, understand it, criticize it, and out of that process a better policy emerges,'' said Hamilton, who has largely supported President Bush's actions in the gulf so far. Since Bush announced Nov. 8 that he was nearly doubling the U.S. force in the gulf to provide an offensive threat against Iraq, support for his policies has weakened at home. In seeking to scare Saddam Hussein, the president also has scared Americans. A key indication of that has come in Congress, which has been holding hearings for more than two weeks hammering away at what many lawmakers and their witnesses believe is the administration's overeagerness for a military solution. Administration officials say they're worried the criticism will weaken the U.S. position when Secretary of State James A. Baker III meets with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Saddam, Baker said at a hearing last week, ``simply cannot receive discordant, or confused or mixed messages.'' So Baker, Bush, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft will be meeting privately with senior members of Congress in an effort to build a united front, one senior official said Tuesday. ``It would be nice if we could figure out a way for at least the leadership to convey a unified message,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Hamilton called Baker's call for congressional restraint ``the classic argument of the authoritarian: `Trust me, fellows. Don't bother me. I can handle it.' That's about as strong an anti-democratic argument as you can make. You can't turn off democracy because it's inconvenient.'' But when the issue involves American lives, is there a time to put aside legitimate disagreements in favor of presenting a united front? To Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., that's part of the tough job of being a lawmaker. ``We've just got to cut this out,'' said Lugar. ``It suggests to Saddam Hussein that Americans have at least two alternative policies, maybe more, none of which has congressional authorization. That makes the situation confusing for friend and foe alike.'' Lugar wants the Democrats who control Congress to call a special session and force members to take sides in a formal vote. Lugar said there are political considerations as well, while few want to talk about it. Democrats seem to be hedging their political bets by not taking a formal position, he said. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., cautioned colleagues in a closed-door session of conservative Democrats last week that the party might never regain the White House if the public perceives that Bush's gulf policies succeeded without help from the Democratic Congress. ``There's no question there will be winners and losers from this politically,'' said Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif., but he added that no one should act based on those considerations. He conceded that if Democrats appear too shy of military action it could revive the ``weakness'' charge effectively used against the party by former President Reagan.

DOC.HEAD: Stallion Undergoes Plastic Surgery; He's One Good-Looking Stud Now
DOC.TEXT: So what if the mares don't care? Robins Parteebuilt is a stud, and his owners care. They want the stallion to look his best. So a plastic surgeon who normally works on patients of the two-legged variety was summoned to repair the dent in 11-year-old Robins Parteebuilt's forehead. The stallion, nicknamed Partee, got the dent in 1989 when he galloped head-first into a fence post. This week, a team at the University of Illinois veterinary school filled in the mark with a sort of body putty. ``This is one of the top 10 sires of halter horses in the nation - a precious animal,'' said owner Roger DeWitt of Gillespie. University veterinarians had patched Partee's face as best they could in 1989, using wires to hold together broken bones. But when it came to a face as pretty as Partee's - the subject of oohs and aahs at the university clinic - the veterinarians decided a plastic surgeon was needed. They called in Dr. Jim Sheridan from Carle Clinic in Urbana. One of his specialties is repairing faces. It took 19 people using a hoist to get the anesthetized, 1,350-pound stallion onto the operating table. ``Boy, he's a handsome dog,'' veterinary surgeon Gordon Baker said after the dent was filled in. And everyone in the operating room agreed.

DOC.HEAD: Most States Spending More to Probe Insurance Complaints
With PM-Consumers-Insurance-List
DOC.TEXT: Most state insurance departments are spending more money to investigate consumer complaints, but some can't keep pace because of budget problems, says a new report. Spending on consumer services rose an average of 12 percent from 1989 to 1990, says the report prepared by a consumer organization and several insurance industry groups and released Tuesday. But the study found wide variations in spending levels. State insurance budgets for consumer services ranged from $38 in Michigan for every 1,000 people, to a high of $712 in Delaware. Massachusetts spends about $60 per 1,000 people on consumer services, while Washington state spends $444. The average is $230 per 1,000 people in the 36 states that provided the information, the study found. ``The good news is that most departments offer many services to consumers,'' said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America. But states such as Michigan and Massachusetts have undergone statewide budget cuts that have hurt consumer services, the report said. Michigan's toll-free phone for insurance complaints was discontinued a number of years ago. Staff size has been cut in half. There is a ``large-scale demand for our services which we are not encouraging or tapping,'' acknowledged Howard Spence, Michigan's deputy insurance commissioner. Despite the cuts, Michigan recovers more than $2 million a year for consumers through the complaint process, Spence said. Despite the budget cuts in Massachusetts, the state managed to recover $600,000 last year for consumers. The best-run consumer services programs, according to the report: -Florida, with a substantial population of elderly residents, spends $567 for each 1,000 people. -New York, with a $5.5 million budget for consumer services in 1990, the largest of any state. That comes out to $307 per 1,000 population. -Texas, which receives almost one-quarter of the 2 million requests made each year to state insurance departments for information about the industry. -Delaware, which funnels 90 percent of its budget for consumer services into handling complaints. The remainder goes for information and education programs. -Kansas and Wisconsin, which each spent more than $1 million this year for consumer services. Half of the states responding to the survey have a toll-free telephone hotline for complaints about insurance. More than 40 percent of the states distribute information about insurance pricing, the insolvency of some insurers and whether there are large numbers of complaints against a particular company. Large states such as Pennsylvania spend a relatively small amount on consumer services, $1.9 million, which comes out to $158 per 1,000 people. But employees in other parts of the state insurance department take consumer inquiries, pointed out Amy Dugan, a spokeswoman for the agency. State insurance departments set rates, approve mergers, investigate consumer complaints and have the power to revoke licenses of insurance companies. Federal law leaves all insurance regulation to the states. The study was prepared by the Consumer Insurance Interest Group, the National Association of Professional Insurance Agents, the American Insurance Association and the American Council of Life Insurance. The consumer group includes the Consumer Federation of America, Public Citizen and the National Insurance Consumer Organization.

DOC.HEAD: The Donald and Ivana are Splitsville, Pricetag Still in Question
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump is back in the singles game. Now the question is, how much is his freedom going to cost the virtuoso dealmaker? A tearful Ivana Trump left court a single woman Tuesday after a judge, citing Trump's ``cruel and inhuman treatment'' of his wife, dissolved their 13-year marriage. That makes Trump, dubbed The Donald by Ivana during happier times, one of the most eligible bachelors around. But with his financial empire crumbling, it's unclear how much that freedom will cost him - and how eligible he'll be after paying off. ``There are two parts to any marriage: One, are we married? And two, do I owe you any money? Today we've cleared the way for the real issue: division of property,'' said Jay Goldberg, Trump's lawyer. The alleged other woman, Marla Maples, kept a low profile. ``Marla is out of town on business. She won't be having any comment,'' said her spokesman, Chuck Jones. Michael Kennedy, Mrs. Trump's lawyer, said Ivana had nothing to say after the uncontested divorce was approved, but Donald issued a brief statement of good will. ``I wish Ivana the best. I have no doubt that she will do very well in the years to come,'' he said. Whether Ivana, 41, will do well with proceeds of a marital agreement updated in 1987 or with a larger piece of the Trump pie remains to be seen. The marital pact calls for Ivana to receive $10 million and the couple's Connecticut estate, worth an estimated $12 million, lawyers have said. Child support, division of property and the validity of any marital agreements will be decided at trial, unless they are settled out of court. Mrs. Trump, in court papers filed earlier this year, said she was seeking $2.5 billion of Trump's estimated $5 billion fortune - a figure financial experts say has dwindled drastically in recent months. The trial is expected to start April 11, Goldberg said. Trump's penchant for publicity backfired somewhat as his marital troubles were splashed across newspapers, radio and television with reports of his alleged affair with Miss Maples, a model who wants to become an actress. A New York Post front-page headline quoted Miss Maples, 26, as saying of her relationship with Trump: ``Best Sex I've Ever Had.'' A picture of a smirking Donald ran next to the headline. Further tales of their trysting, some liaisons allegedly carried out virtually under Ivana's nose at Trump Tower, kept tongues wagging coast to coast until Donald's financial woes edged news about the breakup aside. Mrs. Trump argued in court papers that the couple's updated agreement, signed in 1987, was drawn up while her husband was already committing adultery and intended to leave her. Trump, 45, maintains the agreement remains valid. It was not clear what effect the divorce would have on Mrs. Trump's position as head of the Plaza Hotel. Trump, speaking later at the Plaza, said he had not decided whether to keep his ex-wife as an employee. Trump, who has come under pressure from creditors at his Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City and had to refinance millions in debt to stay afloat, was zapped by the judge in the divorce decree. Judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob Gangel-Jacob said, ``Mr. Trump's cruel and inhuman treatment ... made it unsafe or improper to continue to be married.'' The Trumps have three children, ages 12, 8 and 6, who have been staying with Mrs. Trump since the couple separated last winter.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman: Kuwaiti Supplies Could Sustain Iraq For Years
DOC.TEXT: Economic sanctions will not force Saddam Hussein to back down because his legions looted enough from Kuwait to sustain Iraq for years, a Canadian businessman who fled the captive nation said early today. The Baghdad-born executive said he was ``utterly amazed by the over-simplification of the issue ... that economic sanctions will have their effects on Iraq.'' ``What has been looted from Kuwait is enough to last the system for up to 10 years,'' the 50-year-old businessman said. In addition to computers, cars and other consumer goods, he said the amount of food taken from Kuwait could last Iraq at least two years. ``This issue of starvation is highly exaggerated.'' The University of California at Berkeley graduate lived in Kuwait 11 years and through his work was closely connected to Kuwaiti and Western businesses. He spoke on condition that he and his company not be identified for fear colleagues in Kuwait would be harrassed. There is widespread debate over whether the U.N. embargo on trade with Iraq could by itself force Saddam to back out of Kuwait. The trade cutoff has shut down Iraq's oil exports and food imports, but Baghdad has taken measures toward achieving self-sufficiency. The Canadian was among 14 people who landed in Frankfurt late Tuesday. The group included seven Americans, two Britons, two Canadians, an Irishman, an Italian and an Australian. Their U.S.-chartered Boeing 707 was one of three jetliners delivering former hostages from Iraq on Tuesday. Two others flew to Bangkok and London. U.S. consulate spokesman Craig Springer said the men would take commercial flights to their destinations. Saddam announced last week that he would free all those trapped by the Aug. 2 invasion, and more than 170 former hostages arrived in Frankfurt on Monday in the blanket release's first wave. Another flight, believed to be the last, is expected in Frankfurt on Thursday, carrying the U.S. ambassador and embassy staff from Kuwait. Most of the former hostages looked tired and refused to speak to waiting reporters. Tom Litrenta, 28, of Allentown, Pa., said the mood on the flight ``was really quiet, believe it or not.'' Litrenta, who left behind several Iraqi friends, said he had mixed feelings about the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The people I talked to just said they want no more war,'' said Litrenta, who was working on an irrigation project for the Iraqi government. Iraq fought an eight-year war with Iran that ended with a 1988 cease-fire. The Canadian businessman said an Iraqi friend in Kuwait asked him to give President Bush a message ``that they hope he will not betray them and they are waiting for him to liberate not only Kuwait but the Iraqi people from this tyranny.'' The businessman said he finally left Kuwait at the insistence of his family, which is waiting for him in Mississauga, near Toronto. But he said he planned to continue lobbying for Kuwait's liberation. ``I am willing to fight and encourage the world to flush them out of Kuwait,'' he said. ``I believe the whole world is held responsible for the catastrophe and the tragedy of Kuwait because we don't unite against tyranny.''

DOC.HEAD: Anderson's Sister Expresses Anger Over Plight Of Beirut Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Hostage Terry Anderson's sister says she is happy for freed Americans returning home from the Mideast this week, but angry that her brother remains captive nearly six years after being yanked from a Beruit street. ``This is not the first time, nor the second nor the third time that our families have stood back and watched other hostage situations being resolved,'' Peggy Say said Tuesday on NBC's ``Today'' show, While happy for those families, Mrs. Say said she is ``angry and frustrated that the Beirut hostages have been known as the forgotten hostages for almost six years now. And nobody seems to be angry about that. ``I listened to President Bush and senators and congressmen stand up on television and say America will not tolerate the holding of its citizens. And my brother has been chained to a wall in a dirty basement cell in Beirut - this will be his sixth Christmas. ``For years we listened to `quiet diplomacy is the answer.' Quiet diplomacy is not the answer,'' she said, stressing that nothing will be done ``until people in the media put the feet of the administration to the fire.'' Anderson, The Associated Press' chief Middle East correspondent, was kidnapped March 16, 1985. He has been in captivity the longest of the six Americans and seven other Western hostages held by radical Moslem groups in Lebanon. Mrs. Say, in a letter to Bush published in part in Tuesday's USA Today, asks: ``When did my brother get lost in the course of human events, Mr. President? Who declared his life and liberty less valuable than that of any other hostage ever taken?'' She said that while Bush spoke in ``indignant anger'' about the hostages in Iraq, ``God help those that fall outside the realm of political exposure and expediency. ``They can only weep in despair and puzzled wonder as their president and peers continue to accept their desperate situation.'' She noted that the last picture she received, from Irishman and former hostage Brian Keenan, showed Anderson pedaling an exercise bicycle with an 18-inch chain holding his wrist to the wall.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Kill 26 More Guerrillas in Major Army Offensive
DOC.TEXT: Troops have killed at least 26 more guerrillas in a major offensive against the country's biggest rebel group, the army says. The guerrillas of the leftist Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces were killed Tuesday while soldiers fanned out in the mountains surrounding the rebels' fallen headquarters about 100 miles south of the capital. About 2,000 troops backed by fighter aircraft on Sunday stormed the headquarters, known as ``Casa Verde.'' Observers said the attack was the largest military move against rebel forces in 30 years. The army said 26 guerrillas were killed in Tuesday's fighting. Newspaper and radio reports said at least 50 rebels have been killed since Sunday. Eleven soldiers died in the weekend assault, an army report said Tuesday, but no further army casualty reports were available. ``The military operations are continuing in order to guarantee the integrity and security of troops still fighting in the area,'' army commander Gen. Manuel Murrillo told a news conference Tuesday. The guerrillas issued a communique Monday saying the army attack was the beginning of a ``war of unpredictable consequences.'' The commanders canceled peace talks they have intermittently maintained with the government since 1982. The Revolutionary Armed Forces is Colombia's oldest and biggest rebel outfit with about 6,000 combatants and tens of thousands of supporters in the countryside. The army offensive began the same day Colombians went to the polls to choose an assembly that will rewrite the country's 104-year-old constitution. M-19, a former rebel group that became a political party, captured more votes than any other candidate list in the elections and will control 19 of the assembly's 70 seats. The M-19 signed a peace treaty with the government nine months ago in exchange for amnesty. Colombia's Communist Party issued a statement Monday saying the army attack was an attempt to ``hang a sword'' over the constituent assembly.

DOC.HEAD: DHAKA: Gulshan district.
DOC.TEXT: Ershad, a 60-year-old former army general, resigned Thursday after seven weeks of escalating street demonstrations for his ouster. His opponents demand that he stand trial to answer accusations of corruption and abuse of power during his eight-year rule. About 100 police surrounded the wall-enclosed building to which the Ershads were taken. Earlier in the day, workmen hastily installed air conditioners, beds and carpets. Police tents were pitched in the back garden.

DOC.HEAD: Facing Fifth Drought Year, Southern California to Ration Water
DOC.TEXT: Water will be rationed throughout Southern California as the region nears the beginning of its fifth year of dought. The Metropolitan Water District, which serves 15 million customers in six counties, will fine cities and other agencies it supplies if they surpass limits approved Tuesday. Residential use must be trimmed by 5 percent and farm suppliers face 20 percent cuts beginning Feb. 1. Local agencies that go over the limits will pay tripled fees. The limits directly affect local suppliers, not the 15 million households, businesses and farms the district serves in Los Angeles, Ventura, San Diego, San Bernardino, Riverside and Orange counties. Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley said he has not decided whether to impose mandatory rationing citywide, hoping voluntary reductions will meet the limits.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Council Wants to Place Homicide Liability on Gun Manufacturer
DOC.TEXT: The District of Columbia City Council has given preliminary approval to legislation that would make manufacturers of semiautomatic assault-style weapons liable for injuries and deaths those guns cause in the nation's capital. The council voted for the bill 8-3, with two abstentions, on Tuesday. A final vote was scheduled for next Tuesday. ``It's time for these merchants of death to pay a price,'' said council member William Lightfoot, who sponsored the legislation. ``We can set a very meaningful precedent.'' Carl Rowan Jr., a lobbyist for the National Rifle Association, decried the law as ``good theater, but frivolous legislation'' that could not stand constitutional scrutiny. ``I don't think it stands a chance in court,'' Rowan said. The city already has a very strict gun control law, and sales of semiautomatic assault-style weapons have been illegal since 1976. But police say criminals can get firearms in neighboring Maryland and Virginia, which have less restrictive laws.

DOC.HEAD: Candlelight Ceremonies Along Mississippi and Ohio Rivers Honor Troops
With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Families of soldiers in the Middle East lighted candles, sang songs and prayed for the troops in a vigil held simultaneously in at least 47 cities in seven states along the Mississippi and Ohio rivers. Church bells rang and riverboats aimed headlights skyward while tooting their horns. People shone flashlights and lighted Christmas trees on cue. ``What you have here I think is a major show of support for the troops and the families,'' said organizer Marvin Peter of Evansville, who has a son serving in Saudi Arabia. ``Everyone hopes for peace.'' The tribute began at 6:45 p.m. CST Tuesday in Indiana, Kentucky, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Tennessee and Virginia, Peter said. Most lasted about 30 minutes. ``It was really an Ohio River Valley thing that just sort of snowballed,'' he said. ``We never dreamed it would go this far.'' Evansville and two other Ohio River cities, Henderson and Owensboro in Kentucky, announced last month their plans for simultaneous ceremonies Tuesday. After that, the idea spread to the Mississippi River and some inland points. ``I came because I love my husband and I want him and all the troops to know I support them,'' said Lisa Bean, who held a candle among a crowd of more than 1,000 people praying at the Evansville riverfront. Mrs. Beam said her husband, Marine Sgt. Michael Bean, was scheduled to leave for Saudi Arabia this week. Vietnam veteran Russell Abrams joined 1,000 people in Owensboro who listened as the names of local soldiers serving in the Persian Gulf were read. He said such a ceremony could have boosted morale during his three years serving in Southeast Asia. ``It would have done my heart a lot of good to know this was going on at home instead of what was,'' he said. On the riverfront in Louisville, Ky., more than 200 people sang ``America the Beautiful'' and other patriotic songs. In Jackson, Tenn., soldiers' families were given flags and ribbons to decorate a ``tree of honor.'' In Cincinnati, about 150 people at a riverside park held onto a long piece of orange ribbon and sang ``Let There Be Peace on Earth.'' A passing riverboat tooted its horn as they sang. Almost 90 towboats operated by American Commercial Barge Line Co. were instructed to shine their lights into the air at 6:45 p.m. and blow their whistles.

DOC.HEAD: Ershad Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series. CORRECTS spelling of wife and son's names in 3rd graf. ADDS details on student demo, background. No pickup. ADDS byline. ^By HASSAN SAAED
DOC.TEXT: Deposed President Hussain Muhammad Ershad was arrested and confined to a house in an exclusive diplomatic area on Wednesday, six days after yielding power under massive public pressure. Ershad was escorted by three police cars and three army trucks to the former home of the British ambassador, which was hastily prepared for his detention. Ershad, with his wife Raushan and their 8-year-old son Shahd, looked grim as he rode through the gate of the home in the Gulshan district. The 60-year-old former army general resigned Thursday after seven weeks of escalating street demonstrations for his ouster. His opponents demand he stand trial to answer accusations of corruption and abuse of power during his eight-year rule. More than 150 police surrounded the wall-enclosed building to which Ershad was taken. It is opposite the British embassy, which once served as a guest house for Queen Elizabeth II. The house had stood empty for some time. A sign near the gate said ``Law Enforcement Commission,'' indicating it belongs to one of the country's security forces or intelligence units. Only a few hours earlier, workmen were installing air conditioners, beds and carpets in the two-story colonial-style house. Police tents were pitched in the back garden. Also Wednesday, about 6,000 students chanting ``Hang Ershad'' marched from Dhaka University to the president's office just outside the heavily guarded military compound where Ershad had lived while in office. Students had played a key role in toppling Ershad, who took power in the impoverished country of 110 million people in a bloodless 1982 coup. On Tuesday, police said they were given orders to arrest Ershad and some Cabinet ministers and other officials of his deposed government. Police squads raided a dozen homes in search of officials who had gone into hiding in fear of mob violence. Ershad's home minister, Mahmudul Hassan, was the first to be placed under house arrest. Specific charges against him have not been published. Mahmudul was in charge of the police and the paramilitary forces assigned to keep order during the demonstrations. An estimated 100 people were killed during the campaign begun in October that led to Ershad's resignation, most by security forces and some in clashes between Ershad's supporters and his opponents. Ershad handed over the government to an caretaker administration led by Supreme Court Chief Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed, who was charged with the task of preparing for parliamentary elections within 90 days.

DOC.HEAD: Hartz Mountain to Pay Reduced Fine in Repellent Case
DOC.TEXT:
Hartz Mountain Corp. has agreed to settle an Environmental Protection Agency complaint that it failed to report cases of pet illnesses and deaths from a powerful flea and tick repellent. However, the Harrison, N.J.-based pet product giant admitted no liability, according to a statement. The company agreed to pay $45,000 of the original $90,000 in fines, which stemmed from a 1987 investigation into complaints from veterinarians and consumers that Blockade sprays were making some dogs and cats sick.
---
DOC.HEAD: Pfizer Warns Patients About Heart Valves
DOC.TEXT:
Pfizer Inc. will conduct an unprecedented search to warn about 23,000 patients about rare but often fatal fractures of an implanted heart valve, officials say. The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday it has accepted Pfizer's plan to locate patients who have the Bjork-Shiley 60-degree convexo-concave heart valve. Valve fractures have occurred in about seeen of every 10,000 patients per year, the FDA said. The valve was implanted in about 82,000 people worldwide between 1979 and November 1986, when it was removed from the market. About 23,000 of the patients who are still alive are in the United States and Canada. About 295 fractures of the valve were reported to the FDA, with 178 deaths resulting. When a valve fractures, a patient's life can be saved if the valve is replaced quickly. ``That's why it is important for C-C valve patients to ask their doctors how to recognize early signs of valve fracture and what to do should it occur,'' FDA Deputy Commissioner James Benson said. Public Citizen Health Research Group, a Ralph Nader-founded advocacy group, has been pressing the FDA and Pfizer for years to notify patients about the danger. The company last week sent letters to about 19,000 heart specialists telling them of the program and asking them to contact patients who have the Shiley valve. About 450 hospitals are also being contacted. On Thursday, the company will detail plans for a patient registry that will include a toll-free telephone number for patients to identify themselves. The program will be run by Medic Alert, a nonprofit foundation, which has already set up a telephone number where patients can get further information. The number is 1-800-245-1492.
---
DOC.HEAD: Congressional Investigators Say EPA Lax on Cleanup Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators are accusing auditors at the Environmental Protection Agency of not aggressively pursuing potential fraud by private contractors involved in millions of dollars in environmental cleanup programs. But EPA' Inspector General John Martin told a House subcommittee Tuesday that he stands by his office's work and said its investigations have led to 250 indictments since 1984 as well as the recovery of $16 million in fines through administrative actions. Investigators for both the House Energy and Commerce Committee and for the General Accounting Office testified that hundreds of EPA contracts have not been audited because of backlogs. And in some cases, they said, questions of possible fraud have not been pursued adequately. Three subcommittee investigators acknowledged, however, that their year-long investigation uncovered no proof of fraud or evidence of deliberate wrongdoing by EPA auditors. The GAO report said that most of EPA's contracts dating back four years have yet to be audited because of a backlog both within the EPA and at the Defense Contract Audit Agency, which handles may of the contract reviews for the agency. The Defense audit agency has 273 outstanding requests for contract audits from the EPA as of the end of last month, with 40 percent of them made more than two years ago, said the GAO investigators. Martin, who has been the EPA's inspector general since late 1983, said the congressional investigators ``have not found fraud. ... They have not found anything wrong that we did not find already. ... They found it in our files.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks, Dollar Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rose for the sixth consecutive day on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today, while the dollar inched up against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 172.30 points Tuesday, added 42.44 points today, or 0.17 percent, closing at 23,999.41. The index now has climbed 2,136.8 points in six days. Heavy profit-taking selling pushed the index down at the start, but active buying by institutional investors brought it back up, securities dealers said. ``The strength of large capital shares, such as steel and shipbuilding issues, indicates the bullish sentiment in the market,'' said a dealer with Daiwa Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. Volume on the first section was estimated at 600 million shares, up from 530 million Tuesday. On the currency market, the dollar closed at 131.88 yen, up 0.13 yen from Tuesday's close of 131.75 yen. It opened at 132.20 yen and moved in a range of 131.75-132.28 yen. Currency dealers said a feeling that the U.S. currency is undervalued motivated market players to actively buy the dollar. But when the dollar climbed above 132.20 yen, investors it to buy yen, dealers said. ``It is unlikely the dollar is going to move in any one direction,'' said Yukio Mukoyama, deputy general manager of Fuji Bank's international treasury division. Spot trading totaled $7.51 billion, down from Tuesday's $9.47 billion. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was at 87.90 points at 5 p.m. (3 a.m. EST), down from Tuesday's 87.95-point close. Their yield was 7.070 percent, unchanged from the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Dead Sea Scrolls Editor's Exit Tied to Anti-Semitic Remarks
DOC.TEXT: A Harvard divinity professor's dismissal as editor in chief of the Dead Sea Scrolls was prompted by remarks attacking Judaism, The New York Times said today. In a newspaper interview published last month in Israel, Professor John Strugnell was quoted as describing Judaism as ``originally racist'' and suggesting that all Jews should convert to Christianity. In dismissing Strugnell as editor of the scrolls last week, the international team of scholars overseeing the work had cited health problems and criticism of the slow pace at which the ancient documents are being published. But the Times said today that Strugnell's colleagues acknowledged that the anti-Jewish remarks had forced the issue. ``The interview certainly contributed,'' said Frank Moore Cross, another Harvard scholar on the Dead Sea Scrolls team. ``But the interview was impossible without his illness.'' Strugnell, 60, who has been editor since 1987, could not be reached for comment, the Times said. Harvard spokesman Peter Costa said he was in a hospital, which was not identified, for treatment of an illness, which was not disclosed. The Times reported that several of Strugnell's colleagues said he had a drinking problem, while others alluded to his ``mental condition.'' The Dead Sea Scrolls, discovered in 1947 in a cave in what is now the Israeli-occupied West Bank, contain the oldest known copies of the Old Testament, other Biblical writings, ancient literature and poetry. The scrolls illuminate the evolution of Judaism and the origins of Christianity. About 35 percent to 45 percent of the scrolls remain unpublished. The interview with Strugnell was published Nov. 9 in Haaretz, a Tel Aviv newspaper. In the interview, Strugnell, a Roman Catholic, was quoted as saying of Judaism: ``It's a horrible religion. It's a Christian heresy, and we deal with our heretics in different ways. You are a phenomenon that we haven't managed to convert - and we should have managed.'' The Israeli journalist who interviewed Strugnell, Avi Katzman, said in an article in Biblical Archeology Review: ``Although Strugnell drank beer throughout the interview - this did not surprise me as his drinking habits are well known in Jerusalem - he did not appear to be inebriated. He was lucid and spoke in a firm voice.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Politicians to Seek Understanding from U.S. Black Leaders
DOC.TEXT: Two Japanese legislators flew to the United States today to meet with American black leaders and seek to cool tempers inflamed by insulting remarks the justice minister made about blacks. Yoshiro Mori and Motoji Kondo, senior legislators representing the governing Liberal Democratic Party, were to visit Washington, New York and Los Angeles. ``We're going at Prime Minister (Toshiki) Kaifu's request, but also because I feel personally worried that we haven't really dealt with the problem yet,'' Mori said in an interview. On Sept. 21, following a police roundup of foreign prostitutes in Tokyo, Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama said they ``ruin the atmosphere of the neighborhoods they move into. The area is becoming mixed just like in America where blacks move in and whites are forced out.'' Kajiyama's comment was the latest in a series of minority-related faux pas by Japanese politicians, slips that many analysts blame on ignorance and insensitivity to racial issues. Kajiyama apologized for his remark and was publicly reprimanded by Kaifu. Leaders of the Congressional Black Caucus and other groups have demanded more drastic action. They want Kajiyama's resignation and the teaching of black American history and culture in Japanese schools. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said his ministry ``highly recommended'' the legislators' mission to the United States. ``It should not be a one-shot effort,'' Watanabe said, but the first of several such bridge-building efforts. Mori said he and Kondo hoped to explain to black leaders that Japan takes the issue seriously, although demanding Kajiyama's resignation ``was going too far.'' He said the government planned to promote more awareness of American minorities, although changes in school curricula usually take time. ``Until now, we've tended to avoid teaching about such bad aspects of American society as racial tensions. We thought it would be disrespectful. Now, I guess we'd better start,'' Mori said. Mori said white Americans were to blame for teaching the Japanese racist attitudes. ``I want to stress that Japanese themselves have no bad feelings toward blacks or other minorities. And we respect the United States for making a free and open society with such a diverse mixture of peoples,'' he said. He said Japan must deal with its own complicated racial attitudes. The Korean minority in Japan and people from other Asian countries face social and economic discrimination. Japanese designated centuries ago as belonging to the ``Burakumin,'' or ``village people'' caste, also face deep-rooted prejudice. ``Japan, with all its wealth, hasn't made Southeast Asian refugees feel welcome. And we colonized Korea for 37 long years. We really must reflect on that,'' Mori said. ``It's about time we resolved these issues.'' In 1986, former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone aroused U.S. anger when he said intelligence levels in the United States were inferior ``because of a considerable number of blacks, Puerto Ricans and Mexicans.'' In 1988, Michio Watanabe, the Liberal Democrats' policy chief, said American blacks had few qualms about going bankrupt, implying that they walk away from their debts. Such comments incensed minority groups, which also have accused Japanese firms operating in the United States of deliberately discriminating against blacks and Hispanics in their hiring policies. Those groups plan rallies outside the Japanese Embassy in Washington and Japanese consulates in other cities on Saturday to express their dissatisfaction with Japanese racial attitudes, said Masatake Takahashi, an international political commentator who helped organize the legislators' visit. They also have called for a boycott of Japanese imports to drive their point home.

President Bush will advocate a constitutional amendment to limit the number of terms for members of Congress, says his chief of staff. Bush has been on record for some time as favoring the idea - which is enjoying increasing grassroots support - but it remains unclear how hard he will push the issue. The president also is on record as favoring constitutional amendments to ban abortions and flag burning, to require a balanced budget and to give president line-item veto power over congressional appropriations. All are issues with intense, passionate support among those who favor them - but far less support in Congress, where a two-thirds majority is required to submit a constitutional amendment to the states for ratification. The idea of pushing for a limitation on congressional terms, in particular, could be politically tempting for a president attempting to convince voters that his programs are being stymied by a recalcitrant Congress dominated members of the opposite party - Democrats, in the current instance. John Sununu, Bush's chief of staff, concluded a lengthy speech at the National Press Club on Tuesday by outlining some of the agenda Bush will pursue during the upcoming session of Congress. ``The president will continue to press for reforms such as a line-item veto, he will press for reforms in campaign financing, and he will press for a term-limitation amendment that deals with the problems associated with perpetuating the life of those who are elected to govern people - the public life of those who are elected to govern people,'' said Sununu. ``The reality that incumbency breeds a very different attitude is now sensed by the public and I think if you take a look at what was intended as a structure by those that founded this country, you'll see we've moved a great distance from it.''

DOC.HEAD: Two U.S. Marines Die in Saudia Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. Marines have died in separate incidents, one of a presumed heart attack while exercising, the other from a suspected brain aneurysm, military officials said today. The deaths, which occurred Monday, raised the number of the U.S. deaths in Operation Desert Shield to 56, including 49 in air crashes and other accidents, according to the U.S. Central Command. Names of the two men killed on Monday were withheld pending notification of next of kin. According to a statement, a Marine from the assault ship USS Iwo Jima died of a presumed heart attack after collapsing while participating in group physical fitness training in Bahrain. A medical response team was unable to revive the Marine, who was pronounced dead at 8:30 a.m. The died Marine who died of a presumed ruptured brain aneurysm was medically evacuated to the hospital ship USNS Comfort after complaining of nausea, diarrhea and headaches, the military said in a second statement. He was assigned to the 1st Ballation, 2nd Marine Regiment from Camp Lejeune, N.C. On Sunday, an Army soldier serving with Bravo Co. of the 724th Maintenance Support Battalion was killed when the tractor-trailer truck he was driving overturned, pinning him in the cab. The soldier, who was on a routine water supply training mission, was pronounced dead at the scene. He was identiifed as Pvt. Scott N. Vigrass. No hometown was given.

DOC.HEAD: Ershad Arrested, Confined To House Pending Possible Charges
DOC.TEXT: Six days after yielding power under massive public pressure, deposed President Hussain Muhammad Ershad was arrested today and confined to a house in an exclusive diplomatic area. Home Secretary Azimuddin Ahmed said Ershad and his wife Raushan were ordered detained for 120 days under a law that permits arrest without charges. ``He has been put under safe custody. There are no formal charges as yet,'' Azimuddin said. Police sources said arrest orders were issued for 16 people, including Ershad, his wife and former Home Minister Mahmudul Hassan, who was placed under house arrest on Tuesday. Ershad, a 60-year-old former army general, resigned Dec. 6 after seven weeks of escalating street demonstrations for his ouster. His opponents demand he stand trial to answer accusations of corruption and abuse of power during his eight-year rule. Ershad was escorted by three police cars and three army trucks to the former home of the British ambassador, which was hastily prepared for his detention. The ex-president looked grim as he rode through the gate of the home in the Gulshan district. He was in the back seat of a private car with his wife and 8-year-old son Shahd. More than 150 police surrounded the walled house opposite the British embassy. The two-story colonial-style house once served as a guest house for Queen Elizabeth II but has been empty for some time. A sign near the gate said ``Law Enforcement Commission.'' Azimuddin said the building was administered by the Home Ministry and was being used to hold Ershad since he has no personal home in the capital. Thirty minutes before Ershad arrived at the house, guards were cautioned by their officers not to salute or stand at attention for the ousted leader. A few hours earlier workmen hastily installed air conditioners, beds and carpets. Police tents were pitched in the back garden. Azimuddin said no telephone lines would be connected to the house for Ershad's use. Earlier, army officers and police chased reporters away from the presidential home Ershad had occupied in the city's heavily guarded military compound. His telephones were apparently disconnected. About 6,000 students marched from Dhaka University to the president's office just outside the compound and chanted ``Hang Ershad.'' The students were at the forefront of the campaign to oust Ershad, who seized power in a bloodless 1982 oup and ruled under martial law for four years. He then resigned from the army and was elected president in 1986 in elections his opponents accused him of rigging. Mahmudul, the former home minister, was the first to be arrested. He was in charge of the police and the paramilitary forces assigned to keep order during the demonstrations that toppled Ershad. An estimated 100 people were killed in the protests that began in October, most by security forces and some in clashes between Ershad's supporters and opponents. When Ershad resigned six days ago, he handed over the government to a caretaker administration led by Supreme Court Chief Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed. Shahabuddin says he has no political ambitions of his own, and his main task is to prepare for parliamentary elections within 90 days.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Topples NBC in Ratings
With PM-Nielsens-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Monday night football got its highest ratings of the season and made ABC No. 1 for the second time this fall. The network grabbed a 27 average rating with the Dec. 3 ``NFL Monday Night Football'' game between the San Francisco 49ers and the New York Giants, the A.C. Nielsen Co. reported Tuesday. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. ABC won the week with a 12.7 average. The network's only other win this fall came last month when the game between the Los Angeles Raiders and the Miami Dolphins helped the network trounce its competitors with a 13.4 average. Usually first-place NBC fell to second last week with an 11.9. CBS was in its usual third place with an 11.1. ``60 Minutes'' on CBS got its highest ratings of the season and finished second with a 23 average. ``Cheers'' on NBC, the No. 1 favorite for much of the season, dropped to third. The three-minute premiere of Fox Broadcasting's new ``Simpsons'' video, shown at the end of Thursday's regularly scheduled episode, helped push the animated family up the Nielsen ladder. The video, titled ``Do the Bartman,'' scored higher ratings than the 30-minute ``Simpsons'' episode that preceded it. The video earned a 16.1 average. ``The Simpsons'' earned a 14.9 and landed in 20th place. In the network news, ABC, with Peter Jennings, won its 48th consecutive week with a 12.2 average. NBC and Tom Brokaw tied with CBS and Dan Rather with a 10. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``NFL Monday Night Football,'' ABC, 27; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 23; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 21.4; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 19; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 18; ``Murder, She Wrote,'' CBS, 17.2; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 17; ``The Cosby Show'' and ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC (tie), 16.1; ``Matlock,'' NBC, 15.9.

DOC.HEAD: Solzhenitsyn Refuses Soviet Prize for `Gulag Archipelago'
DOC.TEXT: Exiled writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn has refused a Soviet literary prize for ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' saying that ``the phenomenon of the Gulag has not been overcome either legally or morally.'' The prize, announced Tuesday, was granted by the Russian republic for Solzhenitsyn's three-volume account of Stalin's prison amps, published in the mid-1970s but only recently made available in the Soviet Union. In a statement issued by his New York publisher, Farrar, Straus & Giroux, Solzhenitsyn said, ``This book is about the suffering of millions and I cannot reap an honor from it.'' Solzhenitsyn, who was expelled from the Soviet Union in 1974 and lives in seclusion in Cavendish, Vt., expressed gratitude to the committee for selecting ``The Gulag Archipelago.'' The award is part of a process of rehabilitating artists and writers banned or disgraced under Mikhail Gorbachev's predecessors. Despite the changes in his native country under Gorbachev, Solzhenitsyn has remained a harsh critic of the Soviet government. He noted that ``The Gulag Archipelago'' is still hard to find in the Soviet Union and ``is being sold on the black market at exorbitant prices.''

DOC.HEAD: Calif. County Imposes Near-Ban on Animal Breeding
DOC.TEXT: San Mateo County has tentatively approved what is believed to be the first measure in the nation to require owners of dogs and cats to either buy a breeding license or get their pets sterilized. Over the protests of pet owners, the Board of Supervisors approved the measure 4-1 Tuesday after a four-hour hearing that drew breeders from across the country. The ordinance faces a second vote next week before becoming final. The ban on unlicensed breeding is intended to reduce the number of unwanted animals put to death. Under the ordinance, effective in 1992, professionals and amateurs would have to obtain a license to breed their pets or else spay or neuter them. Rules for the program, such as the cost of the license, have not been worked out. The ordinance would affect only unincorporated areas of San Mateo County, or about 10 percent of the 628,000 people in the primarily suburban, well-to-do county immediately south of San Francisco. Thus, it would not apply to such communities as Redwood City, San Mateo, Menlo Park and South San Francisco. ``We just lost,'' said Betty-Anne Stenmark, a member of Responsible Dog Breeders of San Mateo County. She and others said they may challenge the ordinance in court. The Peninsula Humane Society has said some 10,000 stray dogs and cats a year are put to death in San Mateo County. Breeders argued that they were not responsible for the pet overpopulation problem. They blamed that on stray animals. During the meeting, some in the audience hissed rock singer Grace Slick of the Jefferson Starship as the animal rights activist spoke in favor of the ordinance. ``We're users, the human race. One of the things we use the most are the animals,'' she said. Outside, one of about 50 demonstrators against the ordinance carried a sign reading, ``If the Humane Society had been in Hollywood, there would be no Lassie.'' When introduced, the legislation called for an outright ban on pet breeding. It was later amended to allow owners and breeders to obtain licenses. It was further amended Tuesday night to require breeders seeking a license to submit a plan showing how their litter would be used and pledging that most of the offspring would be spayed or neutered.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against most major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were little changed. Jim O'Neil, international economist at Swiss Bank Corp. in London, predicted the dollar would continue to fall. ``With U.S. interest rates under so much downward pressure, it is very hard to see it (the dollar) bouncing from these levels,'' O'Neil said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.13 yen to a closing 131.88 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 131.45 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: -1.4740 German marks, down from 1.4790 -1.2585 Swiss francs, down from 1.2665 -5.0040 French francs, down from 5.0230 -1.6657 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6683 -1,110.50 Italian lire, up from 1,110.07 -1.1605 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1591 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9475, up from $1.9400 late Tuesday. Bullion trading was quiet, dealers said. ``There isn't much out there to put any sparkle in the market either way,'' said a trader in London. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $371.90 per ounce at midmorning, up from $370.75 bid per ounce late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $371.85, unchanged from late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.74 to close at a bid $372.62. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.07 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $4.06.

DOC.HEAD: Hammer Bar Mitzvah Becomes a Tribute After Death
DOC.TEXT: What was to have been Armand Hammer's bar mitzvah instead became a tribute to the industrialist one day after his death. ``The beauty of it is that while we are celebrating this evening, my grandfather is celebrating the best bar mitzvah ever in heaven,'' said Michael Hammer said Tuesday night at the star-studded ceremony at the Beverly Hilton. Eight hundred guests paid as much as $500 a plate to attend the event, with the money going to Jewish charities. Hammer, who died Monday at age 92, had planned the event as both a fund-raiser and a long-delayed observance of the ceremony marking a Jewish boy's passage into adulthood. Hammer was born a Jew but didn't have a bar mitzvah at the traditional age of 13 because his socialist father eschewed religious practices. As it turned out, the event marked the final fund-raiser organized by the flamboyant, globe-trotting chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corp. who raised millions for cancer research and other causes. ``I think he was a trailblazer and contributed a great deal of resources to cure cancer, to free Soviet Jews and to help children all over the world,'' said actor Elliot Gould, emcee of the event.
