Others who attended included former Govs. Edmund G. ``Pat'' Brown Sr. and Edmund G. ``Jerry'' Brown Jr; actors Cesar Romero and Shelley Winters, and Ida Nudel, a Soviet refusenik brought from Moscow to Israel by Hammer in 1987. ``He was a great man,'' she said. Hammer, who promoted and profited from trade with the Soviet Union throughout most of the 20th century, knew every Soviet leader from Lenin to Mikhail Gorbachev. He is to be entombed Thursday in the family mausoleum at Westwood Village Memorial Park in Los Angeles, not far from Occidental Petroleum's headquarters and the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Culture, which opened last month.

DOC.HEAD: Courtroom Erupts After More Guilty Verdicts in Central Park Jogger Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 8th graf, `As Wise ...'
DOC.TEXT: Courtroom spectators screamed threats at the judge, prosecutor and jurors when two more defendants were convicted in the attack on a jogger who was gang-raped and beaten nearly to death in Central Park. Kevin Richardson, 16, on Tuesday became the first of five people convicted in the April 1989 attack to be found guilty of attempted murder. He also was convicted of rape, sodomy, robbery, assault and riot. Kharey Wise, 18, was cleared of the more serious charges but found guilty of assault, sexual abuse and riot. One juror said physical evidence, like that against Richardson, was lacking in Wise's case. The verdicts came after 12 days of deliberations in the case, which rested chiefly on videotaped statements the defendants made to police. The defense had argued that the teen-agers were intimidated and told what to say by police. Family members and other supporters erupted when the verdicts against Richardson were read, jumping to their feet, yelling threats and waving fists. Some yelled ``white justice'' or ``white racist'' and accused the judge and prosecutor of railroading Wise and Richardson, who are black. The victim is white. Richardson's mother, Grace Cuffey, fainted in the pandemonium, and the court was cleared so emergency workers could administer oxygen. As Wise was led from the courtroom in handcuffs, he turned to Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer and said: ``You, bitch, you're going to pay for this.'' Lederer, who won convictions against three other defendants in an earlier trial stemming from the attack, was escorted from court by police. The case symbolized rising fears of random violence in New York City and brought the term ``wilding'' into the city's mainstream vocabulary. Wilding is a street term for indiscriminate rampages of violence and robberies. Critics in the black community said the case received wide attention only because the victim, an investment banker, was white and affluent. Wise and Richardson face sentencing on Jan. 9. Richardson, charged as a minor, could get a maximum of five to 10 years in prison. Wise, who was charged as an adult because he was 16 when the attack took place, could be sentenced to eight and two-thirds to 26 years in prison. Defense attorneys said they would appeal. Juror Victoria Bryers said Richardson was convicted of the more serious charges because of stronger physical evidence, which included strands of the jogger's hair found on his clothing, and his underwear, which was heavily soiled on the inside with mud and grass stains. In his videotaped statement, Wise claimed he only fondled the woman's legs while holding her down as others beat and raped her. He said the attack ``was my first rape, and it will be my last.'' Richardson admitted less during his statement but acknowledged he was there during the attack. The woman, now 30, was left near death with severe head injuries. She was found about four hours later, unconscious, bleeding and covered with mud. She lost three-quarters of her blood and was initially given little chance of survival. She recovered and returned to her job but suffers lingering problems with her vision, balance and ability to smell. Antron McCray, Yusef Salaam, and Raymond Santana, all 16, were convicted in August of rape, assault and other charges. Each was sentenced to five to 10 years in prison. Steven Lopez, 16, faces trial early next year. Colin Moore, Wise's attorney, repeated complaints that the defendants received unduly vigorous prosecution because they come from poor minority neighborhoods. ``These young men did not have a snowball's chance in hell,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Limits Government Authority to Infiltrate Religious Services
DOC.TEXT: Church officials praised a judge's ruling that the government violated the First Amendment rights of church groups when it infiltrated and secretly tape-recorded religious gatherings. U.S. District Judge Roger Strand ruled Tuesday the government ``does not have unfettered discretion to conduct investigations and law enforcement activities.'' The infiltration came during an investigation of the sanctuary movement, which provided shelter to undocumented Central Americans fleeing political persecution in their homelands. The investigation resulted in the conviction of eight people in May 1986 on conspiracy and alien-smuggling charges. No prison terms were levied. Four Arizona churches and two national denominations sued the federal government later that year over the Immigration and Naturalization Service's use of paid informers to secretly record church services in 1984. ``This is a good victory for one of the basic founding principles of this country, and that was the free exercise of religion from government interference,'' said the Rev. John Fife, pastor of the Southside Presbyterian Church in Tucson, one of the churches that sued. ``The government is constitutionally precluded from unbridled and inappropriate covert activity which has as its purpose or objective the abridgement of the First Amendment freedoms of those involved,'' Strand wrote. But he rejected the churches' claim that their Fourth Amendment rights against unreasonable search and seizure were violated because investigators did not obtain search warrants. Patrick Kane, acting director of the Phoenix INS region, said the agency was satisfied with the ruling, claiming a partial victory because Strand did not find the INS or its agents guilty of specific crimes. ``We see it simply as a validation of the fact that our officers conducted their investigation according to the proper procedures and in an appropriate manner,'' Kane said. Fife said Kane was interpreting the decision to his advantage ``The government was wrong in their sanctuary investigation and they're wrong in (the INS) assertion,'' he said. The other plaintiffs were Camelback United Presbyterian Church and Sunrise United Presbyterian Church of Phoenix, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) and the American Lutheran Church.

DOC.HEAD: Man Gets Longer Sentence In New Trial
DOC.TEXT: A murderer made a 25-year mistake when he appealed his sentence in a 1986 slaying, a prosecutor said. Robert Hernandez was convicted of murder in the slaying of a man trying to protect his brother during an argument, and sentenced to 65 years in prison. He appealed the sentence on the basis of what he claimed was an error during the trial's punishment phase and in 1988 won a new trial. A new jury on Tuesday sentenced him to 90 years in prison and added a $10,000 fine. ``That appeal turned out to be a 25-year mistake,'' said prosecutor Clark Birdsall. Hernandez was convicted of stabbing Ruben Lueda to death Sept. 27, 1986. Two years later, an appeals court ruled that prosecutors erred during closing arguments by inviting jurors to consider state parole laws during their deliberations. Because the improper argument occurred during the punishment phase, the court ruled that he deserved only a new punishment hearing. Jurors were unaware of the earlier sentence Hernandez received for killing Lueda less than three months after he was paroled from prison after serving 10 years of a 99-year prison sentence for aggravated robbery. Defense lawyer Brad Lollar said the stiffer sentence is misleading because any sentence of 60 years or more is weighed the same by the parole board. Hernandez will not be eligible for parole until 2006. Lollar said he will appeal the latest sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Tells Party to Fight Enemies of the Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has urged the Communist Party to fight those ``who are trying to topple the Soviet Union,'' according to a report published today. Publication of Gorbachev's comments came the day after the chairman of the KGB security police warned that unidentified foreign powers were waging a ``secret war'' against Soviet authorities. Gorbachev, in remarks Tuesday ending a two-day plenum of the party's Central Committee, renewed his calls for a new Union Treaty to retain central control over the politics and economies of the 15 Soviet republics. The committee approved Gorbachev's proposed draft treaty, despite complaints from representatives of some republics that it did not give them enough power. Gorbachev said that Soviet leaders had ``abandoned the policy of diktat from the center.'' But he took issue with the sovereignty and independence declarations that have been passed by the legislatures of all the Soviet republics except Kirgizia in Central Asia. ``We must not give a helping hand to those who are trying to topple the Soviet Union under the guise of criticizing the old center,'' Gorbachev said. His remarks were published by the Communist Party newspaper Pravda. ``We must beware of falling from one extreme to the other, instead of ... strong central government, to have something that resembles an amoeba,'' he said. KGB chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov voiced even stronger concerns Tuesday night in a nationally televised address. ``Workers of the KGB see their duty in preventing interference into our domestic affairs by foreign special services, and those foreign organizations and groups who ... have for decades conducted and continue to conduct a secret war against the Soviet people,'' he said. In remarks reminiscent of Cold War rhetoric, Kryuchkov threatened to crack down against what he described as a efforts to block food from being sold though state-owned stores. Kryuchkov, saying he spoke on Gorbachev's orders, described a complex conspiracy in which ``special services'' of unidentified foreign powers were working in tandem with ``ultra-radicals'' to reap financial and political capital while seeking to ``shatter'' the Soviet state. ``The formation of some ultra-radical political movements is not at all spontaneous but it is deliberate and well thought out. Some of them have ample material and moral support from abroad,'' he said. ``Destructive elements take the path of organizing what in effect is economic sabotage, aggravating the situation in the consumer market,'' said Kryuchkov. He said the KGB would work to fight ``economic sabotage'' and prevent foreign products from being illegally diverted. ``Any attempts to hinder these activities will be resolutely stopped by all means that are at the disposal of the KGB,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New York Legislative Leader Indicted in Alleged Real Estate Fraud Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A powerful state legislator has been indicted on fraud charges in an alleged real estate scheme involving the sale of cooperative apartments in New York City. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller - the state's most powerful Democrat next to Gov. Mario Cuomo - was charged Tuesday with Jay E. Adolf, a top aide and former law partner, with cheating their law clients out of hundreds of thousands of dollars. But Miller said the federal indictment contains ``baseless and outrageous charges'' that he will challenge in court. ``I have never defrauded anyone in my life,'' Miller said Tuesday. The allegations, unrelated to Miller's legislative duties, stem from three real estate transactions in the mid-1980s allegedly engineered by Miller and Adolf. ``They were taking advantage of their positions as attorneys to turn a profit without the knowledge of their clients,'' said Andrew J. Maloney, U.S. attorney. Miller and Adolf were named in a 19-count indictment charging them with mail fraud, conspiracy and falsifying documents. The federal felonies are each punishable by up to five years in prison and $250,000 fines. If convicted of a felony, Miller would be expelled from the Legislature. The men will be arraigned next week. Miller has denied any wrongdoing and said federal law enforcers targeted him because he was a prominent politician. Maloney denied the charge. Gerald B. Lefcourt, Miller's lawyer, said of his client: ``He feels among a hunted class of well-known politicians and he is going to deal with it in court.'' Adolf also has denied any wrongdoing. In one alleged scheme, Miller and Adolf are accused of cheating clients of their Manhattan law firm, Adolf & Miller, by secretly investing in valuable apartments in a Brooklyn building that was being converted to cooperative apartments. At the same time, they were representing a group of investors who were purchasing apartments in the same building, according to prosecutors. In another scheme involving the same building, Miller and Adolf allegedly acquired the apartment of a deceased former client by preparing a false affidavit indicating the client had given her purchase rights to a co-conspirator of the defendants. The defendants quickly disposed of the apartments at two to three times the original purchase price, prosecutors said. Miller, 51, a native of Brooklyn who still lives in that borough's Flatbush section, has served in the Assembly since 1970, where he's earned a reputation as outspoken liberal unwilling to shrink from a battle. ``He indicated to me he felt kind of liberated by the announcement because now he can fight this thing and can fight it publicly,'' Cuomo said. Miller and Adolf have given up their law practice. Assistant U.S. Attorney Matthew E. Fishbein, who is prosecuting the case, said that under state law the defrauded clients may seek the return of some $238,000 paid in legal fees to the Adolf & Miller firm.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze: U.S.S.R. Has No Plans For Military Conflict in Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has no plans for any military involvement in the Persian Gulf, Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze told lawmakers today. ``None of our moves on the international scene and none of our diplomatic actions implied, given even the wildest fantasy, any participation of Soviet combat, auxiliary or any other troops or units in any military operations in the gulf area,'' Shevardnadze advised Soviet lawmakers. ``Speculation on this score was totally groundless,'' Shevardnadze said in a text given to the legislators and reported by the official Tass news agency. The foreign minister, who is in the United States, sent the text to the Soviet parliament after a right-wing group of deputies accused him of preparing to send Soviet troops to the gulf without legislative approval. Moscow pulled its troops out of Afghanistan in 1989 after nine years fighting guerrillas trying to overthrow the Afghan government. ``The Soviet Union does not and never had plans to get involved in any form in a possible military conflict in the gulf,'' Shevardnadze said. ``I dismiss as naive accusations by those who would like to project matters as if the Foreign Ministry and the minister personally are heading toward a war in the Middle East,'' Tass quoted the text as saying. ``We did not nurture this thought even for a single moment. We totally excluded this.'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Shevardnadze in recent weeks have abandoned their cautious tone regarding Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and threatened to support military action unless Saddam Hussein's forces end their 4-month-old occupation of the emirate. Although Shevardnadze told lawmakers there were no plans to send Soviet troops to the gulf, he did not rule out the possibility that sometime in the future the executive branch might have to act without parliament's consent. ``We will act this way if the lives and security of Soviet citizens appear to be jeopardized, when rapid and decisive actions are needed to save them,'' he said. In his meetings with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Shevardnadze urged the Bush administration to find ``a sensible way'' out of the gulf crisis in negotiations with Iraq. ``There is still potential for a peaceful solution,'' he said at a joint news conference Tuesday with Baker. At that session, Shevardnadze reiterated Soviet support for U.N. Security Council resolutions imposing an international trade embargo on Iraq and threatening military force unless Iraq withdraws by Jan. 15. Of Soviet participation in military action against Iraq, Shevardnadze said: ``This option is not under consideration. This option is non-existent.'' While Baker said on Tuesday he did not request Soviet military help, he has asked Moscow in the past for at least a token contribution. The Soviet Union has some ships in waters off Iraq, but has not deployed any other forces to join the U.S.-led multinational force assembled against Iraq. Fewer than 3,000 Soviet advisers remain in Iraq, a one-time ally of the Soviet Union. More than 400 have left in the past week. On Tuesday, lawmakers from the Russian republic parliament told national leaders not the let the country get caught up in a military confrontation in the gulf. The Russian Congress of People's Deputies said in a non-binding resolution that Gorbachev must not let the country be drawn ``into a military conflict in the gulf that could lead to very grave consequences for global peace and stability.''

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Steps Down As Solidarity Chief; Tyminski Leaves Country
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Walesa resigning as Solidarity chairman, appealing for support. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WAR51
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa resigned as Solidarity chairman today and asked the trade union he led for a decade to support the ``big changes'' he intends to make as the nation's president. ``I want to thank you for our common effort, thanks to which we achieved the greatest honor,'' Walesa told a meeting of the Solidarity national commission in Gdansk, where the movement was born in the shipyard strikes of 1980. ``It is an honor, and at the same time a great responsibility. I hope you will support the Polish reforms.'' Solidarity, the Soviet bloc's first free trade federation, spearheaded changes that led to the toppling of Poland's Communist government and helped cause peaceful revolutions elsewhere in Eastern Europe. The Solidarity leaders passed by acclamation a resolution thanking Walesa for his leadership. ``He has well served his homeland,'' it said. Walesa, who is to be sworn in by parliament for a five-year presidential term about Dec. 21, is conducting ``intensive talks'' about naming a new prime minster and Cabinet, said Solidarity spokesman Andrzej Drzycinski. The president-elect urged Solidarity to be active in free parliament elections this spring and help Poland weather the difficult transition to a capitalist economy and democracy. Walesa appealed for support in fending off any ``attack of the Tyminskis,'' referring Stanislaw Tyminski, his defeated opponent in the presidential race who had promised quick prosperity for economically struggling Poland. Tyminski left for Canada today after posting a $100,000 bond to assure his return to answer charges of slander. The emigre businessman lost by a 3-to-1 margin to Walesa in Sunday's runoff. Tyminski, who holds Polish, Canadian and Peruvian citizenship, had to plead with prosecutors to allow him to leave the country because of a pending case alleging that he defamed Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki during the campaign. Tyminski, 42, accompanied by his Peruvian wife, Graciela, was seen off this morning at Warsaw's Okecie Airport by about 50 supporters chanting his name and ``Poland is with You.'' ``I am of Poland,'' he said, before being boarding a Polish LOT Airlines flight for London and Toronto. The bond arrangements were made during a session Tuesday night with prosecutors. Tyminski transferred the $100,000 to a bank account. On Tuesday night, Tyminski told reporters he promised to return by Jan. 5 to cooperate in the slander inquiry. He said he wanted to see his children in Canada and work on his defense. The slander investigation was started by the provincial Nowy Sacz prosecutor after Tyminski accused Mazowiecki of treason during a Nov. 17 campaign rally. Tyminski said the prime minister, who was eliminated from the election in the first round of balloting on Nov. 25, had betrayed the nation by creating economic chaos. Meanwhile, outgoing President Wojciech Jaruzelski delivered his own farewell in a nationally televised speech Tuesday night. Jaruzelski apologized for ``each harm, pain and injustice'' caused during his nine years in power - apparently referring to his 1981 decision to impose martial law in an effort to crush Solidarity and the repressions and years of stalemate that followed. ``The word of `sorry' may sound all too casual,'' Jaruzelski said. ``But I cannot find another one.'' Jaruzelski, as Communist Party chief, was Poland's leader from October 1981 until July 1989, when he was elected president - an office whose powers he used only passively. His term will end when Walesa is sworn in. Solidarity's national commission decided its vice chairmen, Lech Klaczynski and Stefan Jurczak, will run the union until an emergency national congress to be held as soon as mid-January. The congress will formally accept Walesa's resignation, elect a new chairman and likely decide whether to form a political wing of Solidarity or stick to union work, representing workers in negotiations with the government, as some members advocate.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Honecker Deathly Ill
DOC.TEXT: Former East German leader Erich Honecker lies ``deathly ill'' in an intensive care unit at a Soviet military hospital near Berlin, a newspaper reported today. The Bild newspaper said Honecker, 78, was suffering from a serious heart disorder and that his kidneys were failing. Honecker is wanted by Berlin justice authorities on charges of manslaughter as a result of shoot-to-kill orders he allegedly issued at the Berlin Wall. Honecker has denied all charges against him. More than 200 East Germans died trying to escape to the West. German police cannot serve a warrant that was issued Nov. 30 because they have been unable to get permission to enter the Soviet military hospital in Beelitz, 20 miles south of Berlin, where Honecker sought refuge in April. The Soviets claim they are keeping Honecker on ``humanitarian grounds.'' Bild said the Soviets had two possibilities to resolve the problem. The first would be to allow Honecker and his wife, Margot, to travel to the Soviet Union for medical treatment. The second would be to turn Honecker over to the Germans. The Berlin Wall divided Berlin from 1961 until late 1989, and was part of the fortifications that prevented East Germans from going to the West. Germany was unified in October, ending the division imposed after its defeat in World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Heart-Lung Test Done 2 Million Times A Year, Despite Poor Doctor Training
DOC.TEXT: Doctors performing a heart-lung test that can cause fatal complications should receive specialized training and certification, say researchers who found many doctors have a poor grasp of the procedure. A written exam about the procedure was given to 496 physicians at 13 U.S. and Canadian hospitals. It found that 47 percent were unable to derive ``even the most basic information'' from the data generated by the test, researchers reported in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. The study did not record any attempt to give the exam to doctors known to have used the heart-lung test. Rather, researchers gave the exam at random to doctors in hospital departments that use the tests the most. The test, called pulmonary artery catheterization or PAC, is performed an estimated 2 million times a year and can provide life-saving information if used by a doctor with adequate training. But it can cause fatal complications or lead to treatment errors if used without adequate knowledge, the researchers said. No training standards exist for doctors learning to use the test and no special credentials are required, they said. Dr. Roger C. Bone, chairman of internal medicine at Rush Medical College in Chicago, said Tuesday a moratorium on the use of the test ``would be going off the deep end.'' Bone said in a telephone interview Tuesday that the rate of serious complications overall is probably 2 percent to 3 percent. And the rate of life-threatening complications less than 1 percent. ``The PAC is very important, very helpful,'' he said. ``It can give us information that may allow interventions that will be life-saving.'' He agreed with the researchers that doctors should have to earn credentials to use the test. Bone serves on the American Board of Internal Medicine and the Critical Care Board, which set standards to certify doctors qualified for those specialties. Bone said the ABIM and the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations, which sets quality standards for hospitals, are evaluating the findings. The PAC, introduced in 1970, involves inserting a tube carrying a monitoring device into a neck or leg vein and threading it through the heart into a lung artery. There, it can measure blood flow, temperature and oxygen. ``It's been an amazing advance to monitor the effects of medication, help in the diagnosis of different cardiac conditions ... (and) in patients with lung diseases,'' said Dr. Thomas J. Iberti, director of critical care at Mount Sinai Hospital in New ork and lead author of the study. ``It also allows you to follow the effects of therapy,'' he said in a telephone interview Tuesday. ``You can now, rather than asking patients if they feel better, get data.'' But the tube, which is sometimes left in place for two to three days, can cause serious or fatal complications such as rupturing the lung artery, disrupting the heartbeat or allowing infection to enter the body, he said. Iberti and his colleagues developed a 31-question, multiple-choice test about PAC and gave it to doctors in the departments of medicine, surgery and anesthesiology at hospitals recruited for the study. The doctors' average score was 20.7 questions correct, or 67 percent, with a low of six correct and a high of 31, the researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf At A Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd item, `Algerian President...' to UPDATE with him arriving in Baghdad, inserts items on Soviets, OPEC. Pickup 4th, `More Americans...'
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis: ---= Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has dismissed his defense minister, one month after sacking the armed forces chief of staff, state radio said Wednesday. Baghdad Radio said the new defense minister is Maj. Gen. Saadi Toma Abbas, inspector-general of the armed forces and a former deputy chief of staff. The outgoing minister, Gen. Abdel-Jaber Khalil Shansal, 70, was named minister of state for military affairs - a position of little authority. ---= Al-Thawra, the newpaper of Iraq's ruling Baath Party, said civil defense authorities have instructed all owners of buildings with two or more floors to conver their basements into bomb shelters. It ordered the owners to post signs informing people where to take cover in case of attack. ---= Algerian President Chadli Bendjedid arrived in Baghdad on Wednesday on a mission aimed at bringing Saudi Arabia and Iraq together to negotiate a settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis. An Arab diplomat in Jordan said on Tuesday that Saudi officials had assured Bendjedid they would meet with Saddam if he begins withdrawing his troops from Kuwait. The Saudis have previously refused to talk until after a total pullout. ---= Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said the Soviet Union has no plans for military involvement in the gulf. The minister, who is in the United States, sent a message to the Soviet parliament after a group of deputies accused him of preparing to send Soviet troops to the gulf without legislative approval. Shevardnadze did not rule out the possibility that the executive branch may one day have to act without parliament's consent. ---= OPEC's president cautioned that current high levels of crude production could leave the world ``awash in oil'' and markets in turmoil once the gulf crisis ends. Sadek Boussena made the statement in opening a conference of the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna. ---= More Americans freed by Iraq were to head home Wednesday after arriving Tuesday night in London and Frankfurt, Germany. A final evacuation flight from Iraq is expected on Thursday. The five diplomats working at U.S. Embassy in Kuwait will be brought home soon, but it has not been decided whether they all will come out on the evacuation flight planned for Thursday, officials said. ---= Iraqi newspapers on Wednesday dismissed reports that Iraq is ready to withdraw from Kuwait. The newspapers said Iraq will never compromise on the emirate it has designated its 19th province. ---= State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said more than 500 Americans, most of them children, remain in Kuwait and Iraq - some voluntarily because they have relatives there and some because the non-American head of household could not get permission to leave. Boucher said except for three Americans with visa problems, he believes that all Americans wanting to leave have done so. ---= Two U.S. Marines have died in separate incidents, one of an apparent heart attack while exercising with a group and the other from a suspected brain aneurysm, military officials said Wednesday. The fatalities, which occurred Monday, raised the number of the U.S. deaths in Operation Desert Shield to 56, including 49 in air crashes and other accidents, the U.S. Central Command said.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Says Afghans Would Welcome Halt to Superpower Weapon Supplies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with further comment. Pickup 8th graf pvs, ``Shevardnadze said... ''
DOC.TEXT: Afghans are tired of fighting and will welcome the superpowers' decision to stop weapons shipments, a Moslem guerrilla spokesman said today. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Tuesday announced the U.S.-Soviet agreement to cut off weapons to the Soviet-backed Kabul government and the Moslem guerrillas, who are backed by the United States, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia. The announcement came after a meeting in Houston with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. In 1989, the Soviets pulled the last of their troops from Afghanistan, where the 12-year-old civil war has claimed 1.5 million lives. ``Most of the mujahedeen (guerrillas) and most Afghans will welcome it. They're tired of war,'' said Azim Nasser-Zia, spokesman for the National Islamic Front of Afghanistan. His group is one of the seven major Afghan resistance parties based in Pakistan. ``It's true everyone in Afghanistan carries a gun. While a gun may give a degree of safety, it also generates fear,'' he said. Both Afghan President Najibullah and Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, leader of the most radical guerrilla faction, have called for reciprocal weapons cutbacks. Najibullah said last month he would accept a lack of symmetry in each sides arms, ``including the Soviet arms assistance program to be cut off, and we would destroy all weapons stockpiles in Afghanistan and turn it into a totally demilitarized and neutral country.'' Diplomats in Islamabad and Pakistani officials called the announced weapons cutoff a significant development in the costly political and military stalemate. Most anticipated a joint statement by Baker and Shevardnadze and had prepared their responses. ``Afghanistan is one of the few irritants remaining in U.S.-Soviet relations,'' said one diplomat, who insisted on anonymity. ``It's a detriment and an annoyance. President Bush and others in the U.S. administration seem convinced it's not worth the aggravation and just want it off the agenda, so it's difficult to understand what the holdup is.'' Shevardnadze said no date has been set for the weapons cutoff. Most of the guerrilla groups say they have not received weapons from the United States since mid-summer. According to reports from the Afghan capital, the number of Soviet transport planes delivering arms, ammunition and other supplies has dropped from an average of 40 per day to about 10 a day. But both sides possess huge stockpiles of weapons and ammunition, and most diplomats and observers believe the fighting will likely continue for some time between troops loyal to Najibullah and the guerrillas. Within months after Moscow withdrew its 115,000 Red Army troops from Afghanistan in February 1989, the superpowers began searching for a solution. But their Afghan clients have proved recalcitrant. Moreover, a superpower deal will be no guarantee of peace in the landlocked, tribal society, which has traditionally resisted interference by outsiders. The guerrilla leaders so far have refused to negotiate directly with Najibullah, instead offering their own ideas for ending the war and holding elections for a new government. The United States has provided as much as $300 million a year to the Moslem guerrillas. Washington has estimated Soviet assistance at $500 million a month, although most observers say the exact amount is difficult to calculate because most of the weapons were pulled out of Eastern Europe and are outdated. One of the major obstacles has been agreeing on an acceptable formula for reducing weapons supplies equally. There have been questions about when a cutoff would start, who it would involve and how it would be verified. It was unclear whether the announcement regarding a cutoff of weapons would apply to Saudi Arabia, which reportedly has matched U.S. assistance to the guerrillas on a dollar-for-dollar basis. In September, Saudi Arabia re-established diplomatic relations with Moscow. Moscow's involvement in Afghan affairs is at least in part driven by Soviet fears the Afghan insurgency could spill across the border into its predominantly Moslem Central Asian republics.

DOC.HEAD: Zhivkov, Aide to Stand Trial for Embezzlement
DOC.TEXT: Todor Zhivkov, Bulgaria's Communist ruler for 35 years, has been indicted for misappropriating funds - including money to pay personal nurses, flight attendants and others. Zhivkov, 79, was placed under house arrest after being ousted in late 1989. He was hospitalized in February for unspecified ailments related to his age. The state news agency BTA, which reported Zhivkov's indictment on Tuesday, said his closest associate, Milko Balev, also was indicted on the charges. It was not known if the two men would be tried together. The indictment was presented to the Supreme Court by the prosecutor general's office on Friday, the agency said. Zhivkov recently told journalists he expects to be cleared of any charges. According to prosecutors, Zhivkov embezzled about $3.7 million between 1962 and 1989 for his own and other people's use. Large sums of money were paid to ``nurses, rehabilitation therapists, air hostesses and other persons who attended to Zhivkov in person,'' BTA quoted the prosecutor's office as saying. Zhivkov also is accused of illegally receiving fees for his numerous books published in Bulgaria and abroad, BTA said, adding it had been ``an open secret'' that the publications that came out under his name were actually written by special teams of scientists and assistants. On Nov. 20, BTA quoted Prosecutor General Martin Gunev as saying Zhivkov would also be tried for abuse of power. BTA said prosecutors were also investigating to determine if anyone will face charges for the crisis in agriculture, the construction of ill-conceived industrial projects, the ``disruption of the ecological balance'' and ``the catastrophic growth of the foreign debt.'' Bulgaria's foreign debt stands at about $11 billion, and Bulgaria halted payments eight months ago because of serious domestic economic problems.

DOC.HEAD: Japan, Germany Lagging in Promised Aid for US Gulf Deployments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 7-9, In Bonn, with German response.
DOC.TEXT: Japan and Germany, two of the world's leading economic powers, have delivered barely one-fifth of the money and materials they promised in support of U.S. military operations in the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon says. Of the six countries that offered the largest contributions to Operation Desert Shield at its outset in August, only Kuwait has given all that it promised, Pete Williams, the chief Pentagon spokesman, said Tuesday. Williams declined to comment on the reasons for the delayed contributions from other allies. Pledges totaling more than $6.5 billion were made for calendar year 1990. Japanese officials denied today that Japan is dragging its feet in disbursing 2 billion U.S. dollars pledged to support the multinational forces deployed against Iraq. A Japanese Foreign Ministry official said that of a total of $4 billion pledged for the military effort and to support front-line states, some $600 million has been contracted or disbursed. The process for disbursing another $600 million dollars in emergency commodity loans for Jordan and Turkey will be completed very soon, said another. The remainder is under discussion at various levels, they said. In Bonn, a spokesman for Chancellor Helmut Kohl today disputed the Pentagon's figures. Hans Klein said his government already has made available more than $1.36 billion for the gulf operation, including $1.09 billion in military equipment and transportation. Williams had said the Germans have delivered $337 million in cash and materials, toward a pledge of $1.5 billion, and Japan, which said it would give about $2 billion for the gulf operation, has provided $426 million. Neither Japan nor Germany has sent armed forces to the gulf, citing constitutional restrictions. Williams said the United States plans to ask an undisclosed number of allied nations to increase their financial contributions for 1991. He said he did not know how much money would be sought or when the requests would be made. ``We will probably seek additional support from other nations to continue their share of the responsibility for Desert hield,'' Williams said. The United Arab Emirates, a federation of gulf sheikdoms bordering Saudi Arabia, pledged $1 billion and has given $280 million, Williams said. South Korea offered $95 million and so far has delivered $4 million. Williams said Saudi Arabia, which is the host nation for the vast majority of U.S. and allied forces arrayed against Iraq, was the only ally to make an ``open-ended offer'' of support. He said that as of Oct. 31, it had provided material support such as fuel, food, water and transportation valued at $987 million. Kuwait's exiled royal family has delivered $2.5 billion, Williams said. That is part of a pot of private and foreign government contributions totaling $3.9 billion - an amount certain to fall short of covering U.S. costs in the gulf. Williams said the Pentagon would ask the Congress in February for supplemental funds to cover Desert Shield expenses in 1991. He said the amount was uncertain because the Pentagon did not know how much the gulf operation will cost and because it's unclear how much more the allies may be willing to contribute. Government and congressional sources said Monday that Desert Shield may cost $30 billion in 1991. The Pentagon's original cost estimate was $15 billion, but that was before President Bush ordered huge reinforcements to the gulf on Nov. 8. Williams said American air, sea and ground forces in the gulf area have risen by 10,000 since last week, to 260,000. The latest arrivals apparently are the lead elements of Army and Air Force reinforcements from Europe and the United States. The Pentagon said Tuesday that elements of Seventh Corps headquarters, U.S. Army Europe, began deploying to the Middle East from their base in Stuttgart, Germany. Also, the U.S. 2nd Corps Support Command began deploying from Nellingen, Germany. By late January, about 430,000 U.S. Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps personnel are expected to be in the area. Williams said forces dispatched to the gulf area from Britain, France and 24 other allied nations now total more than 220,000. He said he could not disclose how many forces were sent by each country. The spokesman also announced that Iraq now has more than a half-million troops in and around Kuwait - 50,000 more than U.S. intelligence estimates of a week ago and five times the size of the army that invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Worst Twister in Decades Leaves Town in Ruins
DOC.TEXT: Japan's worst tornado in decades ripped through a Japanese town just east of Tokyo, injuring 78 people and leaving hundreds homeless, police said today. More than 5,000 households remained without electricity and 800 without working telephones today, police said. They said 250 people whose homes were destroyed by Tuesday night's tornado were now housed in a gymnasium. Electricity to 87,700 households was cut off after the tornado passed through Mobara and nearby areas in Chiba prefecture, Tokyo's eastern neighbor. The twister destroyed or damaged 938 homes or buildings and 162 cars as it passed through the community of about 77,000 people. No one was killed, but seven people were seriously injured, police said. City officials estimated damage at $13 million. Weather bureau officials said small tornadoes occur several times each year in Japan but that Tuesday's twister caused the worst damage in decades. During the storm, lightning was reported in many areas. Near the tornado area, at least one greenhouse covered with vinyl was torn apart by hail. Television broadcasts showed residents going through their wrecked homes today. Other people sat in severely damaged buildings eating by candlelight. One resident told a television crew the tornado lifted his parked car about three feet off the ground and hurled it several yards.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Age Girl Killed in Clashes With Settlers, Army
LaserPhoto JRL-1
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old Palestinian girl was shot to death today when soldiers and Jewish settlers fired at Arab students throwing stones at Israeli cars in the West Bank, Arab reports said. The army confirmed the death, and said it was investigating the circumstances. The shooting came two days after Defense Minister Moshe Arens launched a new offensive against stone-throwing, posting sharpshooters at key intersections in the West Bank and pressing for stiffer sentences for convicted offenders. Today, Palestinians in the West Bank town of Jericho stoned Arens' motorcade, an Israeli photographer said. A large stone smashed the windshield of an army escort vehicle, but Arens' car was not hit, the photographer said. In Arab east Jerusalem, police fired tear gas and rubber bullets in several locations to disperse stone-throwers. Police arrested six Palestinians and closed two schools. The fatal clash occurred along the highway that links the occupied West Bank with the Tel Aviv area and is frequently used by Jewish settlers. About 200 students from the Arab village of Biddiya threw stones at Israeli cars during a demonstration marking the anniversary of the founding of a radical PLO faction, an Arab reporter said. Settlers and soldiers fired at the protesters, and one bullet struck Ahlam Abed in the head, the report said. Her body was taken to Ittihad Hospital in the West Bank town of Nablus. Her death brought to 778 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis since the start of the uprising three years ago. At least 316 other Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of helping Israel. Fifty-four Israelis also have died in the violence. A 16-year-old Palestinian from the West Bank town of Tulkarem was reported in serious but stable condition Wednesday after he was shot in the head by a rubber bullet during clashes with the army Tuesday. In east Jerusalem, dozens of Palestinians threw stones and glue containers at police in the main shopping street. Police responded with tear gas and rubber bullets and arrested five. In the nearby Wadi Joz neighborhood, two Israelis were hurt when their car overturned after the driver lost control of the vehicle when it was stoned, police said. Police also reported stone-throwing clashes at schools in the Arab neighborhoods of Atur and Jabel Mukaber. Police closed two schools and arrested one Palestinian. In the Gaza Strip refugee camp of Rafah, troops sealed the homes of three Palestinians suspected of involvement in killing two suspected informers and firing at an army patrol, the army said. Palestinian reports said the sealings made 50 people homeless. The army has sealed and demolished more than 600 houses since the start of the uprising. Western nations have condemned the practice, saying it constituted collective punishment.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush-Cavazos
DOC.TEXT: Here are the resignation letter from Secretary of Education Lauro F. Cavazos and President Bush's reply, both dated Dec. 12: Dear Mr. President: I, Lauro F. Cavazos, hereby resign as United States Secretary of Education, effective close of business, Dec. 15, 1990. I appreciate the opportunity to work with the administration in helping to further its goals toward excellence in education. I am especially proud of the contributions I was able to make in expanding choice in education, promoting the executive order on excellence in education for Hispanic Americans, and raising awareness of the growing diversity of America's student population. I have only the greatest expectations and highest hopes that each child in America will be educated to his or her fullest potential. Respectfully, Lauro F. Cavazos --- Dear Larry: With deep regret I accept your letter of resignation. For more than two years, and under two presidents, you have distinguished yourself through your devotion to improving the education of our nation's children. With your help and guidance we assembled the 50 state governors in Charlottesville for a historic education summit. There, we established a consensus for a set of national education goals, which today are the driving force behind our education agenda. Your tireless promotion and pursuit of these goals has set us on a path to educational excellence through the end of the decade. I was particularly proud, Larry, to stand with you last September to announce an executive order on educational excellence for Hispanic Americans based on the findings of the task force you led. Hispanic Americans in every community are indebted to you for the inspired leadership you have provided. Barbara and I will always be grateful for the sincerity, diligence and care you brought to the office of the secretary. On behalf of students, parents and teachers across the nation, let me thank you for your dedicated service. Sincerely, George Bush

DOC.HEAD: Daily News `Plowing Ahead' Despite Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `Negotiations in ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with both sides meeting in Washington for mediation. Picks up 8th graf pvs: `Hoge said ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of the New York Daily News says the tabloid will keep ``plowing ahead'' as long as it is gaining ground against an employee strike, a move a union spokesman called ``sheer masochism.'' Publisher James F. Hoge made the announcement Tuesday after a board meeting of the News' parent, the Tribune Co. Some Wall Street analysts had speculated the board would close the paper and cut its losses. ``Our rule is that we are plowing ahead as long was we can show that we are making significant progress,'' Hoge said. Theodore Kheel, the striking unions' legal adviser, countered, ``The decision is a form of sheer masochism.'' ``The News has no hope of survival whatsoever in the absence of a settlement or sale,'' he said. ``The sooner the board realizes that, the better everyone, including the Tribune Co., will be.'' The News, using managers, replacements and employees transferred from other Tribune Co. newspapers, has continued to publish despite the 7-week-old strike by 2,100 employees in nine unions. Negotiators for both sides arrived in Washington today at the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, which is trying to end the six-week-old strike. Members of the negotiation teams began arriving at the service's headquarters shortly after 9 a.m., but declined to comment on the talks. They met with Bernard E. DeLury, director of the service, and other mediators. Hoge said the News is regaining strength daily and increased net paid circulation by 28,000 to 580,000 since the end of last week through a network of dealers and hawkers now totaling almost half the pre-strike number of 12,000 outlets. The paper had daily circulation of 1.09 million copies before the strike began on Oct. 25. ``It is the opinion of everyone involved in this process that we are making significant progress and we are going forward,'' Hoge said. The publisher said the strike is costly ``but not as expensive as trying to run the paper with all the excess costs and contract abuses that we had ... in the old contract.'' Hoge said the paper is losing money but could be profitable if the company reaches reasonable settlements with the unions. He said he is confident many advertisers who left for rival tabloids will return as circulation increases. About 100 people, most from various Chicago unions, picketed the Tribune Tower on Tuesday, led by several of the striking Daily News workers. Tribune Co. also publishes the Chicago Tribune.

DOC.HEAD: Top Security Council Nations Intend To Reassure Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III hopes to meet with foreign ministers of the other permanent Security Council members in Europe this month to reassure Iraq it won't be attacked if it withdraws from Kuwait by Jan. 15, diplomats said today. But the foreign ministers will also tell Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that they will not accept a partial withdrawal, thus forestalling any idea that he could hang on to two islands that control access to the Shatt-al-Arab waterway or part of an oil field straddling the Iraq-Kuwait border. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who is in Washington for talks with Baker and President Bush, urged ``a sensible way'' out of the Persian Gulf crisis in negotiations with Iraq. ``There is still potential for a peaceful solution,'' he said at a joint news conference with Baker on Tuesday. ``It is very important that a goodwill grace period that expires on Jan. 15 is taken up by a very active diplomatic and political effort,'' he said. ``It is also my strong hope that U.S. troops will not see action.'' The foreign ministers agreed in principle to meet in Europe after Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz meets Bush in Washington this month, but before Baker travels to Baghdad for talks with Saddam, diplomats said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The message is intended to emphasize international solidarity behind Baker when he travels to Iraq, they said. Baker has been waiting for word from Baghdad on a date to see Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The United States rejected the Iraqi suggestion of a Jan. 12 date because it is too close to the Jan. 15 deadline. Shevardnadze said, ``We pin much hope on the coming contacts.'' The meeting would involve the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and possibly China. China's willingness to participate is questionable, though, since Beijing is opposed to the use of military force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. China abstained on the Security Council resolution passed on Nov. 29, which authorizes U.N. members to use ``all necessary means,'' up to and including military force, to liberate Kuwait if Iraq doesn't pull out by Jan. 15. Diplomats have speculated that Iraq might be willing to withdraw from Kuwait if it was able to retain the southern end of the Rumailah oil field, which extends from Iraq into Kuwait. An unresolved dispute over whether Kuwait was tapping oil that belonged to Iraq was one reason for Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of the emirate. Iraq also wants a deep-water port, which it was unable to win during the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq war. Baghdad had asked Kuwait for a 99-year lease on two uninhabited islands at the mouth of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway from Kuwait, which would give it control over access to the passage forming the border between Iran and Iraq. Kuwait declined to lease the islands to Iraq the day before the invasion. The meeting of the foreign ministers would emphasize that Iraq must withdraw from the islands of Warba and Bubiyan, and from the Rumailah oil field. Baker has insisted on that point, but has also said recently that when the emir of Kuwait's government is restored to power, Iraq and Kuwait could then negotiate the economic and territorial disputes between them.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. --- Dec. 11 Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal on the Persian Gulf: What do you know: another un-concession from the United States in response to the Iraqi announcement that all foreign hostages could go home. Washington announced that the last U.S. diplomats would leave the beleaguered embassy in Kuwait after all American citizens had been allowed to leave. Administration spokesmen denied it was a conciliatory move, saying it was decided based on the hostage departures ending the embassy's immediate duties in conquered Kuwait, and out of concern for the situation of the diplomats themselves. Perhaps what we are witnessing here is the world's first instance of back-channel diplomacy by press release. In any event, it cannot help but reduce the tension of the Gulf standoff if the remaining U.S. diplomatic personnel in Kuwait were to finish their job and head home. It certainly has the look, if not the fact, of a deliberate U.S. decision to eliminate one potential flash point. The George Bush of long experience in diplomacy and government may indeed be handling this crisis with a more subtle touch than the bombastic rhetoric his pronouncements portray. Whatever else the Kuwait embassy gambit signals, it signals that it is time for Congress and its individual members to lay off the second-guessing of Bush and let him play his cards with his military force ace at full strength. --- Dec. 11 The Richmond (Va.) News Leader on the Persian Gulf: There is in the West a softhearted temptation to declare peace at hand with Saddam Hussein's release of hundreds of foreign hostages from Iraq and Kuwait. People who display such sentiment fall into the trap of treating despots as if they are compassionate individuals. Saddam Hussein, like those numerous bloodthirsty communist leaders who enjoyed American jazz and good Scotch, is unreasonable and uncaring. While supposedly making a grand overture for peace by, as Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney put it, ``stopping a practice that obviously is abhorrent to the civilized world,'' Saddam has proceeded to bolster troop deployments and fortifications in occupied Kuwait. Furthermore, the Iraqi government has refused to offer Secretary of State James Baker a face-to-face meeting with Saddam in time for Iraqi troops to withdraw from Kuwait before Jan. 15 following such a meeting. On its face, the hostage release might appear to be a humanitarian gesture, but Saddam does not see it that way, not even publicly. In announcing the impending hostage release ... , Saddam said their presence had been necessary to deter military attacks by the West, but now that Iraqi troops have achieved full force in occupied Kuwait, it is no longer necessary to hold hostages. --- Dec. 9 The Palm Beach (Fla.) Post on the Persian Gulf: In taking hostages, Saddam Hussein gained nothing but an extra measure of scorn. In releasing hostages, Hussein should be allowed to gain nothing at all. Hussein's quest for gain won't end with humanitarian posturing. Because his invasion of Kuwait and release of hostages came before any new United Nations action on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Hussein undoubtedly will claim credit there. He is capable of unilaterally declaring that his actions have reinforced U.N. concern for the Palestinians. And even if U.N. action has no practical effect, Hussein can - after saving face by declaring himself vindicated and a hero of the Palestinians - withdraw from Kuwait. Hussein doesn't care about the Palestinians. Neither do most of the other Arab leaders, except insofar as the Palestinians are a weapon against Israel. --- Dec. 6 Philadelphia Daily News on the Persian Gulf: Let's all say it together real loud. George Bush is not a wimp. Nor is he a weenie. He is the biggest, baddest critter in the whole forest. Maybe he'll hear and we can skip getting carloads of people killed. This public relations effort to convince us that we should sacrifice American young people may be one of the most cynical exercises since Lyndon Johnson told us all how heavy his heart was. Moments after the polls say we won't back a war in the Persian Gulf except to stop nuclear proliferation, the Bush administration changes its reasoning. ``It's to stop Saddam Hussein from getting the bomb. Yeah, that's the ticket.'' ... Worst of all, though, we continue trying to back ourselves into a corner. Just as it appears that 400,000 troops and a blockade may have created a climate for cutting a deal, Secretary of State James Baker tells us that all he's going to do is lecture and threaten Saddam. None of the rationales for war makes sense, at least not yet. --- Dec. 9 Los Angeles Daily News on the space shuttle program: It has not been a stellar year for space astronomy. First there was the monstrously expensive disappointment of the Hubble Space Telescope, that $1.5 billion eye-in-the-sky that can't quite get things in focus. Now the $150 million Astro observatory, ... plagued by computer trouble. ... More than 100 planned observations, out of about 250, had to be scrubbed. Yet, not all is gloomy out there. Hubble, in spite of its optical flaws, is enabling astronomers to do some serious science and is returning some spectacular images from the Solar System and the realm of distant galaxies. The Magellan probe is currently assembling a remarkable detailed map of the planet Venus. And the Astro observatory, glitches and all, helped astronauts make a significant and poignant bit of history. ... Columbia's astronauts beamed a lesson from space, just as New Hampshire schoolteacher Christa McAuliffe had wanted to do nearly five years ago when she won a place on the disastrous Challenger mission. ... Teaching is probably the most useful thing (along with its usual national security work, launching spy satellites and such) that NASA can do for the country right now. So it is good finally to see someone teaching from orbit, answering questions from kids on the ground. (The) lesson from the shuttle Columbia was a modest comeback for a project that has been stalled far too long - the project of bringing space down to earth. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: to earth.
DOC.TEXT: Dec. 7 Florence (S.C.) Morning News on our resources: Ten years ago an ecologist and an economist took the unusual step of submitting their opposite theories to a reality test: They made a bet. The result was written up in (the) influential New York Times Magazine. The more famous lost. He is Paul Erlich, Stanford University's butterfly expert and the mass media's favorite ecologist. His 1968 best-seller The Population Bomb is among the environmental movement's founding texts. In 1980, Erlich took up the gauntlet thrown down by University of Maryland economist Julian Simon: To demonstrate the point that, far from becoming scarcer as population grows, natural resources actually become more available thanks to human innovation, Simon offered a challenge to predictors of overpopulation. Pick any natural resource, Simon said, and he would bet that its price would decline by any stipulated date. Erlich and two colleagues bet $1,000 on five metals - chrome, copper, nickel, tin and tungsten. The 10 years Erlich stipulated ended in October. World population grew by 800 million in the decade - but all five metals declined in real price. Together they declined by almost 40 percent. This adds one more thing to the long list of Erlich's predictions that have proven false, notably mass starvation in the 1970s and near-depletion of ``many key minerals'' before 1985. .. . Yet Erlich retains his standing with the mass media as an authority on the planet's future. ... Biologists think in terms of closed ecosystems. But market economies are flexible and responsive. Instead of disparaging the economists, ecologists should incorporate the obvious truth that resources are not static but rather depend on man's power to adapt and invent. --- Dec. 11 The Atlanta Constitution on banking laws: Merely a decade late, Washington now appears ready to begin the huge task of reforming the financial system. With proposals being drafted by the Treasury Department, the Bush administration is preparing to revamp banking laws from top to bottom - and Congress may be ready to join the effort. Clearly the system is in great need of reform. The fundamental laws that regulate commercial banks were developed during the Great Depression of the 1930s. As the nation gears up for the 21st Century, new laws are needed to keep up with changing technology, new competitive pressures and growing international commerce. Still, it's not surprising that both the White House and Congress have been reluctant to meddle with a system that grew out of the hard lessons learned in the 1920s and early 1930s. Older Americans still have nightmarish memories of bank runs and lost savings. Tampering with the deposit-insurance system is not something to be done lightly. But the need for reform is now overwhelming. While a complete overhaul may sound radical, the real danger lies in taking halfway steps that leave the system with one foot in the 1930s and the other in 2000. --- Dec. 11 The Daily Oklahoman, Oklahoma City, on trade talks: Collapse of the world trade talks in Brussels is bad news for American producers, especially our farmers. ... Chief cause for the breakdown was the European Community's refusal to cut internal farm price supports. Japan also balked on opening its closed rice market. A successful GATT agreement could increase U.S. exports to developing countries alone by $200 billion over the next 10 years - a large portion of which would be agricultural goods. The United States needs more export sales to help the economy and lower the trade deficit. Negotiators might get the talks back on track in January. If not, fallout may include increasing trade frictions, rising protectionism and possibly even a global trade war. Instead of a new era of free trade and prosperity, the world could split into regional trading blocs, each with its own barriers. This at a time when world leaders should be striving for more, not less cooperation. --- Dec. 10 Houston Chronicle on trade talks: For General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade - GATT - substitute world trade. More to the point, make it: eliminating barriers to increased world trade. ... To further simplify it: GATT is about jobs. ... The process of setting new international rules on matters ranging from banking to patent protection stumbled last week in Brussels on the issue of agricultural protection. U.S. negotiators, backed by most of the world's other large agricultural exporters, wanted to cut internal farm supports by 75 percent; the Europeans would agree to only a 30 percent cut. In effect, the interests of a few heavily subsidized European farmers now threaten the trade structure that has brought increasing global prosperity since just after World War II. There's nothing arcane about that threat; it's plainly and simply wrong. . .. The GATT ministers will meet in Geneva after the first of the year to try to break the deadlock. The subsidies of inefficient European farmers must be cut in the interest of freer global trade. --- Dec. 10 The Greenwood (Miss.) Commonwealth on Lech Walesa: Americans remember Lech Walesa as the courageous Gdansk shipyard electrician who led his fellow workers in strikes against Poland's then communist government. Walesa went to jail for his efforts. That was before Eastern Europe's revolutionary political changes of the past year or so. Now Walesa, a 47-year-old electrician with a vocational school education, is the new elected president of Poland. ... Before communism began to crumble, Walesa had built the Solidarity movement into a broad-based anti-communist social consensus which united Polish intellectuals, workers and the Catholic Church. Once Solidarity took over the government, however, its ranks began to splinter. After four decades of communism, Prime Minister Mazowiecki engineered economic ``shock treatment'' to Poland. It seems to be working. But Mazowiecki's defeat reminds us that it is easier to criticize from outside the government than it is to lead from within, especially when times are hard. Walesa no doubt is going to face the same trouble, for it will not be easy to create a modern market economy in Poland or for that matter in the rest of Eastern Europe. A hard road lies ahead. It is easier to rally people against something or someone than it is to rally people in support of a difficult plan of action, no matter how necessary that plan may be. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: may be.
DOC.TEXT: Dec. 6 The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times on China: Only 18 months since China massacred pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, President Bush was meeting at the White House with China's foreign minister. And U.S. Ambassador to China John Lilley was recently in Seattle, chastising demonstrators against China's gross violations of human rights. What is going on? ... Never mind that China has shown no remorse for its massacre of innocents but has continued to persecute those involved in the pro-democracy movement. ... Bush counted on the shift of public interest to the Middle East as a cover for reopening the door of the White House to Beijing. But not everyone was looking the other way. ... Confronted by demonstrators against China's human-rights abuses, ... Lilley got into a shouting match, calling them ``cowards'' and ridiculously suggesting that if they hadn't been at Tiananmen Square they had no right to protest. He even shouted at a Tibetan man that he should ``go back to China and serve China.''... The ambassador has since admitted he made a mistake, but defended himself by saying he was provoked by name-calling from some of the demonstrators. That is no excuse. Any diplomat so easily pushed to the point of losing control should be in another line of work. In light of the administration's weak-kneed response to China's brutal repression of internal dissent, ... Lilley should have been prepared to take his lumps from demonstrators rightly protesting Beijing's human-rights abuses. An apology is clearly called for, but was conspicuously absent from the ambassador's statement admitting error. And the White House has been silent, derelict in its duty at least to reprimand ... Lilley for his unseemly and unwarranted outburst. But that, we suppose, should come as no surprise. --- Dec. 7 Le Monde, Paris, on the Persian Gulf: Saddam Hussein has finally accomplished one of the gestures that the international community ordered of him four months ago. His decision to free all the hostages without delay or conditions - and no longer, as he previously announced, between Dec. 25 and March 25 - was swallowed Dec. 7 by the parliament in Baghdad. If this initiative, which puts an end to a long scandal, shouldn't reward him with any gratitude, it nonetheless marks a political retreat. For the first time since the annexation of Kuwait, the Iraqi dictator has satisfied one of the principal demands of the United Nations. In the eyes of the United States and its allies, the fate of the hostages - and in particular the fear of taking the lives of these ``human shields'' dispersed on the strategic sites of the ``host'' country - never played the deterrent role that Baghdad expected. Hostages or not, nothing has stopped a logic of war from unfolding in the Gulf. And the Western military detachment, reinforced at the end of the month, is from now on credible. In these conditions, Saddam Hussein has judged it more useful to grant freedom to his hostages. --- Dec. 7 La Repubblica, Rome, on the Persian Gulf: For the first time since Aug. 2, the day of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, it is right to say that the caravan of peace has started to move in the Arabian desert. If Saddam Hussein seriously intends to liberate the thousands of Americans, Western Europeans and Russians who until now have been used as ``human shields,'' and if this is not the strategy of a crafty merchant trying to gain time and divide his adversaries, then the bloodbath in the Persian Gulf is not the one and only inevitable conclusion to the crisis. --- Dec. 9 The Observer, London, on trade talks: Removing barriers to trade in manufactured goods has led to an immense growth in world commerce in the post-war years. Trade has kept growing even at times of economic difficulty. Yet now European and American leaders seem incapable of pursuing a broad common interest, even though they know its long-term benefit to both their own countries and the world community to be beyond doubt. ... The (Persian) Gulf crisis has revealed the reluctance of most of America's European allies for vigorous cooperation now that the Cold War is over. ... If rich Europe relapses into selfish regionalism, it will find itself paying a price. Its prosperity and stability are bound to lure the less fortunate. There is already alarm over the flow of illegal immigrants from North Africa. The collapse of communist border controls in East Europe has made it easier for Asians to slip unnoticed into the West. ... It is time for Western leaders to show they recognize the responsibilities beyond their own parish. --- Dec. 9 Sunday Nation, Nairobi, Kenya, on Angola's reform proposals: For the United States in particular, it is a chance to make amends for the deaths, injuries and economic losses occasioned on Angola through U.S. support to (rebel) Unita. It will also be a major prop for President Jose dos Santos who, at this difficult time, needs all the support he can get from every quarter. With goodwill and support from all, the Angolan case could be Africa's success story this year, second only to the release in February of South Africa's foremost nationalist, Nelson Mandela. ---
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Roundup
Bush Reassures Shamir of Support; Shevardnadze Meeting Today
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 5 grafs new to update with Bush decision on Soviet trade concessions, Shamir meeting with Senate committee.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir told members of Congress today he firmly supports President Bush's decision to ease trade with the Soviet Union as a reward for its liberalized policies. Israel and its supporters in Congress had spearheaded opposition to trade concessions for the Soviets but are now trying to help the strapped Soviet economy since the relaxation of restrictions on Jewish emigration. Shamir spoke to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in a closed session, but Israeli officials relayed the gist of his remarks. Shamir was meeting later in the day with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. The hastily scheduled meeting, requested by the Soviets and arranged by the State Department, reflects the fast-improving relationship between the two countries. Before meeting Shamir, Shevardnadze is calling on President Bush, who has been weighing how to ease immediate Soviet food shortages and to help the economy in the longer term. Bush has decided to temporarily waive the 1974 Jackson-Vanik amendment which limits trade with the Soviets unless they allow free emigration. ``We think it (the amendment) could be dispensed with for a year or more because of the very liberalized policies related to the emigration of Soviet Jews,'' Shamir told reporters at a conference of the American Enterprise Institute. Gorbachev has been allowing Jews out at a rate of 1,000 to 2,000 a day - a far cry from the virtually closed gates of the Soviet Union through most of the 1970s and 1980s. The subject of the flood of immigrants is expected to come up with Shevardnadze, Shamir said, as well as Israel's request for direct flights from the Soviet Union and its desire for resumption of full diplomatic ties which the Soviets broke in 1967. The crisis in the Persian Gulf and prospects for Israeli-Arab peace talks are also expected to come up, said other officials. The session with Shamir will give Shevardnadze an opportunity to try to persuade him that an international peace conference could help settle the Arab-Israeli dispute. But Shamir said ``Israel will not participate in such a conference and Israel will not accept imposed solutions.'' Instead, Israel wants direct talks with its Arab neighbors as outlined in a four-point peace plan Shamir proposed last year and the United States endorsed. ``Peace plans are neither fashions nor automobiles. We must not introduce a new model every year,'' Shamir said. Israel also has not changed its mind about excluding the Palestine Liberation Organization from peace talks, and it hopes the PLO's support for Iraq has convinced the world of its unsuitability as a peace partner, Shamir said. Sounding a conciliatory tone, the prime minister said Israel wants to cooperate with its Arab neighbors on an arms control plan that would rid the volatile Middle East of its vast arsenals of arms. Israel also wants to cooperate on a plan to ease the reigon's increasingly severe water shortages, he said. He pledged again that Israel would refrain from a pre-emptive strike against Iraq unless attacked. Shamir's meeting with Bush Tuesday went a long way toward calming his fears about the steadfastness of U.S. support for Israel, despite recent strains over the new U.S. alliances with Arab states aligned against Iraq. The meeting ``will enhance the special relationshi between the United States and Israel,'' Shamir told reporters at the White House. Shamir said his meeting with Bush convinced him the administration doesn't favor an international conference. The administration has been fighting a proposed resolution at the U.N. Security Council calling for such a conference, mainly to avoid linking the Israeli-Palestinian dispute with the U.S.-led drive to force Iraq to leave Kuwait. Bush also sought to smooth the strains in his relations with Shamir. He voiced U.S. concerns about treatment of Palestinians living under Israeli occupation, said Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly, but he did not bring up the slaying of 17 Palestinians by Israeli police during an October riot at a Jerusalem holy site. Shamir asked Bush for help, possibly in the form of loan guarantees, in absorbing Soviet Jews who are coming to Israel. The president said he would think about it.

DOC.HEAD: ACLU Seeks Removal of Creche, Menorah From Public Property
DOC.TEXT: Two California communities are being challenged by the American Civil Liberties Union to remove religious symbols that mark the holiday season from public property. In Beverly Hills, the American Jewish Congress and four Jewish residents, backed by the ACLU, filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking the removal of a 28-foot Hannukah menorah displayed at a municipal park. In Monterey, the ACLU has demanded that the city remove a Nativity scene from the City Hall lawn by Thursday, or face a lawsuit. The civil liberties union contends the displays amount to a government endorsement of religion, but the communities say they are celebrating the diversity of religious beliefs in the nation by offering space for holiday displays from a variety of groups. Chabad, a movement of Hasidic Jews, installed the large candelabra in Beverly Hills on Monday for public celebration of the eight-day Jewish holiday. The suit filed by the American Jewish Congress contends the menorah on public property violates the First Amendment's guarantee of separation of church and state. Carol Plotkin of the Jewish Congress argued that religious freedom is best preserved by banning all religious objects on public lands. ``There are plenty of opportunities to put up creches or menorahs or any other religious object on private property. Government should be free of any religious objects,'' she said. City Attorney Greg Stepanicich defended the city's approval of the Chabad menorah. ``We have a lighted Christmas tree, a lighted `Seasons Greetings' sign, and now we've allowed the menorah as part of that overall holiday message,'' Stepanicich said. He said that state and federal courts have allowed religious holiday displays if they also show ``cultural diversity and pluralism.'' Hanukkah, or the Jewish Feast of Lights, began Tuesday evening. It commemorates the rededication of the Temple in Jerusalem by the Maccabees after they ousted foreign occupiers 2,100 years ago. It is celebrated by lighting one candle on the menorah for each of the eight days. In Monterey, the city for years has made space on the City Hall lawn available to the Monterey Civic Club to set up the Nativity scene. On Tuesday, the city posted a large sign on the lawn saying the space on the lawn was available for noncommercial holiday displays. The sign also says the city ``does not endorse or support any of the points of view expressed by the displays or their sponsors; the message is the sole expression of the person or group erecting the display.'' But Michelle Welsh, a lawyer representing the ACLU, said the sign doesn't make any difference. ``It's abundantly clear that the law requires the city to remove the creche from city property,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: 45 Beached Whales Destroyed or Given Up for Dead on Cape Cod
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to UPDATE number of dead whales reduced to 43; SUBS 14th graf, ``Two whales,'' with 2 grafs to update condition of whales at aquarium, total count reduced; SUBS the 17th graf pvs, ``In eight,'' to reflect change in count.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HYS1 of Dec. 11
DOC.TEXT: Volunteers coaxed eight beached whales back to sea and took two to an aquarium, but 43 others grounded near the Kennedy family compound were given up for dead or put to death overnight to end their misery. The whales that returned to the sea appeared to be all right this morning despite fears on Tuesday that they would be disoriented, and in danger of beaching themselves again, authorities said. But the whales left behind were less fortunate. Rescuers on Cape Cod had struggled most of the day Tuesday to save the pilot whales, splashing them with water and soothing them with wet towels as the giant mammals - most of them mothers and calves - lay listlessly, making squeaking and whistling noises and occasionally twitching. ``I'm offering a little comfort,'' said one volunteer, Karen Kelly. ``They respond to your touch and your voice. They are scared and they don't know what's going on. ``Say a prayer,'' she added.
