The final American chartered flight is scheduled to leave early Thursday, with about 15 Americans from Iraq on board, including the last remaining person who was a ``human shield.'' After they pop open a bottle of champagne, the Coles planned to take it easy. ``I got my husband home and now I can relax,'' Mrs. Cole said. ``Now, the old adrenalin can kind of slow down.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan, Germany Deny Pentagon Claim They Are Lagging in Aid Payments
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Germany and Japan on Wednesday disputed a U.S. accusation that they have delivered barely one-fifth of the aid they promised to back U.S. military operations in the Persian Gulf. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's chief spokesman, Hans Klein, said Germany has already made available well over half of the $2.24 billion it promised. The Defense Ministry said the aid made available includes $1.09 billion in military equipment and transport. Some of the military supplies are waiting at German ports for delivery to the Middle East, said a Defense Ministry spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. Klein said Germany ``does not know the basis for these calculations (the Pentagon's). In any event, they do not correspond with facts.'' A Japanese Foreign Ministry official said that of $4 billion pledged for the military effort and to support Arab states affected by the gulf crisis, $600 million has been spent. The process for disbursing another $600 million in emergency loans for Jordan and Turkey will be completed very soon, said another ministry official. ``It is not the case that the Japanese government is delaying disbursement,'' he said. Both Japanese officials spoke on condition of anonymity under normal briefing rules. On Tuesday, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Japan had delivered only $426 million in cash and material support, and Germany only $337 million. Neither Japan nor Germany has sent armed forces to the gulf, citing constitutional restrictions. Of the six countries that offered the largest contributions to Operation Desert Shield at its outset in August, only Kuwait has given all that it promised, Williams said. He declined to comment on the reasons for the delayed contributions from other allies. Pledges totaling more than $6.5 billion were made for calendar year 1990. The spokesman said the United States plans to ask an undisclosed number of allied nations to increase their contributions for 1991. He said he did not know how much money would be sought or when the requests would be made. U.S. sources said Monday that Desert Shield may cost $30 billion in 1991. The Pentagon's original cost estimate was $15 billion, but that was before President Bush ordered huge reinforcements to the gulf on Nov. 8.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Rally to Keep One-Room Schoolhouse Open
DOC.TEXT: One of two remaining one-room schoolhouses in New Hampshire is on the verge of being closed to save money, but parents who say their children thrived there are fighting the plan. ``Here's something that works. People care about that school,'' said Bob Wolff, a resident who helped circulate a petition opposing the plan to temporarily close the Alexandria Village School. School Superintendent George Corrette suggested the temporary closure to save an estimated $40,000 a year. But residents who fear that temporary might mean forever presented the petition at a school board meeting Monday. ``I've seen temporary taxes that have been in effect all my life,'' Wolff said. ``You say you're going to reopen it when you have extra money? It's not going to happen.'' The schoolhouse, which was built in the 1840s, is one of two left in New Hampshire. The second is in Landaff, a community of fewer than 300 people. Former Alexandria school board member Fletcher DeWolf said a piece of history would be lost with the school. Eleven other one-room schoolhouses in Alexandria from the pre-Civil War era have been turned into summer cottages, he said. Parents at the meeting said their children would not do as well if they were transferred to the more impersonal environment of the larger regional elementary schools. Community involvement singles out the schoolhouse, said Lori Benson, who teaches its 17 first- and second-graders. Parents drop in daily, to help with projects such as making applesauce and potting spider plants, she said. Even in the face of rising property taxes, several people at the board meeting said they would be willing to pay more to keep the school open. ``A lot of the parents went here, their grandparents went here,'' said Benson, who has taught in the 800-member community for two years. ``It's a very small community. They love and support their one-room schoolhouse.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela, Buthelezi Call For End To Fighting
LaserPhotos JOH3,4
DOC.TEXT: Rival black leaders Nelson Mandela and Mangosuthu Buthelezi on Wednesday urged an end to fighting that has claimed 124 lives. But they declined to meet as they toured this township to urge peace. African National Congress leader Mandela and Zulu leader Buthelezi visited diffekoza, telling followers to end the fighting. Heavily armed soldiers and police in armored vehicles ringed the black township east of Johannesburg and lined the streets to ensure there was no violence. Police said Wednesday that 124 had been killed rent parts of Tosince fighting flared in Tokoza on Sunday. No fighting was reported Wednesday, but police were finding bodies of people killed earlier. Mandela's convoy turned back when it approached some Zulu hostels and about 100 angry Zulu men and women yelled threats, including ``Away Mandela.'' Troops ringed the chanting Zulus and Mandela's group did not appear to be in danger. Black factional fighting in the Johannesburg area has claimed at least 1,000 lives since August. The fighting pits Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the ANC against Zulus tied to Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party. Buthelezi, accompanied by Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok, told about 3,000 Zulus armed with spears, knives and axes there sh Exchange 3p.m. Index:
Market +21 cents Index 179.67 +1.25 American Stock Exchange 3p.m. Index:

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Cheer Formation Of First Political Party
LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Albanians chanting ``Democracy, democracy'' on Wednesday hailed the foundation of the tiny Stalinist country's first non-Communist political party. Albanians reached by telephone said thousands of people surged into University Square in Tirana, Albania's capital, to support students who won unprecedented concessions from the Communist leadership in several days of protests. The developments appeared to herald the end of one-party rule not only in the Balkan nation, but in all of Europe. Albania, a country of just over 3 million, has been the last on the continent to cling to one-party Communist rule. President Ramiz Alia addressed the nation late Wednesday and asked for calm. He called on ``the political and patriotic conscience of you all to avoid mistakes which could have consequences for the entire country.'' His taped radio message was monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in London. Alia and his Communist leadership declared Tuesday that they would allow formation of non-Communist parties in Albania, which was isolated for decades by its hard-line rulers. The crowds cheered wildly Wednesday as students and others announced formation of the Democratic Party of Albania, according to a Tirana engineer reached by telephone from Vienna. Zamira Koleze, a reporter for Albania's official radio, said students would try to register the party Thursday at the Ministry of Justice. The huge peaceful crowd chanted ``Demcoracy, democracy,'' ``We want Albania to be like Europe'' and ``We want democratic Albania,'' the engineer said. He spoke on condition of anonymity. There was also a cheer for Alia for allowing alternative political parties, the engineer said. An editor for the official ATA news agency said those who attended the rally filled a big field, as well as nearby hillsides and the staircases of a student residence. ``It was without disorder, completely regular,'' Koleze said. ``It all went well. When it was over, everyone returned to their homes.'' Estimatesof the number of people who rallied ranged from 10,000 to 100,000. Alia, who has been seeking to slowly introduce moderate reforms, succeeded Tuesday in ousting five hard-line members of the 13-member ruling Politburo of the Communist Party. He called on Premier Adil Carcani to reshuffle the government as well. The Communist Party, formally called the Albanian Labor Party, decided to hold a national meeting Dec. 26. The meeting is to work out the party's electoral platform, but it could also make more leadership changes. The engineer said the new opposition party's guiding committee would meet soon to choose a leader. He said the party intended to contest parliamentary elections scheduled for Feb. 10. But it was not immediately clear whether the Communists would allow the party to take part. Last month, the legislature adopted a new election law permitting more than one candidate, but officials said then that pluralism would not be permitted. Alia told representatives of the students he met with Tuesday that any new political organization would have to apply for registration with the Justice Ministry. Alia previously rejected the type of democratic reforms that swept Communists from power in Eastern Europe last year. On Tuesday, he appealed to the police as well as the students to ``act correctly, in a civilized and democratic way,'' ATA reported. The engineer indicated the people who attended the rally also wanted to avoid bloodshed. ``We want to go ahead without blood, absolutely without blood. All will be solved by speaking and by discussion,'' he said. Since assuming power in 1985 after the death of his predecessor and Albania's founder, Enver Hoxha, Alia has sought to lead his country out of self-imposed isolation, establishing diplomatic relations with dozens of countries and seeking to renew ties with the superpowers. Wednesday's mass rally followed four days of protest by students and weekend clashes with police in which several people were injured and some arrested. Reports that one or more people may have been killed could not be confirmed. Students, who boycotted classes this week after Sunday's violence, returned to classes Wednesday, according to an official reached by telephone from Vienna. He also spoke on condition of anonymity. The Albanian official said there were no reports of unrest elsewhere in the country. The student demonstrations were the first known major opposition to the Communist leadership since July, when thousands of Albanians stormed foreign embassies and refused to leave until they were granted permission to emigrate. On Tuesday, about 10,000 people who gathered in the university quarter welcomed the announcement that pluralism would be permitted with chants of ``Down with the dictatorship,'' ``Long Live Freedom'' and ``Long live Democracy,'' the Austria Press Agency reported. An Italian member of the European Parliament visiting Albania, Alexander Langer, told APA in a telephone interview that officials were becoming ``increasingly pluralistic by the hour. This appears to reflect what is happening.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Support Democracy in Angola, Rebel Leader Says
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze extended the hand of reconciliation Wednesday to the Angolan anti-communist rebel leader whose forces have been at war with the Soviet-backed government in Angola for 15 years. ``The foreign minister has assured us of their desire to help the Angolans achieve peace, stability and democracy,'' insurgent leader Jonas Savimbi said after an unprecedented 45-minute meeting with Shevardnadze at the Soviet Embassy. ``The most important thing is that all the big powers understand they can cooperate to find peace and stability of our country.'' Shevardnadze said if the MPLA government and the UNITA rebels are able to reach a cease-fire agreement, ``then it would be easier for us to address the possibility of a cutoff of arms.'' The Soviets have been a generous arms supplier of the MPLA government since 1975. The United States has been aiding Savimbi's forces for the past four years. The Bush administration's rationale for continuing to arm UNITA is that the leftist government would otherwise have less incentive to negotiate a settlement. The end of the Cold War generally has had little impact on the series of regional conflicts spawned during the era of Soviet-American hostility. For some time, though, the momentum has been on the side of a political settlement in Angola as opposed to a military victory by either side. That perception was underscored when Savimbi ascended to the second floor of the Soviet Embassy Wednesday for his meeting with Shevardnadze, passing below a large portrait of Lenin while en route. Almost simultaneously, Secretary of State James A. Baker III was meeting with Angolan Foreign Minister Pedro de Castro Van Dunem. The idea of a Savimbi-Shervardnadze meeting was first broached privately by Baker when he met here with Savimbi in early October. To make sure Van Dunem could arrive on time for the hastily arranged talks, the Bush administration took the unusual step of allowing the Angolan aircraft in which he flew here to land at nearby Andrews Air Force Base, Md., sources close to Van Dunem said. He went straight to the Soviet Embassy for a meeting with Shevardnadze. After his talks with Baker, Van Dunem said, ``Progress is being made towards an agreement which can lead to a cease-fire.'' Wednesday's discussions will be followed up on Thursday with a five-party meeting involving representatives of the two Angolan factions, the United States, the Soviet Union and Portugal, the former colonial power which has been mediating the conflict. Portugal's chief mediator, Jose Manuel Durao Barroso, told reporters in the Angolan capital of Luanda on Tuesday that a cease-fire agreement could be in place by March. A stumbling block is the timing of an election once a cease fire is reached. Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos said recently he believes an election could be held within three years of a cease-fire. But Savimbi, in a written statement issued after his meeting with Shevardnadze, said he told the Soviet diplomat that a long delay would risk the collapse of the truce. Dos Santos has said he believes that an extended delay is required because roads have to be cleared of mines and problems involving voter registration.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Higher Education Standards
With AM-Cavazos Quits, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The nation should raise its educational sights to reach world class standards, President Bush said Wednesday. ``American kids already rank too low compared to our chief industrial competitors,'' Bush said at an awards ceremony for the Jobs for America's Graduates Program. ``America's schools must, and will, aspire to world-class standards.'' He said schools have been stifled with ``requirements and red tape. Let's give our schools something teachers and principals don't have enough of - authority.'' Bush invoked a catchword, ``empowerment,'' which is emerging among some officials as an administration theme for achieving better educational performance. Using the empowerment notion by allowing parents to decide what schools their children should attend ``is the fundamental reform that drives forward all the others'' in education, Bush said. Parental choice involves a variety of methods to allow parents to send their children to public schools outside their neighborhoods. ``We've got to raise our sights - for our students, for our schools,'' Bush said. Jobs for America's Graduates is a 19-state program that helps place high school graduates in job training programs. The organization is funded privately, with matching funds from the Job Training Partnership Act, and with state funds. As vice president, Bush was a founding member of the board of directors, He said the program has helped low-income young people who might otherwise have had little career success.

DOC.HEAD: FEC Says Wright Failed To Disclose Use of S&L Execs Plane
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Election Commission said Wednesday that two fund-raising committees for former House Speaker Jim Wright accepted an illegal contribution from a Texas businessmen later imprisoned in connection with the savings and loan scandal. FEC spokesman Scott Moxley said Wright's principal fund-raising committee and his leadership political action committee have agreed to pay penalties totaling $1,500 to settle the case. At issue was Wright's use of a chartered airplane that crisscrossed Texas between June 30 and July 2, 1985, to promote a ``Cowtown Jamboree'' in Fort Worth. The fund-raiser sought $1 million for Wright's principal campaign committee, the Wright Appreciation Committee, and his leadership PAC, the Majority Congress Committee. Wright, a Fort Worth Democrat who was House majority leader at the time, was on his way to Haiti Wednesday and could not be reached for comment, a spokesman said. Under the conciliation agreement, the two committees acknowledged they accepted an illegal contribution from the owner of the plane, Kenneth C. Hood, and that they failed to disclose the receipt of the contribution. The committees also acknowledged a violation stemming from the way they repaid Hood for the use of the plane 46 months later, Moxley said. Wright repaid Hood $8,050 in April 1989, in the midst of a House ethics committee investigation that led to his resignation a month later. At the time, Wright said the failure to pay the bill was an ``oversight.'' Hood had purchased the plane from Sunbelt Savings Association, a failed thrift in Dallas, through a $1.3 million loan from Sunbelt. Hood owed Sunbelt Savings $90 million by the end of 1986, the FEC said. Hood told the FEC that Edwin McBirney, then owner of Sunbelt Savings Association, said Wright needed the airplane, and that McBirney promised that he and Thomas M. Gaubert, owner of another S&L, would pay for the trip. After the flight, Hood said McBirney and Gaubert told him that it would be a ``positive gesture'' to absorb some of the costs, Moxley said. Hood then billed them $8,050, two-thirds of the actual cost, Moxley said. Gaubert told the FEC he was merely a passenger on the flight and was not connected to the campaign committee or to Hood, Moxley said. McBirney denied he pressured Hood to let Wright use the jet. Gaubert, whose S&L was closed by state regulators in 1987, had persuaded Wright to intervene with federal regulators on behalf of the Irving-based thrift, Independent American Savings Association. FEC's general counsel had recommended that the commission find Wright violated the law because he was on the airplane, but the FEC found no reason to believe that was the case. The commission also said it had no reason to believe McBirney or Gaubert paid for any costs of the flight. The commission, however, said it found reason to believe Hood made excess, illegal contributions to Wright. Hood was sentenced Feb. 15, 1990, to two years in prison and fined $50,000 for making false statements to a federally insured institution - Sunbelt Savings. He also was sentenced to five years' probation and fined another $50,000 for conspiring to defraud the Internal Revenue Service. McBirney was indicted in July on 17 counts alleging bank fraud, misappropiation of funds, false entries and making false statements to regulators.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Seeking Meeting Of Permanent Security Council Foreign Ministers
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III hopes the Soviet, British, French and Chinese foreign ministers will join him in Europe this month to demand again that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15, diplomats said Wednesday. The foreign ministers would also assure Iraq that it won't be attacked if Iraqi troops leave Kuwait by that date, the diplomats said on condition of anonymity. The ministerial meeting by the five permanent Security Council members would be intended to abolish any impression that Iraq could retain two islands that control access to the Shatt-al-Arab waterway or part of an oilfield straddling the Iraq-Kuwait border. Baker has said, however, that when the emir of Kuwait's government is restored to power, Iraq and Kuwait could then negotiate any economic and territorial disputes between them. Diplomats said the permanent Security Council members don't want Saddam Hussein to feel that the U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf is determined to attack Iraq whether it obeys the council or not. Saddam would have no motive to withdraw if he believed attack is inevitable, they said. The foreign ministers would meet in Europe after Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz meets President Bush in Washington this month, but before Baker goes to Baghdad for talks with Saddam, the diplomats said. Baer has been waiting for word from Baghdad on a date to see Saddam since he turned down Jan. 12 because it was too close to the U.N.-ordered Jan. 15 deadline for withdrawal of Iraqi troops. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who is in Washington for talks with Baker and Bush, said Tuesday that ``It is very important that a goodwill grace period that expires on Jan. 15 is taken up by a very active diplomatic and political effort.'' Shevardnadze said, ``We pin much hope on the coming contacts.'' The United States, Britain, France, and the Soviet Union agree in principle that their foreign ministers should meet in Europe with China's foreign minister to send a message to Baghdad, diplomats said. China's willingness to participate is in question, because Beijing opposes using military force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. China abstained when the Security Council voted 12-2 on Nov. 29 to adopt a resolution authorizing U.N. members to use all necessary means, including military force, to liberate Kuwait unless Iraq withdraws by Jan. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Serbian Communists Score Landlside Victory
DOC.TEXT: President Slobodan Milosevic and his renamed Communist Party crushed all opposition in first-round balloting in Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, according to official results released Wednesday. Milosevic, the hard-line leader of the former Serbian Communist Party, carried 65 percent of the vote, Caslav Ignjatovic, the head of the Serbian Electoral Commission, told reporters. That was enough to be re-elected to Serbia's powerful presidency outright. His leading challenger, Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement, won only 16.4 percent. Milosevic's Socialist Party, the renamed Communist Party, crushed all opposition in the first-round vote Sunday, capturing 87 of the 250 parliamentary seats in the republic's first multiparty election since 1938, the results showed. Runoff elections will take place in 152 electoral districts, where no candidates won a majority. Twenty opposition parties on Wednesday announced they would form a coalition to oppose Milosevic's Socialist Party in the second round Dec. 23. Milosevic captured 65 percent of the vote - a 4-to-1 triumph over his nearest challenger, Draskovic, according to the Serbian Electoral Commission. His party won 45.8 percent of the parliamentary vote, the Serbian Renewal Movement won 15.7 percent and independent candidates 9 percent. More than 20 other parties took smaller percentages of the vote. The runoffs are not expected to substantially alter the overwhelming victory of the Socialists. The sweeping victory, along with a similar Communist victory in the neighboring republic of Montenegro, may push Yugoslavia's fragile federation one step closer to disintegration. Milosevic's win threatens to deepen the rift between Serbia and Western-minded republics of Croatia and Slovenia. While Serbia is holding its runoff elections, Slovenia will be voting in a plebiscite on independence from Yugoslavia. The Slovenian daily Nezavisni Dnevnik ascribed the Socialist victory ``primarily to the fact that the authority had the power to introduce a veritable media occupation of Serbia.'' The Socialists' victory in Serbia was marred by a boycott in Kosovo province, which is dominated by ethnic Albanians. Elections there will have to be repeated in 30 of 34 districts in which less than half of the voters participated. Communist authorities in Serbia dissolved Kosovo's parliament and government and shut down influential Albanian-language media after parliament tried to proclaim Kosovo a republic earlier this year. The Serbian leaders said they had to take control to prevent Kosovo from seceding from Serbia and Yugoslavia to join neighboring Albania, and to protect the non-Albanian population. In runoff balloting, the boycott will be ineffective because a simple majority of the voters who cast ballots will be enough to elect deputies.

DOC.HEAD: Golden-Haired Women Awaken Nobel Laureates On Lucia Day
DOC.TEXT: Some Nobel Prize winners will wake up Thursday in their hotel rooms surrounded by golden-haired young women with candles on their heads, singing carols. It's Lucia Day, when Swedes brighten up the darkest period of the year with celebrations embracing a Roman Catholic martyr and a pre-Christian light festival. Before the Gregorian calendar was adopted, the feast of St. Lucia was on the shortest day of the year. It commemorated a virgin who was martyred in Syracuse, Sicily in 304 A.D. Pagan Swedes had their own mid-winter celebrations of light on the year's shortest day. After Sweden was Christianized, the Roman Catholic saint portrayed with lights in her golden hair became a natural favorite. Nowadays Lucia processions occur throughout Sweden in offices, on the streets and in schools. Singing young women with electric-candle crowns lead the parade. People dressed as gnomes hand out ginger snaps. Little ``star boys'' march along with cone-shaped caps and star-topped wands. The festival falls three days after the Nobel Prize awards ceremony. Many of the scientists, authors and statesmen are still on hand, giving lectures and participate in seminars. Gun Lannergren, who has directed the processions at the Grand Hotel for 15 years, said the laureates always are told in advance about the 7 a.m. Lucia Day wakeup calls. With the laureates' agreement, young music students are given keys to enter their rooms and awaken them with song. ``The girls go from room to room and sometimes the laureates join the procession in their pajamas to hear the girls sing once again,'' said Lannergren. Traditionally, only Nobel Prize winners have enjoyed the private spectacle. Other hotel clients can enjoy the singing later in the morning when 20-25 young women perform a brief concert in a separate room at the hotel. Swedish children sing for their parents on Lucia morning before going to school to participate in choir performances. Young women go about with strands of tinsel in their hair. Cookies, saffron bread and mulled wine are consumed at impromptu parties. The popular Neapolitan song, ``Santa Lucia'' is always sung. It's about the oldest part of Italy's Naples, the Santa Lucia quarter which was named after the saint. Lucia is considered the patron saint of Syracuse and the patroness of eyes. She is frequently shown with two eyes in a dish, a possible reference to her martyrdom. The name Lucia comes from the Latin word for light. The first accounts of Lucia celebrations in Sweden date to the 17th century. In the old medieval calendar the ``Lussi'' night between Dec. 12-13 was the longest night of the year and associated with mysterious happenings. Country folk believed all children should be christened before Lucia or the devil could take them from their parents.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Replaces Aging Defense Chief With Battle-Hardened Veteran
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 19th, `U.S. officials...' to UPDATE with previous report that official had been executed. Pick up 20th pvs, `Khazraji was...'
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein has dismissed his aging defense minister and replaced him with a battle-hardened commander who was a hero of the war with Iran, Iraq's official media reported Wedneday. It was the second major shuffle in Iraq's high command in a month. Baghdad Radio, quoting a presidential decree, said the 70-year-old defense minister, Gen. Abdel-Jabbar Khalil Shanshal, was retiring because of his age. He held the post for just over a year. The radio said the new defense minister is Maj. Gen. Saadi Tuma Abbas, the inspector-general of the armed forces and a former deputy chief of staff. Abbas, who is in his fifties, was a hero of the 1980-88 war with Iran. He commanded the defense of Basra against the Iranians, whose attacking armies came within a few miles of the southern port city. He was the strategist behind the formidable defensive lines built to protect Basra from Iranian ``human wave'' assaults. The Iraqis, who have an estimated 450,000 troops in and around Kuwait, have built similar fortifications around Kuwait. Abbas later commanded troops involved in heavy fighting with the Iranians in the southern Iraq theater, the main battleground in that conflict. Shanshal's dismissal comes just over a month before the U.N. Security council's Jan. 15 deadline for him to quit Kuwait or face a possible military assault. Some analysts said that by appointing Abbas, Saddam was underscoring readiness to go to war. U.S. officials have reported a steady buildup of Iraqi forces in Kuwait and southern Iraq in recent weeks. They estimate there are now more than 500,000 troops, half Saddam's army, in the Kuwait theater. By mid-January, the Iraqis will face a 650,000-strong U.S.-led multinational force with formidable firepower in the region. The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, quoted Saddam as telling Shanshal in a letter that it had been agreed earlier that ``your assumption of this post would not exceed two years and would not be less than one year.'' Shanshal was named a minister of state for military affairs, the post he held before he was appointed defense minister. Analysts said the post carries no authority or influence. ``It may be that Shanshal supported negotiations and supported a position that represented too much of an adjustment in Saddam's attitude for him to be able to accept,'' said Don Kerr, an analyst with London's International Institute for Strategic Studies. ``The implication is that he's making sure that all those involved in military decision-making will toe the line,'' said Paul Rogers, a defense analyst at England's Bradford University and an expert of Middle East military affairs. Appointing an officer of Abbas' caliber ``could mean that Saddam is less than ready to compromise'' on Kuwait, Rogers said in a telephone interview. Saddam dismissed his chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Nazir al-Khazraji, Nov.8 in a surprise shuffle. Analysts said at the time it indicated dissent within the upper echelons of the army over the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the risk of a showdown with the U.S.-led multinational force. U.S. officials said Khazraji, who had been one of Saddam's inner circle of military advisers, was apparently sacked for opposing Saddam's strategy. Syrian newspapers and Arab sources later reported that Khazraji and seven other senior officers were executed. But there was no independent confirmation of that and no official word in Baghdad. Khazraji was replaced by Gen. Hussein Rashid, deputy chief of staff for operations and commander of the elite Republican Guards divisions. He is a hard-liner and comes from Takrit, Saddam's hometown north of Baghdad. The Iraqi leader has filled key positions with relatives and others from Takrit.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Settlements Reported `Blossoming' Despite Uprising
LaserPhoto JRL1
DOC.TEXT: Jewish settlements in the occupied territories ``are growing and blossoming'' and their population has increased to 100,000 despite the Palestinian uprising, Defense Minister Moshe Arens said Wednesday. President Bush is an outspoken opponent of Israeli settlement building in the lands captured in the 1967 Middle East war. He considers these enclaves to be a major obstacle to peace efforts. Arens spoke in an Israel radio interview hours after his motorcade was stoned in the West Bank town of Jericho, shattering a window of the lead escort vehicle, Israeli reports said. Arens' car was not hit. In other developments Wednesday: -A teen-age Palestinian girl was shot to death in the occupied West Bank when soldiers fired at Arab students throwing stones at Israeli cars, Arab and Israeli reports said. -The government barred prominent Palestinian activist Sari Nusseibeh of east Jerusalem from leaving the country for three months, noting unspecified security reasons, Israel TV reported. Nusseibeh has been mentioned in the past as a prospective peace negotiator. Israel has accused him of playing a leadership role in the 3-year-old uprising. Arens said, ``Today there are 100,000 Jews in Judea and Samaria,'' using biblical names for the West Bank. He said this was higher than before the uprising began, without giving further figures. Previous estimates said about 70,000 Jews lived in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Settlement activity, Arens said, ``isn't being stopped by the intefadeh,'' the Arabic word for uprising. ``To the contrary it is blossoming ... and growing.'' The United States has conditioned $400 million in loans to build housing for Soviet immigrants on the homes not being built in the occupied territories. In Wednesday's fatal clash, about 200 students from the Arab village of Biddiya stoned Israeli cars on a highway in a protest marking the anniversary of the founding of a radical PLO faction, Arab reports said. Soldiers fired and one bullet struck Ahlam Abed in the head, killing her, the reports added. Arab reports listed her age as 13, and said Jewish settlers also fired guns during the confrontation. Israeli radio stations and TV said she was 16. The army said it was investigating. It brought to 778 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the uprising. Fifty-four Israelis also have died. At least 316 other Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of helping Israel. At least eight other Palestinians were wounded and two soldiers injured by rocks in scattered clashes Wednesday in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, reports said. Troops sealed the homes of three Palestinians suspected of involvement in killing two suspected informers and firing at an army patrol in Rafah in the Gaza Strip, the army said.

DOC.HEAD: Most Americans Managed To Leave Before Saddam's Final Offer
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 3,500 Americans were trapped by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, but most of those wanting to leave had already made their way out by the time Saddam Hussein agreed last week to free all foreigners. By Wednesday, four days after the mass releases of Westerners began under Saddam's decree, the State Department said only a few Americans were known to be awaiting evacuation from Iraq. The final American chartered flight is scheduled to leave early Thursday, with about 15 Americans from Iraq expected aboard, including the last remaining captive who served as a ``human shield'' at a strategic site, U.S. officials said. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait, the U.S. government has evacuated 2,520 American citizens and their family members on 13 chartered flights, the department said. About 510 American citizens, most of them children with dual citizenship, have opted to remain in Kuwait and Iraq, Boucher said. Iraq sealed its borders Aug. 9, a week after its lightning takeover of Kuwait. The border closing came the same day the first American troops landed in Saudi Arabia to defend the kingdom against any further Iraqi aggression. In the early days of the crisis, an undetermined number of Americans managed to escape, many by driving across the the desert to remote border crossings. Early on, foreign governments were reluctant to refer to the trapped foreigners as hostages, fearing that would inflame the situation at a time when their release might still be arranged. But Iraqi troops began rounding up Westerners, and it became clear that Saddam intended to try to use them to force concessions from Western governments forming a coalition against him. On Aug. 20, fears for the safety of trapped Westerners were heightened when Iraq said some of the captives were being scattered at strategic sites around the country to serve as ``human shields'' against attack. The first large group of Americans allowed to leave consisted of 52 wives and children of diplomats at the American embassy in Kuwait. They were permitted to cross overland into Turkey on Aug. 26, but were forced to leave husbands and fathers behind. On Aug. 28, denounced by governments around the world for his hostage-holding, Saddam said all foreign women and children would be free to leave. U.S. officials chartered flights to ferry them out. The first U.S.-chartered jet to evacuate Americans and other Westerners left Baghdad on Sept 1. for London and Washington. By the time the tenth American charter left on Nov. 18, U.S. diplomats estimated 2,300 to 2,400 Americans had managed to leave Iraq and Kuwait. After the series of U.S.-chartered flights, Americans continued to trickle out of Iraq. Some got out on regularly scheduled flights to Jordan, others departed on planes chartered by other governments and still others on flights arranged by various dignitaries who traveled to Iraq to bargain for hostages. The private hostage-freeing missions caused some dissent within the anti-Iraq alliance. The U.S. government saw Saddam's piecemeal release of the hostages as a bid to divide the coalition. On. Nov. 18, Iraq offered to release all the hostages in batches over a three-month period extending from Christmas to March 25 if nothing happened to ``mar the atmosphere of peace.'' That was seen by U.S. officials as an effort by Saddam to drag out the process during a likely time frame for any attack. Saddam also said hostages' relatives could come for Christmastime visits, and suggested that those who traveled to Iraq might be allowed to bring loved ones home with them. That prompted some relatives to make the trip to Baghdad, against State Department advice. Last Thursday, with the numbers of hostages dwindling daily, Saddam decided to release all foreigners. His rubber-stamp parliament endorsed the decision on Friday. Former U.S. Treasury Secretary John Connally flew out of Iraq last Saturday with 21 former American hostages. They were the first to leave in the wake of Saddam's decision, although their release was arranged prior to it. On Sunday, the evacuation began in earnest. A U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways jet took 174 Americans and 149 other Westerners to Frankfurt. Fourteen other Americans left Baghdad on Tuesday on a British charter to London and on an American charter to Frankfurt.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Moscow Summit in February, Bush, Gorbachev Hope to Sign START Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines a0647-a0649-a0651-a0653-a0655; new material throughout. Picks up 12th graf a0621, ``Hardships have xxx''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today announced plans to meet Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow Feb. 11-13 , and said he hopes the two will be able to sign a treaty slashing long-range nuclear weapons. Bush also said he was making the Soviets eligible for credits totaling $1 billion to buy U.S. agricultural products ranging from grain to cheese. ``The Soviet Union faces tough times,'' Bush said at a Rose Garden appearance also attended by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The twin announcements provided a fresh reminder of how much U.S.-Soviet relations have progressed in a few years - from grim superpower rivals to partners in the effort to force Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and negotiate reductions in nuclear weapons. Shevardnadze hailed Bush's comments as a ``very important statement'' and said he looked forward to seeing Bush and Gorbachev sign the arms control treaty, which has been years in negotiations. He said he also looked forward to agreements covering trade, science, technology and investments. The arms control treaty would reduce the most powerful and dangerous nuclear weapons in both countries arsenals by about 30 percent. Bush granted the Soviets a temporary waiver of legislation that has linked expanded U.S.-Soviet trade to liberalized Soviet immigration policy. Bush said he welcomed the ``generally excellent progress'' of the past year during which the Soviets have permitted tens of thousands of Jews to emigrate to Israel. But he added, ``I still look forward to the passage of a Soviet immigration law.'' Bush departed the Rose Garden without taking questions from reporters. Baker told reporters that some highly technical issues remain to be settled before the arms control treaty can be signed. But he expressed hope the obstacles could be cleared in time for the February summit. Baker and Shevardnadze met Monday and Tuesday in Houston to discuss the arms treaty, food aid and other issues affecting their two countries. The two nations have already begun to eliminate short- and medium-range nuclear weapons, and a treaty slashing non-nuclear forces in Europe was signed at a ceremony last month in Paris. Baker said the main issues still to be resolved on a long-range treaty involve verification. A February Bush-Gorbachev summit would be the fifth meeting between the two presidents in a little more than a year. The two men held their first summit last December in Malta, and have since met in Washington, Helsinki and Paris. Bush met with his Cabinet earlier today to put the finishing touches on the aid package. Shevardnadze said he knew that it was not easy for the president to waive the legislation. ``I'm sure everyone in the Soviet Union will welcome and appreciate that decision,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Hardships have, 12th graf a0621
Potbellied Pigs' Bacon Saved; Biosphere II Takes Them Off Menu
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 16th graf, ``The wild,'' to CORRECT attribution to Ms. Dyhr.
DOC.TEXT: The prospect of someone feasting high on the hog - the Vietnamese potbellied variety that some people keep as pets - had one pig owner squealing. Three of the miniature porkers were to be among the menagerie in the Biosphere II project, scheduled to begin in March. There was a possibility that one of the critters might become dinner for the closed environment's human tenants. ``They're domestic pets; they've never been raised or used for food in this country,'' said Ingrid Henze, 32, of Los Angeles, a pig owner who protested. Fear not: Their ribs have been spared. The portly potbellied porcus has been removed from the larder. The Ossabaw swine, a feral pygmy breed found in Georgia, will forage in its stead. The pigs were to join about 3,800 other plant and animal species and a crew of four men and four women in March on a two-year stay in a 3-acre, sealed compound like a giant greenhouse. The Biosphere's areas of desert, ocean, marshes, savannah and rain forest make it the most comprehensive effort to duplicate Earth's environment as a possible prototype for space living. Its environments, plus an intensive agriculture area and housing for the humans, will be sealed and all air, water and wastes will be recycled. Pigs are needed because they are extremely efficient recyclers, capable of rapidly converting to fertilizer roughages such as the stems of broccoli plants that other animals will not touch. ``Sort of like a quick compost machine,'' said Biosphere spokeswoman Kathleen Dyhr. And in a closed environment, smallness counts. Potbellied pigs weigh 50 to 150 pounds, about the size of the Georgia pig. Some varieties of swine raised for food weigh up to 1,000 pounds. A proposal to substitute the Georgia pig as more appropriate for the Biosphere's needs had been under review for about the last nine months, ``independently of the pig people,'' Ms. Dyhr said. She said Biosphere II received four or five complaints, but she declined to say if they caused the switch. She noted that several animal species, including types of deer, chicken and goat, have been changed during the planning. And in any case, said Kayla Mull, ``these are not good pork chops. These are lard-hogs. They make fat.'' Mrs. Mull has bred potbellied pigs since 1985 through Creatures of Comfort in Norco, near Los Angeles. The wild Georgia pigs, accustomed to the warm and humid climate in Biosphere II, also will be more adaptable to eating greens, Ms. Dyhr said. Their role as ham will be secondary, though they are more suitable for meat production than the potbellied pigs, she added. Another factor against the potbellied variety, Ms. Dyhr said, was that they're expensive. Their popularity as pets means a healthy neutered male, tamed and vaccinated, can cost $1,500 to $2,500, and breeding stock at least $5,000, said Kiyoko Hancock. She operates the International Gold Star Registry Service, publishes Pig Tale Times and breeds potbellied pigs in Pescadero, Calif., south of San Francisco. The pets, also known as Chinese potbellied pigs, are indigenous to Southeast Asia. Mrs. Hancock said virtually all the animals in the United States stem from potbellieds sent from Vietnam to the East Berlin Zoo in the 1950s. Twelve sows and four boars were imported from Germany into Canada around 1985, with offspring brought into this country, she said. Mrs. Mull put the potbellied pig population at between 6,000 and 10,000, ``multiplying like mice.'' Ms. Henze and her boyfriend have had their porcine pal, named Forbes, for more than a year. She had wanted a pet ``more sophisticated and interesting than a dog,'' without smell, barking, shedding or fleas. ``And we've never been happier,'' she said. ``He's small, he's clean, he's quiet. He's basically a housepig, he's housebroken, he's a very sophisticated, intelligent animal, very interesting.'' Said Mrs. Mull: ``Visualize a dog that never smells bad, never has to have a bath, that will sleep on the bed all night without waking you up barking at the sound of a fire engine.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Soviet Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here is the text of President Bush's remarks Wednesday on aid to the Soviet Union and plans for a Feb. 11-13 summit in Moscow to sign a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, or START.
I have just had an opportunity to discuss with Foreign Minister (Eduard) Shevardnadze a number of issues of U.S.-Soviet relations, including cooperation in the (Persian) Gulf, and I'm pleased with the great progress we've made on START and hopeful that we'll be ready to sign a treaty at a summit in Moscow on Feb. 11 through 13. We also talked at length about the situation in the Soviet Union and the response of the United States to the economic problems there. I asked Minister Shevardnadze to convey to President (Mikhail) Gorbachev my desire to respond both to the short-term needs of the Soviet Union and to contribute to fundamental economic reform. I've long supported perestroika and continue to. We discussed frankly the relationship of economic change in the Soviet Union to the critical task of democratization and I reiterated our strong desire to see both political and economic reform continue because they are inextricably linked. I outlined specific and important steps that we're willing to take in support of reform, and after consulting closely with Secretary (of Agriculture Clayton) Yeutter as well as Secretaries (Nicholas) Brady (of Treasury) and (James A.) Baker (of State), I told Minister Shevardnadze that I am prepared to respond to a Soviet request for credit guarantees for purchase of agricultural commodities through a waiver of the Jackson-Vanik amendment. While I've taken this step, I still look forward to a passage of the Soviet immigration law codifying the generally excellent practices of the past year. And this then will permit us to make further progress toward the normalization of the U.S.-Soviet economic relationship. In addition, we have proposed to the Soviets a special technical assistance project to help in assessing their food distribution problem and to support market reforms. I will also authorize a joint public-private medical assistance effort to help the Soviet Union cope with immediate shortages of pharmaceuticals and basic medical supplies. In the longer term, only steps that the Soviet Union itself takes can assure the economic health there. Thus to promote fundamental economic reform, I will propose that the World Bank and the IMF (International Monetary Fund) work out with the Soviet Union a special association to give the USSR access to the considerable financial and economic expertise of those institutions. I have asked Secretary of the Treasury Nick Brady, as U.S. governor of both institutions, to pursue this proposal with them and also without other allies, whom I'm sure will be in accord. As I've said before, I want perestroika to succeed. The Soviet Union is facing tough times, difficult times. But I believe that this is a good reason to act now in order to help the Soviet Union stay the course of democratization and to undertake market reforms. The United States has an interest in a Soviet Union able to play a role as a full and prosperous member of the international community of states. And I'm hopeful that these initiatives will further that goal.

DOC.HEAD: Five Napa Wines, One From Washington State, Make World's Best List
DOC.TEXT: California wines outnumbered French varieties for the first time in a magazine ranking of the world's top 10. Five wines from California and one from Washington state were among the best on the list of the 100 greatest wines ranked by quality and price by Wine Spectator. The magazine has compiled the list for three years. Two Napa Valley wine topped the list, which was released Tuesday. The other California wines and the Washington wine were in the top 10. Beringer Cabernet Sauvignon Napa Valley Private Reserve 1986, $30, was No. 1, followed by the $50 Caymus Cabernet Sauvignon Napa Valley Special Selection 1985. Other Napa Valley wines in the top 10 were: $60 Heitz Cabernet Sauvignon Napa Valley, Martha's Vineyard 1985, No. 5; $68 Opus One Napa Valley 1987, No. 6, and $36 Spottswoode Cabernet Sauvignon Napa Valley, 1987, No. 9. It was the first time a Washington state wine broke into the top 10. Woodward Canyon Cabernet Sauvignon Columbia Valley, at $18.50, was in 10th place. The Wine Spectator put two French wines among the top 10. Chartron et Trebuchet Chassagne-Montrachet Les Morgeots 1988, $34, was ranked third, and Daniel Rion Nuits-St.-Georges Les Vignes Rondes 1987, $35, was in seventh place. Italy's $36 Poggio Antico Brunello di Montalcino 1985 was ranked fourth, and Germany's $24 Joh. Jos. Prum Riesling Spatlese Wehlener Sonnenuhr (Cask 2) 1988, took eighth place. The top 100 included 44 California wines, 24 French wines, 15 from Italy, 5 from Spain, 4 from Washington State, 3 from Germany, 2 from Oregon, 2 from Australia and 1 from New Zealand. Two of the judges are from San Francisco, two from New York and two from Europe. The tastings are blind, but when wines are judged to be comparable in quality, the least expensive one gets the nod. U.S. wines had an advantage this year, with the franc rising 20 percent against the dollar. Harvey Shanken, the Wine Spectator's editor and publisher, said that while price might make a difference, quality is the most important ingredient. He noted that 1987 was not a great year for French wines and this is the first year that vintage reached the market.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Say Hatch Failed on Fatal Plane
DOC.TEXT: Investigators found a broken emergency release in the tail of a Northwest Airlines DC-9 in which eight people died after it collided with another plane on a runway, federal officials said Wednesday. A flight attendant and a passenger tried to escape through the hatch, but the two died after the release jammed and trapped them inside, The Detroit News reported Wednesday, citing an unidentified source. A Boeing 727 was racing toward takeoff at Detroit Metropolitan Airport on Dec. 3 when it struck the taxiing DC-9, which had turned in front of it. The Northwest 727's right wing clipped the DC-9 behind the co-pilot's seat and knocked an engine off the DC-9. The ensuing fire moved quickly through the DC-9, which had 39 passengers and four crew members aboard. The 145 passengers and eight crew on the 727 escaped injury. ``Investigators have found, after extensive testing, that the interior tail cone release mechanism failed to separate the tail cone and deploy the emergency slide,'' National Transportation Safety Board member John Lauber said. ``The interior release handle was found partially raised from its stowed position during the safety board's initial examination. Investigators inspected the interior release handle and have found the stem of the handle broken.'' The source told the newspaper that investigators determined the flight attendant and the passenger made it through one emergency hatch to a catwalk in the plane's tail cone, and one of them pulled a red handle designed to pop off the tail cone and release a slide. Alan Pollock, an NTSB spokesman, said the board was only reporting the broken handle, and wouldn't speculate on whether the flight attendant or passenger had pulled it. ``We can't get into that kind of analysis at this time,'' he said. ``The NTSB did not interpret the findings, and neither can Northwest,'' the airline said in a statement. Spokesman Doug Miller said airline officials wouldn't elaborate. The airline checked the tail-cone release mechanisms on its 139 DC-9s Sunday night and Monday, said spokesman Bob Gibbons from Northwest headquarters in Eagan, Minn. The unidentified investigator told the News the bodies of flight attendant Heidi Joost, 43, of Dearborn, and Kingsley Brown, 30, of Pittsburgh, were found a few feet from the tail cone release lever. Autopsies showed Joost died of soot and smoke inhalation, and Brown died of head injuries along with soot and smoke inhalation. Christy Clapp, a Northwest spokeswoman, said the red handle in the tail cone section pulls cables that release four latches holding the cone. The cone is spring-loaded and designed to pop away from the aircraft, Clapp said. She said an inflatable slide automatically deploys from the tail hatch, 5 feet above the ground, allowing people to escape. Cheri Quinn, an off-duty Northwest flight attendant who was on the DC-9, said a similar chute at the plane's left front exit failed to open and passengers were forced to jump or were lowered to the ground. The chute at the front right side of the plane opened properly.

DOC.HEAD: A Heartstopping Lurch, Darkness, Then Escape
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS next-to-last graf to CHANGE `collision' to `crash,' since one train wasn't moving
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX6,9,16
DOC.TEXT: A heartstopping lurch shattered windows and plunged the cars into darkness as train lights went out. Then the passengers had to make their way above ground through thick, gritty smoke from a diesel fire. Others were trapped below ground and had to wait for crews to pull them from the wreckage. It was a commuter nightmare come to life Wednesday when an Amtrak train derailed and smashed into a Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority train at a Back Bay station, injuring 264 people. Jeffrey Weitzenkorn, who travels daily on the train from his hometown of Stoughton, had been reading the newspaper and was getting ready to move out of his chair when the Amtrak train hit. ``There was a big bang and I got thrown to the floor. I went into a fetal position to protect myself,'' said Weitzenkorn, who suffered bruises on his face, lost his glasses and hurt his knee. Joe Povoas, a passenger on the commuter train, said that immediately after the crash one fellow passenger said: ``Let's everybody keep calm and go out of the exits calmly.'' People filed out the open car doors, and began groping for an exit through the smoke. ``You just don't have a concept of when you're going to get fresh air,'' said Povoas, 35, who has used the train for seven years. Finally, passengers found stairs leading out of the station. ``It was like a chimney. The smoke was just flowing up the stairway,'' he said. Lt. Mike Walsh, a firefighter who arrived at the scene two minutes after the first alarm, said there were no signs of panic. ``There was an eerie calm,'' said Walsh, whose face was black with soot. Walsh, like other firefighters, said he gave his oxygen mask away to victims. ``I don't even know where it is now,'' he said. Fire Lt. Jack Joyce brought breathing equipment for two Amtrak engineers, and waited with them for more help to arrive while other firefighters kept flames at bay outside the car. ``They were totally dazed and completely out of it,'' Joyce said, adding that they suffered head injuries. The trains were so mangled that Joyce said he had no idea what part of the train the engineers were trapped in. ``All we were doing was crawling into holes,'' he said. At the point of impact, the trains were indistinguishable from one another, smashed and twisted together ``like a coathanger,'' Walsh said. The crash took out concrete and steel support columns in the train tunnel, and buckled the road above. One set of railroad tracks was tangled and pushed several feet up against a wall. A diesel leak left the station smelling like a fuel tank. One car was carrying mail, and diesel-soaked Christmas catalogs were strewn around the site of the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Rubber Gloves to Get Quality Standards
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday it will soon impose minimum quality standards for medical gloves worn by health care workers to protect themselves agaist AIDS and other diseases. The federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta recommends that physicians, dentists and other health care workers wear protective rubber or plastic gloves. Under current FDA regulations, manufacturers of medical gloves conduct their own testing. The FDA had no standard it could enforce. New regulations, published in Wednesday's Federal Register and scheduled to go into effect in 90 days, will standardize the testing and define the failure rates, the agency said. It said gloves that do not meet the standards will be seized if necessary to keep them off the market. As part of the new testing, the agency said randomly selected samples of gloves will be examined for tears, holes and any foreign matter embedded in the gloves. The gloves will also be filled with about a quart of water and checked for leaks. Sale for medical uses will be forbidden for batches of gloves if leaks are found in more than 25 per 1,000 for surgeons' gloves and 40 per 1,000 for patient-examination gloves. Surgeons' gloves were given a stricter standard because they are in contact with a patient's blood and other bodily fluids for a longer period of time than those used in examining patients. The Centers for Disease Control knows of 20 published cases in which a health care worker has been infected with the AIDS virus on the job. Most of these were believed to have been accidental needle pricks, but at least four were believed to have been infected when chapped or scratched skin was exposed to the virus.

DOC.HEAD: Old Cowboy Duds Get Recycled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT Melvin to Mervin
DOC.TEXT: Big time, big city customers are paying big bucks for used clothes broken in by real Montana cowboys. A Montana native who's lived in New York City for 30 years says customers at his Whiskey Dust store pay $65 for ``Montana Broke'' jeans. ``Two years ago I decided I wanted to try out the Montana look in New York and it's really taken off,'' Mervin Bendewald said in a telephone interview Tuesday. ``People don't want to wear new boots or jeans and look like a dude. They want them broken in. ... It's a certain look you can't manufacture.'' Bendewald has scouts in Montana, including some of his 26 nieces and nephews, who track down used cowboy clothes. He gets his Montana Broke jeans from Judy McFarlane, who sells the brand from her office in another Manhattan - a tiny town in southwestern Montana, about 15 miles west of Bozeman. McFarlane began her end of the business about a year ago, when she joked to a friend that Easterners were so enamored with Montana that she could even sell them used jeans. Every pair that wears her Montana Broke label has been worn, and often worn out, by a Montana bronc rider, roper, rancher or farm hand, she said. So far she has sold 160 pairs of Montana Brokes to Whiskey Dust and a store in San Francisco. Each comes with a sepia-toned label offering information about the cowboy who wore the pants. All the labels come with this advice: ``In the spirit of our Big Sky cowboys, talk quiet, ride tall and wear your jeans with pride.'' There are a few problems, of course. Most real cowboys are not built like most real New Yorkers. McFarlane said the typical cowboy is a 30-slim. Most New Yorkers are not. ``I try to find pants from steer wrestlers,'' she said. ``Generally, they're brawnier.''

DOC.HEAD: Self-Proclaimed Militia Chief Vows to Prevent Priest's Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 9 bgng `Aristide told' to CORRECT to `Lafontant told...' Picks up 10th pvs, `Lafontant, who...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAP2
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - The self-proclaimed head of the Tonton Macoute militia vowed on Wednesday to prevent a leftist Roman Catholic priest from becoming Haiti's president. Haiti's first democratic national elections since independence are scheduled for Sunday. The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who is adored by the Caribbean country's impoverished masses, is widely viewed as the front-runner. The 37-year-old Aristide, who was ousted from his order for political activism, was denounced by Tonton Macoute chief Roger Lafontant, who called him a menace and an ``ultra-Communist.'' ``We will do everything to prevent this danger. My country will never be delivered to Communism,'' said Lafontant, who himself was barred from contesting the election. Aristide is an advocate of Liberation Theology, which holds that the Roman Catholic church should help the poor better their lives through political action. Lafontant said he was not calling for violence by his forces, but said ``there is always something bad that can happen.'' ``We will do our best to prevent it,'' he said. Aristide, advised of the remarks, said, ``Lafontant has a right to say whatever he wants.'' But, he said: ``The law has to be followed.'' Lafontant told reporters he would ask the police and army to increase security for the balloting. More than 600 international observers, including former President Jimmy Carter and representatives from the United Nations and Organization of American States, will monitor the vote. Lafontant, who was one of 11 candidates disqualified from participating in the election for technical reasons by the independent Electoral Board, fled Haiti after the overthrow of Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier. Lafontant returned to Haiti in July to run for president. A warrant for his arrest accusing him of crimes committed during the Duvalier years has never been served. Lafontant, speaking to reporters at the fortress-like headquarters of his Union for National Reconciliation Party, said he was ``proud'' to be chief of the militia that violently enforced the Duvalier dictatorship for 29 years. ``I am leading the Duvalierists. I'm the chief. I'll never deny I'm a Duvalierist,'' he said. Lafontant blamed Aristide for last week's grenade and gun attack that killed seven people and wounded 50 others as an Aristide campaign rally was breaking up. Aristide blamed the attack on Lafontant and urged the army to arrest him. ``He should be on trial,'' Aristide told reporters. But Lafontant boasted: ``No one can arrest me.'' The capital of Port-au-Prince was calm Wednesday, although many city residents were heading for the interior to avoid possible violence during the elections. At least 34 voters were killed at the polls in Port-au-Prince by army-backed thugs during the 1987 elections. The Electoral Council was pushed aside by the army, which controlled the national elections in January of 1988. Haiti has been wracked by political violence since Jean-Claude Duvalier's departure, which ended nearly three decades of a brutal family reign begun by his father, Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier.

DOC.HEAD: Ol' Blue Eyes' 75th Birthday Celebrated at the `My Way Cafe'
DOC.TEXT: There's nary a corer in the My Way Cafe where your gaze won't meet Ol' Blue Eyes. Frank Sinatra is the appetizer, main course and dessert at this roadside tavern and mini-shrine to the entertainer, who turned 75 Wednesday. ``It didn't start out to be a shrine,'' owner, bartender and chef John Bove said as he prepared for an evening birthday bash. ``I must put up 30 to 50 pieces of memorabilia a year.'' Bove, 54, converted his two-story home 20 miles north of Albany into the cafe seven years ago. He had sold his 150-seat Italian restaurant in nearby Clifton Park and was looking for something a little more intimate, something with a theme. He considered Marilyn Monroe and John Wayne before settling on Sinatra. ``The place itself leaned toward being a roadhouse, and that's where he (Sinatra) started out, playing in little places in New Jersey. It just seemed to fit the bill,'' Bove said. Bove holds a combination My Way anniversary-Christmas-Sinatra party every Dec. 12. The day has always been a big one for his business. Bove expected several hundred people to celebrate Francis Albert's 75th birthday their way. ``It's busy on his birthday every year, but this year it's been crazy,'' Bove said. When he opened the restaurant in 1983, Bove had five Sinatra album covers decorating the walls. He now has more than 100. Sinatra's image covers nearly all available wall space in Bove's three-room establishment. Hundreds of album and magazine covers, song sheets, movie posters, billboards and photographs chart Sinatra's rise from his big band days with Harry James and Tommy Dorsey to ``chairman of the board'' status in the entertainment industry. A white paper silhouette of Sinatra's likeness, complete with glowing blue eyes, hangs near the bar. Most of the items were given to him by friends, relatives and customers. Two-thirds of the songs on the juke box are by Sinatra. When the bar's stereo system is turned on, it plays nothing but Sinatra tapes, said Bove, who has 96 Sinatra albums in his apartment above the restaurant. Each dish Bove prepares is named for a Sinatra song. Diners can start out with the ``Yesterday'' onion soup and ``New York, New York'' chicken wings, work their way through the ``My Way'' prime rib or ``Strangers In The Night'' baked manicotti and top it off with ``The Nearness of You'' strawberry shortcake. The Sinatra motif and music create a mood that attracts people from 23 to 83, mostly couples, Bove said. Their common bond is a love of Sinatra and his music. Most don't care about Sinatra's well-publicized run-ins with the press, the three divorces or the reputed connections to organized crime, he said. ``When you go to see somebody, who really cares who he's with or what he's doing, as long as he's up there entertaining people and making them happy,'' Bove said. Bove has attended five Sinatra concerts, including one in Albany earlier this year when he and his wife Beverly had fourth-row seats. While she got close enough to touch the singer, Bove said he wouldn't know what to say to Sinatra if he ever got the chance. ``But it would be a real pleasure to cook for him. That would make me feel good,'' Bove said.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Charge Gotti With Castellano Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with no bail for Gotti; picks up 9th graf, ``To my ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY30,35
With AM-Gotti Junior
DOC.TEXT: John Gotti, whose acquittals gained him the reputation of ``The Untouchable Don,'' was charged Wednesday with ordering his Mafia boss slain so he could take over the nation's most powerful mob organization. Gotti was charged in a federal racketeering indictment with ordering four murders, including that of reputed Gambino crime family head Paul Castellano and with conspiring to kill a fifth person. The 11-count indictment also accused Gotti of gambling, loansharking, obstruction of justice and tax evasion. Gotti was arrested Tuesday night, as were three other reputed crime figures, including the son of the late Mafia Boss of Bosses Carlo Gambino. Prosecutors called Gotti a danger to the community and said they would seek to have him held without bail. If convicted, the man also known as ``the Dapper Don'' for his expensive suits, would face life in prison without parole. Gotti pleaded innocent at his arraignment Wednesday. He was ordered held without bail. Gotti and his two top associates - underboss Frank ``Frankie Loc'' Locascio and adviser Salvatore ``Sammy Bull'' Gravano - were arrested at Gotti's Manhattan hangout, the Ravenite Social Club in Little Italy. Thomas Gambino, an alleged family ``capo'' or captain, was picked up about the same time when he left the Garment District office of his trucking company, said James M. Fox, head of the FBI's New York office. Gambino, Locascio and Gravano also pleaded innocent. Gambino was released Wednesday on a $500,000 personal recognizance bond. Locascio and Gravano were jailed without bail. A hearing on possible bail for Gotti and the two other defendants was set for Monday. ``To my knowledge, this is the first time that we have taken down the entire hierarchy of an organized-crime family - the boss, the underboss, the consigliere (counselor),'' said Fox. Federal officials say Gotti took over the leadership of the Gambino crime family with the Dec. 16, 1985, assassination of Castellano on the street outside a Manhattan steak house. A bodyguard also was killed. Law enforcers believe Castellano was shot by three gunmen - Anthony Rampino, John Carneglia and Gotti's younger brother Gene, a law-enforcement source said on the condition on anonymity. The three, who have not been charged in the slaying, are in jail on unrelated charges. Gotti, who allegedly headed a crew of Gambino ``soldiers,'' reportedly had Castellano gunned down because of ``Big Paul's'' rule that any member or associate of the Gambino family who was found to be involved in narcotics trafficking would be murdered. At the time of the killing, Castellano himself was on trial on racketeering charges. Law enforcement officials say the organization's sources of income include drug dealing, gambling, extortion, loan sharking, union control, airport rip-offs and domination of New York City's garment district. Gotti's lawyer, Bruce Cutler, maintained his client was the innocent victim of a prosecution vendetta. Gotti has beaten three government cases since 1986. ``It's the same kind of crap that we dealt with in 1986 and 1987. The same kind of Mafia madness, nonsense, that starts with a two-week blitz in the newspapers. I know it's a vendetta. It's happened three times. If that's not a vendetta, I don't know what is,'' Cutler said. Cutler maintains the 50-year-old Gotti is a salesman for a plumbing company and for a company that sells zippers and hangers to the fashion industry. ``His real job is boss of the most powerful crime family in this country. That's his real job and the real source of his income,'' said U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney. ``He's a murderer, he's not a folk hero.'' Gotti has been indicted three times in recent years on a variety of state and federal crimes, but prosecutors have been unable to convict him. The previous state cases against Gotti were an assault in Queens and an assault and conspiracy trial in Manhattan, neither of which was considered a very strong case. The federal case was prepared before Gotti's alleged ascension to mob boss, although the acquittal came after the Castellano slaying. Maloney told reporters it would be different this time. He said the evidence against Gotti includes eyewitnesses and secretly recorded conversations between Gotti and his minions. Gotti, Locascio, 58, and Gravano, 45, each are charged under federal racketeering statutes with murder, gambling, loansharking, obstruction of justice and other crimes. Gambino, 61, is accused of gambling and loansharking. If convicted, Gravano also faces life imprisonment without parole. Locascio faces up to 65 years and Gambino a maximum of 40 years.

DOC.HEAD: Snow In Colorado And Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell over parts of Minnesota and Colorado on Wednesday, but otherwise only light precipitation was scatered over parts of the West. A weak upper-level weather disturbance produced snow over Colorado's ski resort country, with up to a foot of snow forecast in the mountains of the state's southwestern corner. Some places had 3 inches by midday. Colorado State Patrol officials said roads were icy and snowpacked in the southern sections of the state, and adequate snow tires or chains were required on Red Mountain and Wolf Creek passes. The weather change followed on the heels of a heat wave. Earlier this week, the Denver area had unseasonably warm weather with temperatures hitting the high 60s, about 20 degrees above normal, weather officials said. Another upper-level weather disturbance brought snow to northern Minnesota from late Tuesday into Wednesday morning. North-central sections of the state received 4 to 6 inches of snow. Elsewhere in the West, a few snow showers were over Wyoming and eastern Montana. A few light showers were scattered over southern California and southern Arizona, and southern Utah got a few rain and snow showers. Light showers associated with a cold front also spread along the northern Pacific Coast. Strong southwesterly wind prevailed ahead of a cold front in the central part of the nation. Temperatures were in the 50s as far north as lower Michigan at midday. Early afternoon temperatures were in the 20s and 30s in the north central part of the country and in northern New England and upstate New York. Caribou, Maine, had a morning low of 5 above zero. Readings dipped below freezing in the plateau region and the rocky mountain region. Overnight lows in the teens and single digits were reported in parts of Oregon, Idaho and Montana, the National Weather Service said. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was zero at McCall, Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: Immunity Offered to Son of Suspended Navajo Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors in the latest trial of suspended Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald and his co-defendant son moved Wednesday to force the son to testify against his father. Special prosecutor Robert Rothstein submitted a motion to dismiss the conspiracy charge against Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr. and a separate motion that would require him to testify under immunity. Opening statements were presented Tuesday in the trial of the two on charges stemming from the tribe's 1987 purchase of the Big Boquillas Ranch for $33.4 million hours after it had been sold to a third party for $26.25 million. In another development Wednesday, tribal Judge Robert Yazzie granted a prosecution motion and dismissed election-fraud charges against suspended Vice Chairman Johnny Thompson in exchange for his testimony against MacDonald in the Big Boquillas trial and an upcoming one on election-fraud charges. In the Big Boquillas trial, the elder MacDonald is charged with single counts of bribery, fraud and conspiracy and 10 ethics violations. His son, an unemployed lawyer from San Jose, Calif., faces a single conspiracy count. After the motions aimed at the younger MacDonald, Yazzie granted a continuance in the trial until Thursday in order to give defense attorneys time to research immunity laws. MacDonald was suspended by the tribal council, now known as the Navajo Nation Council, on Feb. 17, 1989, after a U.S. Senate committee heard testimony from Rocky MacDonald and others that the elder MacDonald accepted cash payments and other favors from people doing business with the tribe. Thomas Hoidal, an assistant federal public defender who said he has been appointed by the U.S. District Court in Phoenix to represent Rocky MacDonald, appeared in tribal court and expressed concerns as to whether testimony by his client in tribal court could be used against him in federal court. Rothstein said Assistant U.S. Attorney Wallace Kleindieist has agreed to present a letter saying his office will honor a tribal court's grant of immunity and not use that testimony to prosecute Rocky MacDonald in federal court. A federal grand jury in Phoenix has been investigating matters related to the MacDonald administration, though neither MacDonald nor his son have been charged in federal court. Asked later by a reporter whether Rocky MacDonald was prepared to testify against his father, Hoidal replied: ``We'll see.'' Other attorneys declined to comment. The MacDonalds were convicted on Oct. 17 in tribal court of bribery, conspiracy and ethics violations. That trial involved allegations that the elder MacDonald took bribes and kickbacks from businessmen operating on the reservation. The elder MacDonald is also to stand trial Jan. 16 on election fraud charges. Thompson had faced more than 60 counts in that case stemming from the tribe's 1986 election. But, Thompson's legal advocate, Daniel Deschinny, said: ``He was totally unaware of what was happening with the Big Boquillas Ranch and the election of 1986.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 14th graf ``All Told'' to CORRECT numbers flown out in the last few days; ADDs 4 grafs with Hill testimony
DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Accuses Iraq of Blocking Talks
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Wednesday accused Iraq of blocking any agreement to schedule talks more than a few days before a U.N. deadline for withdrawing Iraqi troops from Kuwait. Meanwhile, a U.S.-chartered plane was expected to leave Baghdad, Iraq early Thursday with 15 Americans aboard, the last official flight out for the foreseeable future. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said no decision had been made on whether five American diplomats at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait would be aboard. Boucher said the Iraqi government was refusing to budge from its proposal to have Secretary of State James Baker III visit Baghdad on Jan. 12. The United States has rejected that date, saying it is too close to Jan. 15. The U.N. Security Council has voted to authorize force if the Iraqis have not quit Kuwait by then. President Bush proposed a diplomatic exchange - including a White House meeting with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz - as a last-ditch effort to find a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis, and Iraq accepted the idea. However, Boucher said, ``We have offered 15 dates and Iraq has offered none. ... Iraq continues to block agreement on dates.'' Iraq has suggested that its foreign minister come to Washington to see Bush on Dec. 17. Boucher said the United States would not accept that date unless a date had been fixed for Baker's trip to Iraq. Joseph Wilson, the U.S. charge d'affaires in Baghdad, has been discussing dates with Nizar Hamdoon, Iraq's deputy foreign minister, Boucher said. Hamdoon talked with Wilson most recently on Wednesday by telephone. ``The Iraqis had no new proposals,'' Boucher said.
