Baker noted that ``We have said that we would be willing to go to Baghdad for a meeting on any one of the 15 days between Dec. 20 and Jan. 3 because we think these meetings are important and because we are serious about them.'' Meantime, Boucher said no final decision had been made on whether the five American diplomats at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait would leave on Thursday's flight. An estimated 15 evacuees from Baghdad were planning to be aboard the plane, including one man who was held as a ``human shield'' at a strategic site in Iraq. The Kuwait embassy staff will be allowed to leave when they have determined finally that no Americans who want to get out of the area are left, Boucher said. All told, about 188 Americans have been flown out of Iraq and Kuwait the past few days, he said. They include 70 people who were in hiding, 86 ``human shields'' held at strategic sites in Iraq and 32 private citizens who were at the U.S. embassies in Kuwait or Iraq. Some 500 Americans - mostly children - apparently will stay. If Americans want to leave Kuwait in the future, they will be able to fly by commercial Iraqi carrier to Iraq and then on to Jordan, Boucher said. The spokesman said the former hostages are providing information to U.S. officials. ``We're obviously talking to the people coming out,'' he said. ``We've talked to them during the course of the trip and once they get back here.'' ``We're most interested in what they might know about other Americans,'' he said. On Capitol Hill, a former Reagan administration official told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that any war that breaks out would be seen in the Middle East as a U.S. war against Iraq, and added that the perception could be even worse. ``A number of Americans are concerned that we may end up in this whole affair on the wrong side of history, defending emirs and kings,'' said Richard Murphy, who was assistant secretary of state for the Near East. Across the Capitol, a former Army chief of staff, Gen. Edward C. Meyer, said that if Bush decides to give sanctions a year to 18 months to work, a presidential mobilization of up to one million men and women in the ready reserves would be necessary. ``You can't do it with active forces,'' agreed Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Commission Chosen to Crack Down on `Sleaze'
DOC.TEXT: A commission has been chosen to enforce a presidential order to crack down on pornography, the Soviet culture minister said Wednesday, but he promised it won't be ``a new Inquisition.'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev this month ordered Culture Minister Nikolai Gubenko to form the committee to ``protect public morality'' from pornography. Gubenko said the committee consists of 30 people and includes chiefs of creative unions, state committees, public organizations, representatives of religious movements and prominent cultural figures, the Tass news agency reported. He said it will begin work after its membership is completed next week. In his order, Gorbachev cited public concern about the spread of erotic photos and videos as well as pseudo-medical literature. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness, and a new law on the press has virtually ended censorship, allowed democratic debate to flower and let many new people into the publishing business. But many Soviets find offensive some of the new private publishers' choice of material. Soft-core ``erotica'' has been flourishing in the traditionally puritan Soviet Union. Pinup-style posters and calendrs of naked women are sold openly near the entrances of many Moscow subway stations, sometimes tacked up in full view of commuters. Sex manuals are sold on city streets. Popular movies such as ``Little Vera'' and ``Interdevochka'' (Intergirl) have featured some nudity and explicit scenes, although they were comparatively mild by Western standards. Soviet television also broadcasts movies from other countries that are somewhat more explicit than those shown on American TV. Tass headlined its story on the commission's meeting Wednesday, ``Soviet Union Prepares to Clamp Down on Sleaze.'' Its report said the ``emancipation of public morals and the freedom of commercial activities have had a negative impact on the moral health of Soviet society. ``It is necessary to stop the squall of pornography, pseudo-medical literature, erotic films and propaganda of violence and cruelty.'' The agency said the commission will study the experience of countries such as Denmark, Sweden, France, the United States and Germany in fighting pornography. ``In order to solve this problem, we won't resort to tough measures, for instance, like in China,'' Tass quoted Gubenko as saying. China this year launched a widespread campaign that meted out harsh penalties for those convicted of disseminating pornography. ``We have no plan to launch a new Inquisition here,'' he said. Gubenko told Soviet TV that commission priorities will be to ``work out mechanisms to regulate processes in the framework of culturally traditional and religious coloring of various territories of our country.'' Asked if the commission will focus on barring certain materials, Gubenko replied: ``Not at all, otherwise we would cut our own throat as far as the freedom of information is concerned.'' ``An adult person who has access to all kinds of information - it's their personal affair,'' he said. ``We are talking about the younger generation, which we must protect from the danger of destroying its psyche.'' Gubenko said the Soviet parliament and the president, not his commission, probably would be the final authority.

DOC.HEAD: Remains of Two MIA Vietnam Servicemen Identified
DOC.TEXT: The remains of two servicemen who had been listed as missing in action in Vietnam have been identified, the Pentagon said Wednesday. The remains of Air Force Lt. Col. William R. Andrews and Navy Lt. Cmdr. Frederick W. Wright III were among those of 20 others repatriated by Vietnam in September. One other set of remains was identified earlier. The Pentagon said the remains of Andrews and Wright would leave Hickam Air Force Base in Hawaii with a full honors ceremony Thursday and be flown to Travis Air Force Base in California. Andrews, of Eugene, Ore., was reported missing in action Oct. 5, 1966; Wright, of Haworth, N.J., on Nov. 10, 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Drugs Overshadow Other Problems for Young People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6:30 p.m. EST, time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Young people see drugs as by far their generation's No. 1 problem, and 77 percent favor random employee drug testing in a national poll released Wednesday. The Gallup Organization asked people ages 16-24 what they think is the biggest problem facing the youth of today, and 58 percent named drugs. No other issue was named by more than 5 percent. When asked what is the biggest problem facing the United States as a whole, the young people mentioned a variety. Among them were: drugs, 23 percent; federal deficit or economy 16 percent; welfare, poverty, homelessness, 9 percent; environment, pollution, 8 percent. Psychologist and author David Elkind said the results confirmed what he had observed as a professor of child study at Tufts University. ``Kids are very concerned about drugs and they're very concerned about the world we live in today,'' he said. ``Kids no longer see this idea of progress, that the world is getting better.'' The young people were asked about problems such as illegal drug use and the environment, and whether each had gotten better, stayed about the same or gotten worse over the last five years. The predominant answer was ``worse'' - 73 percent felt the country was losing ground on drugs, 72 percent on AIDS, 63 percent on the environment. But 72 percent thought the United States had gotten better or stayed the same in literacy. Fifty-three percent saw improvement toward world peace. But the poll was conducted in June and July, before the Persian Gulf crisis. The poll was commissioned by Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. Inc. and included a marketing survey on the purchase of cassette tapes and compact discs. In a related issue question, 64 percent said they thought prerecorded music should have warning labels regarding the lyrics. Gallup conducted the poll by phone, reaching 1,003 young people in a random sample with a margin of error of just over 3 percentage points in either direction.

DOC.HEAD: Scrolls Editor's Dismissal Tied To Anti-Semitic Remarks
DOC.TEXT: A Harvard divinity professor's anti-Semitic remarks in an Israeli newspaper contributed to his dismissal as chief editor of the Dead Sea Scrolls project, his colleagues said Wednesday. But others said John Strugnell was removed last week because of longstanding problems managing the project's scholars, who still haven't published up to 45 percent of the scrolls nearly four decades after they were discovered. The scholars voted to dismiss Strugnell last week, one month after appointing a co-editor to share his duties, said Eugene Ulrich, a member of the editing team and a University of Notre Dame theology professor. ``The main reason for the removal was his health,'' Ulrich said. But Ulrich acknowledged Wednesday that Strugnell's anti-Jewish remarks in an interview with Haaretz, a Tel Aviv newspaper, ``all the more confirmed that the decision was a correct one.'' Strugnell, a Roman Catholic, was quoted in the interview as saying: ``I think that Judaism is a racist religion. It is a religion for a race, just like Hinduism. Something very primitive ... what I would call folklore.'' He said Judaism was ``a folk religion. It's not a higher religion.'' He suggested that all Jews abandon their beliefs and convert to Christianity. The interview, which appeared in Hebrew on Nov. 9 and will appear next month in the English-language Biblical Archaeology Review, also quotes Strugnell as saying of Judaism: ``It's a horrible religion. It's a Christian heresy and we deal with our heretics in different ways.'' Asked if his views affected his work on the Scrolls, which trace the evolution of modern Judaism, Strugnell said: ``I don't, when I'm working on a Qumran (area where scrolls were found) text, think how stupid and wrong the Jews were. I'm concerned with trying to find out what a document is saying in its context.'' Strugnell insisted he had nothing against Jews, saying ``I don't love or hate Jews more than I love or hate anybody else.'' The New York Times on Wednesday quoted Frank Moore Cross, another Harvard scholar working on the scrolls, as saying the interview ``certainly'' contributed to Strugnell's dismissal. Ulrich, who was appointed as one of three editors to replace Strugnell, called the remarks ``highly and inflammatorily anti-Semitic.'' But Ulrich also said he doesn't believe Strugnell meant what he said. ``I have known John for 20 years and I've never heard him say anything like that,'' Ulrich said. Strugnell, 60, who has been editor since 1987, has been unavailable for comment. Harvard spokesman Peter Costa said he was in an unidentified hospital for treatment of an undisclosed illness. Ulrich, however, said Strugnell told him Sunday ``he does not see it as all over and done with.'' The Dead Sea Scrolls were discovered by Bedouin shepherds in 1947 in a cave in what is now the Israeli-occupied West Bank. They contain some of the earliest known biblical texts, including copies of the Old Testament dating to the second and third century B.C. They are kept at the Rockefeller Museum in Jerusalem. Scholars say the 800 scrolls shed light on the life of the Essenes, an ancient sect of Jews, as well as the roots of early Christianity. Strugnell has been criticized for the scholars' slow pace in publishing the scrolls, some of which were found in fragments as small as a dime. ``It's been very clear for awhile that John has not been moving quickly enough,'' said New York University professor Larry Schiffman, a Dead Sea Scrolls scholar who is not on the editing team. Schiffman said Wednesday poor management was the real reason behind Strugnell's dismissal, although the anti-Jewish remarks didn't help. Hershel Shanks, editor of Biblical Archaeology Review, dismissed the explanation that Strugnell was fired for health problems. ``You don't fire a man because he's ill,'' Shanks said. ``It's because they don't want to be associated with an anti-Semite.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Panel Seeks to Test 3-year-olds
DOC.TEXT: A congressionally mandated study panel is preparing to recommend nationwide testing of 3-year-olds and 6-year-olds, an Education Department official said Wednesday. Critics said the tests might not be reliable or useful for the younger children. The Special Study Panel on Education Indicators concluded two days of meetings in Bethesda, Md. after developing a draft report, said John Ralph, study director. The panel, formed a year ago to suggest to Congress how to update indicators that are used to measure education quality, operates within the National Center for Education Statistics, part of the Education Department. The most controversial item under consideration by the 19-member group is the proposal to assess a sampling of 6-year-olds to determine how prepared they are to enter school and to assess 3-year-olds so educators can identify and measure things that put them at risk of failure in school. The proposal was first reported by the trade publication, Education Daily. The group will meet again early next year to refine its report before submitting it to Congress in May. ``We're extremely concerned about the plan for a nationwide assessment of 3-year-olds,'' said Barbara Willer of the National Association for the Education of Young Children. The study group, she said, appears to be unaware of the problems of testing young children. She said the items they want to assess ``are virtually impossible to assess, all of these are emerging areas'' for testing in 3-year-olds, and ``to test them doesn't seem to be a wise use of money.'' Roy Truby, executive director of the governing board of the National Assessment of Educational Progress, said, ``I don't know of any real good assessments or valid tests for 3-year-olds that can be given to large samples of students.'' The sampling approach suggested by the study group is similar to that used by the national assessment, popularly called ``the Nation's Report Card'' because it measures what students know in grades four, eight and 12 and what skills they possess. ``Society can undertake early preventive measures that minimize the deficits these children might carry with them into their subsequent educational experiences,'' said the study group's draft report. The early testing can help determine ``the sources of educational inequities near their roots, rather than after children have already spent time in elementary school.'' ``Separate information may also be useful for the subgroups of children that differ in the number of parents living in the household, maternal education levels, preschool-kindergarten experiences, and geographic regions,'' said the report. It said testing of 3-year-olds and 6-year-olds must measure reading and mathematics skills such as pattern recognition, vocabulary, knowledge of concepts such as far and near and motor skills, attitudes and social behavior.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Gambling Arms Treaty Will Be Ready In Time
With AM-US-Soviet Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is gambling that a new treaty with the Soviet Union will be ready for signing when he goes to Moscow in February for a summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. After eight years of negotiations and several crash efforts, the treaty to slice long-range nuclear bombers, missilesand submarines on both sides by about 30 percent remains elusive. Bush had made completion of the treaty a precondition for going to Moscow. And yet he set Feb. 11-13 as the date to meet with Gorbachev with the accord still incomplete. A senior U.S. official said the President had never ruled out setting a date before the treaty was done. Asked if it would be ready by the time he saw Gorbachev, the official, who insisted on anonymity, said: ``Nobody can be certain. Things can always come up. The assumption is we have made progress and are very hopeful we will have a treaty to sign. There are no guarantees.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze tackled some of the remaining issues at a two-day meeting in Houston that ended Tuesday night. ``We made some very good progress in Houston,'' Baker said Wednesday. ``There are still some issues that remain.'' They are mostly technical, Baker said. He singled out the monitoring of solid rocket and missile assembly facilities. Others include a Soviet demand to inspect U.S. B-2 bomber plants and how much information from missile flight tests will be exchanged. In recent weeks some other nagging issues were resolved. These include some kinds of restrictions to be imposed on Soviet SS-18 missile tests and leeway for the United States to divert some Trident submarine technology to Britain. Even after all the problems are resolved it will take about three weeks to put the provisions in treaty language - in English and in Russian. Initially, Bush hoped the treaty would be ready by January. By scheduling the summit for February he not only leaves more room for the details to be worked out. It also means the President will not be in Moscow when the crisis in the Persian Gulf could reach the boiling point. The U.N. Security Council, at the urging of the administration, has set Jan. 15 as the deadline for Iraq to quit Kuwait or risk war. Gorbachev has supported the resolution threatening force as well as a trade embargo and other sanctions aimed at President Saddam Hussein. And yet the Soviet leader has sought to stress seeking a diplomatic way out of the dispute over Iraq's seizure of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Few Whales Survive Mass Beaching, But Scientists Take Comfort That Any Did
LaserPhoto HYS2
DOC.TEXT: Forty-three of 53 pilot whales that ran aground on a Cape Cod beach died, but scientists took solace Wednesday from the few they managed to save. Eight of the whales that were discovered beached Tuesday on Squaw Island peninsula were returned to the sea. Two were taken to the New England Aquarium in Boston. Of 315 whales previously stranded on area beaches over the past 10 years, only three are known to have survived and successfully returned to sea. Scientists began dissecting the carcasses of the dead whales hauled to a secluded corner of the town dump but held out little hope that they might explain the mysterious occasional tendency of the whales to beach themselves. ``We're not really building toward the ultimate answer,'' said Greg Early, associate curator for animal care at the New England Aquarium and coordinator of the rescue effort. Blood from the 43 whales, many of which were put to death to end their misery, will be checked for contamination that might have caused the whales to become disoriented. Biologists said previous examinations of beached whales have provided few clues. They theorize that whales may be disoriented by the gentle slopes of sandy beaches, or by extreme high tides like those that battered Cape Cod last week, or that diseased male guide whales lead the rest to shore, or the whales, which are descended from land-based creatures, may follow their instincts when in danger and head inland. The mass beaching was the first in three years on Cape Cod. The biggest earlier beaching was of 97 whales in Eastham in 1984. The three whales known to have survived were taken to the New England Aquarium and stabilized before being released. Predicting that the high tides and full moon of last week might disorient some whales and cause a stranding, experts called an alert over the weekend and moved their research boat from its berth less than a mile from Squaw Island to Sesuit, on Cape Cod's bay side. The research boat is equipped to play the sounds of whales feeding underwater to try to lure the animals away from shore. But the boat was positioned exactly opposite of where the stranding ultimately happened. ``We were half right,'' Dave Wiley, co-coordinator of the Cape Cod Stranding Network, said Wednesday. Three other pilot whales were stranded on Cape Cod on Tuesday and Wednesday in unrelated incidents. Only one survived.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Recall Leader Hangs Self
DOC.TEXT: Peter Goelden, who ran for governor in 1987 as an independent, apparently hanged himself, police said. He was 48. The body was found Tuesday night, hanging from the middle of the showroom in a Shreveport carpet store, where Goelden worked as a salesman, police said. No suicide note was found at the store, police said. Anger over nearly $700 million in new taxes prompted Goelden to start a recall drive in 1984 against Democrat Edwin Edwards, who was then governor. He fell 35,000 signatures short of the 750,000 needed for a recall election. Goelden was among seven people who ran against Edwards in the 1987 election won by Democrat Gov. Buddy Roemer.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Soviet Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``I'm pleased with the great progress we've made on START and hopeful that we'll be ready to sign a treaty.'' President Bush, announcing that he and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet in February. --- ``The Soviet Union is facing tough times, difficult times. But I believe that this is good reason to act now in order to help the Soviet Union stay the course of democratization and to undertake market reforms.'' President Bush, waiving trade restrictions against the Soviet Union through June 1991. --- ``I know it was not easy for the president to take that decision, and therefore we very much appreciate the president's decision ... The Soviet people will cope with their problems.'' - Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. --- ``It is not a payoff or a payback for the cooperation we've seen on the gulf crisis.'' - Secretary of State James A. Baker III, on the U.S. decision to waive trade restrictions against the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Education Secretary Resigns; Sources Say He Was Fired
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with sources saying Cavazos will not return to Washington, reasons for firing, ADDS Lynn Martin as possible replacement candidate. Picks up 14th graf pvs `Cavazos, whose ...'
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos, the nation's first Hispanic-American Cabinet member, resigned without explanation Wednesday and a White House source said he had been fired. The source, who insisted on anonymity, said Chief of Staff John H. Sununu personally told Cavazos about the firing Tuesday. In his two years as Education Secretary, Cavazos was best known for promoting the idea of allowing parents to decide where to send their children to school. He also advocated bilingual education. But another official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said Cavazos was seen as lacking dynamism and not making enough progress in education, an area Bush designated as a high priority for his administration. A White House source said Cavazos was out of town and had let it be known he would not be back, not even for the kind of personal departure appearance that Bush made with the other top officials who have left his administration. Other administration sources said Cavazos, 63, had tired of criticism from the White House and elsewhere. Cavazos himself gave neither a reason for his resignation nor details about his future plans, said Education Department spokeswoman Etta Fielek. The resignation was announced at a Cabinet meeting, which Cavazos didn't attend. Fielek said Cavazos didn't attend the meeting because ``he's not very good at farewells and he thought this is the most comfortable way to do it.'' Cavazos is the third major administration official to resign since October. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole quit to join the American Red Cross and William Bennett, head of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, stepped down and later was named head of the Republican National Committee. ``Basically, it would be hard to tell what would have been different if we hadn't had a secretary of education at all during this period of time,'' said longtime critic Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers. ``I hope they don't keep the position vacant for another three years.'' But Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, said Cavazos ``proved to be a decent man with the interest of America's children at heart.'' The resignation is effective Saturday, with Deputy Education Secretary Ted Sanders serving as acting head of the department. Sources said that Sanders has been lobbying for Cavazos' position. Also considered to be possible successors are Lynne Cheney, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities; former New Jersey Gov. Thomas Kean; Rep. Patricia Saiki, a former schoolteacher who lost her November bid to unseat Sen. Daniel Akaka, D-Hawaii; and Rep. Lynn Martin, who also has been mentioned as a possible successor to Mrs. Dole. Cavazos, whose father was a cattle foreman at the King Ranch in Texas, earned a bachelor's degree in zoology and a master's degree in cytology at Texas Technological College, which later became Texas Tech University. He received a doctorate in physiology from Iowa State University in 1954. Cavazos was president of Texas Tech when he became the first Hispanic Cabinet official in the waning days of the Reagan administration. Bush kept him in the job. ``For more than two years, and under two presidents, you have distinguished yourself through your devotion to improving the education of our nation's children,'' Bush said in a letter accepting Cavazos' resignation. Cavazos said in his letter that he was proud of the contributions he made in ``expanding choice in education, promoting the executive order on excellence in education for Hispanic Americans, and raising awareness of the growing diversity of America's student population.'' Cavazos was a far less controversial secretary of education than Bennett, his predecessor, who warred with teacher unions and was an acerbic critic of America's universities. Cavazos made peace with the National Education Association and other leading groups in the education establishment. But Antonio Rigual, president of the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities, said it was widely known that the administration wasn't supportive of Cavazos because ``he just wasn't fitting the mold that the administration wanted to head the Education Department.'' Rep. William D. Ford, D-Mich., incoming chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor, said he had ``remarkably little contact'' with Cavazos. But Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah, ranking Republican on the Senate Education and Labor Committee, said Cavazos ``brought increased visibility to the importance of education for all Americans.'' Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Education, Arts and Humanities, said Cavazos' ``commitment to educational opportunities for minorities and the poor has been without question.'' Cavazos was only the fourth person to be secretary of education. The post was created when education was elevated to Cabinet status in 1980 during the Carter administration.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Purchasing Chief Quits; Criticized In Stealth Mismangement Report
DOC.TEXT: John A. Betti, the Pentagon's top procurement official who was roundly criticized last week in an internal report on mismanagement in a $50 billion stealth aircraft program, said Wednesday he was resigning. Betti, a former Ford Motor Co. executive who had been undersecretary of defense for acquisition for 16 months, said in his letter of resignation he would leave effective Dec. 31 so he would not be covered by new ethics laws next year that impose tougher post-employment restrictions on former government officials. In his letter of resignation, Betti made no mention of the unfolding story of mismanagement in the development of the Navy's A-12 attack plane. Speaking privately, two Pentagon officials said Betti had intended to leave soon anyway but the timing of his announcement was connected to the recent revelations about the A-12 being developed by McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp. One of the two said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's plans to slash the responsibilities of the job also led Betti to quit. A Navy admiral was forced to retire last week and two other officers were reassigned after disclosure that they had failed to pass word up the chain of command about cost increases and schedule delays in the A-12. The A-12, called the Avenger, is a radar-evading ``stealth'' plane supposed to replace the elderly A-6 aboard carriers starting in 1995. Betti's office referred calls to a Defense Department spokeswoman, who said she had no information on whether Betti already had lined up a new job. In a written statement, Betti said he believed he had considerably improved the Pentagon's oft-criticized purchasing system. But he also said ``substantive, lasting improvements in defense acquisition will not occur overnight. ``Rather it will be a long, slow and arduous process requiring patience and constancy of purpose.'' Cheney, in a letter accepting the resignation, also made no mention of the A-12 controversy and told Betti ``Your dedicated and successful efforts to strengthen the acquisition process ... have been instrumental in maintaining a strong national defense.'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said Betti's resignation ``shows how resistant the Pentagon is to change.'' Aspin said the job was created by Congress ``to buy weapons that work on time and at cost,'' but was soon to be vacant for the third time in four years. Rep. John Conyers Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the Government Operations Committee, said the resignation ``would not put an end to the cozy old-boy's network at the Pentagon, where problems are swept under the rug while airplanes crash and contractors reap unearned billions.'' The A-12 development program is now a year behind schedule and 20 percent over the planned $4.7 billion cost. Defense Department Inspector General Susan J. Crawford said in a report last week that word of the problems didn't reach Cheney and other top Pentagon officials in large part because the contractors had control over the work done by government inspectors. But she also said Betti had been informed of some of the problems by a deputy but ``failed to report the conclusions reached by his own staff regarding the A-12.'' ``Mr. Betti relied on general assurances, which he invited, from the contractor and prior Navy assurances that the A-12 development contract would be completed within ceiling costs,'' Crawford's report said. ``We find Mr. Betti's failure especially troublesome in view of a prior warning.'' The A-12 controversy was not the first time Betti has faced criticism for his office's policies. In July, Betti faced hostile questioning from a members of a congressional panel who demanded he accept a Justice Department recommendation that Northrop Corp. be barred from Pentagon business for its criminal fraud conviction on charges it faked tests involving nuclear cruise missiles. Betti rejected the demands but admitted he had never reviewed evidence from several federal investigations of Northrop's conduct. In the same testimony he also acknowledged he was not aware the military had repeatedly waived contract requirements for cruise missiles, even after allegations of misconduct arose and a federal prosecutor warned that such waivers could harm the government's case against Northrop. ``You don't know what your managers are doing, your managers don't know what Northrop is doing, your costs are going up and you have criminal investigations going on,'' Committee Chairman Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., said at the July hearing. ``I am worried that no one knows what is going on.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Burlingame-dated item in AM-People to CORRECT dateline to San Francisco, spelling of O'Neal, sted O'Neil; UPDATES throughout with additional airline comment and McEnroe's whereabouts unknown. A version also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: John McEnroe, the tennis world's notorious bad boy, apparently got as upset at missing a connecting flight to Hawaii on Wednesday as he does at missing a serve. McEnroe and two gate agents were escorted to the San Francisco Airport police station after an apparent shouting and shoving match, said airport police Sgt. Gary O'Donnell. McEnroe was traveling with his wife, actress Tatum O'Neal, their two children and a nanny, O'Donnell said. It was evident after about 45 minutes that neither side wanted to pursue the incident, he said. United spokeswoman Sara Dornacker refused to confirm the police account, saying only that there was ``an incident'' after the McEnroe party missed Flight 31 from San Francisco to Kona. McEnroe was booked on a later United flight to Hawaii, she said. The airline ``has not signed any complaint or pressed any charges in this matter, and we do not intend to,'' Dornacker said. Dornacker said the flight was held several minutes to wait for McEnroe and his party. The tennis star couldn't be reached for comment on the incident. ornacker wouldn't say what flight he was traveling on and his whereabouts were unknown.

DOC.HEAD: Small Florida Town Faces Indictment
DOC.TEXT: Already grappling with debt and governmental problems, this beleaguered town of 1,650 is under federal investigation of its sewage plant that could lead to indictment. ``Obviously the whole town can't be put in jail,'' town attorney Eugene E. Waldron said Tuesday. ``But this could result in substantial penalties on the town.'' Zolfo Springs received the latest bad news Monday night, when Waldron told other town officials he had been summoned to a ``pre-indictment'' conference in Tampa. Waldron said he expects to be informed at the Friday conference of possible charges the town faces in connection with its lone sewer plant. He believes the hamlet could be indicted as a corporation. The charges would be based on intentional environmental violations at the plant, Waldron said. ``Certainly, we deny it,'' Waldron said. He wouldn't comment on whether treated sewage was flowing into a nearby river, as state inspectors have claimed. Problems at the plant have prompted the town, about 70 miles southeast of Tampa, to ban new residential or commercial construction since 1989. The plant can't handle the extra sewage, engineers say. The $3.2 million plant, built with federal Farmer's Home Administration grants and loans, began operation in 1987. Within a year, the U.S. Department of Agriculture began looking into its operation. Florida Department of Environmental Regulation inspectors have said they discovered that treated sewage discharge from the plant was flowing into a tributary of the Peace River. The discharge was supposed to be absorbed into soil at the site. Steve Thompson, one of the state inspectors, said last week he had appeared before a federal grand jury in Tampa to answer questions about the plant. Bob Peters, who was on the Zolfo Springs Town Council at the time the plant was being built, also said he testified before the panel. Assistant U.S. Attorney Robert Munk would not comment. Federal law prohibits his discussing grand jury matters. Cost overruns from the plant were a major reason the town ran out of money last year and was forced to declare a financial emergency. The mayor and most of the town council resigned in the wake of the problems and November's municipal election had to be delayed because not enough candidates had signed up to run.

DOC.HEAD: Want to See Santa? Let Me Pencil You In
DOC.TEXT: Santa is such a busy man these days his helpers at one downtown department store have resorted to scheduling appointments to see him. If the wait to see Kris Kringle at Frederick & Nelson is longer than 20 minutes ``the Santa Claus System'' kicks in, store spokesman Dave Fisher said. Parents are given a coupon assigning their children a time to sit on the old man's lap. ``If it's 10:30 a.m., you might welcome the chance to do some shopping,'' Fisher said. ``When you return, you show your coupon and get in the right position in line.'' Fisher said appointments aren't necessary most of the time, but the wait can be an hour or two on Friday nights and weekends. One of Santa's red-suited helpers, who gave her name only as Kathryn, said the appointments appeal to people who would rather shop and eat lunch than stand in the rain. Some people complain ``because they like the traditional way of standing in line,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Chrismas Carols Banned on Radio Program for Gulf Troops
DOC.TEXT: A British forces radio station being started to cheer up troops in the Gulf has barred Christmas carols from its airwaves to avoid offending the Moslems. The British Forces Broadcasting Service has ruled out religious programs and Christian references - including carols. Chris Russell, in charge of starting BFBS Middle East on Dec. 17, said: ``In deference to the host nation, Saudi Arabia, we are making one or two adjustments to our normal output. ``For instance, there will be no religious broadcasting, and no Christmas carols with overtly Christian words. But there will be plenty of seasonal music and lots of laughs.'' The Ministry of Defense is financing the $161,500 radio station that will transmit a mix of entertainment, news and features on the VHF waveband. Initial broadcasts will be from Al Jubayl, where Britain's Desert Rats soldiers are based, and have a range of about 30 miles. Later, more transmission sites will be set up for forces closer to the Kuwaiti border, on guard for possible action against Iraqi troops in occupied Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Salvador Fighting Kills 51; Helicopter Forced Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with later Honduran developments, specify six dead in Jiquilisco. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels forced down a government helicopter Wednesday in a series of attacks that left at least 51 dead. The armed forces said the heaviest combat was in the eastern provinces of San Miguel and Usulutan. Sporadic fighting continued throughout the day. Honduras said about 200 Salvadoran soldiers, some seriously wounded, crossed its border after a battle with the rebels on Salvadoran territory. Honduran Foreign Minister Mario Carias Zapata said U.N. military observers were sent to the area to verify the incident and provide assistance. Rebels did not pursue the soldiers into Honduras, he said. The incident has been reported to the Salvadoran government, and the troops will be sent home, the ministry said. The ministry also said that Miguel Saenz, a senior official of the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, had scheduled a meeting with President Rafael Callejas to discuss the incident. Salvadoran military officials were not available for comment. The FMLN attacks began with a rebel assault Tuesday night on army positions on the fringes of San Jorge, 95 miles southeast of San Salvador. The army said 11 soldiers and 30 guerrillas died in the San Jorge fighting. The rebels' clandestine Radio Venceremos said guerrilla ground fire forced down a government UH-1H helicopter early Wednesday near the Honduran border. The armed forces said the helicopter was only slightly damaged but acknowledged that one gunner was killed and the pilot, co-pilot and a second gunner were wounded. The FMLN also attacked an army garrison 45 miles north of the capital in Chalatenango. The military said the rebel mortars fell short, hitting the nearby City Hall and four adjacent houses instead. There were no reports of casualties. The rebels wounded two soldiers in an attack on a nearby outpost, the armed forces said. Radio Venceremos said FMLN fighters captured 11 soldiers near Chalatenango and gave the soldiers' names. The armed forces refused to comment. Guerrillas also attacked the 3rd Infantry Brigade in San Miguel, 100 miles east of the capita, on Wednesday morning, and the armed forces said three soldiers were killed and 11 wounded. In the capital, rebel explosives exploded at four bank branches Wednesday, causing substantial damage but no casualties. The armed forces said rebels halted morning traffic on the international highway on the outskirts of Santa Tecla, 10 miles from the capital; burned a bus and flattened the tires of dozens of vehicles. Three soldiers and three guerrillas were killed in Jiquilisco, 75 miles southeast of San Salvador, the army said. In San Vicente, 37 miles east of San Salvador, 10 soldiers and eight guerrillas were wounded, the armed forces said. Rebel radio said 69 soldiers were killed or wounded in heavy fighting in Usulutan province. The armed forces gave no province-wide count. The FMLN began stepping up the pace of combat Nov. 20 in what it said was a campaign to force the right-wing government into concessions at the negotiating table and punish the armed forces for human rights abuses. At least 73,000 people - many of them civilians killed by military-linked death squads - have died in more than a decade of war between the rebels and a succession of U.S.-backed governments in this Central American nation of more than 5.5 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Leaves 6 Missing, High Winds Blow Little Auks Off Course
DOC.TEXT: Fierce northerly winds Wednesday blew a flock of arctic seabirds over Britain, one of the largest movements of little auks ever recorded here. Little auks, relatives of guillemots and puffins, were spotted flying in an almost continuous stream off Whitburn, Tyne and Wear in northeast England near the Scottish border. ``This is one of the greatest movements of these normally scarce visitors to British waters ever recorded,'' said Peter Collins, the National Trust warden at Whitburn. Almost 4,000 little auks were spotted in five hours, and birdwatchers manning Whitburn Observatory said they may have missed many more flying low among the waves. The birding report came as gales swept the North Sea on Wednesday, capsizing a fishing boat with six men aboard, threatening oil rig crews and driving mountainous waves onto Britain's east coast. The storm followed weekend snowstorms that buffeted Britain and much of Europe, leaving about 20 people dead, stranding hundreds of travelers and downing power lines supplying thousands of homes. Flood alerts were issued along the east coast on Wednesday. Helicopters lifted oil workers off wind-lashed rigs miles from the coast, but after a day-long search the Scottish coast guard called off efforts to find the six missing fishermen - three of them brothers. There was no hope of finding them alive, a spokesman said. Coast guard spokesman Robert Crowther at Lerwick in the Shetland Islands north of Scotland, said the 68-ton fishing boat Premier, registered at Inverness, had been sighted 30 miles out to sea, capsized and with an empty life raft nearby.

DOC.HEAD: Judge To Rule in Case of Comatose Woman
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Cruzan's parents will find out Friday whether a county judge will allow a halt to their comatose daughter's food and water so she can die. The U.S. Supreme Court cleared the way in June in its first right-to-die decision by ruling that Missouri could keep a patient on life support in the absence of ``clear and convincing'' evidence the person would want to die. Probate Judge Charles Teel announced Wednesday he will hand down his decision in Carthage, in southwest Missouri, on Friday. Ms. Cruzan, 33, has been hospitalized in a persistent vegetative state with no hope of recovery since a 1983 car accident. She is kept alive by feedings through a stomach tube at the state-run Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon. Last month, three people told Teel they believe Ms. Cruzan would rather die than live in her current condition. They based their comments on statements they said Ms. Cruzan made between 1978 and 1982. The state was dropped from the case by Teel in October at the request of Missouri Attorney General William Webster, who said the state has ``no recognizable legal interest.'' The woman's court-appointed guardian, Carthage attorney Thad McCanse, has sided with the parents, Joe and Joyce Cruzan of Carterville, saying that allowing Ms. Cruzan to die would be in her best interest.

DOC.HEAD: American, Soviet Scientists Sign Agreement For Vaccine Research
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Encephalitides in 11th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Army has signed a pact with Soviet scientists to develop a vaccine to combat hemorrhagic fever, a deadly disease found in Asia, the Soviet Union and elsewhere, the military said Wednesday. It is the first agreement of its kind between Army medical researchers and a Soviet scientific agency. Army scientists have developed a vaccine that they believe will work against hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome. Under the agreement, Soviet scientists will work with them to refine the vaccine and test it on thousands of volunteers. ``This kind of collaboration is another confirmation of the openness that is developing and the willingness to draw closer together on scientific matters and other things,'' said Col. Thomas Monath, chief of virology at the U.S. Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases. The Fort Detrick institute is the Army's lead laboratory in medical defense against biological weapons, but hemorrhagic fever is not considered a biological warfare threat, Monath said. The Army would use the vaccine to protect soldiers deployed in parts of the world where the disease is prevalent. The World Health Organization estimates that 100,000 to 500,000 cases of the disease occur each year. The disease is a major health problem in the Soviet Union, Asia and Scandinavia, Monath said. Significant outbreaks have been reported in parts of Eastern Europe. Thousands of U.S. soldiers contracted the disease during the Korean War. Fewer American soldiers die of it today, but the potential for losses exists if troops are deployed in areas where the disease is widespread, Monath said. In 1987, 18 U.S. Marines contracted the disease in Korea; two died. Hemorrhagic fever produces flu-like symptoms and low blood pressure. In its most serious stages, the disease causes kidney problems and internal bleeding in the brain, lungs and digestive system. The disease is spread by rodents, Monath said. It is found in airborne dust contaminated by rodent urine. Fort Detrick researchers will work with about 10 scientists at the Institute of Poliomyelitis and Viral Encephalitides. The institute is part of the Academy of Medical Sciences, a government agency for medical research in Moscow. Tests to determine whether the vaccine is safe and effective will be conducted on rats and monkeys at Fort Detrick for at least six months, Monath said. After that, the vaccine will be tested on up to 12 human volunteers at Fort Detrick, he said. It will then be tested in Bashkiria, Siberia, where most cases in the Soviet Union are found. Researchers at Fort Detrick plan to travel to the Soviet Union next spring to prepare for trials using placebos and the vaccine. The trials will involve as many as several thousand volunteers. Testing in the Soviet Union could begin as early as 1992, Monath said.

DOC.HEAD: Family of Slain Tourist Files Notice of Lawsuit Against City
DOC.TEXT: The family of Brian Watkins, the Utah tourist slain in a subway mugging last summer, has notified the city it intends to file a lawsuit seeking $100 million, the comptroller's office said Wednesday. The notice said the city and the Transit Authority, which oversees the subways, failed to provide ``a competent, adequate and safe place for the general riding public'' the night Watkins was killed. Watkins, 22, of Provo, Utah, was on an annual trip to the U.S. Open tennis tournament with his family when they were mugged Sept. 2 in a subway station by a group of youths. Watkins interceded when one youth punched his mother in the face. He was stabbed in the chest and died a short time later. Eight suspects have been arrested and charged with murder. Watkins' death capped a summer of seemingly escalating random violence and helped trigger Mayor David Dinkins campaign to hire thousands of new police officers. The notice of intent to sue also said the city Emergency Medical Service was negligent in its response and treatment of Watkins. The notice was received by Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman's office Nov. 23. The family's attorney, Charles S. Brofman of Carmel, was ou of his office Wednesday and could not be reached for comment on when the lawsuit would be filed, his secretary said. The family has until December 1991 to file suit.

DOC.HEAD: Sweden Moves Toward EC Membership
DOC.TEXT: Parliament gave the government the green light on Wednesday to apply to join the European Community next year, under a timetable that could make Sweden a member by 1995. The move increased pressure in Norway and Finland to join, too. ``Only as a member can our country fully participate and have an influence on the EC cooperation,'' the parliamentary majority said in a statement. ``A Swedish membership in the EC, while still keeping Sweden's policy of neutrality, is in accordance with our country's national interests.'' Present members of the world's biggest trading bloc are Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Britain, Spain and Portugal. Spain and Portugal, the last additions, joied in 1986. EC Commission president Jacques Delors says the bloc will not expand before 1993. By then, the existing members are to have completed consolidating their economies into a single market. ``Norway has to move together with Sweden in its European policies,'' Jan. P. Syse, Norway's Conservative leader and former prime minister said in reaction to Wednesday's news. ``An EC with Sweden as a member will move Scandinavia's center of gravity into Europe.'' Syse's coalition government fell apart in October in a dispute over negotiations with the EC. Finnish Foreign Minister Pertti Paasio said the question of Finnish membership may ``become a more central issue'' in next year's election campaigns. ``I think the pressures (to join) have been increasing all the while.'' The Social Democrats, who control Sweden's minority government, were supported on the motion by the Moderate and Liberal parties, which have formed a coalition to try to win next year's elections. The Center Party changed its previous position and voted for the EC application. The Environment Party and the Left Party, formerly the Communists, voted against. The vote in the 349-seat Riksdag was 287 for EC membership, 40 against, and 22 abstentions. ``It looks as if the application will come next year,'' said Lars Vargo, spokesman for the Foreign Affairs Committee which drafted the plan. The EC takes no official position on prospective members until they apply. But the Nordic countries, with their well-developed modern economies, have the impression their applications would be looked upon favorably. Norwegian Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland favors eventual EC membership.

DOC.HEAD: UN Backs Ban on Antarctica Mining, Planning `Earth Summit'
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday unanimously endorsed a ban on mining in Antarctica and said it wanted a role in any decisions on protecting the frozen continent. A resolution, adopted 98-0 with 7 abstentions, ``expresses regret'' that the U.N. secretary-general had not been invited to meetings of the Antarctic Treaty nations considering such environmental measures. The United States, Soviet Union, France, Australia and New Zealand were among a number of nations that said they were not participating in the vote. Decisions on Antarctica have historically resided within the Antarctic Treaty signatory group. Twelve of the 39 Antarctic Treaty nations - particularly France, New Zealand and Australia - are seeking to designate Antarctica a vast nature preserve or world park. No commercial mining or oil exploration is being conducted in the southernmost continent, but a ban on future activity is considered a key to the plan. The treaty nations recently met in Chile to discuss how to implement a ban on commercial mining in Antarctica, which is believed to contain large quantities of minerals beneath its surface. The U.N. resolution said issues on Antarctica should be brought before a U.N. summit on the environment scheduled in June 1992 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Environmentalists say at least several of the 26 Antarctic Treaty nations with decision-making power generally resist moves to yield any of their authority to the United Nations or world community. Bruce Manheim of the Environmental Defense Fund in Washington noted that rising fears about possible exploitation of the continent, recent oil spills and burgeoning tourism have led the world community to call for a greater voice in the process.

DOC.HEAD: German Company Charged With Not Telling of Drug Deaths Overseas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to ADD that drug relabeled to warn against hemolytic anemia.
DOC.TEXT: The German maker of an anti-depressant that was sold worldwide said Wednesday it will plead guilty to charges it waited too long to notify U.S. regulators the drug killed two patients in Europe. Hoechst AG marketed the drug nomifensine in the United States under the name Merital and voluntarily pulled it from shelves in 1986. The company's U.S. subsidiary, Hoechst-Roussel Pharmaceuticals Inc. in Somerville, was not charged. A spokeswoman there said the German company intended to plead guilty to the charges and pay the maximum fine of $202,000. A court date has not been set. The charges were filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Newark against Hoechst AG and its former research director, Rainer Zapf. The case marks the first time a foreign drug maker has been prosecuted for failing to inform the Food and Drug Administration of adverse drug reactions that occurred outside the United States, said U.S. Attorney Michael Chertoff. More than 14 million people in 96 countries used the anti-depressant between its introduction in the early 1970s until it was approved for use in the United States in December 1984, the company said. Hoechst began marketing the drug in the United States in July 1985. Charges were filed because Hoechst waited until 1986 to inform the FDA of a 1984 nomifensine-related death in France and a 1981 death in Italy, authorities said. ``Accurate and timely reports of serious drug complications - irrespective of where in the world those reactions occur - are critical to millions of Americans who rely on the Food and Drug Administration to help ensure that prescribed medications are safe and effective,'' Chertoff said in a statement. Hoechst pulled the drug after it noticed an increase in hemolytic anemia, a potentially fatal form of leukemia in which the red blood cells that carry oxygen through the body are destroyed faster than the body can replace them. The two patients in Europe died from hemolytic anemia associated with the drug, court papers showed. Andrea Stine, a spokeswoman for both the parent company and the U.S. subsidiary, said she did not know how widely the drug was used in the United States. She said the company recorded $5 million in U.S. sales from the anti-depressant, but she did not know what it cost. Rick Blumber, an attorney for the FDA, said Hoechst acted properly when it reported another death associated with the drug in Europe in April 1985. He said the anti-depressant was relabeled as a result of that fatality to warn that the drug could cause hemolytic anemia.

DOC.HEAD: School District Mourns Student Slain at School
DOC.TEXT: In classrooms across the city, students and teachers paused for a moment of silence Wednesday for a high school pupil they never knew. Kingsley Allen, 17, was stabbed to death Tuesday in a hallway of Boston High School. Witnesses told police Allen was killed when he resisted a robbery attempt, said police spokesman Scott Gillis. Allen was the 140th in the city's record number of homicides this year and acting Superintendent Joseph McDonough said he believes it was the first killing inside a Boston school. The previous homicide record was 135 in 1973. Allen's classmate, Robert L. Reynolds, 18, pleaded innocent to murder charges Wednesday and was held without bond. Educators said the most difficult part for students may be coming to grips with an act of violence in a place they considered safe. ``The schools have been perceived in the city as a haven, and up to now they have been,'' said Michael Contompasis, headmaster at Boston Latin High School. ``The young people have, by and large, felt comfortable leaving behind the stresses of the streets and neighborhoods.'' School officials and parents Wednesday began organizing a systemwide campaign aimed at preventing such violence. And administrators at Boston High School said students will face stepped-up security when they return Thursday. The campaign ``will focus on how young people can resolve their problems without resorting to violence,'' said schools spokesman Larry W. Faison. As a first step, administrators asked the city's 115 schools to begin with a moment of silence Wednesday. McDonough also asked teachers to discuss the implications of the tragedy with the system's 57,000 students. At Boston High, where classes were canceled Wednesday, administrators held a daylong program to prepare teachers to deal with their returning classes. ``We let the staff air out their feelings and discuss the grief that normally comes with this kind of incident,'' said Headmaster Thomas Hennessey. Teachers were instructed to acknowledge the incident with students, dispel rumors and ``tell them its okay to have strong feelings about it,'' he said. ``Most important, you get back to the normal routine as quickly as possible.'' But that may be difficult when school officials use hand-held metal detectors to frisk students as they enter the building Thursday. ``Due to the nature of the tragedy, we're going to have some extraordinary precautions,'' Hennessey said. Faison said the anti-violence campaign must show students ways other than violence and drugs to deal with anger or despair. ``We have to show them a way out,'' he said. In addition, young people must be made to understand the long-lasting impact of violent acts, he said. ``Of two young people yesterday, one is dead and the other's life is actually destroyed,'' he said. ``We want to make sure they understand that this is the end result when you use violence.''

DOC.HEAD: Underground Train Derailment in Boston Injures More than 250
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to UPDATE with trainee operating train, SUBS grafs 8-10 bgng `An Amtrak trainee ...' with 8 grafs to UPDATE with details about trainee, engineer involved in 1984 train accident, data taken from cabins will show speed of train. Pick up 13th graf, `The crash...' ADDS 1 graf at bottom with station closed through weekend.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Train Collision-Scene
LaserPhotos BX6,9,16,19
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak train operated by a trainee derailed and slammed into a rush-hour commuter train in a tunnel Wednesday, injuring 264 passengers in a crash so violent cars were flung into the tunnel ceiling and buckled the road above. ``All the lights went out, people started screaming, the place was filled with smoke, a few people were trapped under seats,'' said Chris Good, a passenger on the suburban Stoughton Line train. About 1,500 gallons of diesel fuel spilled and ignited after the impact, sending dense smoke into the cars that passenger Joe Povoas said ``you could grind with your teeth, you could spit it out.'' Many passengers, dazed and covered with soot, wandered out of the station, some crying, many assisted by emergency personnel. One elderly woman, her face black with soot and wearing no shoes, asked police: ``Where's my luggage? Where are my shoes?'' Ten people were in critical condition, including the engineer of Amtrak's Night Owl train from Washington, D.C., said Jon Fasana, director of the city's emergency services. Overall, 264 people, including four rescue workers, were hurt, said Thomas Glynn, general manager of the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. The injured passengers were among 190 aboard the Amtrak train and about 900 on the commuter train. They suffered from cuts and bruises, smoke inhalation, broken bones and head injuries. An Amtrak trainee was operating the train under the supervision of an engineer with 25 years' experience, said D.J. Beatty, general supervisor for Amtrak. Richard Abramson had three years of training and was qualified to operate the train under the guidance of the engineer, Beatty said. Abramson regularly operated trains as part of his training, Beatty said. Abramson was listed in stable condition at St. Elizabeth's Hospital with a broken collarbone, an injured back and facial injuries. The engineer, Willis Copeland, was in critical condition. Amtrak spokeswoman Marci Larson said Copeland was the engineer in a head-on collision on a New York City trestle in July 1984 in which one person was killed and 115 were injured, but that he was ``completely exonerated.'' That was verified by news reports on the NTSB's investigation of the accident. Federal officials were investigating Wedneday's accident, which occurred in the same Back Bay station in downtown Boston as an almost identical crash three years ago caused by a faulty signal system. ``We'll be very interested in seeing if there are any connections,'' said NTSB spokesman Brent Bahler. The Federal Railroad Administration also sent a team of inspectors and administered mandatory alcohol and drug tests to the crew. The results will not be available for several days. Glynn would not comment on recorders taken from the cabins of both trains, which have been turned over to NTSB investigators. The speed of the Amtrak train will be determined by analyzing cabin data. The crash left parts of the two trains twisted ``like a coat hanger,'' said Fire Lt. Mike Walsh, who arrived at the scene two minutes after the first alarm. ``There was an eerie calm,'' Walsh said. He said he and other firefighters gave their oxygen masks to victims. The commuter train, which originated in Stoughton, south of Boston, was sitting on an adjacent track running in the same direction as the Night Owl when it was hit toward the rear at around 8:30 a.m., said Nancy Sterling Gleason, a transit authority spokeswoman. The Night Owl, which left Washington at 10:30 p.m. Tuesday, apparently derailed on a curve and went into the side of the other train, said Clifford Black, a spokesman for Amtrak in Washington. Two engines, two passenger cars and two baggage cars on the Night Owl derailed and smashed into the parked train, hitting the engine that was in the rear of the commuter train. The Amtrak train jackknifed, hit the ceiling tunnel and broke concrete and steel support pillars, said John Harrison, acting fire commissioner. ``We were sitting on the train and the next thing - crash, bang, boom,'' passenger Kathy Simons said just before she was carried away on a stretcher to an ambulance. ``I ended up on the floor with a seat on top of me.'' A nearly identical crash occurred at the same station between an Amtrak train and a commuter train in 1987. The NTSB determined that crash was caused by an improperly designed signal system, with human error considered a secondary factor. Transit Authority spokesman Jim Ball said that signal system was repaired shortly after the accident. But for Phyllis Laorenza, the crash brought frightening memories of the 1987 crash, which she also experienced as a passenger on a commuter train. ``The first thing I thought of was, `No, I can't believe this is happening to me again,''' Laorenza said. ``It was very scary.'' Officials said the train station would be out of service through the weekend while the wreckage was cleared away.

DOC.HEAD: Four-Year Drought Forces Mandatory Rationing in California Cities
DOC.TEXT: Parched by four years of drought, Southern California cities and water agencies face stricter conservation measures, including mandatory rationing and hefty fines for those who fail to comply. Efforts to conserve dwindling water supplies accompany a growing fear that winter precipitation won't be enough to stave off a devastating fifth year of drought. Wednesday, the City Council's intergovernmental committee approved a proposal to seek statewide water rationing patterned after the city's own conservation ordinance. The measure must be approved by the full council, where it is expected to pass easily, Council President John Ferraro said. The board of the Metropolitan Water District, Southern California's largest water supplier serving about 15 million people, imposed a strict mandatory rationing plan Tuesday on its client cities and agencies. The district serves Los Angeles, Orange, San Diego, Riverside, San Bernardino and Ventura counties. Both actions point to a growing realization that the region is running out of water rapidly and that voluntary conservation measures may not be enough. ``What if next year the drought should continue?'' asked Metropolitan Water District spokesman Bob Gomperz. ``What we've done is we've drawn down reservoir sources of water and now we're down to the bare bones.'' In seeking statewide water rationing, Los Angeles risks aggravating a longstanding conflict with Northern California over water rights. The rift has grown in recent months as residents of several Northern California cities, including San Francisco and San Jose, have been ordered to conserve water. ``Anytime we start talking about this (statewide legislation) in Southern California, Northern Californians think we're trying to steal their water,'' Ferraro said. ``We've got to be careful sponsoring legislation because that's so sensitive. ``As the shortage develops, I think they'll be more receptive,'' he said. No bill has been drafted yet. Under the district's rationing plan, water agencies and cities must achieve reductions equal to a 5 percent cut in residential use and a 20 percent reduction in agricultural use. Violators will be charged triple the usual price for each acre-foot of water over the limit. An acre-foot is about 326,000 gallons. The district left it to local entities to determine how to accomplish the reduction goals. Following the district's action, Mayor Tom Bradley said the city will look at imposing similar mandatory conservation measures. But a decision likely will be delayed until February, when officials can better assess the effect of winter precipitation. Since early this year, the city has relied on voluntary conservation to achieve a 10 percent reduction in consumption. The program is part of a conservation plan that calls for restrictions that become increasingly strict as they are phased in. In Phase 2, the 10 percent reduction becomes compulsory and violators are assessed substantial fines. Phase 5, the plan's final segment, requires a 25 percent reduction in water use. San Diego, another large Southern California water consumer, has no immediate plans to impose mandatory rationing on residents, said Paul Downey, spokesman for Mayor Maureen O'Connor. He said water use had been cut voluntarily 10.7 percent between June and September, indicating no need for mandatory restrictions. Stanley Sprague, general manager for the Municipal Water District of Orange County, said voluntary cutbacks had reduced water use by 8 percent during the past year. He did not expect local water agencies to move to mandatory measures. ``Very few water agencies in the county have mandatory ordinances in place,'' he said. ``Even if they wanted to go mandatory, they'd have to go through the whole ordinance procedure. That can take two to four months.''

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Clan Charged $280,000 on Visa
DOC.TEXT: While deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega claims poverty from his Miami prison cell, a newspaper reported Wednesday he and his family had quite a penchant for plastic money. The fallen general amassed a fortune of $31.5 million and charged nearly $280,000 from 1986 to 1988, USA Today reported. The newspaper said it had obtained Noriega's Visa credit card accounts and many of his previously undisclosed bank records. Records indicate during that time that the Noriega family ran up charges to almost $280,000, mostly at establishments like Christian Dior and Valentino's in Paris, and Harvey Nichols in London, Princess Di's favorite luxury department store. In Miami, where the family spent more than $38,000, the focus was on family and household needs, frequently at sprawling Dadeland Mall, south of Miami. Typical among the flurry of charges were Toys R Us, Baker Shoes, Docktor Pet Center, Linens N Things and J.C. Penney. One Miami charge made by Noriega's wife, Felicidad, in 1987 was for $1,642 at A Christmas Place. Noriega claims he is now destitute, unable to pay his lawyers in his drug conspiracy case. Federal prosecutors have frozen $21 million in Noriega's funds in 27 bank accounts. His lawyers are threatening to pull out of the case and the judge has said he will appoint a public defender. Frank Rubino, Noriega's lawyer, doesn't deny his client may have once controlled hundreds of millions of dollars. But, he adds: ``I don't believe today he has the ability to get one penny. If he did, I'm sure he would (pay his lawyers) so we could go on with the case. I mean he is really upset.'' The general is now a Prisoner of War, receiving a monthly federal stipend of $59 and CARE packages from the Red Cross while held at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami. Meanwhile, in a $6.5 billion civil lawsuit, the Panamanian government says Noriega looted his nation of at least $300 million through corrupt military and government officials. It also claims Noriega shifted funds to personal accounts from Panama's casinos, lotteries, ports and immigration offices.

DOC.HEAD: Army Publication Calls for More Than Doubling Defense Spending
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to CORRECT percentage increase to 150 percent sted of 250. Picks up 12th pvs, `He said...'
DOC.TEXT: A publication of the China's People's Liberation Army has called for a 150 percent increase in defense spending over the next decade. Such an increase could substantially strengthen the army at a time when some Asian neighbors have been worrying that Beijing might seek to settle territorial disputes with its neighbors by force. The call came in the May edition of a Chinese military magazine, Military Economic Research, which is generally restricted to the military and the Communist Party. A copy was obtained by The Associated Press in Hong Kong. In the report, writer Li Yuansheng, an officer in the logistics department of the Chengdu Military Region, argued that China's army has ``lived in debt for a long time.'' Li said increasing the army's budget to $15.5 billion by the year 2000 - from 1990's figure of $6.16 billion - would be ``both appropriate and feasible.'' The jump would mean an increase of 150 percent in a military budget that grew only 30 percent between 1980 and 1989. ``The world has not yet ushered in an era of peace and prosperity,'' Li wrote, ``and China's security is still subjected to actual and potential military threats from some of the peripheral countries.'' The magazine is published by the army's Academy of iilitary Economics, its think tank for defense spending. A Western military official said the report appeared to reflect the current thinking of policy-makers. Professor Ngok Lee, an expert in the Chinese military at the University of Hong Kong, said such a spending increase would appear to be an attempt by China to assert what it sees as its traditional influence in Asia. ``Ministers from all ASEAN states are scared like hell,'' he said, referring to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations grouping of Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines and Brunei. Lee said he believed the army had the political capital to obtain a 150 percent budget increase, especially given the crucial role it played in suppressing a movement for democracy on June 4, 1989. He said several other developments point to the potential for a more ambitious China during the next decade. Over the last two years, China's military has fundamentally revised its force doctrine, called ``people's war,'' from a defensive strategy to an offensive one, following improved ties with its longtime No. 1 enemy, the Soviet Union. The key element of the new doctrine is called ``local war,'' founded on the concept that China will be the aggressor in warfare conducted within limited space, time and means for limited objectives. Secondly, the army is believed to have recently obtained in-flight refueling technology for its jet fighters, which would allow the army to project force hundreds of miles outside China's borders. Western military officers and press reports say China has received the technology from Iran, which obtained it from the United States when Washington enjoyed good relations with Tehran. Additionally, China's military has been training rapid-deployment forces, called Fist Battalions, since 1988. In October, 600 paratroopers conducted a mock attack on an island in the South China Sea, according to China's official Liberation Army Daily. Troop cuts are also helping China fashion a professional fighting force. Since 1985 the army has demobilized 700,000 troops, 25 percent of its total military strength, in a move away from a ``peasant army.'' China has border disputes with India, Vietnam and the Soviet Union. It fought a brief, victorious border war with India in 1962 and almost fought again in 1987. In 1979, it attacked Vietnam in a failed attempt to teach Hanoi ``a lesson'' for invading Cambodia, then a Chinese client state. One flashpoint has been identified as the Spratly archipelago, a group of islands 600 nautical miles south of China's Hainan province, believed to be rich in oil deposits and minerals. China, Malaysia, the Philippines and Taiwan have all made claims on the territory. In March 1988, the Chinese navy sank one Vietnamese military vessel and damaged two others during a skirmish near the islands.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Gains in Elections, But Danish Premier Vows to Stay On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with final returns, jockeying for new government, quotes. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Social Democrats scored big gains in parliamentary elections Wednesday, but Conservative Prime Minister Poul Schlueter said he will try to stay on by expanding his center-right minority government. ``I will seek to build the broadest possible foundation for a non-socialist government,'' he said. Schlueter, who has headed successive center-right coalitions since 1982, said final results showed a continued non-socialist majority of 91 seats in the 179-seat Folketing, or parliament. With all ballots counted, the Social Democrats had gained 14 seats for a total of 69. Social Democratic Party leader Svend Auken demanded that Schlueter resign, saying, ``Now is the time for a change of government and a new majority in Danish politics.'' But Schlueter said he will invite two small centrist parties, the Center Democrats and the Christian People's Party, to join his coalition of Conservatives, Liberals and Social Liberals, which dropped one seat for a total of 66. ``We must discuss the three-party coalition tomorrow (Thursday), but it's clear there is a non-socialist majority,'' he said. If formed, it would control 89 seats in parliament - one shy of a majority. The Social Democrats' success was largely at the expense of the allied Socialist People's Party, which slipped from 24 to 15 seats. It was uncertain if the Social Liberals, who dropped three of their 10 seats, would stay in the government. Economy Minister Niels Helveg Petersen, the Social Liberal leader, said the party would support Schlueter's efforts to head a new government in any case. The Center Democrats and Christian People's Party took part in a round-table discussion among party leaders after returns were in, but declined to say if they would accept Schlueter's offer to join a new coalition. Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen's Liberals gained seven seats for a total of 29, while Schlueter's Conservatives dropped from 35 seats to 30. The Center Democrats held their nine seats and the Christian People's Party kept its four. Thirteen parties fielded candidates, but only the eight that sat in the outgoing parliament secured the 2 percent of the vote needed to be represented. Schlueter called the election on Nov. 22 when the Social Democrats blocked parliamentary passage of the government's finance bill. Voter turnout from among the 3.9 million registered voters was 82.8 prcent, compared with 85.7 in the 1988 ballot. It was Denmark's fourth parliamentary election in six years.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Fair Housing Law Can't Be Applied to Insurer Accused of Redlining
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ruled the federal fair housing law cannot be applied to insurers, rejecting two of five charges against an insurance company accused of discriminating against black homeowners in Milwaukee. U.S. District Court Judge Stadtmueller on Tuesday dismissed two of five claims in a class action lawsuit against American Family Mutual Insurance Co. by the NAACP. Lawyers for eight black homeowners, including Milwaukee Alderman Marvin Pratt, and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said the decision will be appealed. The NAACP has said it is attempting to apply the federal law guaranteeing fair access to housing to providers of homeowners insurance because homeowners who cannot get such insurance are unable to buy homes. The case is ``significant because it addresses a problem that has substantial adverse impact on housing in the cities across the nation,'' said William Lynch, a lawyer for the plaintiffs. The U.S. Justice Department's Civil Rights Division and the National Fair Housing Alliance, a Washington-based advocacy group, have filed briefs in support of the lawsuit. The lawsuit claims American Family discriminates in a practice known as redlining, in which insurers instruct agents to avoid selling policies in areas with more than 25 percent black population. The lawsuit includes a memo the NAACP alleges was written by a American Family supervisor instructing an insurance agent to ``stop writing those blacks.'' It also alleges the insurer failed to hire and retain black agents, did not locate offices in black neighborhoods and offered blacks ``less advantageous'' policies than whites. The two claims dismissed against the company were that individuals need court action against the company because state law doesn't allow them to take direct action against insurers and that it is unlawful for insurers to discriminate against homeowners based on location of house In dismissing those claims, Stadtmueller said any discriminatory practices by insurance companies could not be considered in violation of the U.S. Fair Housing Act. Stadtmueller cited a 1984 decision that said the Fair Housing Act, enforced by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, was not aimed at insurance agencies.
