John Powell, ACLU national legal director, disagreed with the judge, saying other court decisions since 1984 apply the Fair Housing Act in lawsuits against insurance companies. ``I'm fairly confident the 7th Circuit Court (of Appeals) will overturn his decision because they've already spoken'' and ruled fair housing statutes apply to insurance companies, he said. The insurance company's attorney, Tom Shriner, said he expected the judge to dismiss the two counts because ``Congress and the state Legislature pass the laws, judges don't.'' Felmers Chaney, president of Milwaukee's NAACP, said he was not surprised by the ruling, but said the judge should have interpreted the Fair Housing Act differently. ``I remember back in the days before the civil right laws were put into effect - if Congress didn't rule, the courts had to act,'' Chaney said.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Attack in Medellin Leaves Seven Policemen Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS two grafs background, details.
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded Wednesday night in a bus carrying police officers, killing seven policemen and injuring four others in Medellin, officials said. No details were immediately available on the circumstances of the attack nor on who was responsible for the blast in Medellin, which is Colombia's second largest city and home base to the world's most violent cocaine cartel. More than 250 police have been killed between August 1989 and July in bombings, shootings and attacks by hitmen hired by the Extraditables, who oppose the government's policy of extraditing noted drug trafficking suspects to the United States to face trial. The Extraditables, an arm of the cartel, called Tuesday for a truce in their war and said they would not attempt further terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Noted for Anti-Terrorist Cases Commits Suicide
DOC.TEXT: A French judge known for his handling of numerous terrorist cases shot and killed himself at his home in Paris early Thursday, police said. Gilles Boulouque, 40, died after shooting himself in the mouth with a handgun, according to police. They could not provide a motive for Boulouque's suicide, but said they had no doubt the judge died by his own hand. Boulouque was experiencing some family problems and was particularly fatigued in recent weeks, according to sources close to the judge.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Premiers Resume Talks in Closed Session
DOC.TEXT: The premiers of North and South Korea met in closed session Thursday to seek common ground for easing 45 years of confrontation, but a vacant place at the table symbolized their gap. Prime ministers Yon Hyong Muk of Communist North and Kang Young-hoon of capitalist South shook hands and chatted briefly before taking their places with official delegates on either side of a large rectangular table in a hotel ballroom. ``Both sides need to exchange frank opinions,'' Kang said. ``Even if there are differences in various matters, we must solve them one by one.'' The talks are the third round since September in the highest-level meetings between the Koreas since the peninsula was divided in 1945 and the border tightly sealed. The North Koreans return home Friday. The vacant place belongs to Kim Jong-hwie, an official South Korean delegate and special presidential aide for diplomacy and national security. Kim was traveling to Moscow Thursday with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo for a summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. North Korea has bitterly criticized the trip. North Korea said Wednesday that its relations with Seoul could not improve unless South Korea stops what the North called its flunky-like diplomacy of soliciting foreign influence to help ease tensions on the peninsula. Roh said he would ask Gorbachev for help in ending Cold War tensions in Korea and to pressure the totalitarian northern regime to open up its society. At Wednesday's two-hour opening session, both sides offered proposals that were little changed in substance from past talks. ``The talks showed how big and wide are the valleys of distrust between the two sides,'' said Limb Dong-won, a delegate and spokesman for the South. While talks were going on, about a dozen North Korean reporters slipped away from their official guides and explored Seoul by taxi and subway. South Korea lodged a protest with the North Korean delegation Thursday, which said the impromptu trips would stop.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Decides Scrooge Deserves Bad Rep
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf to CORRECT spelling to Angela, sted Angelo.
DOC.TEXT: Even the ghost of Jack Benny couldn't save Ebenezer Scrooge on Wednesday when a judge refused to clear the name of the miserly main character of ``A Christmas Carol.'' The tongue-in-cheek ruling by Municipal Judge George Choppelas came at the Court of Historical Review and Appeals, a mock court that met to decide if the name of the character created by Charles Dickens should continue to be synonymous with greed and avarice. In the past, the court has ruled on such weighty questions as the existence of Santa Claus or if chicken soup deserved to be considered Jewish penicillin. Yes on both, the court found. The puns during the court's 65th session moved fast with ``little Dickens'' and ``you've been Scrooged'' bringing moans from 100 or so spectators. Scrooge, dressed in black and wearing a top hat, pleaded his case, saying he had been ``sorely hurt by an early, early love.'' Scrooge, portrayed by retired drama teacher E. Wyman Spalding, claimed his mentor, Jacob Marley, should be blamed. ``It was Marley, Marley,'' he told the judge. ``Marley was the real Scrooge.'' The miser was defended by Frank Winston, who said the world actually owed a debt to ``Eb,'' insisting that comedian Jack Benny's tightwad image was inspired by the Scrooge character. Even the names were familiar, the lawyer said. BENny and eBENezer. Get it? ``Eb was always a grand guy,'' Winston said. The references to Benny led Choppelas to try an impression of the late comedian. ``I'm thinking, I'm thinking,'' he said at one point, a slight Benny tone in his voice. Prosecutor Angela Alioto said Scrooge deserved his bad name despite his change of heart at the end of the novel turned into a popular Christmas movie. ``Those nightmares would scare the hell out of anybody,'' she said. ``You can't change with a four-hour period of being nice.'' Scrooge also drew the fire of Noah Griffin, a San Francisco Examiner columnist who wrote a poem for the event. One stanza read: ``But tears from Scrooge were mean and vile Befitting but the crocodile. His so-called heartfelt transformation Was nothing but media manipulation.''

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Delays Mideast Resolution Vote Once More
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with council decides to delay resolution vote. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council on Wednesday postponed a vote on a resolution endorsing a Mideast peace conference until after Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze meets PLO chairman Yasser Arafat. The deputy Soviet ambassador, Valentin Lozinskiy, asked the delay in light of ``negotiations on the political level which have been recently occurring'' and to give the council more time to reach consensus. The United States and eight other members voted to postpone; four voted against; France and China abstained. The meeting was postponed until Monday. Shevardnadze, who was in Washington on Wednesday meeting separately with Israeli Premier Yitzhak Shamir and President Bush, will meet Arafat on Friday in Ankara, Turkey, said diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity. PLO officials confirmed Shevardnadze would be meeting Arafat, but declined to provide details. Shevardnadze will pressure Arafat to distance his Palestine Liberation Organization from Iraq, which has been championing the Palestinian homeland issue since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The delay will give the United States and the non-aligned nations on the Security Council more time to try to work out a compromise on the resolution on the Israeli-occupied territories. The United States has been struggling to remove from a Security Council resolution language endorsing a Mideast peace conference, fearing it would look like a concession to Iraq. Rumors circulated that the paragraph endorsing the conference would be taken out of the resolution at America's insistence and put in a separate, non-binding statement from the council president. However, the Yemeni ambassador, who also is a co-sponsor of the resolution, said, ``That has been a suggestion, but we have not moved an inch.'' When U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering was asked if any understanding had been reached, he replied, ``Not that I know of.'' The situation became more complicated Wednesday when France announced it could not support any resolution that did not contain the call for a peace conference. France did not indicate whether it would cast a veto, however. A vote on the resolution has been put off six times in a week. Israel, the traditional U.S. ally in the Middle East, strongly opposes any international peace conference that would encompass the issue of Palestinians in occupied lands. The Israelis say they will not accept any imposed settlement, and fear a peace conference would force them into a ``land-for-peace'' deal with their Arab neighbors. They want bilateral talks with their Arab adversaries. The United States has been caught in a diplomatic bind. U.S. officials say they must veto the resolution if it endorses the peace conference because it gives the appearance of linking that issue with the Persian Gulf crisis. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein says he will withdraw from Kuwait only in the context of a comprehensive Middle East peace conference that would address all problems in the region. But U.S. officials fear a veto could weaken support from Arab nations that joined the coalition against Iraq following its invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Testimony Begins Trucker's Trial Over Accident That Killed Eight
With AM-Interstate Pileup
DOC.TEXT: A combination of faulty brakes and insufficient warning caused a fiery interstate crash that killed eight people, the lawyer for a trucker charged in the deaths said Wednesday. Manuel Cruzado Jr., 26, of Buffalo, N.Y., went on trial Wednesday in Magistrate Court on eight misdemeanor counts of negligent homicide stemming from the July 26 accident on Interstate 79. The accident occurred because the brakes on Cruzado's 68,000-pound loaded car-carrier failed as he descended a 2-mile-long hill, rounded a blind curve and came upon stalled traffic at a construction site that had closed the right lane of a bridge, said Cruzado's attorney, Gary Collias. Prosecutor William Martin argued that Cruzado was going faster than the 50 mph speed limit and ignored warning signs that started more than a mile before the construction site. He also said Cruzado had been behind the wheel without a break for a period longer than allowed by federal regulations. A family of five from New York were killed when their car was crushed between Cruzado's truck and a parked highway dump truck. Three Fairmont residents were killed when a vehicle fell off Cruzado's car-carrier atop their car.

DOC.HEAD: Census Bureau Finds At Least 750,000 More Americans
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf: ``The Census,'' to state that bureau checked homes that had not sent in form as well as some of those that did
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau has found at least 750,000 people it missed during the April 1 national head count, officials said Wednesday. ``At this point we feel we have done a very thorough census,'' said Barbara Everitt Bryant, census director. More than 6,000 local governments have filed challenges saying the census was inaccurate. They include all of the 51 largest cities. ``Virtually everybody's count will go up,'' Bryant said. New York Mayor David Dinkins and William Althaus, mayor of York, Pa., scheduled a meeting with Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher to discuss correcting the count in major cities. The mayors represent the U.S. Conference of Mayors. Bryant and Michael Darby, under secretary of commerce for economic affairs, said the newly counted people were found through five programs designed to check the census' accuracy. The Census Bureau compared its count against parole and probation records; asked people to come forward if they were missed; sent workers to recanvass some households that mailed in forms to check the accuracy of the forms; sent canvassers to count people in households that had not mailed a form back and checked vacant and uninhabitable housing to see if someone lived there after all. Officials refused to say exactly how many people had been added since the April 1 count. They would say only how many people or households had been checked under the programs and what percentage had produced additions to the census. Bryant said the bureau checked 1.2 million parole and probation records and found 34 percent should be aded to the initial count. That's about 408,000 people. Most parolees and probationers are men in their 20s and 30s, the bureau said. The bureau's ``Were You Counted'' program asked people to contact the bureau if they thought they hadn't been counted. Nearly 166,000 responses produced additions to the census count, according to Bryant's figures. Some responses may have added more than one person. Also: -Workers found at least 125,000 missed households through recanvassing. -Nearly 46,000 households thought to be vacant were found to have residents. -Workers found people living in nearly 9,000 houses that were thought to be uninhabitable. The newly counted people will be added to the preliminary U.S. population count of 245.8 million. Census numbers are used to determine how many representatives a state sends to Congress and how federal aid is divided among the states.

DOC.HEAD: Queen Elizabeth Holds Palace Ball to Mark Four Royal Birthdays
DOC.TEXT: More than 800 guests attended a glittering ball held by Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace on Wednesday night toate the 90th birthday of her mother this year and three other royal anniversaries in 1990. The ball marked the 90th birthday of Elizabeth the Queen Mother on Aug. 4, the 60th birthday of the queen's sister Princess Margaret on Aug. 21, the 40th birthday of the queen's daughter Princess Anne on Aug. 15 and the 30th birthday of the queen's second son Prince Andrew, the Duke of York, on Feb. 19. Guests at what the palace called ``the dance of the decades'' included personal friends of the royals from the arts, politics and high society and scores of other celebrities and dignitaries. The palace in a brief statement described it as a private function as opposed to a formal state occasion. Almost every member of the royal family was present to welcome the guests. The British domestic news agency Press Association described it as the biggest party at the palace since the one in November 1988 marking the 40th birthday of Prince Charles, the queen's eldest son and heir to the throne. Guests held dinner parties at top restaurants throughout London's West End before driving to the palace for the ball, which began shortly after 10 p.m. Because of the large number of guests, the palace picture gallery with its valuable collection of Old Master paintings was transformed into a ballroom. Its gilded ceiling was hung with blue draperies and the gallery was lit by a starry constellation of white lights. Drawing rooms and and the music room leading from the gallery were filled with huge arrangements of flowers. Guests included songwriter Tim Rice; singer Cleo Laine; Maj. Ronald Ferguson, the father of Prince Andrew's wife the Duchess of York, formerly Sarah Ferguson; Mark Thatcher, son of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, and Thatcher's American wife Diane.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Nosair Confined at Rikers Island
DOC.TEXT: A judge Wednesday ordered the man charged in the assassination of Rabbi Meir Kahane to be removed from Bellevue Hospital and returned to Rikers Island jail. The judge, Ira Gammerman, ruled that El Sayyid Nosair's wounds and other ailments were not serious enough to keep him at Bellevue, as his lawyer, Michael Warren, had requested. ``You don't have to keep a patient in a hospital because he has wax in his ears and stiffness in his neck,'' Gammerman said. He said Nosair could be treated at the hospital as an out-patient. Nosair, 35, an Egyptian immigrant who lives in Cliffside Park, N.J., was shot in the neck by a federal officer Nov. 5 as he fled the Manhattan hotel where he allegedly shot Kahane to death after the Zionist rabbi had given a speech. The judge ordered an examination of Nosair by a private doctor after Warren disputed a Bellevue report that his client could return to the jail's general population. Warren charged that the city doctor was biased. Bail of $300,000 for Nosair was suspended and a hearing to set a new bail scheduled for Dec. 18.

DOC.HEAD: All Encephalitis Advisories Lifted; Cases At 209
DOC.TEXT: Health alerts have been lifted in all 27 Florida counties hit by St. Louis encephalitis, a sometimes fatal illness carried by mosquitoes, a state spokeswoman said Wednesday. ``We're doing good,'' said Melanie Mowry, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. The advisories recommended that people stay indoors in the evening when the mosquitoes were active. Although they have been lifted, people should still use insect repellent and wear long pants and sleeves, Ms. Mowry said. She added that overnight camping should be delayed for a couple more weeks. On Wednesday, the number of confirmed cases in Florida stood at 153 and presumptive cases - people who have tested positive in one of two tests needed for confirmation - at 56. No one has reported symptoms starting after Nov. 16, Ms. Mowry said. And only three cases have developed in the last five weeks. Since the flu-like illness, which can turn fatal with brain inflammation, was first reported in mid-August, eight deaths have been reported.

DOC.HEAD: Confession Stuns Jurors at Opening of Chico Mendes Murder Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with father reportedly held party after Mendes was killed, town celebrates after confession, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XAP2
DOC.TEXT: A 22-year-old rancher's son confessed Wednesday that he killed famed rainforest activist Chico Mendes, bringing a surprising end to the opening session of the murder trial. Darci Alves Pereira stunned a packed courtroom by admitting he shot Mendes on Dec. 22, 1988, shortly after dark outside his home in this remote Amazon town near Bolivia's border, 2,650 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro. Pereira's confession came minutes after he had twice denied shooting Mendes, who was one of Brazil's most outspoken critics of development of the Amazon basin. Mendes' case has reached such proportions that film producers and authors have besieged his widow with competing offers to tell his story. Pereira, whose father also is charged with plotting the murder of the noted ecologist, faces a 12- to 30-year sentence. Sentencing is expected on Thursday. The trial had drawn worldwide attention as a test of Brazil's commitment to protecting its rainforests against encroachment and to meting out equal justice for rich and poor. Mendes, who defended the rainforest from landowners and ranchers who wanted to cut it down to develop the fragile Amazonian basin, has become a symbol of Brazil's impoverished. Ilzamar Mendes, widow of Chico Mendes, was sitting in the gallery when the confession occurred. She clapped her hands in surprise. ``He confessed?'' she asked incredulously. ``It's hard to believe.'' She added, ``He's probably doing it to protect his father.'' Pereira's father, rancher Darly Alves da Silva, also is on trial on charges of planning the shooting. He pleaded innocent. Mendes had repeatedly told police that da Silva was plotting to kill him, after rubber tappers prevented the rancher from clearing a tract of rainforest. The trial began at 9 a.m. A boy picked the names of seven jurors out of a hat containing 21 slips of paper with local resident's names written on them. Outside, two dozen state police in army camouflage pants and bulletproof vests stood guard with submachine guns and pistols. Officials feared violence between rubber tappers and gunmen reportedly hired by ranchers. The 240 officials, politicians, family members, and journalists allowed in were frisked before entering the 36-by-48-foot courtroom. Four state troopers led in the defendants, who sat staring down as the charges were read. Da Silva, 54, wearing an unbuttoned blue shirt, slacks and thick glasses, was called to the bench. He denied accusations he plotted Mendes' death and had ordered his son to carry it out. Then Pereira approached the bench and also denied the murder charge against him. He claimed he was in another town when Mendes was killed. The short, muscular Pereira was shown evidence found by police near where Mendes' killer hid: a 16-gauge shotgun, a black nylon raincoat, a burlap sack, two bottles and cigrette cartons. Asked if he recognized the items, Pereira shook his head. Then, as bailiffs were leading Pereira from the courtoom, Judge Adair Longhini leaned over the bench and asked again if the defendant committed the crime. Pereira paused, stared at Longhini and said, ``I confess.'' ``What?'' said the judge. ``You killed Chico Mendes?`` ``I shot him, yes,'' Pereira said. There was turmoil among the 240 observers packed into the tiny wooden courtroom. Longhini called for order. Speaking softly and slowly, Pereira recounted in chilling detail how he carried out the murder. On the afternoon of the killing, Pereira said, he picked up a shotgun loaded with one cartridge at his father's Parana ranch 7 miles outside Xapuri and rode his motorcycle into town ``with the intention of killing.'' ``I was alone,'' he said. ``No one else was involved.'' Pereira said he waited for nightfall and then walked along the Acre River that runs behind Mendes house. Shortly before 7 p.m., he crept into Mendes' yard through an open gate and waited. Ten minutes later, he said, Mendes emerged from the back door, reportedly to go to a shack in the rear of the yard to go to the bathroom. ``I saw his face in the light of the lamp he held,'' Pereira said. ``I raised the gun and squeezed the trigger. I did not see him fall, I was already walking back along the river.'' He did not say why he reversed his plea of innocence. However, Marcio Thomaz Bastos, chief lawyer for the prosecution, said the confession was a planned maneuver to spare his father. ``Darci is being an obedient son,'' Bastos said during a break. ``His father told him to kill, and he killed. Now he told Darci to lie, and he's lying to protect his father.'' Bastos hopes to convict the elder rancher on the strength of testimony from a 15-year-old boy who worked on da Silva's ranch. The boy will reportedly testify da Silva threw a party the night after the killing, in celebration. Defense lawyer Ruben Lopes Torres said he was ``completely surprised'' by the confession. ``Until the moment he confessed I didn't think he committed the crime,'' said Torres. ``Darci's decision to say `I killed Chico Mendes' was completely his own.'' Pereira and his father, who also faces prison terms of 12 to 30 years, are not eligible for bail because both face charges for other killings. Ilzamar Mendes, in a yellow T-shirt stamped with Chico Mendes' face, concluded, ``We believed in justice.'' The town had a festive atmosphere after hearing the news, people celebrating with glasses of rum-like cachaca in the town's tree-lined streets.

DOC.HEAD: Houston-area Company to Pay Millions to Soviets to Fly Employee on Mir
DOC.TEXT: A Texas company signed a multimillion-dollar contract to make one of its employees a ``guest cosmonaut'' on the Soviet space station Mir. Space Commerce Corp. President Art Dula, who negotiated the deal, said a Houston area company he did not identify will pay more than the $12 million the Tokyo Broadcasting Service paid to put one of its newsmen in space for eight days. That trip, the first for a journalist and for a Japanese national, ended Monday. Dula would not disclose the amount the company will pay or any other details. The employee will spend up to a week in space during the last quarter of 1992, Dula. The agreement was reached last month, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Blocks Friday Execution of Robert Sawyer
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday blocked Friday's scheduled execution of a convicted murderer. U.S. District Judge Henry Mentz set a Jan. 2 hearing to examine conflicts in the record of the trial of Robert Sawyer, 40. Earlier Wednesday, the State Pardon Board refused to recommend that Gov. Buddy Roemer commute Sawyer's sentence to life in prison. Sawyer and Charles Lane were convicted in 1980 of the murder of Frances Arwood of Avondale. They were accused of beating and raping Arwood and setting her on fire after a night of drinking. Sawyer was sentenced to die in the electric chair. Lane was given a life sentence.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Axes Three Series, CNBC Drops Morton Downey Jr.
DOC.TEXT: The ax fell Wednesday on NBC's ``Grand,'' ``Ferris Bueller'' and ``Parenthood'' series and on the year-old cable talk show of Morton Downey Jr. on NBC-owned CNBC. NBC also announced three new series that it said will join its prime-time schedule in January: ``Dark Shadows,'' a new version of the old daytime gothic horror series; ``Blossom,'' a comedy; and ``Sunday Best,'' a one-hour Sunday series that uses new material and clips from existing NBC shows. CNBC's ``Downey'' cancellation marked the second time since 1989 the aggressive talk-show host has gotten the chop. His syndicated, confrontational-style ``The Morton Downey Jr. Show'' was dropped after a two-year run. ``We're sorry to see him go,'' said Susan Greene, an NBC vice-president for business development. But CNBC is revamping its prime time lineup and `` `Downey' does not fit in with the direction we're taking,'' she said. NBC's ``Grand'' was in its second season. The low-rated ``Ferris Bueller'' and ``Parenthood,'' each based on movies, were in their first season. The premiere dates for the new shows will be announced shortly, NBC said.

Japan and Germany, two of the world's leading economic powers, have delivered barely one-fifth of the money and materials they promised in support of U.S. military operations in the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon says. Of the six countries that offered the largest contributions to Operation Desert Shield at its outset in August, only Kuwait has given all that it promised, Pete Williams, the chief Pentagon spokesman, said Tuesday. Williams declined to comment on the reasons for the delayed contributions from other allies. Pledges totaling more than $6.5 billion were made for calendar year 1990. The spokesman said the United States plans to ask an undisclosed number of allied nations to increase their contributions for 1991. He said he did not know how much money would be sought or when the requests would be made. ---= VIENNA, Austria (AP) - Challenged by three straight days of student protests, Albania's Communist leadership has promised to allow competing political parties and fired five members of the ruling Politburo. The actions Tuesday appeared to signal a major defeat for Communist hard-liners in Europe's last bastion of Stalinist rule, which President Ramiz Alia has described as being on the verge of economic disaster. The Balkan nation of 3.1 million, which opened its borders slightly this year after decades of isolationism under the late Enver Hoxha, would be the last country in Europe to introduce a multiparty system. Alia met with student representatives in Tirana late Tuesday and said the government is willing open up a dialogue. He also urged them to return to classes or ``incidents which nobody desires could occur.'' ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir says his meeting with President Bush went a long way toward calming his fears about the steadfastness of U.S. support for Israel. But his problems may not be over: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze wants to talk to him about agreeing to an international Mideast peace conference, a concept that is anathema to Shamir. Shevardnadze and Shamir meet in Washington tonight, and their talks are expected to focus on the Persian Gulf crisis and on the flood of Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union to Israel. Shevardnadze met earlier this week in Houston with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The two decided to head back to Washington on Tuesday night instead of today, partly to give Shevardnadze time to see Shamir, said U.S. officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. ---= MOSCOW (AP) - The Communist Party used to advertise itself as the ``conscience of the nation.'' By the time Andrei Sakharov died, that title was more commonly accorded to him. Since the physicist and political activist's death a year ago this Friday, friends and colleagues in the human rights movement have battled for Sakharov's cause. But they say no one has emerged to take his place. ``The conscience of the nation - that has remained a vacant position,'' said Sergei Grigoryants, editor of the unofficial journal Glasnost and one of many former political prisoners who Sakharov pressured the government to free. Since Sakharov died of heart failure at age 68, public esteem has continued to climb for the man who helped invent the Soviet hydrogen bomb and later won the Nobel Peace Prize.

DOC.HEAD: Taxes a Never-Ending Problem for Politicians
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: There's a one-word diagnosis for the headache issue politicians can't seem to shake, and the word is taxes. That chronic problem is worsened by voter suspicion that 49 cents of every tax dollar goes to waste. Pollsters and Republican political consultants warned GOP governors here that the budget and tax dilemma most states face is likely to deepen before the next elections. They urged the executives to start dealing with it early, to ease the sting before the 1992 campaign season. ``There's no place for a governor to hide,'' said Richard Wirthlin, who conducts polls for the White House. He said the governors should shape clear strategies for handling the budget squeeze and the tax issue, and tell their constituents about it. Wirthlin said a poll his organization conducted in September found that the average American believes that local, state and federal governments waste 49 cents of every dollar taxpayers send them. Eighty-two percent of the people think government wastes the money it gets, Wirthlin said. ``That's a presumption as a governor that you've got to take on and take on very directly,'' he told the Republican governors conference this week. The peril in taxes hardly came as a surprise to the governors. Fourteen states switched party control in gubernatorial elections this year. In almost every case, when incumbents or their parties lost, taxes were a factor. Surveys by Wirthlin after the Nov. 6 elections showed that among people who made their choice on the basis of a single issue, 9 percent said the issue was taxes. Only 1 percent of single-issue voters were swayed by taxes in the prior election. Neal Newhouse, an analyst with the Wirthlin organization, said that when the question before the voters is whether or not to increase taxes, Republicans hold the advantage - but when it becomes what taxes ought to be raised, the edge shifts to Democrats. Congressional Democrats succeeded in shaping the issue of federal taxes into a debate about fairness, accusing the Bush administration of seeking tax breaks for the rich. ``When it's tax versus no tax, Republicans win,'' Newhouse said. But that may not be the question in the next two years, with the economy slipping, state revenues declining and no help in sight from a strapped federal government. Indeed, the governors complained that Washington is increasing the burden on their treasuries with laws that mandate state spending. ``They say, `where's the money coming from?' '' Vice President Dan Quayle said after conferring with the governors. Winding up their conference on Tuesday, the GOP governors said they want President Bush to know that they are frustrated about program mandates they blame on Congress, and want him to do something. Gov. Carroll A. Campbell of South Carolina, their new chairman, said federal requirements that force state spending on health care and the like are taking money away from education and other vital programs, and governors are frustrated by it. ``Our message to the president is please stop it, use your veto,'' said Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin. Federally mandated spending is a longstanding complaint of governors in both parties. It irks them more in a time of strained budgets, when some of them may be forced to seek tax increases despite the political peril. ``When you get into the tax issue, be sure you know which taxes are supported and which are not,'' Wirthlin told the governors, ``because that is in fact very dangerous ground.'' Linda DiVall, president of American Viewpoint, Inc., said governors should cover that territory as early in the election cycle as they can, explaining to constituents as they do so. ``And do it again and again and again,'' she said. ``... The tax issue is still incredibly strong.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Presbyterian Look at Critics Finds They're Appreciated
DOC.TEXT: Checking up on an organization that has been a persistent and cutting critic, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) found that many members seem to appreciate the onslaughts. This has been somewhat of a stunner for church leaders. But in the denomination's open operating style, it laid the matter all out plainly. Responses ran nearly 3-to-1 in support of the dissenting organization, the Presbyterian Lay Committee, said the Rev. James V. Johnson Jr., chairman of a special committee set up to look into the group's ways. ``It would be accurate to say that the special committee has been very surprised by the breadth and depth of support'' for the group, he added. The Presbyterian Lay Committee, based in Springfield, Pa., consists of an 18-member board of directors, which puts out a bimonthly newspaper, The Presbyterian Layman. It reports a circulation of 400,000 and regularly assails church policies and programs. Charging that the denomination supports leftist and socialist causes and views, the editor, J. Robert Campbell, said the church should stay out of politics and stick to its ``unique mission.'' That is ``the proclamation of the Gospel and making of disciples,'' he said in a telephone interview. He said the church findings mean ``the denominational leaders have refused to listen to people out across the church. There's a tremendous gap between what the denominational leaders think and what the people in the pews think.'' Victor Jameson, editor of the denomination's monthly, Presbyterian Survey, based in Louisville, Ky., interprets the findings quite differently. ``Our people have a kind of feeling that everybody should have their say, even if they don't like what's said and even if it's wrong and ought not to be said,'' he said. The special committee set up by the church's 1989 governing assembly to check into relationships with the Presbyterian Lay Committee solicited responses from the church-at-large. Sixty percent of about 200 responses considered the criticizing group ``a valuable voice of dissent in the church, even though it tends to overdo it,'' Johnson said. He said 10 percent supported the paper without reservation and 30 percent considered it harmful to the church. Johnson said the committee also received more than 6,000 pre-printed forms distributed by the critical group that supported it. In testimony to Johnson's committee, elected national assembly representatives, serving in five program areas, charged the lay committee's paper with errors, misstatements and personal attacks. The 3 million-member denomination's representative assembly repeatedly has objected to the group's fund-raising methods and charged journalistic excesses and unauthorized use of church mailing lists. Editor Campbell said his group supplied material to John S. Tomkins, a Presbyterian layman and author of an article in the current Reader's Digest sharply critical of his denomination and some other Protestant bodies. Also credited as a source for the article is the Washington-based Institute on Religion and Democracy, a backer of conservative causes. Like the critical Presbyterian lay organization, Tomkins charges that bureaucrats have taken over the denominations and that a wide gulf exists between the bureaucrats and average parishioners. The Rev. S. David Stoner of Louisville, executive director of the Presbyterian General Assembly Council, said both the Institute on Religion and Democracy and the dissenting Presbyterian group have ``strongly political agendas of their own.'' He said Tomkins has a right and duty to state where he thinks the institutional church has erred, but those disagreeing have a similar duty to clarify the facts. Rebutting the contention that bureaucrats have taken over the denominations and are out of touch with church members, Stoner cites the Presbyterians' democratic processes. He said members elect their representatives who choose their leaders and said staff are hired using carefully set guidelines. He also challenged Tomkin's implication that mainline churches are losing many members to conservative churches. ``Scientific surveys conducted in recent years indicate that very few former members of mainline churches have left to join conservative churches,'' he said. ``Most members who leave are lost not to conservatism but to non-affiliation with any church.'' The special Presbyterian committee, set up to consult with the dissenting group and discuss its asserted refusal to comply with denominational guidelines for special organizations, is to make its final report to the 1991 assembly in June. Johnson said some things his committee learned so far are: - There is a ``widespread feeling in the church'' that the criticizing group ``performs a useful function as a dissenting voice,'' but many who see its value ``have questioned its journalistic tactics.'' - There is a compelling need for the church to ``work for reconciliation among various factions in the church who do not trust and are afraid of each other.''

DOC.HEAD: Reality Brings Kids Back For More of the Baby Sitters Club Books
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It's not like Nancy Drew or The Hardy Boys. They're detectives. They chase bad guys and drive cars. The girls in the Baby Sitters Club books mostly just have trouble with neighborhood snobs, bullies or, maybe, parents. Author Ann M. Martin's characters - seven distinctly different girls who form a baby-sitting cooperative - are like friends to 11-year-old Lynette Kirkman and other admirers of the series, which has put into print 41 million books over the last four years. ``The books are about being a normal kid today,'' said Lynette, of Bristol, Pa. ``They talk about real life and things.'' Being a kid today can be tough. Parents get divorced, and sometimes they marry other people. Then you have two families. Or maybe you move, or a grandparent dies, or your father loses his job. It gets complicated. ``So when you're having problems with your parents or there's something you don't understand, it helps to have a friend around,'' said Megan Brown, 13, of Indianapolis. Into each story are integrated situations that reflect life as it really is lived across America, and that includes elements such as stepfamilies, working mothers, death, adoption and friends or relatives with disabilities. The girls also encounter all sorts of smaller prepubescent woes in each monthly addition to the 43-book series. ``And if I can believe what the kids write to me, they are responding to ... the realism. Kids will write and say, `I really enjoy your books because I can identify with the characters,''' Martin said. Martin, 35, who lives in New York City with a cat named Mouse, plays it straight with her mostly 8- to 12-year-old readers. She doesn't talk down to them or gloss over difficult topics. ``More kids today have been exposed to divorce ... or moved around a lot. They start watching television at an earlier age and watch things that are more sophisticated than what we watched at an early age,'' she said. Jean Feiwel, editorial director at Scholastic Inc., came up with the series idea about five years ago, melding young girls' dual passion for books about clubs and books about baby-sitting. The formula was an instant hit that has topped chain store best-seller lists of children's books 90 percent of the time since the first title appeared in August 1986. Two home videos also are on the market. ``It's one of the most successful series for children ever,'' said Diane Roback, children's book editor at Publishers Weekly. ``And I don't see any signs of its popularity diminishing.'' Meanwhile, the imaginary town of Stoneybrook, Conn., has become a pre-teen's fictional mecca, the place where the Baby Sitters Club meets three times a week to accept clients' phone calls and review sticky situations. ``Like in No. 10 - well, maybe not No. 10 - but in one of the books, one of the kids they baby-sit for gets a hand stuck down the drain in the bathroom tub,'' offers 8-year-old Marian Walsh of Watertown, Conn. ``My favorite one is `Boy-Crazy tacey,' where she goes baby-sitting at the beach and gets crushes on all the boys,'' says 11-year-old Melonie Marnien of Bristol, Pa. ``That was really funny.'' A lot of girls like Stacey the best. In fact, in a Baby Sitters Club Super Special Contest, 27,000 fans cast their votes for the sophisticated, clotheshorse who moved to Connecticut from New York City. But others prefer Claudia (slightly insecure and artistic), Dawn (an ex-Californian who shuns junk food), Kristy (the bossy club president based on one of Martin's close childhood friends), Mary Anne (a shy and responsible girl based on the author herself), Mallory (a would-be children's books author from a big family) or Jessica (an outgoing black ballet dancer). ``I just love them so much ... because you think these girls could be you in a few years,'' enthused Marian, who hopes to start baby-sitting when she gets a little older. ``You'd never think of Pippy Longstocking as a baby sitter.'' Adds Marian's 10-year-old neighbor, Carla Oliva: ``They're not just books to read for enjoyment. They teach you a lot of things . .. like how life is different for different people and how to get along with each other.'' Although Martin weaves serious themes into her books, she chooses not to address such weighty topics as sexual or substance abuse of any kind. It's not that the issues shouldn't be dealt with, the author said. ``I think there are a lot of girls who would benefit from reading about (them), but there are also first-graders out there who are reading these books and those subjects are too heavy for them,'' she said. So Martin sticks to more manageable problems, including the perennial trials of youth: ``Questions about their self-esteem, their self-worth. How important is it to be pretty, to be popular? All sorts of things that we worried about when we were younger. I don't think those things ever change.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues PMs, Dec. 18

DOC.HEAD: Another Marilyn Monroe Documentary At Large
DOC.TEXT: Wowee, the Fox network tonight is showing a special about Marilyn Monroe, ``Marilyn: Something's Got to Give.'' Now the bad news. It may be to documentaries what ``Ishtar'' was to film comedies. Oh, sure, it's daring. Not many Marilyn Monroe documentaries, for example, would put on the screen a slide identifying an interviewee as MONROE'S PSYCHIATRIST'S DAUGHTER. Not many, either, would come right out and say the late actress was ``said to be having an affair'' with President John F. Kennedy. And not many would disclose that the troubled actress, said to have committed suicide in 1962, often was absent from what proved her last movie and ``one morning she nearly fainted under a hairdryer and had to go home.'' But then, this report on her sad last months and the film, the never-finished ``Something's Got to Give,'' is the very first documentary by Fox Entertainment News and must do something to stand out. FEN is Fox's new show-biz news unit. It has vowed to do far more than puff pieces. We should believe them because they say it is so. Tonight's grand opening includes the famous scenes of Monroe cavorting nude - no bare bosoms are sighted - in a sound-stage swimming pool at 20th Century Fox studios. The show is written and narrated by Henry Schipper, who is very earnest and carries on as if chronicling Important Stuff, which is refreshing in this era of TV reporters who smile a lot. (A former print reporter of entertainment news, he has a new book due out soon - ``Bridge Over Troubled Water: An Inside History of The Grammy Awards.'') Schipper appears to be a fan of Monroe, who would be 64 now had she not died at 36 and made it kind of impossible to press on. His thesis is that she wasn't a drug-wracked wreck, as is commonly thought, when fired from ``Give'' after eight weeks of filming. She even was quietly re-hired later, he reports, so nyah, nyah, nyah. Early on, he discloses that she had her personal demons, but as accompanying clips of her screen tests show, she also was ``working hard as an actress and lighting up the screen as only she could.'' ``To the very end, Marilyn Monroe had a beauty and a sensual glow that no other actress could touch.'' Schipper gets a seconding motion from a film editor who worked on ``Give,'' a light-hearted sex comedy. Says the editor: ``She was like a goddess. ... She looked absolutely beautiful.'' Moving right along, Schipper also interviews various others who worked on the film, up to and including the producer. But perhaps the show's main value, such as it is, is the footage from ``Give'' that had been thought destroyed. The, er, historic shots of a mostly happy, radiant Monroe include her with two kids who played her children - they're interviewed, too - and with Jess, a poodle hired for the film. Jess keeps forgetting to bark on cue. The off-screen dog trainer is heard to snap: ``Jess, speak! Speak! Jess, speak!'' It is a high moment in the show, better even than the nude-Monroe swimming scenes, which seem quite modest now but wowed 'em in '62. She was said to have had a cold when she did the scene, but was a trouper, Schipper says, asserting that ``although her four hours in the pool had aggravated her virus, Marilyn continued to work, and work well.'' The other highlights in the show include Schipper's report that Monroe's absences from ``Give,'' its ensuing budget overruns, and the studio's bloated ``Cleopatra'' caused stern measures to be taken at Fox. Not only were other productions stopped, but the watering of lawns on the lot was halted, and the studio commissary was - gasp - shut down. Despite such fascinating reportage, Fox's Monroe special just doesn't turn up anything scandalous, or even exciting. Schipper tries hard, by golly. But when he concludes that the poor lady ``was a scapegoat for Hollywood's dying studio system'' and ``was not an assembly-line star,'' well ... Better he had devoted the entire hour to insights about the actress from Monroe's Psychiatrist's Daughter. --- Elsewhere in television ... THE AXMAN COMETH: As expected, NBC's new based-on-a-movie series, ``Ferris Bueller'' and ``Parenthood,'' have been axed, as has the second-season ``Grand.'' Three newcomers are due January on NBC: ``Dark Shadows,'' a new version of the old gothic horror series, ``Blossom,'' a sitcom about a teen-age girl who lives with two older brothers and her divorced father, and ``Sunday Best.'' The last, the latest hopeful opposite CBS' toprated ``60 Minutes,'' is billed as a one-hour ``topical and comedic magazine show featuring mostly original material.'' It also will offer ``select clips of NBC programs.'' Oh, boy, a new art form: minireruns. On the bright side, CBS' ``Lonesome Dove'' miniseries, which became the nation's 14th most-watched show of its kind when aired last February, will be rerun Jan. 20 and 22-24.

DOC.HEAD: New Leading Economic Indicator: Jobless Insurance for Homeowners
DOC.TEXT: First they bought a piece of property. Now, as fears of joblessness spread, homeowners are being urged to buy some peace of mind. More and more lenders have been trying to sell coverage to homeowners that promises to pay monthly mortgage bills in the event of a job loss. The new insurance pitch, appearing in glossy brochures recently mailed out by banks to prospective and current homeowners, is one of the latest leading indicators of today's rising unemployment. The Labor Department reported last week that the nation's jobless rate shot up to a three-year high of 5.9 percent in November. ``We're getting swamped now with requests from all over for the coverage,'' said Richard T. Harris, president of Morgard Inc., of St. Davids, which is one of the largest insurance agencies offering this sort of coverage. Roughly 40 banks and mortgage companies recently began marketing the new insurance, he said, including Chase Manhattan Corp., Shearson Lehman Bros.' mortgage division and California Federal Savings Loan. For years banks have offered consumers the chance to buy insurance that covered the minimum balance on their monthly credit card bills in the event of unemployment, death or disability. Banks say the new mortgage coverage is good for them as well as mortgage holders - protecting the bank's monthly loan payments and guarding a homeowner's most valuable asset against foreclosure. But consumer groups, who have vigorously criticized credit card insurance as a high-profit product that costs consumers too much, say that homeowners should approach the new mortgage insurance with similar caution. ``We found that various forms of mortgage insurance are priced extremely high and are one of the primary methods banks are making their profits,'' said Peggy Miller of the Washington-based Consumer Federation of America. Miller said the group had not yet studied the new unemployment insurance offerings. But, she added, prospective homeowners are particularly vulnerable to buying insurance without shopping around because they are ``extremely worried about getting a mortgage.'' Morgard said it graduates rates according to the occupation and geographic location of the policy holder. Its insurance is underwritten by large insurance firms, including Montgomery Ward Insurance Co. Using monthly reports from the U.S. Labor Department, Morgard deems some occupations and locations riskier than others in terms of their job-loss potential and raises rates accordingly, Harris said. Morgard's average national rate is 3 percent of a homeowners monthly mortgage payment, he said. For a homeowner with a monthly payment of $1,000, that would mean an insurance premium of around $30 a month. However, some consumer groups said the window through which policy holders can collect seemed narrow. For example, the insurance doesn't begin paying benefits until 31 days after the homeowner becomes unemployed, or the second mortgage payment. If the homeowner becomes unemployed within 90 days following the inception of coverage, benefits are limited to a refund of premiums. After the second year of coverage, the 90-day cap is eliminated. Coverage also is limited to a year of monthly payments and a maximum of $2,500. Considering the payback, ``it's a fairly high premium,'' said Robert Hunter, president of National Insurance Consumer Organization. He said that it made sense for homeowners who are ``very high risk for losing your job and are not going to get laid off too soon but maybe some day.'' Harris expects 5 percent to 8 percent of Chase's roughly 200,000 mortgage holders to sign up for the insurance. Initial mailings went out to 30,000 Chase customers on Dec. 1. Harris said the bank's profit on the premium was minimal, with commissions averaging 5 percent to 10 percent of the premium and usually covering only the bank's cost of adminstering the insurance.

DOC.HEAD: The Man Inside the Woman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Havana'' opened in New York on Dec. 7, in other markets on Dec. 12 and 14.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Lena Olin was a tomboy. She didn't want to be pretty. She cut her hair short and refused to wear dresses. She preferred sports to dolls and fighting to tea parties. She changed once she turned 13 - no one who's seen ``The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' and ``Enemies, A Love Story'' would question that. But watch those films, the way she uncorks a wine bottle with her teeth or the erotic tension between Olin and other women and you'll see a masculine spirit that runs much deeper than a bowler hat. And she hasn't stopped looking for new ways to bring that quality into her professional life. As a Swedish actress, she's been compared to Garbo, but when Olin speaks of tackling classic roles it's not only ``Camille'' that's on her mind. ``One of my first stage parts was in a comedy called `Able Drugger,' an English comedy,'' Olin, dressed in jeans and a simple, white blouse, recalled in a recent interview. ``I played a man and I enjoyed that. I very much would like to play a man. I'd like to do `Hamlet.''' Hamlet is a tragic male, incapable of making up his mind. But Olin might be too tough as the Danish prince. Her characters - Sabina in ``The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' and Masha in ``Enemies, A Love Story'' - are erotic cynics: intelligent, complex, highly sexual, painfully self-aware. There's something otherwordly about them; they're objects of desire yet very much alone. They make their own rules. Fair play no longer matters; they've been hurt too often. Sabina is an avant-garde artist living in Czechoslovakia during the 1968 uprising, a free spirit in an oppressed country, the mistress of a seductive doctor who can make tugging a curtain seem pornographic. Masha, for which Olin received an Academy Award nomination for best supporting actress, is an embittered Holocaust survivor, a force of life but an even stronger force of death. In ``Havana,'' her new film, Olin plays Roberta Duran, a Swede trapped in a ``Casablanca''-like love triangle, torn between American playboy-gambler Robert Redford and Cuban revolutionary Raul Julia. Roberta - or Bobbi as she's called -is somewhat softer than Masha or Sabina. She's more passive, easier to manipulate and, for Olin, an easier person to like. ``Sabina's so bored with life, so fed up with life,'' Olin said. ``And Masha's so distraught. She was hard to live with. I like to be able to close the door to the studio, but it's very difficult with some characters. I also felt very vulnerable when I did Bobbi. I wanted to be good when I did Bobbi, and I kept that with me. ``Masha was very hard to come back to every night, to sleep with every night. You touch areas in yourself that I don't think are very healthy to touch.'' Olin, 35, was born in Stockholm. Her parents were actors, her father, Stij Olin, appearing in Ingmar Bergman's classic ``The Seventh Seal.'' But they divorced when she was little and for all her all spirit, she remembered herself as self-conscious and insecure, more at home with inner thoughts than with the outside world. ``I was a weird child and I still see things differently,'' she recalled in a soft voice, smiling shyly. ``I always remember very strange things. I have a capacity to walk in an apartment where there are boxes and papers, and someone will say, `Excuse the boxes and papers.' And I'll say, `Oh, I didn't see that.' I think I concentrate on other things, small things that can be revealing.'' Acting was the perfect way to express herself, and at age 20 Olin entered the Royal Dramatic Theater School, joining Bergman's famed company of players. On stage, she starred in the plays of Shakespeare, Strindberg and Chekhov and she also worked with Bergman on films, appearing in ``After the Rehearsal'' and ``Fanny and Alexander.'' Olin sees nothing peculiar or silly about her tomboy roots. It was a phase to build upon rather than outgrow, a yearning to be in touch with all sides of herself, a rebellion against the rules that men and women are supposed to obey that went beyond mere role-playing. ``If I ever had a daughter I'd bring her up the same way, encourage her to do what I did,'' said Olin, a single mother whose son, August, is named after Strindberg. ``I think it's important for everyone to stay open, not to be afraid, and if you push that way, I think that makes a difference for an actor. The great thing about Marlin Brando, he's very macho and all of that, but there's a huge woman in there as well.''

DOC.HEAD: CDs: Perfect Sound, Forever? Collectors Disagree
DOC.TEXT: Victor Bisio doesn't consider himself a fanatic about music, even if he does own some 10,000 albums and 2,500 compact discs. But when he buys CDs, he expects them to live up to their original slogan - ``perfect sound, forever.'' No pops. No hisses. No scratches. Music that brings you right in the studio. That's why Bisio's massive collection includes a credit slip, good for three albums, from Columbia Records. The slip arrived last summer, a few months after he had purchased CDs of Barbra Streisand's first three records. ``There had been mention from Columbia that they couldn't find the original tapes but they put out the CDs anyway,'' said Bisio, a recording engineer who lives in Encino, Calif. ``They were are the worst sounding CDs I ever heard. They were screechy and distorted. When she hit the high notes, it just shattered your speakers.'' Compact discs arrived in the mid-1980s, and pushed LPs out of stores. Since then, Bisio and other collectors have spent long hours comparing notes and keeping the pressure on record companies. Phil Cohen, a Florida collector who owns over 6,000 records, bought the CD of Jimi Hendrix's ``Electric Ladyland'' three times before he found a satisfactory copy. Background noise made some tracks on James Taylor's ``Sweet Baby James'' virtually unlistenable for another collector. Collectors blame CD problems on laziness and greed, insisting records made from inferior tapes were rushed onto the market and that songs were shortened or eliminated to fit albums on single discs. The record companies admit mistakes, but say some problems were unavoidable in switching from LPs to CDs. ``In the beginning, at least, for the people who were asked to handle it, it took a little bit more understanding of technology than to just say, `Pull this tape and have it mastered,''' said Bill Levinson, director of catalog development at PolyGram Records. ``We had a handful of records, (Eric Clapton's) `461 Ocean Boulevard,' that were just not done from correct tapes. The `461' record was bad enough that we put out a new one, and I told people in the press that we had done it.'' Among the worst CDs: -Fleetwood Mac's ``Rumours.'' A multiplatinum record originally released in the mid-1970s, it was pressed by Warner Bros. Records a decade later from an old production tape and the result was a muffled, badly distorted CD. A dramatically improved version was later released. -The Jefferson Airplane's ``After Bathing at Baxter's'' was released in such poor condition that RCA Records apologized, remastered the tape and offered an exchange. Collectors also had complaints about albums by Elton John, Simon and Garfunkel, Boz Scaggs, Jimmy Buffett, Carly Simon and Yes. Harry Chapin's ``Verities and Balderdash'' come without the booklet of photos and lyrics that was included on the LP; Gordon Lightfoot's ``Gord's Gold'' was minus a song available on the LP. ``There are some companies where no one in the music department makes the decision,'' Levinson said. ``Someone at the managerial desk says, `These next six ones are for reissue because the computer says these are the ones to go.' Maybe they're good, maybe they're not.'' Artists are beginning to take an active interest. John Arrias, Streisand's personal engineer, put together remastered versions of her first three records, which have not yet been released. Guitarist Jimmy Page was so unhappy with the condition of several Led Zeppelin CDs released by Atlantic Records he went back to the studio and helped produce a box set. The Bee Gees consulted with PolyGram on a recent anthology which collectors say is very good. And Columbia, which received the most criticism from collectors, started Columbia-Legacy Records this year. Legacy has already put out well-received box sets of blues great Robert Johnson and the Byrds, made with the assistance of former band member Roger McGuinn. Rich Bauer, product manager of catalog reissues at Legacy, said he hoped the problems were behind them. ``When you try to put together a package from a record that's 20-25 years old, it can be difficult to do everything as well as it can be done,'' he said. ``There are some records that haven't come out, such as the first two Jeff Beck records, because of problems finding the original tapes.'' PolyGram, one of the first companies to set up its own domestic plant for producing CDs, received the most praise from collectors. Rhino Records is also well regarded, especially since it's an independent label and needs permission from other companies to acquire master tapes. ``We put out a compilation of hits of the 1970s and it was difficult,'' explained Gary Stewart, vice president of A&R (Artist and Repertoire) at Rhino. ``Major labels are very professional, good to deal with. But for independent sources, we have a hard time tracking them down and making deals, especially companies no longer in the music business.'' CDs are digitally mastered (as opposed to analog for LPs), a concept first tested in France in the 1920s. Digital is thought to produce a ``cleaner'' sound, with less noise and distortion than analog. Digital recordings (also known as PCM, or Pulse Code Modulation) were first demonstrated in the late '60s and became available to the general public in 1972 when Denon released the Mozart Hunting Suite by the Smetana Quartet. PCM recordings were only available on vinyl and cassette until the '80s when they were issued in the form of a 5-inch ``compact disc'' developed by Sony and Philips. Collectors have few complaints about new albums, but records made more than 10 years ago create problems. Companies may have a hard time tracking down the original master and end up using a second- or third-generation tape. Also, technology has advanced so rapidly that re-creating sounds produced on old equipment can require drastic measures. ``I recently completed several classical records released in the 1950s and 1960s,'' said Dennis Drake, PolyGram's vice president of studio and technical operations. ``To transfer this catalog to CD we had to reconstruct the original machines: a tube tape recorder and tube console. These machines playing back the masters gave us the exact sound of the original recordings.'' Collectors hope the worst is over. Pete Howard, publisher and editor of International CD Exchange (ICE), a monthly newsletter that reviews compact discs, notes that letters he receives these days deal more with minor compliants - song length, lyrics etc. Still, hard feelings remain. Collectors have asked record companies to drop the price of CDs not made from the original masters, and to label discs to inform the customer whether they've been remastered from an earlier version. ``But the sticker could mean different things,'' said PolyGram's Levinson. ``The implication of remastering could mean the previous one was no good, or the previous one might have been good and you're making it better. ``I also wouldn't want to have to put it in the artwork all the time. It costs more to do that than to do remastering. ...It's a tough issue of balancing information and consumer needs. Sometimes the consumer thinks he deserves more than we can give.''

DOC.HEAD: Episcopalians Debate Arizona Convention After King Rebuke
DOC.TEXT: Episcopalians are caught up in agonizing debate over plans to hold their 1991 national convention in Arizona now that the state's voters have rejected a holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr. Even if the site remains the same, as now seems likely, leaders say it will be a different sort of convention, shorn of celebrative frills and highlighting racial justice. The debate has become so emotionally strained that the Episcopal Church's presiding bishop, the Most Rev. Edmond Lee Browning, has called a special executive council meeting for Jan. 5 to consider ways to trim down the affair. After weeks of debate, contentious conference calls and consultations with church members, especially blacks, Browning said he was convinced the church must adhere to its scheduled meeting place in Phoenix July 10-20. ``I believe that this rougher road is the one that the church is meant to walk,'' he said. He has authority to determine the site, with advice and consent of the executive council of the 2.5 million-member denomination. The convention won't be ``business as usual,'' Browning said, suggesting that it could be shortened and modified and also that it could offer a powerful witness in Arizona to racial equality. At his invitation, South Africa's Anglican archbishop, the Rev. Desmond Tutu, widely honored for his struggles against racism, agreed to lead a rally to open the convention. Browning's comments haven't quieted the arguing, although the denomination has avoided a racial split. Whites and blacks are on both sides of the debate. Twelve of the 99 domestic Episcopal dioceses - and scores of local congregations - have formally urged that the triennial governing convention either be canceled or held somewhere else. Warnings have come that some elected representatives might refuse to take part if the meeting stays in Phoenix. The Washington, D.C., diocesan council, for example, recommended its representatives not participate if it's in Arizona. In urging another site, the Diocese of Atlanta, the birthplace of King, offered to play host to the convention, which usually draws more than 10,000 church people. The furor broke out after Arizona voters in a Nov. 6 referendum narrowly defeated a proposed state holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader. Although months of advance planning already had been made for the Episcopalians' once-in-three-years convention, calls quickly arose for a switch in plans. Holding the convention in Phoenix ``and the economic benefits associated with it'' would be ``an inappropriate witness'' to the church's stand for racial equality, the New York diocesan council declared. Ohio became a virtual intrastate battleground. The Ohio diocesan convention, based in Cleveland, called for a new site, but the southern Ohio diocese, based in Cincinnati, urged sticking with Phoenix. Southern Ohio Bishop Herbert Thompson, a black, said that it was important to go to Phoenix to show support for racial equality and that it would be costly and irresponsible to abandon numerous contracts made for the convention. He said pulling out would imply abandoning Arizona blacks and ``we need to stand with them at this time'' to ``overcome this injustice and prejudice.'' But Ohio's Suffragan Bishop Arthur Williams Jr., also black, said he didn't see how the convention could help much since ``we will spend most of the 20 days in an air-conditioned hall ... or eating and sleeping.'' Ohio Bishop James R. Moodey, a white, said some money might have to be paid to cancel advance guarantees, ``but moral leadership, not money, should guide our decision.'' Other diocesan bodies calling for moving the meeting included the Rio Grande Diocese, based in Albuquerque, N.M., which includes southwestern Texas, and the New England province, which has seven dioceses. Many secular and some auxiliary Episcopal organizations scrapped plans for Arizona meetings after the defeat of the King holiday. The commissioner of the National Football League said he will recommend the 1993 Super Bowl be moved from Phoenix. ``We do not have that choice,'' Browning said. ``We are in this for the long haul. We cannot turn our backs on the injustices done to minorities ...'' He said many Arizonans have worked hard to overcome prejudice and need support. He urged that ``we stand with them and together make a vigorous witness to the dignity of all God's people.'' Browning said the church's executive council would discuss ways to scale down the convention rather than move it during the special meeting next month in Elizabeth, N.J. But that question conceivably could be opened by the 40-member council. Several church leaders who have met with Browning have suggested the convention should make an ``economic witness'' such as particularly patronizing minority-owned businesses.

DOC.TEXT: The monthly U.S. Catholic said that 76 percent of readers responding to a survey would welcome female priests in their parishes and that a third believe that perpetuating the male-only priesthood is sinful. The magazine, which is published by the Claretian order, said the results were based on responses from 274 of the 1,300 readers to whom questionnaires were mailed. A majority of the respondents were women. Sixty-nine percent said they thought that if Jesus were living today in the United States, he would ordain women. If women were admitted to the Roman Catholic priesthood, 50 percent of those responding said they would encourage their daughters to become priests. But 68 percent said they saw little hope in their lifetime of women being allowed in that role. --- NEW HAVEN, Conn. (AP) - The Knights of Columbus says the 108-year-old Roman Catholic fraternal and charitable organization has enrolled its 1,500,000th member - Michael J. March of Antigonish, Nova Scotia. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - The Southern Baptist executive committee has elected a new vice president for public relations for distinctly promotional purposes, separating that job from news services. The post previously was seen strictly as a news-reporting task, prior to the firing earlier this year of the top journalists of Baptist Press at the behest of new fundamentalist leaders. ``Our convention at this time needs to hear about good and positive things that are occuring within the convention,'' said the executive committee's chairman, Sam W. Pace of Antlers, Okla. In naming Mark T. Coppenger, an Indiana state Baptist leader, to the new post, Pace said that ``we feel this is more of a public relations responsibility than a press responsibility.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Nearly 2,000 ministers of the United Church of Christ signed a newspaper advertisement calling on President Bush to refrain from war with Iraq. The full-page ad, which appeared in the Washington Post on Dec. 11, said: ``Mr. President, do not go to war with Iraq. We ... call on you to work through the United Nations and with other nations for a just and peaceful solution of this crisis. ``It is our prayer that war can be avoided, that the lives of thousands of innocent people can be spared, and that a just peace will prevail in the Middle East.'' --- RYE, N.Y. (AP) - The Union of American Hebrew Congregations says using force against Iraq would be ``an acceptable moral option'' after other means of resolving the Middle East crisis had been considered and explored. The 200-member policy-making board of trustees of the union, representing Reform Judaism, said using force would be acceptable to eliminate Iraq's nuclear capabilities and to free invaded Kuwait if peaceful means did not work. --- RICHMOND, Va. (AP) - Members of the Discovery United Methodist Church have produced a Christmas video that portrays the story of the birth of Jesus and also the history of Santa Claus. ``Many people just don't realize the connection between Santa Claus and the birth of Christ,'' said the Rev. Jim Lavender, the church's pastor. ``We want to bridge that gap between religious and secular philosophies and let people know that, indeed, two historical legends are intertwined.'' Church members wrote, produced and acted in the 30-minute video, using help from a Richmond-based production company. The video has a cast of 70 people, 30 sheep, 4 camels and a donkey.

DOC.HEAD: Daihatsu Charade: Spartan Economy, but With Legroom
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The Daihatsu Charade is a practical car that has special appeal for budget-minded households, environmentalists, quality-conscious consumers and anyone who frets over the safety of small cars. Built by the 83-year-old Japanese manufacturer Daihatsu Motor Co., the Charade is a relative newcomer to the United States. It arrived in the 1988 model year and sales thus far have totaled only about 36,500. The little car has gained attention in a short time, however. The Charade is among the most fuel-efficient cars sold in the United States, which admirers say makes it both economical and cleaner than many competitors. The consumer group Public Citizen named it one of the top environmentally sensitive vehicles in the country on the basis of fuel economy. In October, the automotive marketing research firm J.D. Power and Associates reported that the Charade received more owner recommendations per vehicle than any other nameplate except Acura in Power's 1990 customer satisfaction survey. And last year the Charade ranked top in its class in crashworthiness tests by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The car protects its owners' wallets pretty well, too: The base price of $6,597 is less than half that of the average car, and fuel economy in mixed city-highway driving is over 40 miles per gallon. The thriftiness is squeezed out of a three-cylinder, 1-liter engine that develops only 53 horsepower. Pickup suffers with an engine that small, and Daihatsu should consider a tachometer to help drivers make their way through the five-speed manual transmission. The 1990 hatchback offered for testing got good marks for maneuverability, however, thanks to its small size - 144.9 inches long - and rack and pinion steering. The exterior was simple: a 3-door hatchback design similar to the Ford Festiva and Dodge Colt. There wasn't even molding on the sides of the Charade body. But fit and finish were admirable. The interior was Spartan and fairly loud from engine and road noise, though without rattles. There were no side map pockets on the doors but there was a coin holder beneath the parking brake lever, and the rear seat was fairly well cushioned. Another nice touch: The ventilation fan did a good job of moving air around inside. Rear legroom was surprisingly good when the front seats were moved up a ways, though my knees touched the seatbacks when they were moved all the way back on their tracks and reclined slightly. Daihatsu says there is 31.8 inches of rear legroom in the car, nearly equal to the 31.9 inches in the new Toyota Tercel, which is nearly 17 inches longer on the outside. There was a handy rear tray to help cover items stowed in the hatchback area. Rear carpeting in the hatchback area was thin and had a tendency to bunch up behind the rear seat. The seat, by the way, folds down for additional cargo space. The car meets its goal of providing basic transportation and is a worthy competitor in the crowded subcompact field, which includes the Tercel (starting at $6,488), the Nissan Sentra (starting at $7,999) and the Honda Civic (starting at more than $6,600). Daihatsu says on average its buyers are about 30, have some college education and an annual household income of between $25,000 and $40,000. The 235 Daihatsu dealers in 22 states are still selling 1990 models, the company says. It does not expect 1991 models to arrive in showrooms until February. Prices of the 1991 models have not been announced. Consumer Reports did not have an owner trouble report for the Charade.
