DOC.TEXT: The nation's purchasing managers predicted a recession will grip the economy in the first half of next year, but forecast a turnaround by early next summer. The report, issued Tuesday by the National Association of Purchasing Management Inc., reflects the views of many financial analysts who say the economy has or soon will slip into a recession. The association's semiannual economic forecast reported its members were ``extremely pessimistic'' about the economy for the first half of 1991. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Industrialist Armand Hammer was remembered as a tireless crusader for international peace who improved the huan condition by investing millions in education, medicine and the arts. The flamboyant, globe-trotting chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corp., the nation's 16th largest industrial company, died Monday at his home in the Westwood district late Monday following a brief illness. He was 92. There was speculation his death could make Occidental a takeover target. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A big new decline in bank earnings makes it increasingly clear the government fund insuring deposits will sink to a historic low and need more money, a top regulator said. Hurt by sinking real estate values in the Northeast, commercial banks earned $3.75 billion in the July-September quarter, down 29 percent from the previous quarter, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Tuesday. Profits slipped from $5.4 billion in the second quarter and $6.3 billion in the first three months of the year. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman predicted continued bleak news when results are reported for the final three months of the year. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - President Bush renominated a top banking regulator over the reported objections of his chief of staff, John Sununu. The White House, in a brief statement, said Tuesday that Bush planned to appoint Robert L. Clarke to a second five-year term as comptroller of the currency, the regulator of nationally chartered banks. He must be confirmed by the Senate. --- VIENNA, Austria (AP) - OPEC oil ministers were told that crude prices should remain robust as long as the military standoff continues in the Persian Gulf region. But one minister called on the 13-nation cartel Tuesday to cap its gushing output immediately to help bolster prices. ``In view of the situation in the oil markets at the moment, I am worried about the production figure,'' said Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh. The cartel, badly battered by the Gulf crisis, will open its formal winter strategy session on Wednesday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The nation's foreign trade deficit, hurt by higher oil prices and increased military spending from the Persian Gulf crisis, widened a sharp 13.9 percent in the July-September quarter, the government said. The Commerce Department said Tuesday the $25.6 billion third-quarter deficit was up from a second-quarter deficit of $22.5 billion. It was the largest quarterly imbalance since a $26.7 billion gap in the final three months of 1989. The higher deficit in the July-September quarter was viewed as especially ominous because an improving trade balance had been the only bright spot in a lackluster economy this year. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A court order consolidating nearly 70,000 asbestos lawsuits against Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. got an important legal boost, but representatives of injured workers promised to fight the settlement effort. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein in Brooklyn on Tuesday proceeded with imposing a class action for Eagle-Picher after a request to place the company in involuntary bankruptcy in Cincinnati was withdrawn. Weinstein issued written orders certifying the class, suspending all asbestos claims involving Eagle-Picher but ordering the company to begin paying $45 million to victims who already have settled their cases. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The Equitable, the nation's third-largest life insurer, said it will convert from a mutual company to one owned by stockholders so that it can more easily bolster its troubled finances. The Equitable, which has more than $135 billion in assets, would become the the largest insurer to take such a step, industry analysts said Tuesday. By converting from a mutual company, which is owned by its policyholders, to a stockholder company, the Equitable will be able to raise funds by selling shares to investors. --- LONDON (AP) - Shares in Britain's 12 regional electricity companies surged as much as 66 percent on their first day of trading, prompting opponents to accuse the government of selling the industry off too cheaply. Prime Minister John Major on Tuesday rejected the charge, and called the $10 billion privatization the most popular in the government's decade-old program. It's also the biggest and most complex. A package of 1,000 of the 12 stocks jumped to 1,578 pounds, or $3,061, by the close of trading from an opening price of 1,000 pounds, or $1,940. ---

The stock market eased back Tuesday, as losses among high-tech issues helped erase Monday's modest gains. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 10.64 points to 2,586.14. The dollar strengthened against major foreign currencies. Bond prices rose. Gold prices were mostly lower. Energy futures fell. Grains and soybean futures were mostly lower. Livestock and pork futures were mixed. Coffee futures soared.

DOC.HEAD: A Phone in Every Village, New Telmex Owners Promise
DOC.TEXT: The new owners of Mexico's phone system have promised to double the size of the company within six years. A consortium including St. Louis-based Southwestern Bell, France Cable & Radio and Mexico's Grupo Carso conglomerate is buying a controlling interest in Telefonos de Mexico, the state-owned telephone company, for $1.76 billion. Grupo Carso is the lead partner and will run the newly privatized Telmex. ``We promise the investment and effort necessary to grow rapidly, 12 percent a year, a rate that means the size of the company will double in six years,'' Grupo Carso President Carlos Slim said Tuesday. He said the number of public telephones would be quadrupled in four years and every village with at least 500 residents would have access to a telephone by 1994. The emphasis, he said, will be on expanding and modernizing the service by investing ``at the most intense rhythm possible.'' Digital equipment, mobile telephones, better support services for major clients and decentralization are top priority, he said. But it will take time, he warned, to give Mexico a truly modern, efficient telephone system. ``One must have patience,'' he said. Slim also said the new owners will do their ``utmost to avoid reducing personnel and instead train them for new jobs that modernization will demand.'' Telmex, which now provides only about 5 million lines to this nation of more than 80 million people, has 50,000 people on its payroll. Union opposition to the privatization eased somewhat after the government agreed to provide $325 million in financing so the employees can buy stock representing 4.4 percent of Telmex. In addition, the government plans to sell Telmex stock on the Mexican and international stock exchanges. Slim said the resources, experience and technical expertise of Southwestern Bell and France Cable & Radio will be important to Telmex's success Even though the foreign partners will not play a role in administering Telmex, they will have a decision-making role. The privatization of Telmex is a centerpiece of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's campaign to modernize Mexico's economy and attract foreign investment.

DOC.HEAD: Toymakers Help Other Inventors While Building Business
LaserPhoto DN-6
DOC.TEXT: Two inventors have crafted their own Santa's workshop in a Fort Worth suburb, breaking into the tough toy industry while helping others do the same. After running into closed doors at several leading toy companies, Gary Blankenship and Dorian Sandlin formed a merry, if loose-knit, band of toymakers who are developing their own products. ``We try not to let the everyday drudgery of business, bookkeeping bring us down on our creativity. The main thing here is to have fun and create,'' Sandlin said. Blankenship, 34, and Sandlin, 39, started talking toys when they met in church two years ago. Blankenship asked Sandlin, a commercial artist, to design a package for a stuffed dog he'd created. Sandlin then started pitching toy ideas of his own and last year they formed Yapco Toy Co., named for that first stuffed dog, Yappie the Yuppie Pup. The pair, who now operate out of a small office in Bedford, first achieved success with KidsFlex, which hospitals have purchased to help develop the eye-hand coordination of therapy patients. The toy is a crescent-shaped tube filled with water and a rubber ball. Grips at both ends of the tube are squeezed to move the ball from one side to the other. The toy is the lead product for Yapco, which is projecting more than $1.5 million in sales next year. Blankenship and Sandlin said they are negotiating with a Japanese company to distribute KidsFlex there. To finance more creations, Blankenship and Sandlin started helping other inventors launch theirs. This year, they created Toyquest Inc. to provide other toy creators advice and help with packaging, patenting and making a prototype. Toyquest can develop simple toys, like card games, for as little as $5,000, Sandlin said. More sophisticated toys, such as electronics items, may take an investment 10 times that size. Initial inquiries are free. ``We found ourselves in a situation where we go to toy companies with an idea and they'd basically laugh you right out,'' Sandlin said. ``We saw a market out there, friends of ours who had ideas, good ideas from good people out there. That's what we wanted to tap into and hopefully make part of the Yapco line. That would help us and help them, too.'' Inventors have the option of joining Yapco's toy line, and many have. Blankenship and Sandlin and more than 30 of their clients will unveil abot 50 products at the New York Toy Fair, the industry's showcase event, in February. ``It's pretty exciting once you've had an idea and you see it being exhibited in one of these shows. It's pretty spectacular,'' Blankenship said. ``Gary and Dorian really bring a quality agenda with Toyquest,'' said Dale Brandon, a Cleveland-based toy consultant. ``There's plenty of room for champions to come along in this industry.'' Brandon, who founded a specialized toy retail chain, is one of 26 people whom Blankenship and Sandlin turned to for advice and guidance. He believes the toy industry has suffered by squeezing out creative inventors such as them. ``We're still propped up by Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles and sedentary video games,'' Brandon said. About 30 percent of the sales by toy giant Mattel Inc. are items that come from idea submissions outside of the company, said Mattel spokeswoman Donna Gibbs in Los Angeles. Mattel's Magic Nursery doll was an inventor's idea and has become one of the company's top-selling items this holiday, Ms. Gibbs said. ``There's a stable of inventors that we stay pretty much in constant contact with,'' Ms. Gibbs said. Those inventors usually have previous experience in the toy industry, though, she said. In addition to Yappie and KidsFlex, Yapco has developed a series of stuffed cats built around Cruising Charlie, who looks like a gaudy tourist, several educational products, some board games and a few gag items. Yapco already sells some of the items in specialty stores in California and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Eagle-Picher Action Just First Step in National Legal Crisis
DOC.TEXT: A judge's order consolidating nearly 70,000 claims against Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. is a first - and by no means guaranteed - step in resolving the nation's biggest product liability problem, legal experts say. Lawyers for victims said they will appeal the move by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, which they claim would lead to a settlement that short-changes workers suffering from lung cancer and other diseases. Attorneys for other companies with large asbestos liabilities plan to wait for the Eagle-Picher case to develop before seeking class action status. And experts warned that Eagle-Picher's claims represented just a fraction of a crowded legal docket. ``It is unprecedented, innovative and one way to attack the problem, but it does not represent a solution,'' said Drew Berry, a Newark, N.J., lawyer who represents several defendant companies. For instance, one hitch in a global settlement is that nearly all of the 100,000 asbestos claims clogging state and federal courts name several companies whose products were used at a work place. Therefore, resolution of claims against Eagle-Picher would represent only partial settlement of a victim's demands. Lawsuits would remain on court dockets until claims against all defendants were resolved. Nonetheless, Weinstein got an important legal boost Tuesday when a federal bankruptcy judge in Cincinnati dismissed a motion to throw Eagle-Picher into involuntary bankruptcy proceedings. That could have suspended all action in the case. The motion was a last-minute attempt by victims' lawyers to stop Weinstein from declaring the class action, which consolidates all present and future claims against Eagle-Picher for settlement. In addition to declaring the class, Weinstein suspended all asbestos litigation involving Eagle-Picher but ordered the company to begin paying $45 million to victims who already have settled their cases. A proposed settlement plan calls for creating a trust estimated at $625 million over 20 years to pay Eagle-Picher claimants. Victims representatives complained it offers too little money, few safeguards and allows the company to pay its bills but not settle claims. ``Under the plan, asbestos victims are the last in line to receive awards for compensation for their illnesses and deaths,'' said Heather Maurer, executive director of the 18,000-member Asbetos Victims of America. Plaintiffs lawyers said they would challenge the class action in the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on numerous legal grounds. They said Weinstein lacked jurisdiction, appointed lawyers unfit to represent their clients and supported a plan that would short-change victims. Also unresolved is whether Weinstein can usurp jurisidiction from cases now in state courts. In addition, no method of payment has been established, which both victim and company lawyers would be likely to fight. ``We believe the judge does not have the power to do what he is purporting to do,'' said Fred Baron, a Dallas lawyer for several thousand victims, who said attorneys would mount a ``frontal attack'' on Weinstein's order. The battle over Eagle-Picher could shape the future of what is by far the biggest product liability problem ever to confront the U.S. legal system. Cases clog state and federal courts nationwide and new claims are being filed daily. Asbestos was used widely in insulation, boilers, automobile brake linings and other products. Illness from inhaling asbestos fibers often takes decades to appear, and cases have been mounting since the early 1970s. Weinstein favors mass settlements to save the time, enormous cost and damage to companies' reputations in bankruptcy proceedings. But he is charting new waters, and some companies with large asbestos liabilities said they were not eager to plunge in. ``We're very interested in what the judge is doing. We have some question about whether he can pull it off,'' said John O'Brien, associate general counsel of Keene Corp., which is struggling to cope with about 70,000 lawsuits stemming from insulation products made by a subsidiary for more than 50 years. More than a dozen companies already have filed for bankruptcy court protection because of their asbestos liabilites, including Celotex Corp. and National Gypsum Co. in the last six weeks. To declare a class action, companies must demonstrate their funds are so limited that they cannot meet claims and continue normal operations. Eagle-Picher said it faces bankruptcy soon without a resolution.

DOC.HEAD: Influential Trade Group Predicts Recession
DOC.TEXT: A prominent trade group predicts the nation will dip into a recession next year, but says export growth and a strong dollar will brighten the economy by next summer. The National Association of Purchasing Management issued its semiannual economic forecast Tuesday. It matches the views of many financial analysts who say the economy has entered or soon will slip into a recession. ``The only difference I have with them is my recession has already started,'' said Edward J. Campbell, senior economist with the investment firm Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. The trade group, which is composed of purchasing managers at manufacturing companies nationwide, reported its members were ``extremely pessimistic'' about the economy for the first half of 1991. The association conducts regular research on the economy, including a monthly survey of its members. ``Although pessimistic about a recession in 1991, purchasers expect a recovery to begin in the later half of the year fueled by continued relatively strong growth in exports and a declining trend in inflation,'' said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee. Overall economic growth will be 2.2 percent next year, with costs for wages and benefits rising 4.2 percent, the report predicted. The association also dramatically cut its forecast for capital spending in 1990. In May, it predicted an 8.1 percent increase in capital spending this year. Now it has reduced the growth estimate to 1.4 percent. The group's purchasing managers index for November, first reported last week, stood at 41.3 percent - its lowest point in eight years. The index, developed in conjuction with the U.S. Commerce Department, gauges production, employment, new orders, vendor performance and inventory. Companies surveyed also reported they are operating at only 82 percent of their normal capacity, down from 85 percent a year ago. Mild inflation is forecast, despite the recent runup in oil prices spurred by the Persian Gulf crisis. ``It sounds like a pretty good and standard forecast for next year,'' said Mike Penzer, senior economist for Bank of America in San Francisco. Penzer agreed with the group's prediction of export growth and a stronger dollar next year. But economist Lacy Hunt disagreed with the association's forecast that the economy will expand through enhanced trade. ``Exports are not going to be the panacea that we hoped for,'' said Hunt, chief U.S. economist with the Hong Kong Bank Group Inc. in New York. The softening economies in Japan and Germany mean there will be ``a smaller pie in which to generate these exports,'' he added. Several analysts agreed with the association's prediction of a short-lived recession. Giulio Martini, economist for the investment firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. Inc., said prospects for a faster economic rebound are enhanced because businesses aren't burdened with large inventories. Overbuilt inventories accelerate the shock of a recession, he said. The 40th semiannual forecast is consistent with the association's earlier predictions of economic hard times. In its report last week, the group said the economy continued to decline for the fifth consecutive month, leading to a drop in new orders and declines in production and employment.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bank Earnings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of commercial bank profits, or losses, by state for the third quarter of 1990 and the third quarter of 1989. The figures, provided by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., are in millions of dollars.
State
DOC.HEAD: 3Q90 3Q89
Earnings Seen Lower Until Economy Revives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Bank earnings are headed down and won't reverse course until the economy emerges from its slump, analysts say. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Tuesday that the nation's 12,399 commercial banks earned $3.75 billion in the July-September quarter, down 29 percent from $5.4 billion in the econd quarter. Banks earned $6.3 billion in the first three months of the year. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman blamed the deterioration on a rise in sour real estate loans, particularly in the Northeast. He described the outlook for the final three months of the year as bleak and declined to predict when bank earnings would recover. The problem ``will drag on just as long as the economy is in whatever it's in now,'' Seidman said. ``I won't say the R-word,'' he said, referring to the Bush administration's reluctance to describe the economic downturn as a recession. Economist Paul Getman of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., said, ``I wish I could say it's going to get better, but it's going to get worse before it gets better.'' Seidman warned that banks' problems are translating into mounting strain on the government insurance fund protecting bank deposits. He raised his estimate of the FDIC fund's 1990 loss from $3 billion to $4 billion or more and said it was becoming ``increasingly clear'' that banks will have to inject more money into the fund. The loss would leave only $9 billion to protect $2 trillion in deposits. ``We're probably under more pressure in the banking system than we have been at any time since the 1930s,'' said economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. ``I'd look for continued strains on the system in general.'' Jones said the health of the economy and of banking are deteriorating in a vicious circle: slumping economic conditions create loan losses for banks. That causes banks to cut back lending, which fuels the economic slump. Still, 89 percent of commercial banks made money in the third quarter. The profitability of small banks, those with less than $100 million in assets, suffered only slightly, but problems in larger institutions in the East dragged down the industry totals. Banks posted losses in the District of Columbia and eight states: Arizona, Connecticut, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey and New York. Delinquent real estate loans, in which borrowers are three months or more behind on their payments, rose 12.9 percent to $31.3 billion in the third quarter. The real estate delinquency rate was highest in Rhode Island, 14.66 percent, followed by Arizona, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Texas, Oklahoma, New Hampshire, Louisiana, New York, the District of Columbia, New Jersey, New Mexico and Colorado. However, the rate was headed down in the Southwestern states and up in the East. Getman noted that recent weakness in West Coast real estate markets has yet to surface in bank data. ``The other shoe has yet to drop and the other shoe is California,'' he said. Consumer loan delinquencies also are rising. They were up 10.4 percent to $14 billion in the third quarter. Getman predicted that, as the recession progresses, credit card delinquencies will emerge as the next big area of concern to bankers. For the first time, the FDIC issued a report on the 479 savings banks it supervises. These state-chartered institutions - a hybrid of a commercial bank and a savings institution - are located primarily in the Northeast and concentrate on real estate lending even more than commercial banks. They lost $771 million during the third quarter. During the first nine months of the year, 35 percent of the savings banks lost money and as a whole lost $1.2 billion, compared with $20 million in earnings during the same period of 1989. However, they remain well capitalized. On average, their owners' investment represented 7.02 percent of the savings banks' assets. Capital acts as a cushion between losses and the insurance fund.

DOC.HEAD: Union Says Defense-Electronics Firm Plans Extensive Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Thomson-CSF SA, one of France's biggest defense contractors, plans to lay off 3,800 to 4,000 employees because of declining demand for military products, union sources said Wednesday. The sources, who requested anonymity, said Thomson will announce details of the payroll cut at a worker-management committee meeting on Thursday. Thomson, citing legal restrictions, refused to comment. The reported layoffs would involve more than 10 percent of the company's work force of 37,800. Alain Gomez, Thomson's chairman, told financial analysts last month that the company would undertake a ``reconfiguration'' in 1991 to cope with declining demand for its defense-related products. He said annual growth of the world defense and electronics market will slow to 1.5 percent over the next eight years from 8.5 percent in the 1980s. Gomez also said the company's profit in 1990 will decline compared with 1989, but predicted that earnings will recover over the next three years. Thomson's consolidated revenue in 1989 was 33.693 billion francs, or about $6.7 billion at current exchange rates.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Implements Drug Plan Over Union Objections
DOC.TEXT: A Boeing Co. plan for handling alcohol and other drug abuse has been implemented over vehement objections by the aerospace giant's largest union. Under the policy put in effect Tuesday, Boeing's approximately 150,000 U.S. employees, from janitors to executives, may be tested after on-the-job accidents or when company officials find a reasonable suspicion that an employee used drugs. ``There are sufficient checks and balances built into the testing portion of our policy so that it can't be applied arbitrarily or capriciously,'' said Russ Young of Boeing. Employees found to have prohibited substances in their system could enter a treatment program after the first offense but would face dismissal for a second offense. Employees who voluntarily entered the treatment program would be allowed a second chance. In the past, Boeing officials say, employees caught with or using drugs on company property were fired. `I think the workers are going to be astonished, as I am, that the company would implement an agreement that the membership doesn't want,'' said Tom Baker, president of International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers District Lodge 751. ``They believe that they should be able to test by any reliable source, any source that they consider reliable, whatever that means,'' Baker said, adding the union thinks that could lead to abuse by management. Members of the union, which represents about 40,000 Boeing workers in and around Seattle and another 10,000 in Portland, Ore., and Wichita, Kan., voted 86 percent last month to reject the plan sought by Boeing. Baker said then the plan would foster ``a police-state mentality.'' ``We are presently in discussion with our legal counsel to see what appropriate legal action we should take, whether that be through the courts or whether that be through unfair labor practice charges'' filed with the National Labor Relations Board, Baker said. In negotiations during August, September and October, union leaders sought unsuccessfully to impose greater limits on testing and gain greater assurances of confidentiality under a plan administered by both the union and Boeing. A second Boeing union, the Seattle Professional Engineering Employees Association, agreed in September to accept the company's plan. The association represents about 27,000 Boeing engineers and other professional workers.

DOC.HEAD: Marvin Davis Reveals First Interstate Stake, Suggests Sale
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire investor Marvin Davis revealed that he is a major stockholder of First Interstate Bancorp and urged the company to cut overhead or consider a buyout by another banking firm. In a surprise letter Tuesday, Davis expressed dissatisfaction with First Interstate management. ``Along with other First Interstate stockholders we have watched with distress First Interstate's deteriorating financial condition and results of operation over the past few months,'' Davis wrote. ``This is an ideal time for the First Interstate board to either achieve the operating economies which are long overdue or to consider a sale of the bank to another banking institution.'' First Interstate is struggling to rebuild itself after massive problems at its Arizona and Texas banks contributed to a $124.5 million loss last year. First Interstate's stock traded as high as $48 per share during the past year, but recently has fallen to about half that level. The stock rose 37{ cents to close at $25.12{ a share Tuesday in New York Stock Exchange trading. Davis wrote to Chairman and Chief Executive Edward M. Carson, who replaced the fiery Joseph J. Pinola as head of the company last year. ``We've seen (Davis') letter and we do take his concerns seriously as we do with all shareholder concerns,'' said Ken Preston, a First Interstate spokesman. ``But we're also encouraged by the progress we've made so far for the first nine months,'' Preston said. ``Under our new management team, we've returned to profitability this year.'' Davis revealed that his family interests own a ``significant amount'' of First Interstate stock. He didn't say how much, although investors are required to reveal their stakes to the Securities and Exchange Commission when they acquire more than 5 percent. He noted in his letter that John Neff, portfolio manager of the Windsor mutual fund, has said the fund might join other big shareholders in pressuring First Interstate to put itself on the block. However, Neff made his suggestion in a letter eight months ago when talk of consolidation in the banking industry was rife and First Interstate's major problems seemed more immediate. ``This is hardly an ideal time to sell a bank or parts of a bank,'' Neff said Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Instruments, Toshiba Reach Chip Pact
DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc. has reached a new 10-year royalty agreement with Toshiba Corp. of Japan covering a broad class of Texas Instruments' microchip technology, the company announced. Terms of the agreement announced Tuesday were not disclosed. But analysts say the deal - the first of several expected between TI and Japanese chipmakers - could net the Dallas-based technology firm hundreds of millions of dollars. The pact stems from a 1986 patent infringement lawsuit filed by TI against nine semiconductor manufacturers. It replaces a five-year agreement expiring at the end of the year. Terri West, spokeswoman for Texas Instruments, said the company expects the agreement to increase Toshiba's annual royalty payments. The payments will be based on worldwide sales of Toshiba semiconductors. Texas Instruments has been negotiating with other semiconductor manufacturers whose licensing agreements also expire at the end of the year. They include most of the nine companies TI sued in 1986, Ms. West said. Toshiba is the first of the companies to renegotiate the royalty arrangement. The lawsuit also named Fujitsu Ltd., Hitachi Ltd., Oki Electric Industry Co., Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., NEC Corp., Mitsubishi Electric Corp. and Sharp Corp. of Japan and Samsung Co. of South Korea. Texas Instruments holds basic patents on the integrated circuit, the memory chip and other semiconductor technology. In recent years, the company has been aggressively enforcing its semiconductor patents, suing U.S. and foreign manufacturers it believes are using its technology without paying royalties.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Gulf Crisis Pivotal for Energy Industry
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis should be viewed as a ``decisive event'' in energy history and its outcome will change the dynamics of the oil industry, an annual oil and gas study says. ``Significant changes have occurred in world oil fundamentals that will have profound and lasting effects after the conclusion of the current Gulf crisis,'' Victor Burk, managing director of oil and gas industry services for Arthur Andersen & Co., said Tuesday. Daniel Yergin, president of Massachusetts-based Cambridge Energy Research Associates, said he believed the crisis will lead to an emphasis on energy security and diversification of supply sources, plus give ``a new kick to exploration and production around the world.'' The comments came as Cambridge and the Houston office of Arthur Andersen released their annual survey of world oil trends. The survey found the financial considerations of the Persian Gulf crisis to be substantial for OPEC. In 1986, for example, OPEC earnings fell to $77 billion. This year, the trends survey estimated OPEC earnings could top $160 billion. The effect of the higher prices, however, also has been to cut demand somewhat. ``By November ... demand had fallen because of higher prices and economic downturn,'' the survey showed. ``The world oil market was in balance - but a very precarious balance with no margin for error.'' Yergin said a war in the Persian Gulf would send oil prices soaring, but he believed the jump would be short-term. The annual survey showed world oil consumption in 1989 reached record highs, while U.S. consumption was at its highest level in 10 years. At the same time, non-OPEC oil production was declining for the first time since 1973 with two major oil producers - the United States and the Soviet Union - both posting production drops that are expected to continue. Yergin referred to the United States and the Soviet Union as the ``two sick men of world oil.'' In the United States, production has declined by 2 million barrels a day from 1986 to summer of 1990. ``The loss of that output is a greater volume than Kuwait was producing before the Gulf crisis began,'' Yergin said. ``In other words, the fall in U.S. production is as though a major oil exporting country has been obliterated or snuffed out.'' Yergin said the effects were momentous both in the United States and overseas because the decline upset the global balance in oil production. ``In this country, there's been a hazy fog where people have not recognized the significance of the seriousness of this drop,'' he said. The result, according to the survey, was U.S. oil imports rose from 4.4 million barrels a day in 1985 to 7.7 million a day in first half of 1990. In the Soviet Union, the sweeping fundamental changes and the fall of communism in eastern Europe are having effects on the energy industry worldwide as well because of reduced production and export of Soviet oil, Yergin said. But he said the changes in the Soviet Union also meant opportunities for oil companies. ``Here is a door that was slammed shut 70 years ago,'' he said. ``That door has been abruptly opened. The problem they (oil companies) face is who to deal with. The question is: `Who's in charge here?''' Yergin said the threat of an economic recession also hangs over the industry.

DOC.HEAD: Quasar Ordered to Pay $2.5 in Discrimination Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. District Court ordered Quasar Co. to pay nearly $2.5 million to three former employees charging discrimination on the basis of age and nationality, officials said. Quasar also must pay court costs and attorney fees, making the total judgment greater than $3 million, said attorney Norman Berger, who represents the plaintiffs. The exact total of those fees was not available late Tuesday. Quasar was found guilty of violating both the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, according to Berger. ``This is the first case we're aware of that, after a trial, a Japanese company has been found guilty of this type of discrimination,'' Berger said. The company said it disagreed with the ruling and intended to appeal. Quasar, based in suburban Elk Grove Village, handles sales and distribution of consumer electronics and employees about 50 people. The company is a division of the Japanese-owned Matsushita Electric Corp. of America. Quasar officials said they were disappointed in the case's outcome. ``We are fully confident of the merits of our position and believe the court has made substantial errors in both law and in fact,'' said Quasar spokesman John Monaco, reading an official statement. ``Of course, we intend to appeal the decision and firmly believe that ultimately our position in this case will be upheld.'' The plaintiffs, John Fortino, Carl Meyers and F. William Schulz, were fired from their management positions during Quasar's 1986 company restructuring and 50 percent work force reduction, Berger said. Before the company's reorganization, Quasar had 89 managerial employees. After the restructuring, the staff was cut to 23, Berger said. Of that total 14 were Americans and nine were Japanese, he said. ``The evidence showed that Quasar had full knowledge of the laws which prohibit discrimination, and yet it tried to circumvent these laws,'' Berger said. ``The court found that Quasar would not have fired any of our clients but for their national origin.'' In a 1988 ruling, a jury awarded $1.9 million to the plaintiffs in settlement of the age discrimination lawsuit. All three were over 50 at the time of their dismissal. The three were told that their jobs were being eliminated, but their functions were reassigned to younger people, Berger said. U.S. District Judge James Alesia upheld the jury's 1988 decision in post-trial motions and assessed additional fines in the nationality discrimination case Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Occidental May Cut Dividend, Sell Assets
With PM-Hammer-Memorial
DOC.TEXT: With its longtime chairman gone, the future of Occidental Petroleum Corp.'s dividend is in question and the company may sell some assets, analysts say. Armand Hammer's death at 92 on Monday sparked a surge of activity on Wall Street, where Occidental stock was the most actively traded stock Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange. It rose $1.87 to $22.62 per share in heavy trading Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange - a gain of 9 percent. Some analysts said the $2.50 per share annual dividend appears in jeopardy. Several said an outsider may borrow heavily to buy Occidental, then profit by selling off its pieces: oil and gas; chemicals; natural gas pipelines; coal; beef and pork processing. A less likely scenario had Occidental management buying the company. But the economic downturn, combined with dried up junk bond and bank lending for takeovers, has made a buyout seem less likely for Occidental, the 16th largest U.S. industrial company with about $20 billion in annual sales. Occidental itself may now sell some of its holdings to reduce its staggering $8 billion debt. One possible sale would be a 5 percent interest in the company that makes Arm & Hammer baking soda, which people mistakenly thought Hammer founded. Ray R. Irani, Occidental's president and chief operating officer, immediately succeeded Hammer as chairman and chief executive. He declined Tuesday to discuss Occidental's future. Warren Shimmerlik, an independent energy analyst, said under Irani's management Occidental will likely undergo a ``major philosophical change'' and significant restructuring. ``Hammer's style prevented a rationalization that would be beneficial to the company,'' Shimmerlik said, noting Hammer preferred to position Occidental as an income-producing stock rather than a growth company. ``There didn't seem to be any real momentum in the company.'' Eugene Nowak, vice president and director of the energy group at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said he expects Occidental ``to take a very hard look at all the assets. ... The company will move from an entrepreneurial concern to professional management.'' Nowak said Occidental was an unlikely takeover candidate. ``The company has been left in very strong hands,'' he said. ``The star of Occidental's operations will continue to be foreign energy exploration and production.'' Alan Gaines, president of energy stock specialist Gaines, Berland Inc., took a bleaker perspective. ``This is not a growth company,'' Gaines said. ``And I don't think they're saleable.'' He said Occidental's dividend was in immediate jeopardy. ``The death of Hammer portends a dividend reduction,'' Gaines said. ``I think the company has very poor fundamentals and I don't think the dividend can be maintained - it was imprudent to begin with.'' He said Hammer ``is the one who controlled the banks and the directors were beholden to him.'' Gaines said some banks may be unwilling to support what Gaines feels is an excessive dividend and may call on Occidental to improve its balance sheet. Gaines said the company is highly leveraged, with a dividend payment of $800 million annually and crippling interest expense. ``That's $2.1 billion out the door before taxes, gone,'' Gaines said. ``And what buyer is going to assume $8 billion in debt? It's an overleveraged petrochemical company. Who wants it?''

DOC.HEAD: New Measures to Support German Exports to East
DOC.TEXT: Some 2,000 companies in former East Germany will be able to keep their export markets in the Soviet Union and other East European countries under measures announced Wednesday. Exports to the ruble-based trading bloc were economic mainstays of East Germany before it united with West Germany in October. But the conversion to the West German mark threatens to put an end to such business, depriving wobbly economies in the east of their traditional source of modern equipment. German economists say hundreds of thousands of jobs in eastern Germany depend on continuation of exports to the east. Officials of the Treuhandanstalt, the trust agency charged with disposing of most of the former state-owned assets of East Germany, said the government-backed Hermes export insurance agency will support, under certain conditions, new contracts that companies in eastern Germany are able to make with Soviet or other East European customers. The contracts must be in hard currency, and the Treuhand will have to verify that the German companies are making progress toward the efficiency standards of the free-market economy, Wolfram Krause, the Treuhand's finance director, told a news conference. Many companies in former East Germany that the Treuhand hopes to privatize face a deadline of Jan. 1 to convert long-term contracts from the inconvertible Soviet ruble into hard currency. The German government is backing $10.8 billion worth of such ruble-denominated east-bound exports in 1990, Krause said. That support expires at the end of this year, but the new export insurance will help to continue the valuable direction of business. The companies will be more attractive to purchasers, he said, adding, ``We know that this is the time to sell.'' ``What makes eastern Germany so attractive for investment is this is the only country in the world where you have two directions of the economy,'' said Treuhand spokesman Thomas Schneider. ``West Germany has the western direction, and East Germany has the eastern direction. If you are looking for a new market, it will be in the east.'' Eastern German companies will only be attractive in the future if they retain their markets in the east, he said, and the export insurance measure was one way to support such business. The Soviet Union is an especially important customer for concerns in eastern Germany, he said, showing Treuhand statistics that gave the Soviets 80 percent of the production of excavators, cranes and rail equipment; 70 percent of production of fishing vessels and 60 percent of eastern Germany's electronics output.

The stock market headed higher today, bidding to revive its yearend rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 13.86 points to 2,600.00 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 536 up, 412 down and 573 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 25.36 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Since climbing to a 2{-month high for the Dow Jones industrials a week ago, the market has run into resistance from sellers. But analysts noted that the ensuing pullback proved to be shallow, suggesting that stocks were still benefiting from solid support not far below their recent levels. Brokers also say many investors seem convinced that the Federal Reserve will take whatever steps are necessary to cushion the effects of the economic slump. With assistance from the Fed, many optimists in the financial world believe, the economy could begin to show renewed signs of vigor as early as mid-1991. Nike class B shares gained 1} to 37{. The company said its earnings for the fiscaal quarter ended Nov. 30 came in above analysts' estimates. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .58 to 179.00. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .10 at 306.21. On Tuesday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.64 points to 2,586.14. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 5 to 3 on the NYSE, with 585 up, 999 down and 458 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 145.33 million shares, against 138.65 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: EC Maintains Controls over Subsidies to Auto Industry
DOC.TEXT: The European Community Commission said Wednesday it had extended for two years its controls over state subsidies to the beleaguered auto industry in the EC's 12 member states. The commission's authority to bar large state awards to car manufacturers ``is crucial to ensure that a climate of normal and fair competition prevails'' as the industry approaches an uncertain future, the commission said in a statement. The commission's 2-year-old framework says all state subsidies exceeding 12 million European currency units, or $16.4 million, must be approved by the EC's executive commission. The commission said it fears that current intense competition in the EC auto industry could push some member states into approving huge subsidies if the commission's powers to curb state aids were ended. Separately, the EC allowed France to fund 40 percent of a $240 million research project between car makers Renault and Peugeot for fuel-efficient automobiles with clean-burning engines. The commission said it approved French aid of about $97 million for the eight-year project, which will involve several research organizations and focus on clean-burning engines, development of a new two-stroke engine and electric and gas-powered vehicles. The commission said the framework on member subsidies was vital in preparing for a unified motor vehicle market once the trade bloc unifies after 1992. It said clamping down on huge state subsidies was ``the best guarantee that the industry will be able to improve its competitiveness on world markets.'' EC demand for cars in 1990 and 1991 is expected to decline before returning to a longer-term annual growth of 1 percent a year, the commission said. It said the ``uneertain outlook for the industry as a whole adds to the case for vigilance in the control of state aids.''

DOC.HEAD: Data General Chairman to Retire
DOC.TEXT: Data General Corp. today announced today that Edson D. de Castro, the 52-year-old chairman of the troubled computer maker, would resign on Dec. 31. Vice Chairman Herbert J. Richman, 56, will retire at the end of its fiscal year in September. A company statement gave no reasons for the retirements of the two executives, who helped found Data General in 1968. Ronald L. Skates, the company president and chief executive officer, praised de Castro as ``an industry legend.'' He also commended Richman for leading the company's sales and marketing efforts. Skates said Richman deserved much of the credit for Data General's rapid rise in the market for mid-range minicomputers. That market has fallen on hard times. Data General has not enjoyed a profitable year since 1985, when its employment peaked at 17,700. Since then, the company has suffered a string of losses, and employment has shrunk to around 9,500. Analysts say Data General has responded with some strong products, particularly its AViiON workstations. But the minicomputer slump has continued to act as a drag on earnings, hampering the company's repeated efforts to turn a profit. The company lost $139 million in its most recent fiscal year. Revenues were $1.22 billion, compared with $1.31 billion the year before. Neither de Castro nor Richman will seek re-election to the board of directors, but Richman will continue to serve as executive vice president for the AsiaPacific region until he retires, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Announces Bonus Program for Frequent Fliers ^Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix coding.
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines has fired a new salvo in the battle for business fliers, announcing a bonus ticket program for frequent fliers. Delta said Tuesday it will award a free ticket to any member of its frequent flier club who completes eight ``segments'' on coach fares between Dec. 15 and March 15. The program also gives passengers a choice of first-class upgrades rather than free trips. Two round trips with a change of planes each way would provide eight segments. If the flights were non-stop or one-stop with no plane change, it would take four round trips to qualify. The bonus was announced five days after rival Eastern Airlines made a similar move. The Eastern program offers a weekend ticket for $91 to anyone who makes a single round trip at a ``corporate rate'' fare during December or January. Bonus tickets for Eastern, which is trying to survive by gaining business fliers at Delta's expense, are redeemable from Jan. 3 through June 18. Delta's are good for travel between May 15 and Dec. 31, of 1991. Delta spokesman Neil Monroe said this morning that the latest promotion comes at a time when sluggish demand for air travel and higher fuel costs are hurting the air travel industry, but he said the freebies should not harm the bottom line at Delta because most passengers are expected to opt for the first-class upgrades. That costs Delta virtually nothing, he said. Delta will limit the number of seats available on each flight for passengers who choose the free travel, Monroe said.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Struggles to Continue, Ford President Says
DOC.TEXT: The recession the nation's auto industry slipped into this year likely will continue in 1991, when car and truck sales are expected to dip by 5 percent, Ford Motor Co.'s president said today. In a year-end briefing with reporters, Philip Benton estimated automakers would sell 14.2 million cars and trucks this year in the United States. ``Beyond that, there remains considerable uncertainty,'' he said, adding Ford estimates U.S. industry sales of 13.5 million vehicles in 1991. He said a soft U.S. economy, consumer caution and the continuing Middle East crisis lend to the industry's uncertainty. General Motors Corp., Ford and Chrysler Corp. all expect to lose money in the fourth quarter, which would be the first quarter since mid-1981 that all the Big Three posted losses. ``The relative weakness is in North America,'' Benton said. ``This is basically a North American problem.'' Ford counts on North America for a large portion of its profits to offset such overseas troubles as weak vehicle demand in Britain and Spain, an economic crisis in Brazil and three European labor strikes. Benton said he expects ``substantial improvement'' overseas, especially in Europe, but looks for North America ``to continue to have a difficult year in '91. ``Profits are under enormous pressure in North America, and they started out from an abysmal level.'' On other matters, Benton said: -Ford's dividend of 75 cents a share appears safe for now. However, because of the econoimc and Mideast uncertainty, ``you can't say the dividend is secure.'' -Ford will cut an unspecified number of white-collar jobs beyond the normal 5 percent attrition rate to trim costs. He said a 1- to 2-percent cut is probable. Ford's 1989 annual report said 66,900 of its 175,100 workers were salaried. -Product development into the mid-1990s is on track. ``The '92 push is going to be very heavy in trucks.'' -Ford is moving cautiously into Eastern Europe, giving priority to establishing dealers, parts and service networks for cars brought into the region from Western Europe. ``I don't see us, in the near term, with any assembly plants.''

The stock market showed some modest gains today, bidding to revive its yearend rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.14 points to 2,597.28 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. But analysts noted that the ensuing pullback proved to be shallow, suggesting that stocks were still benefiting from solid support not far below their recent levels. Brokers also say many investors seem convinced that the Federal Reserve will take whatever steps are necessary to cushion the effects of the economic slump. With assistance from the Fed, many optimists in the financial world believe, the economy could begin to show renewed signs of vigor as early as mid-1991. Ford Motor dropped ~ to 26}. The company said it couldn't say for certain that its 75-cents-a-share quarterly dividend was secure. Nike class B shares gained 1} to 37{. DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Makes New Proposal for Short-Term Notes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The cash-strapped city government, rebuffed by Wall Street in its last attempt to pay its bills, has made another formal proposal to sell short-term notes. Mayor W. Wilson Goode said today the proposal had been sent Monday night to several potential investors, including the city pension fund and local banks. A statement released by Goode's press secretary, Karen Warrington, said the city hoped to complete the deal by the end of next week. It did not disclose how much the city was seeking. Goode and other state and local Democratic leaders previously have said the city would need $250 million to $300 million to avoid running out of sufficient cash to meet city payroll, vendor payments and other bills until major tax payments come due in February and March. A $375 million note sale flopped in September amid concerns about the city's shaky fiscal condition. Its credit rating has dropped to junk-bond levels, the lowest among major U.S. cities. Goode said the proposed transaction includes ``a process by which state funds otherwise owed to the city between now and May 31, 1991, would be paid by the state directly to a trustee for the noteholders.'' He said the arrangement, approved Tuesday by state Treasurer Catherine Baker Knoll, would lend additional security to the deal. Many workers and retirees have opposed using any of the $1.5 billion city pension fund to buy Philadelphia notes. The Board of Pensions and Retirement meets Thursday and Friday. The Public School Employees' Retirement Board, which oversees the $16 billion state teachers pension fund, also meets Thursday and Friday. Each pension fund is limited to buying 25 percent of a debt issue, or $75 million of a $300 million issue.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Grain and Soybeans Lower in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures opened slightly lower today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The market shows signs of firming in the wake the Agriculture Department's supply and demand report. The report, released Tuesday, is being viewed by traders as broadly neutral to slightly supportive to futures. Adding to the firm tone of the market is anticipation that President Bush today will announce U.S. food aid or export credits to the Soviet Union, said Barney Janecki, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The president is meeting in Washington with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Wheat futures may be boosted by a pickup in export activity, and weakness in soyoil is expected to weigh on soybean prices. In early trading, wheat was a \ cent to 1 cent lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.53{ a bushel; corn was a { cent lower to a \ cent higher with December at $2.26} a bushel; oats were a { cent to } cent lower with March at $1.19} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 1} cents lower with January at $5.93\ a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Strong demand for pork offset pressure on future caused by lower cash prices for live hogs. DOC.BYLINE: Attorneys General of Six States Sue Large Mortgage Lender ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys general in six states have filed suit against the GMAC Mortgage Corp., accusing the lender of overcharging consumers by millions of dollars in excessive escrow payments. The action seeks to bar the Detroit-based lender from building big cushions into escrow accounts and to force GMAC to recalculate the way it determines escrow payments. GMAC holds about 400,000 mortgages nationwide. Attorneys general from California, Iowa, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New York and Texas filed suit Tuesday in federal court in Manhattan. The six states acted because the federal government has not enforced its own laws against the practice, New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams said. Abrams said that if the suit succeeds, homeowners could receive millions of dollars in refunds. Officials from GMAC Corp. declined immediately to comment on the suit. In April, the attorneys general released a study critical of mortgage lenders' practice of requiring excess funds in escrow accounts. ``When we released the report of the illegal escrow practices of GMAC and other lenders, we urged the federal government to enforce its own statutory limits on escrow payments. So far, it has taken no action, thus prompting suits like (this one) at great cost to the states,'' Abrams said. That study said consumers were being overcharged $2 billion to $4 billion by the nation's mortgage lenders. Lenders maintain escrow accounts to make payments for propertyttaxes, insurance and other items that borrowers must pay. Extra money in escrow accounts hurts consumers but is a bonanza for lenders, who regulators say get to use the funds for free or by paying a very low rate of interest on it. About two-thirds of the nation's home mortgages involve escrow accounts. Federal law limits lenders to keeping a two-month ``cushion'' in escrow, or enough money to make payments for two months. The cushion allows lenders to make tax and insurance payments even if the consumer is late making a monthly payment. ``Our report estimated that the `excess cushion' averages about $150 per homeowner,'' Iowa Attorney General Tom Miller said. ``That means we think lenders are holding several billion dollars that should be in the hands of their customers.'' The report called on Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp to tighten enforcement of the law. The attorneys general said inaction by HUD led them to file the suit. The two-year study focused on big lenders who operate nationwide. A survey of four of the largest - Citibank, GMAC Mortgage Corp., Fleet Mortgage Corp. and Lomas Financial Group. - ``indicated that lenders may be holding excessive and illegal cushions in more than 70 percent of escrow accounts.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Pharmaceutical Executive Pleads Guilty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A former executive of Bolar Phamaraceutical Co. pleaded guilty today to making false statements and obstructing a Food and Drug Administration inquiry in order to help her company get approval for a generic drug. Gloria H. Schetlick, former manager of regulatory affairs for the company, entered the guilty plea to making a false statement and obstruction of justice before a federal judge in Baltimore, the Justice Department said. Prosecutors said Schetlick and other company officials submitted false scientific data to the FDA in 1984 and 1985 to support Bolar's application to produce a generic version of the hypertension drug ``Dyazide.'' The Justice Department said it had information that Schetlick and other Bolar executives also tried to obstruct inquiries by the House Energy and Comerce oversight and investigations subcommittee. The guilty plea was part of a continuing investigation into corruption of the FDA's procedures for approving applications for new drugs or generic equivalents. U.S. Attorney Breckinridge L. Willcox said in a statement that the investigation was continuing and more charges were expected. Schetlick, who could be sentenced to up to five years and fined $250,000 on each count, has agred to cooperate with the investigation, officials said. So far 16 people, including five former FDA officials, and three generic drug companies have pleaded guilty in the investigation. Bolar, based in Copiague, N.Y., posted sales of $140 million for its generic equivalent of the hypertension drug between 1987 and 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Distance Companies Settle Lawsuits Out of Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf AT&T comment after 13th graf pvs, bgng: MCI spokeswoman; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and MCI Communications Corp. said today they had reached an out-of-court settlement on lawsuits and countersuits that had alleged theft of customers and false advertising. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. As part of the agreement, the two companies agreed to propose adoption by the Federal Communications Commission of industrywide standards to protect consumers from being switched to other long-distance companies against their will. The proposed standards would permit long-distance carriers to switch a customer's service only by one of the following means: -A customer-initiated call to an 800 number of the carrier to which the customer is switching. -Independent third-party confirmation. -Signed letter of authorization. -A call placed by the customer to their local or long-distance telephone company. The two companies, along with US Sprint, have been locked in a fierce battle for customers. AT&T and MCI, or their agents, have been placing calls to millions of phone users each month trying to get them to switch their long-distance service. State and federal authorities and local phone companies have received tens of thousands of complaints about unauthorized switching. Since the breakup of the old Bell System in 1984, AT&T's share of the long-distance market has eroded to below 70 percent. MCI, the nation's second largest long-distance carrier, now has about 15 percent of the market. AT&T, which had claimed it was losing customers because of unauthorized switching by MCI and its telemarketing agent, had asked the FCC to require a customer's written authorization before a change could be made. MCI spokeswoman Pam Small said officials were bound by the agreement not to comment further on the settlement. AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said the company wanted to ``get beyond'' the ``squabbling,'' which he said ``is really not good for either AT&T or MCI, or for the customer.'' But he emphasized that AT&T ``will continue to pursue customers and try to retain existing ones with the same resourcefulness and aggressiveness we have pursued in the past.'' MCI had sued AT&T in U.S. District Court in Washington on Oct. 10, 1989, alleging false and deceptive advertising practices. AT&T countersued on Oct. 26. On Jan. 10 this year, AT&T sued MCI and its telemarketing agent in Newark, N.J., federal court, alleging false and deceptive telemarketing practices. Both sides denied any wrongdoing and no dollar amounts were specified in the suits.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Companies Accused of Driving Up Prices by Giving Gifts to Doctors
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top six grafs new to update with testimony given, picks up 5th graf pvs, `But witnesses'; also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: The prescription drug industry today defended itself against accusations that it is driving up drug prices by squandering millions of dollars on lavish and unnecessary gifts and trips for doctors. Drug companies' representatives are a crucial link to physicians and their practice of offering symposia and conferences provide important information to physicians, the head of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association told the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. ``To develop the knowledge necessary, medical practitioners must have prompt, reliable and detailed information regarding products and the diseases they treat,'' Gerald Mossinghoff said. ``The entity in the best position to provide in-depth information is the company that develops the new drug,'' he said. Mossinghoff also defended the use of gifts of ``nominal value'' which he said help remind physicians of the name of a particular product. Dr. Daniel Johnson, a Louisiana radiologist and an American Medical Association official, told the panel that while some questionable promotional practices still exist in the drug industry, physicians have taken steps to identify unethical behavior and steer clear of it. Both the AMA and the pharmaceutical manufacturers last week adopted ethical guidelines on the issue, he said. Asked specifically about expense-paid conferences for physicians, Johnson said, ``there should be no accepting of money directly or indirectly'' by physicians. But witnesses who testified before the panel Tuesday cited example after example of drug companies offering everything from frequent-flyer miles to outright cash to physicians in exchange for prescribing a company's product. ``Drug companies have institutionalized deception,'' said David C. Jones, a former public relations official for Ciba-Geigy Corp. and Abbott Laboratories. ``The price of prescription drugs is determined by what the market will bear,'' he said. ``Pain, suffering and desperation will support a high price.'' Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., the committee chairman, said his staff had determined that the pharmaceutical industry spends more than $5 billion a year on promoting drug products in the United States. Much of the spending is legitimate, but some is not and is contributing to the rise in drug prices that has outpaced inflation, he said. Companies spent $85 million in 1988 on symposiums often held in plush resorts, with expenses paid for both physician and spouse, Kennedy said. In some cases, physician are paid honoraria for attending. ``Doctors who accept lavish industry gifts are jeopardizing their objectivity and compromising the trust of their patients,'' Kennedy said. Four drug companies were asked by Kennedy to testify, but all four - Ciba-Geigy, Abbott Laboratories, Hoffman-LaRoche and Wyeth-Ayerst - declined. A spokesperson for Ciba-Geigy said the company declined to testify unless two other companies also agreed. At Senate hearings in 1973, the company was the only one to testify and ``ended up getting blamed for the sins of the industry.'' Abbott Laboratories said it declined because it has complied with Kennedy's request for written background material on the company's educational and promotional practices, said spokesman Jed Weiner. Hoffman-LaRoche spokeswoman Nancy Mattison said her company declined because it was unable to get specific enough information about the questions the senators would be asking. Wyeth-Ayerst spokeswoman Audrey Ashby said the company had already provided the committee ``fully and promptly'' all the information that was requested.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders of Wall Street Firm Approve Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: CS First Boston Inc. said Wednesday its institutional and management shareholders had approved a $725 million restructuring designed to reverse the investment firm's sagging fortunes. The plan calls for the sale of $300 million in equity by CS First Boston to its Swiss owner, CS Holding, and the injection of $425 million in cash in exchange for the bulk of a troubled loan portfolio. After the restructuring, CS Holding will control about 60 percent of the privately controlled investment bank, up from 44.5 percent. First Boston Corp. is the North American subsidiary of CS First Boston. In a statement, CS First Boston said the loan portion of the deal is expected to be completed on Friday with the rest of the restructuring done by Monday. ``The depth of our commitment to CS First Boston is clear and the strength of our investment banking affiliate is beyond question,'' said CS Holding Chairman Rainer Gut. First Boston, though, has undergone a major shakeup in recent weeks to clean up its balance sheet and cut costs during a severe downturn in business on Wall Street. The firm has been hurt largely by troubles in the junk bond, merger and real estate markets. As part of its overhaul, several top First Boston executives have resigned or been ousted in the last six weeks and the firm has been laying off about 200 employees in the last two months of the year. The company said all of CS First Boston's institutional shareholders and 94 percent of its management shareholders approved the restructuring. The bailout by CS Holding, which owns the the Swiss bank Credit Suisse, is the second this year by the parent of an ailing Wall Street subsidiary. American Express Co. early this year injected $1.3 billion into Shearson Lehman Holdings Inc. and took the company private. The First Boston restructuring rids the firm of the majority of $1.1 billion in temporary ``bridge loans'' made to corporate clients that the firm has been unable to sell because of the collapse of the junk bond market. Under the restructuring, CS First Boston is placing all its bridge loans, except for those to Campeau Corp.'s Federated Department Stores subsidiary and to Jerrico Inc., into a special limited partnership. In exchange, CS First Boston will receive a stake in the partnership and the $425 million in cash. The firm still will be exposed to $377 million in bridge loans. Additionally, CS First Boston is writing off $360 million in soured investments. That is expected to reduce the firm's 1990 earnings. First Boston made just $11 million last year and reportedly has losses so far this year.

For Release AMs Friday, Dec. 14
DOC.HEAD: Those Awful Job Figures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES cycle designator.
DOC.HEAD: By JOHN CUNNIFF
DOC.TEXT: The official November job report was one of the bleakest in many years, further documenting the process by which elements of a sliding economy reinforce each other and lead to recession. Depicted graphically, it would look like a Rube Goldberg contraption in which one action generates another and another and another, the end result being nothing produced but a waste of time, energy and capital. In terms of a sliding economy, you might begin with big debts and tight money, which lead to lower consumer and business spending, which produces lower profits, income strains and layoffs, forcing further spending cuts. Viewed in that sense, the consequences of the terrible November job report become clear: Fewer workers working fewer hours means less money for retailers, who cut their orders to wholesalers and wholesalers, who cut jobs and spending. There was almost no good news in the report, delivered by Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. In her own words: -Employment declined sharply, and the declines were widespread throughout both the goods and the service sectors of the economy. -The unemployment rate rose from 5.7 percent to 5.9 percent. The rate is now more than 0.5 percent higher than it was in the first half of the year. -The number of payroll jobs declined sharply for the second month in a row. A reduction of 265,000 jobs in November followed a loss of 180,000 in October. We have not had consecutive job losses of this magnitude since the end of 1982. -Three-quarers of the November reduction occurred in the already weak manufacturing industry. Nearly 800,000 factory jobs have been dropped since January 1989. Even service-sector jobs were affected. Jobs in retail trades fell by 70,000. Wholesale trade employment fell sharply. And, as has been well publicized, big losses occurred in the real estate and finance industries. The one piece of news that might be construed as positive really wasn't. Employment in the health services industry rose by 80,000 jobs, bringing to more than 600,000 the number of jobs added in that category within a year. Why isn't that good news? For those who found employment it was, of course, good news, but for the rest of us it was ominous. Health service spending has been out of control for years. Each year it consumes more of the gross national product. Each year its inflation rate exceeds that of the general economy. How can the deterioration be changed? In the old days you primed the pump with government spending, but government already is spending too much. Because of that, an unusually large role falls to the Federal Reserve. The Fed can do its part in a number of ways, such as easing credit restraints, putting more money into the economy and allowing interest rates to fall. So far, it hasn't done a great deal in that respect. In the past, Chairman Alan Greenspan has espoused a goal of zero inflation, and inflation for the current quarter might be 6 percent - not terribly bad, but not zero. Greenspan is one of the most dedicated anti-inflationists ever to sit as Fed chairman. He has sound reasons for fearing it, considering the amount of debt already existing, the dollar's value and the fragile financial system. But that November jobless report - not just the increases in joblessness but the speeding up of the process - might force him to forgo the pursuit of zero inflation and get more Americans back to work.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv AMs Friday, Dec. 14.

DOC.HEAD: CBS To Repurchase $2 Billion of Own Stock
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 7 new grafs with selection of Tisch as chairman, conforming changes, updated stock price. Picks up 8th graf pvs, ``This offer ...
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. today announced an offer to buy back $2 billion of its own stock and disclosed that it lost $55 million from its coverage of major league baseball this year. The company also said its board has unanimously elected the company president and chief executive, Laurence A. Tisch, for the additional post of chairman, succeeding William S. Paley who died on Oct. 26. The company said it would repurchase up to 10.5 million shares of its common stock at $190 per share, a significant premium over recent prices. CBS stock has been hit hard recently by the network's disclosure that it would report a loss for the fourth quarter and lower earnings in 1991. The loss would be its first for any quarter excluding a restated loss in the fourth quarter of 1986. CBS has been hit hard by losses on sports programming and weakening ad revenue. As part of the buyback, CBS said the Paley estate, which controls an 8 percent stake, and Loews Corp., the Tisch-controlled company that holds a 24.9 percent interest in CBS, would tender their shares. A portion of their stakes would be repurchased, but their relative holdings of CBS common stock would not change. The estate has been negotiating with CBS to sell the shares to pay tax obligations. The announcement boosted the price of CBS stock, which was up $4.25 a share to $174.12{ in midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock recently traded below $160 a share. ``This offer will provide CBS shareholders with the opportunity to receive a premium over recent market prices of CBS shares for a significant portion of their shares while retaining a substantial equity investment in the company,'' Tisch said in a statement. Tisch said that after the buyback CBS still will have $800 million in cash and securities to finance currnt operations. The statement also said that ``in light of the repurchase of shares and the outlook for 1991'' CBS expected to reduce its common stock quarterly dividend below the currrent $1.10 a share. CBS for the first time disclosed an after-tax operating loss of $55 million for the 1990 fourth quarter and the year from its expensive contract for baseball programming. The network was hurt by weak advertising and the Cincinnati Reds four-game sweep over the Oakland Athletics. CBS also said it would take a $115 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to pay for anticipated losses over the course of its four-year, $1.06 billion major league baseball contract. CBS last month announced that it would lose money for the October-December quarter. Estimates on its baseball losses for 1990 had been reported at under $100 million. The network earned $60.1 million, or $2.33 a share, in the same 1989 period. Other factors cited by the network for the losses included lower advertising revenue because of the economic downturn, increased news costs covering the Middle East crisis and reduced demand for advertising at its television and radio stations. The company last month also announced that it would cut payments to television network affiliates next year for carrying its programs by 20 percent, a move expected to save the company about $30 million in 1991. CBS also has laid off workers to cut costs. CBS said the stock buyback offer would begin in the next several days and expire on Jan. 21. If the offer is fully subscribed, CBS would buy back an equal percentage of the amount tendered by all stockholders.

DOC.HEAD: Great Western Dumps Realty Unit, Leaving 1,500 Jobless
DOC.TEXT: Great Western Financial Corp. bowed out of the stagnant real estate brokerage business Wednesday, saying it would close its Great Western Real Estate subsidiary. The shutdown, combined with layoffs announced last month at the real estate company, puts 1,506 people out of work - 241 staff members and 1,265 real estate agents who had contracted to work for Great Western full time. Little effect was expected on the parent compny's financial statement, according to Great Western Financial, whose biggest subsidiary is Great Western Bank, the nation's second-largest savings and loan. The real estate company was a tiny fragment of Great Western's business. The Beverly Hills-based parent company had $3.8 billion in revenues in 1989; the Yorba Linda-based realty subsidiary had just $50 million in gross sales commissions. There has been a host of recent layoffs and cutbacks at real estate companies throughout California, where the market has slowed drastically in the past year after several years of booming sales and soaring prices. No attempt was made to find a buyer for the Great Western real estate unit, spokesman Steve Hawkins said. He said employees of some field offices had inquired about taking over those offices. In November, Great Western Real Estate laid off its new-home sales force in Yorba Linda. Great Western Financial is generally regarded as healthy but has had big losses recently on commercial real estate loans in the Northeast. Great Western said the real estate unit never consistently met profit objectives since it was acquired in 1983. Hawkins described the closure as part of Great Western's attempts to refocus on its core businesses of mortgage lending and retail banking. Hawkins said the company would complete all transactions in escrow before shutting down so that customers would not be affected.
