With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: `Likeable' Harris Brings New Leadership to Beleagured Continental
DOC.TEXT: Hollis Harris built a reputation in the airline industry as an easygoing executive with an optimistic, cheerleading management style. When he left Delta Air Lines Inc. in August after 36 years, Harris seemed to be just what Continental Airlines Inc. needed - someone with the financial savvy to keep the carrier afloat and an exuberant personality to encourage dispirited employees. ``It may sound a little corny, but I say, `Continental team, let's go get them!''' he told employees when he was introduced as chairman-elect. But Harris will have to use all those spirited traits - and more - if he's to see Continental through Chapter 11 federal bankruptcy proceedings. The nation's fifth-largest carrier filed for protection from creditors earlier this month, citing soaring fuel costs and mounting interest payments on its $6.2 billion debt. It was Continental's second bankrutpcy filing. Harris' predecessor, Frank Lorenzo, built Continental through a series of mergers and acquisitions over nearly two decades. But he incurred the wrath of union workers during the first reorganization in 1983 when he insinuated greedy unions were hurting the company. Harris has painstakenly tried to avoid such confrontations. ``Our 37,000 employees have earned a reputation for working hard and smart while providing American travelers with the services they need,'' he remarked, following the company's bankruptcy filing announcement. Harris, still commuting from his home in Georgia, was unavailable for an interview, Continental officials said. Harris has said he sees his role as part of a leadership continuum for the company and believes his job is to make the airline run more smoothly. Lorenzo's role, he said, was building the airline. ``In the '80s, people were concentrating more on growing. Now the focus is on competing with service,'' he said. In four months, the 58-year-old Harris has endeared himself to his employees. ``Mr. Harris is a very positive, people-oriented person which is something we haven't known a lot of around Continental for awhile,'' said pilot Robert Finley. ``It seems like a breath of fresh air to see a man like him in that job. ``If anyone can pull us through these difficult times - where fuel costs are skyrocketing and all costs are elevating at an enormous rate while the fares are still being depressed and the fare wars are going on - I think Mr. Harris is the guy who can do it.'' Friends and associates had equally kind words. ``He's a very likeable person. I can't remember anybody saying anything unkind about him,'' said Clara Bailey, who graduated high school with Harris in 1949 in Carrollton, Ga., about 55 miles west of Atlanta. Ms. Bailey, who keeps in touch with Harris and his wife, fellow Carrollton native Joyce Harris, said the Continental leader has always been a private person who cared about others. The son of the Rev. C.L. Harris, a retired Methodist minister, Harris excelled in school. But Ms. Bailey said he never flaunted his achievements. ``He was one of the most intelligent people in the class, but he was also the most unassuming,'' she said. Harris holds a bachelor of aeronautical engineering degree from the Georgia Institute of Technology. The father of two sons and a daughter, he gained a reputation in Atlanta for his involvement in several community projects including the Boy Scouts of America. Harris was instrumental in setting up a fund-raising system for the council that provided about $200,000 for the group last year alone. Harris remains active in other civic activities. He serves on the advisory council of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society and was past chairman of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, among others. Harris joined Delta in 1954 as a transportation agent in the marketing division and later became an aircraft engineer, eventually rising to head of that department. He subsequently served in key management roles in the facilities department, inflight service, passenger service and operations. Harris was named president of Delta in 1987 and was responsible for all marketing, operations, technical operations and personnel functions. ``He was very much liked here,'' said one former employee, who asked not to be named. ``And his hometown and Georgia were very proud of him. I'm sure Houston and Texas will be, as well.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, Dec. 16

DOC.HEAD: Hitachi, Nissan Form Car Electronics Company
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese electronics maker Hitachi Ltd. and the Japanese carmaker Nissan Motor Co. Ltd. said Wednesday they will form a joint-venture company to make automotive electronics products. The new Japanese company, to be called Xanavi Informatics Corp., will make and market products such as automotive audio and video equipment, mobile telephones and navigation systems, the companies said in a news release issued in New York. Hitachi will supply 51 percent of the company's initial capital, which will total about $18.9 million, while Nissan will supply the remainder, the companies said. The company will market its products worldwide under the Xanavi brand, they said.

DOC.HEAD: The Economy and a Little Bit of Luck Can Make or Break the Season
LaserPhotos
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: How merry Christmas 1990 will be depends on economic and geographic basics - what you do for a living and where you do it. But it also depends on some intangibles, like luck, timing and creativity. The following vignettes, reported by AP writers Jonathan Yenkin in Boston, Steven P. Rosenfeld in Des Moines, Gry Eriksen in Los Angeles, Marc Rice in Atlanta and Joyce M. Rosenberg in New York, look at the holiday season from a variety of vantage points. ---=

Homer's jewelry store sits in the heart of Boston's downtown shopping district, and like the holiday seasons of years past, the aisles are crammed with people who peer into glass cases and try on gold bracelets. But this scene does not sparkle like it normally would for store manager Donald Cohen. After 108 years in business, Homer's is holding one last sale before closing its doors, becoming another casualty of hard times in New England. ``This is the only place I ever worked,'' said Cohen, 55, who first came to the shop as an errand boy in 1950. ``It's going to be quite different after 40 years getting up each day and coming to work here.'' Homer's is a virtual landmark in Boston, but its fate is not so unique. The Massachusetts economy, sinking into recession for more than a year, has forced thousands of people out of work. That gave may retailers a dim outlook for this Christmas season. Jewelers find it is difficult to sell gold and diamonds to people keeping a close eye on their wallets. ``We have so many people coming in, talking about relatives losing their jobs,'' said Cohen. ``It's more important that they have food on their table.'' With business declining, Homer's owners decided to close down now rather than watch the shop sink further.

For Iowa farm wife Debbie Hardersen, spending $60 on a blouse and skirt is unusually extravagant. But the clothes were on sale and times are good - if not great - for farmers. So she bought the outfit for herself on a shopping spree recently during the Iowa Farm Bureau convention. ``I didn't feel too badly buying it,'' Hardersen said. ``I've spent $350 here and I'm not done yet,'' she said. ``Christmas is a time I do like to splurge.'' There's no scrimping or pinching pennies this year. Iowa manufacturers such as Winnebago Industries Inc. and Deere & Co. may be laying off workers this fall as sales slump, but the farm economy is on the mend from the freefall of the 1980s. Hardersen, 36, went to the convention with her husband, Don, 41. Their two children stayed at their home outside the eastern Iowa community of Anamosa, where the couple farms 600 acres and raises hogs and cattle. Cattle prices were at all-time highs during convention week and hog prices remained comfortably above the break-even point. While corn and soybean prices have been slumping, the crop was good and cheap feed grains reduce the expense of raising livestock. ``Overall, the mood out in the country is much more optimistic,'' Debbie Hardersen says.

The economy is weak, it's a dismal holiday season for retailers, and Bob and Susan Rabascho braved three hours on the freeway from San Diego just to go to a discount home furnishing store in Burbank, Calif. They had to wait another hour to get inside the Ikea store, but they didn't care. Nor have other shoppers who have mobbed the 110-room store since it opened last month. The Sweden-based Ikea is a rare Southern California retailing success story at a time when sagging real estate prices and layoffs in aerospace and construction have put the brakes on spending. So many people have gone there that Burbank police have assigned 29 officers to handle the traffic jams that followed the store's $3 million advertising campaign. Things got so bad that cars on the Burbank Boulevard off-ramp backed up on the Golden State Freeway. Police finally implored the state Transportation Department to put a sign on the freeway directing drivers to another exit. After the Rabaschos finally made it inside, they spent six hours and about $200 at Ikea. The store features assemble-it-yourself furniture and offers amenities such as supervised childcare and free diapers to keep families happy while they shop.

DOC.TEXT: Every year artisans from all over the Northeast flock to the annual holiday crafts fair at Columbia University in New York to sell their pottery, jewelry, quilts and clothing. But this year, the market for crafts - like that for goods sold by more traditional retailers - is in a slump. Cherry Schacher has been selling patchwork goods at the fair for 10 years, but this year, she sold more placemats and pillows than $500 quilts. ``It is off a bit,'' she said of her sales. But after having had a slow year, Ms. Schacher came into Manhattan expecting business to be down from the robust sales she enjoyed at past fairs. Like many artisans, Ms. Schacher depends on her handiwork for a large portion of her income. However, she and her husband, who live in upstate Ballston Spa, N.Y., also make their living by playing in a country band several nights a week. The music business helps make up for a drop in crafts sales. Alan Goldfarb, a glassblower from Burlington, Vt., also expected his business to be down at the fair, but he was pleasantly surprised. Goldfarb's goblets and glass fish range from $12.50 to $350 in price, and he came prepared with more lower-priced than higher-end pieces. Yet by the end of his three days at the fair, Goldfarb had his highest sales total ever for the New York show. He also found that the new works he displayed sold very well. ``We were taking a chance ...'' he said. ``But if you follow your heart, it works.''

Instead of buying Christmas gifts for his family, David Ryan has been shopping for something else lately: a job. At 26, Ryan is among the young adults coping with unemployment during the economic slump in Massachusetts. Ryan lost his job at a Boston investment firm several months ago, and that means a holiday season without glitter. ``My relatives have told me not to buy any gifts until after I get back to work,'' Ryan said. ``It's a little hard for me. I would like to give some gifts to express my feelings about what they do for me during the year.'' Ryan has had to budget his money tightly. He even is cutting back on greeting cards. Unemployment officials say they have encountered many similar tales this year. Mary Muir, director of the state employment and training office in Woburn, Mass., said she sees more young unemployed people these days. ``For many of these people, it's the first time they've been unemployed,'' she said. ``It's a shock to them.'' Ryan said initially he didn't think he would have much trouble dealing with unemployment. But he has had to let some bills slide and he receives help from his family. And with no luck so far in finding a new job, Ryan said he's had trouble getting into the holiday spirit.

This may be the season of austerity in gift-giving, but Thank Your Lucky Stars is selling what some might consider a frivolity: astrological gift certificates. The company, a career-oriented astrological firm based in suburban Atlanta, is selling certificates for its services, which range from a personalized astrological profile for $19.95 to a business-friendship compatibility report for $29.95 to a full-scale consultation for $80. Many retailers have reported consumers are looking for practical gifts this season, like flannel shirts and sweaters, but Thank Your Lucky Stars is confident there's a market for its services. ``Our astrological practice, if this is not an oxymoron, is a very conservative astrological practice,'' said Sandy Keefe, a partner in the firm. Ms. Keefe, who also runs a standard personnel firm out of the same office, also offers star-guided suggestions for holiday gift giving. But all people do not fare equally under Ms. Keefe's astrological gift guide. For example, because a Leo yearns for appreciation and recognition, it is suggested that season tickets to the theater or gold jewelry would make a fine present. A Sagittarius, on the other hand, wants to find out more about the world. An atlas is advised as an appropriate gift. It's enough to make someone lie about their birthday.

DOC.HEAD: Delaware Judge Awards $110 Million to Former Shell Shareholders
DOC.TEXT: A Delaware judge Wednesday awarded approximately $110 million to about 1,000 former Shell Oil Co. stockholders who relinquished 1 million shares in a merger deal five years ago. The shareholders, most of whom are present or former Shell employees, were awarded $71.20 per share for their stock by Vice Chancellor Maurice Hartnett III in Delaware. Houston-based Shell Oil Co. became a wholly owned subsidiary of the giant Royal Dutch-Shell Group of Cos. on June 7, 1985, completing a $5.7 billion merger. As part of the merger, the shareholders were given the option of accepting $60 per share or seeking a court appraisal of stock value, said Houston attorney Lee Godfrey, lead counsel for the shareholders. The shareholders who received the $71.20 had sought the court appraisal rather than the $60-per-share offer. The judge also awarded interest to the shareholders on the $71.20 price at 10 percent interest from June 1985, increasing the amount to about $110 per share. ``Our contention all along was that Shell's foreign-owned parent paid far too little in the 1985 cash-out merger,'' said Lee Godfrey, lead counsel for the 1,000 shareholders. Plaintiffs' attorneys maintained the fair value was $89 per share, while experts for Shell said the value was $55 a share. Shell officials can appeal the decision issued Wednesday, but company officials would not discuss their plans. ``We don't have a comment at this time. Our attorneys are still studying the document,'' said Shell spokeswoman Eydie Pengelly. Last month, Hartnett awarded some 20,000 other former Shell stockholders an additional $2 per share for 15 million shares relinquished in the same merger deal. Those shareholders were given $58 per share, plus $2 a share for giving up their right of appraisals. That award followed a June 1990 court finding of disclosure violations in materials Shell distributed to shareholders describing their options in the buyout. Hartnett ruled last June that the material mailed to shareholders failed ``to disclose the existence of oil and gas reserves having a value of approximately $1 billion.'' Plaintiffs' attorneys still are seeking interest on the $2-per-share award and attorneys' fees.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys General File Suit Against Mortgage Lender
DOC.TEXT: The federal government's inaction against mortgage lenders with excessive amounts held in escrow forced legal action against the GMAC Mortgage Corp., attorneys general in six states said Wednesday. Attorneys general in Iowa, California, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New York and Texas filed the suit Wednesday in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. GMAC Mortgage Corp. of Detroit and several of its subsidiaries ``routinely hold in these mortgage accounts more funds than either federal law or the homeowners' mortgage contracts allow,'' the lawsuit alleges. ``The suit would bar GMAC's illegal practice of requiring excess money to be held in homeowners' mortgage escrow accounts,'' Massachusetts Attorney General James M. Shannon said in a statement Wednesday. GMAC ``will take appropriate action'' to defend against the allegations in the suit, said Rick Gillespie, a GMAC vice president in Elkins Park, Pa. ``GMAC Mortgage Corp. is confident it has been and remains in full compliance with federal and state laws and industry practices and that these practices are fair to each consumer and our company,'' Gillespie said. He said the corporation voluntarily gave information to the attorneys general to aid their research. GMAC has about 400,000 residential mortgages nationwide. Escrow accounts are kept by lending institutions to make payments for property taxes, insurance and other items that borrowers must pay. Extra money in escrow is a bonanza for lenders because they can use the money for free or pay only a low rate of interest on it. About two-thirds of the nation's home mortgages involve escrow accounts. Federal law limits lenders to keeping a two-month ``cushion'' in escrow, or enough money to make payments for two months. The cushion allows lenders to make tax and insurance payments even if the consumer is late making a monthly payment. In April, the attorneys general issued a report critical of the practice of requiring excess money in the accounts. They asked Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp to tighten enforcement of the escrow law. ``When we released the report of the illegal escrow practices of GMAC and other lenders, we urged the federal government to enforce its own statutory limits on escrow payments. So far, it has taken no action, thus prompting suits like the one filed today, at great cost to the states,'' New York Attorney General Robert Abrams said. ``Our report estimated that the `excess cushion' averages about $150 per homeowner,'' Iowa Attorney General Thomas Miller said. ``That means we think lenders are holding several billion dollars that should be in the hands of their customers.'' The two-year study said consumers were being overcharged $2 billion to $4 billion by the nation's mortgage lenders. The study focused on big lenders who operate nationwide. A survey of four of the largest - Citibank, GMAC Mortgage Corp., Fleet Mortgage Corp. and Lomas Financial Group - ``indicated that lenders may be holding excessive and illegal cushions in more than 70 percent of escrow accounts.'' Bob Brammer, an administrative assistant in the Iowa attorney general's office, said inquiries still are being made into escrow practices of the other lenders. ``We don't contemplate any lawsuits regarding them in the immediate future,'' Brammer said. Massachusetts Assistant Attorney General Ernest Sarason, who handled the suit for Shannon, said the states have been studying the issue for more than two years. ``The reason that we filed the suit is that we were very concerned about mortgage companies not complying with federal law limiting the amount of mortgage escrow,'' Sarason said.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Ministers to Continue At Current Oil Production Levels
LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: OPEC will continue pumping oil at high levels to offset crude losses caused by the Persian Gulf crisis, officials said late Wednesday. Indonesian Oil Minister Ginandjar Kartasasmita said the 13 nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would sign a statement Thursday endorsing continued increased production. He said in an interview that they also would promise to reduce their output to levels set in late July, once the gulf crisis has ended. In August, after Iraq invaded Kuwait, the cartel temporarily suspended its quota system to permit higher pumping by nations with spare capacity. ``We will continue with the August agreement,'' Ginandjar said. ``We are reaffirming everything,'' said Gabonese Oil Minister Jean Ping. The August accord was put together so that heavyweight Saudi Arabia and other producing nations could make up for lost Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. About 4 million barrels of oil a day have been pulled from the market because of international sanctions imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Ginandjar said that when the gulf troubles subside, the cartel would reimpose the output caps in force in late July. Under that accord, all 13 nations agreed to hold production to 22.5 million barrels a day in an effort to reach a target of $21 dollars a barrel. The cartel's current production is pegged at around 23 million barrels a day. Saudi Arabia, the world's largest crude exporter, is close to pumping 8.5 million barrels a day, sources have said. Its quota under the July accord was 5.4 million barrels. Other members pumping above their previous levels are Venezuela, Nigeria, the United Arab Emirates, Iran and Libya. The ministers, who agreed to meet again in early March, made their decisions during five hours of formal and informal talks on the opening day of their winter strategy session. It was the first time since the invasion that all 13 oil-producing representatives have been represented. Iraq and Libya did not attend the meeting at which the cartel's quota system was suspended. No sparks were reported between Iraq and Kuwait, seated next to each other in the conference room's alphabetical arrangement. Ramzi Salman Abdul Hussain, director of Iraq's State Oil Marketing Organization, said little. But he told reporters that Iraq could increase its crude production to strong levels ``as soon as we want.'' ``None of the facilities are damaged,'' he said. Iraq is estimated to be producing a mere 400,000 barrels a day, compared to earlier levels of more than 3 million barrels. Rasheed Salem al-Ameeri, the oil minister for Kuwait's government-in-exile, also insisted his country could get its oil industry back to former levels quickly with a peaceful resolution. He said Iraqi invaders ``have done extensive damage to our oil industry. ... But we have plans to reconstruct it in a short time.'' Earlier in the day, OPEC President Sadek Boussena opened the strategy session by criticizing oil-consuming nations for failing to do much to ease the oil crunch. Instead of tapping crude in their inventories, he said, the rich nations appeared to have added oil to their storage tanks in case of a worsening of gulf troubles. As a result, he said, OPEC has been forced into ``extreme levels of output.'' ``This is clearly an ill-contrived move,'' Boussena, the Algerian mines minister, told his counterparts. ``If such an escalation does not occur and - as we all hope - an early, peaceful solution is found to the crisis, then the world will be awash with oil,'' he said. He warned that OPEC would ``be faced with another decade of turmoil'' like the roller-coaster 1980s. ``Nobody in our organization wants a repetition of that era of rampant instability,'' said Boussena. The cartel has been in disarray since the gulf crisis. After the invasion, ministers agreed to lift their production caps to offset the loss of crude from Iraq and Kuwait. The result has been a flood of oil on the market and sharp swings in prices. Prices for light sweet crude peaked in October at $41 a barrel. They since have skidded to under $30 a barrel on hints of peace in the Middle East and worries about an oil glut. The average price of a basket of crudes monitored by the cartel was $26.25 a barrel Monday, well above its target price of $21 a barrel set in July. OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Grains, Soybeans Higher As Market Anticipates Credits to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade in anticipation of the granting of export credits to the Soviet Union. On other markets, silver plunged while gold gained, livestock and pork futures were mixed and energy futures fell. Grain and soybean futures opened lower in reaction to the release Tuesday of the U.S. Agriculture Department's supply and demand report, said Gerald Zusel, an analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. The market rallied later in the morning after Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., said immediate action was needed to extend $3 billion in credits to the Soviet Union. Dole's request was considered bullish because the market has been speculating the export initiative would be around $1.5 billion. ``We mainly had a lot of speculative buying in anticipation the government will announce a big credit package,'' Zusel said. After the close of trading, President Bush announced a waiver of trade restrictions on the Soviet Union and granted credit guarantees. Secretary of State James Baker said the amount of credits would be between $500 million and $1 billion, significantly less than what Dole asked for and what a U.S. Agriculture Department official last week told Congress could be made available. Wheat settled 1 cent lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.55 a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 1 cent higher with December at $2.27 a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents lower with December at $1.10 a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents to 2} cents higher with January at $5.96} a bushel. Silver prices fell on the New York's Commodity Exchange amid fund and technical selling. Willian O'Neill, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Futures Inc., said silver is following a trend downward that was established at the beginning of the year. ``Silver is functioning as an industrial metal rather than as a precious metal,'' O'Neill said. ``That places silver in a weak position. Investment demand is sluggish to non-existent. And with the economy not expected to do well into next year, the industrial side does not look all that positive, either.'' Gold prices gained during Wednesday's trading. Gold benefited from continued uncertainty in the Persian Gulf and the failure of the United States and Iraq to agree on a date for a meeting of their diplomats, O'Neill said. Gold was 70 cents to $1.80 higher with February at $373.50 a troy ounce; silver was 4.1 cents to 4.9 cents lower with December at $4.026 a troy ounce. Energy futures were lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the weakness in the heating oil market the main feature of trading. ``The market has become aware that there is too much heating oil out there,'' said Jim Ritterbusch, an analyst with PaineWebber Inc. in Chicago. ``We are not having the kind of December we had last year. Temperatures are warmer than normal and they are expected remain that way (for a time).'' The energy market tended to shrug off the meeting in Vienna of 13 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Ritterbusch said. The ministers decided late Wednesday to continue current levels of crude output. Light sweet crude was $1.01 to $1.22 lower with January at $25.35 a barrel; heating oil was 2.36 cents to 3.11 cents lower with January at 74.63 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.23 cents to 2.30 cents lower with January at 64.49 cents a gallon; natural gas was .08 cent lower to .005 cent higher with January at $2.204 per thousand cubic feet. Livestock and pork futures were mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .33 cent lower to .13 cent higher with December at 88.85 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .30 cent higher with January at 88.72 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .25 cent higher with December at 49.85 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .35 cent lower to .27 cent higher with February at 66.92 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Shuffles Management, Ponders Cutbacks To Boost Profits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf pvs, `Nikki Richardson ...,' to UPDATE with stock price.
DOC.TEXT: Trying to rediscover a recipe for success, Digital Equipment Corp. has shuffled some of its top executives while the computer maker tries to cut costs by about $1 billion. Also looming on the horizon are possible layoffs, which would be the first in Digital's 33-year history. For months, Digital has been seeking ways to cut costs to cope with a slump in computer sales. Mark Steinkrauss, director of investor relations for the Maynard-based company, said Digital is trying to reduce its expenses by about $1 billion, though the figure is only a rough target. ``In this economic environment, one has to assume a low level of profitability,'' Steinkrauss said Wednesday. The cost-cutting steps have included slashing the payroll through voluntary means and consolidating operations. Digital, which employs about 123,500 people worldwide and had revenues of $12.9 billion in its last fiscal year, is trying to eliminate 5,000 to 6,000 employees this fiscal year. So far, the world's second-largest computer maker has avoided layoffs by using a voluntary severance program. Nikki Richardson, a Digital spokeswoman, said Wednesday about 600 people have left the company under the recent severance program, which is set to expire Dec. 31. She said many employees will wait until the last minute to make a decision whether to take the severance package. Digital's stock rose $2.37{ a share Wednesday to close at $57 in New York Stock Exchange trading. ``The work force reduction program is going slowly,'' said Barry Willman, an analyst at the New York investment firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. Digital likely will make a decision in January whether to extend the severance program or take the more forceful step of layoffs, Richardson said. ``We will look at it in conjunction with the business climate,'' she said, adding that layoffs ``may be a possibility.'' Digital President Kenneth Olsen has refused to rule out layoffs. Digital posted its first-ever quarterly loss earlier this year, and its earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30 plunged 83 percent, while revenues dipped 1 percent. In the wake of these results, Digital has decided to restructure part of its senior management. David Grainger, who was vice president of Digital's U.S. sales and service organization, will now head a newly created group overseeing the company's worldwide network of distributors and resellers, who tailor products to individual customers. Digital ``may have let some opportunities slip by'' in this area, Steinkrauss said, adding that the company will look at new ways to distribute its products. Donald P. Zereski, formerly vice president for customer service, is taking over responsibility for Digital's U.S. business, under a structure that will reduce bureaucracy in sales, Steinkrauss said. Russell A. Gullotti, who headed Digital's corporate consulting services, will also assume customer service duties. In another recent switch, Bill Hanson, who oversaw manufacturing operations, assumed worldwide responsibility for the flow of materials and other asset management. Robert Palmer, who headed semiconductor operations, became vice president of manufacturing. Cliff Friedman, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co., said these management moves signal another change at Digital, where John Smith, the senior vice president for operations, is gaining more authority to make the necessary steps. Smith appears to be taking over more day-to-day responsibility for running Digital from Olsen, who co-founded the computer maker, analysts say. Like other computer companies, Digital has suffered from an industrywide downturn in sales in recent years. Digital also has seen sales slip in its minicomputer line, its mainstay products, as customers switch to increasingly powerful personal computers for some uses, analysts say.

DOC.HEAD: New York Could Get Second Oil Futures Market
DOC.TEXT: Is this town big enough for two oil futures markets? Now that the Persian Gulf crisis has made crude oil a hot commodity, the New York Mercantile Exchange may be in for some competition. The neighboring Commodity Exchange, which shares the same trading floor with the Merc, has discussed a deal with London's International Petroleum Exchange that could lead to crude oil trading on the Comex, officials said Wednesday. The Mercantile Exchange, currently the world's largest market for crude futures, hasn't faced any competition in this country since the Chicago Board of Trade gave up oil trading a few years ago. Oil experts say breaking into the oil market would be difficult for any newcomer. ``There is a rule of thumb that only one contract in the same commodity would succeed in any given time zone,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. The Comex, located with other New York futures exchanges in the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan, deals primarily in precious metals. ``We've been considering agreements with many exchanges and now we're talking with the IPE about joint trading benefits,'' Commodity Exchange President David A. Halperin said in a statement. A Comex official who would speak only on condition of anonymity said crude futures were part of the discussions, but the official was not sure what the plans entailed. The official was not sure how soon an offering might be made, assuming the Comex and London can strike a deal. A phone call placed to IPE's New York office was not immediately returned. Crude oil has been the ``sexy'' futures contract in recent months, since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August sent oil prices swinging wildly, said Christian Gohler, an oil broker with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. The bustle of trading at the Mercantile Exchange oil pit has contrasted sharply with relatively weak demand for metals. If the Comex offered sweet crude oil contracts, it would compete directly with the Mercantile Exchange. But the Comex might offer contracts in sour crude, which could put it a step ahead of the Mercantile Exchange, which is now considering a sour crude contract. Sweet crude has a low sulfur content and is most desirable for refining. Sour crude has more sulfur and is more difficult to refine. The two New York futures markets have failed in past discussions to reach agreement on a merger. IPE was also once talking with the Mercantile Exchange about a trading agreement, but those talks fell through. Oil traders said the emergence of a crude contract on the Commodity Exchange could stir bad blood between the exchanges. The Mercantile Exchange said it would not fear any competition. ``We think we're the best at what we do, so we're ready to take on any comers,'' said Robert R. Davis, senior vice president at the Mercantile Exchange. Analysts who follow oil futures pricing doubt that the Comex would be successful in offering a contract that competed with the Mercantile Exchange's light sweet crude futures. Generally there is just room for one market for each commodity, because the big players tend to gravitate to the place where the volume is greatest and they can get the best deals, Beutel said. At the time the Mercantile Exchange first offered its futures contracts for light sweet crude in 1983, the Chicago Board of Trade began offering contracts for Louisiana Light Sweet crude, but those sales were soon abandoned, traders said. But Beutel said an oil contract that could be traded in both London and New York would create advantages for the biggest oil trading companies that maintain offices in both cities. ``The fact that you could enter a position in London and remove it in New York would come close to that 24-hour trading that some people want,'' he said. It would put local traders and smaller companies at a disadvantage, he said, because they would have a harder time keeping abreast of trading for so many hours each day. London oil traders can now deal in futures of Brent Blend, a North Sea oil. Oil futures are also available on the Singapore International Monetary Exchange, but its contracts for Dubai crude oil are not widely traded, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drifts Lower in Quiet Trading, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar drifted lower against foreign currencies Wednesday in what traders said was one of the quietest trading days of the year. Gold prices were mixed. With currency trading thinned by the pre-holiday season, the dollar eased largely on technical factors, mostly ignoring the day's few external influences. ``A lot of people are already sidelined for the holidays. We had absolutely no indicators come out today,'' said Gabriele Schmitt, vice president for Bank of New York. Traders said the British pound showed signs of strength after Chancellor of the Exchequer Norman Lamont said British interest rates would remain at their current level and not be lowered. Sterling strengthened to $1.9502 in New York from late Tuesday's $1.9380, and in London, the pound rose to $1.9435 from $1.9400 late Tuesday. But traders said the market shrugged off an early-day rumor that Iraq would withdraw its troops from Kuwait before the Jan. 15 deadline imposed in a resolution passed last month by the United Nations. The rumor later proved to be untrue. The resolution permits the use of military force against Iraq if the country remains in occupied Kuwait beyond the mid-January deadline. ``People are pretty happy to stay square and not really get involved that much,'' said Renato Strauss, currency trader at Bank Julius Baer & Co. ``I had one of the lowest volume days of the year.'' The dollar lost ground against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 131.45 yen from 132.40 late Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 131.88 Japanese yen from 131.75 yen at Tuesday's close, and later in London it was quoted at 131.75 yen. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4756 German marks, down from 1.4784; 1.2610 Swiss francs, down from 1.2650; 5.0120 French francs, down from 5.0190; 1,112.00 Italian lire, down from 1,114.00; and 1.1606 Canadian dollars, unchanged. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.4788 German marks, down from 1.4790; 1.2650 Swiss francs, down from 1.2665; 5.0240 French francs, up from 5.0230; 1.6675 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6683; 1,113.25 Italian lire, up from 1,110.07; and 1.1599 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1591. Gold rose in New York, closing up 70 cents a troy ounce to $372.70 on the Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $371.45 a troy ounce, down 55 cents from late Tuesday. In London earlier, gold rose to a late bid price of $371.75 a troy ounce from $370.75 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $371.60 from $371.85. But in Hong Kong earlier, gold fell $2.74 to close at a bid $372.62. Silver fell on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $4.026 a troy ounce, down 4.1 cents. The metal also fell in London to a late bid price of $4.03 a troy ounce, from $4.06 bid late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Data General Chairman To Retire
DOC.TEXT: Struggling with a string of losses, Data General Corp. announced Wednesday that two of the computer company's founders will take early retirement, including 52-year-old Chairman Edson D. de Castro. De Castro will retire Dec. 31, and Vice Chairman Herbert J. Richman, 56, will leave the company at the end of its fiscal year in September. A statement from the company gave no reasons for the retirements of the executives, who were among the founders of Data General in 1968. Company spokesman James Dunlap said De Castro was not available for comment. Data General's stock closed unchanged Wednesday at $4.37{ a share in New York Stock Exchange trading. Ronald L. Skates, Data General's president and chief executive officer, praised de Castro as ``an industry legend.'' He also commended Richman for leading the Westboro-based company's sales and marketing efforts, saying Richman deserved much of the credit for Data General's rapid rise in the market for mid-range minicomputers. That market has fallen on hard times. Data General has not enjoyed a profitable year since 1985, when its employment peaked at 17,700. Since then, the company has suffered a string of losses, and employment has shrunk to around 9,500. Analysts say Data General has responded with some strong products, particularly its AViiON workstations. But the minicomputer slump has continued to act as a drag on earnings, hampering the company's repeated efforts to turn a profit. Data General faces the added strain of lower profit margins as it puts more focus on ``open'' computer systems, or those that adhere to industry standards. Because the market is more competitive, open systems are less profitable than the proprietary machines that fueled much of the the company's growth. Data General lost $139 million in its most recent fiscal year. Revenues were $1.22 billion, compared with $1.31 billion the year before. Barry Willman, an analyst at the New York investment firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., said de Castro had been assigning increasing responsibility to Skates, who assumed his present title last year. Willman described de Castro as a ``visionary'' industrialist. But Sonny Monosson, president of Monosson Technology Enterprises, a Boston firm that monitors high-tech industries, said he believed Data General would gain from de Castro's departure. ``Really he was a hindrance to development,'' Monosson said. ``He was a strong-minded guy.'' De Castro served as president from 1968 until he was named chairman of the board and chief scientist in November 1989. The company said both de Castro and Richman would not seek re-election to the board of directors. But Richman will continue to serve as executive vice president for the AsiaPacific region until he retires.

DOC.HEAD: General Mills Profits Up 29.3 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: General Mills Inc.'s core businesses performed solidly in the second quarter but a 29.3 percent increase in profits included a one-time $9.2 million gain, the food and restaurant company said Wednesday. Net earnings of $118.2 million, or 72 cents a share, for the quarter ended Nov. 25 compare with $91.4 million, or 55 cents a share, in the second quarter of fiscal 1990. Sales grew 13 percent, from $1.63 billion to $1.84 billion. Excluding the net after-tax gain of $9.2 million, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of the Lancia Bravo pasta operation and a restructuring charge for Yoplait yogurt operations, profits for the quarter were up 19.2 percent. Chairman H.B. Atwater, Jr. said expense controls contributed to the growth in net income. The company said its consumer foods, including Cheerios, Wheaties and Betty Crocker products, had a 12 percent gain in second-quarter sales and a 23 percent increase in operating profits. Those figures exclude the gain related to the pasta sale and Yoplait restructuring. Atwater said the restaurants division had a 15 percent increase in sales and a 16 percent gain in operating profits. The increases were led by strong gains by The Olive Garden chain and moderate increases by Red Lobster operations in the United States. General Mills is experimenting with a new restaurant concept, China Coast, which restrained overall restaurant earnings growth, Atwater said. Development costs associated with the fast-growing Olive Garden chain also affected earnings, Atwater said. For the six months ended Nov. 25, the company had net income of $247.7 million, or $1.51 per share, compared to $206.3 million, or $1.25 per share, in the first six months of fiscal 1989. Revene increased to $3.58 billion from $3.13 billion. Atwater said the company expects continued operating gains from both of its divisions in the second half. He said overall results also will reflect a gain on the sale of the O-Cel-O sponge business, completed Friday, that will be reported in the third-quarter results.

DOC.HEAD: Border Merchants Float On Tide Of Canadian Money
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollars are U.S.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BF1
DOC.TEXT: Merchants along the country's northern border are floating on a tide of Canadian dollars, watching sales figures swell at a time when shopping elsewhere in the United States is slumping. Canadians have been traveling by car and bus from as far as 100 miles away this year to snap up goods that sell in the United States for as low as half their cost back home. As a result, stores all along the border that reported record sales last year - when retailing nationwide was stagnant - say business is even better this Christmas. Bob Bowen, merchandising manager of a Kmart Corp. store outside Niagara Falls, N.Y., said sales were up 15 percent over last year. ``And last year was a banner year, too,'' he said. Down the road, stores at the Factory Outlet Mall have been reporting sales increases of anywhere from 5 percent to more than 10 percent over last year, said Pat Doyle, the mall's marketing manager. She said up to 90 percent of the mall's customers are Canadian. Parking lots at the Kmart and the mall were filled Wednesday with cars bearing Ontario license plates, and chartered buses from Canada were parked at the front. But seven miles away, at a Kmart in Niagara Falls, Ontario, only three cashiers were on duty and the store was noticeably quiet. ``You Buffalo people are killing us,'' said merchandising manager Dan Gimpel. ``There's not a heck of a lot we can do. People are convinced there's bargains over there and they go over.'' Richard Delisle, assistant district manager of Canada Customs in Niagara Falls, Ontario, said the number of people paying duties on goods purchased in the United States between April and October, the most recent figures available, jumped 75 percent from last year's record high. ``Each year we're looking at increases to unprecedented levels,'' Delisle said. The story is the same in border towns across the country. In Bellingham, Wash., 45 miles south of Vancouver, business at the Bellis Fair Mall is up slightly thanks to the Canadians, said marketing director Wendy Ripley. ``People are always amazed to see our parking lot and all the Canadian cars in it,'' she said. In northern New York, motels are full of shoppers from as far away as Ottawa and Montreal, and three-hour delays have been reported on the international bridges. A recent study estimated that Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, businesses lose $140 million a year in sales to stores in much smaller Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. The study, by Ernst & Young in Toronto, estimated the loss nationwide at $2 billion. Shopping by Canadians has surged even though Canada officially is in a recession. Bern Rotman, spokesman for the New York State Department of Economic Development, said the hard times in Canada might actually spur more cross-border shopping. ``As the expendible income gets smaller in Canada - if that's the case - it may very well be that the bargain that's had in the United States is even more a siren song,'' he said. The price differences on many everyday items are staggering. An eight-pack of batteries, for example, costs $3.97 in the United States but $6.85 in Canada. A roll of color slide film that would be less than $10 in New York is $14.59 in Ontario. Canadians pay the equivalent of $2.16 a gallon for self-serve unleaded gas, while those in Buffalo pay $1.43. ``A Canadian Kmart could probably come over here and buy power tools cheaper off my counter than they could from their distributor in Canada,'' said Thomas Reddy, general manager of the Niagara Falls, N.Y., Kmart. Pam Clarkin said she drives 65 miles round-trip from her home in Grassie, Ontario, to do her weekly grocery shopping in Niagara Falls. ``Usually at home I pay about $120'' for a week's worth of groceries, Clarkin said. ``Here I can get it for about $70.'' Brian Kellett, a 19-year-old student at the University of Toronto, said his fellow students make the 90-mile drive to Niagara Falls as often as every two weeks to stock up on cheap booze and cigarettes. ``Everybody comes down, they buy like a big jug of schnapps or something,'' he said. Last year, Niagara Falls, N.Y., residents grumbled about the traffic and litter problems they blamed on the Canadians. Merchants said they had heard fewer complaints this year and speculated that American shoppers have simply learned to put up with the crowds. ``They stay off the roads or go to Amherst (15 miles south) where it's not so bad,'' said Bill Hench, manager of a Wallet Works store at the outlet mall.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Company, Soviets Agree To Cellular Phone Pact
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. telecommunications company said Wednesday it had signed an agreement to build and operate a cellular phone network for the Soviet republic of Byelorussia. CommStruct International Inc. is committing an initial investment of $7 million to introduce service to about 4,000 residential and mobile customers in the city of Minsk by mid-1991, the company said. More than 200,000 customers in Minsk will be able to receive the service when the system is completed. ``CommStruct looks forward to taking an active role in speeding the development of communications in Byelorussia, the USSR's gateway to Eastern Europe,'' said James Lewis, chairman of US CommStruct Inc., a subsidiary of CommStruct International. Residents of the Minsk region must wait years for a private phone, Lewis said. A cellular network would immediately serve a portion of the hundreds of thousands of people awaiting phone service in Byelorussia, he said. Two other cellular phone agreements with other non-Soviet companies have been announced for the cities of Moscow and Leningrad, he said. US CommStruct Inc. will build the system, while TLK & Associates of Yorba Linda, Calif., will engineer the system's radio frequency. TLK also is a subsidiary of CommStruct International Inc., a privately held, Vestal-based telecommunications company.

DOC.HEAD: MGM-UA Delays Debt Payments; Moody's Downgrades Rating on Studio
DOC.TEXT: MGM-Pathe Communications Co. said Wednesday it will delay paying interest for nearly a month on $400 million in debt incurred in the MGM-UA Communications Co. buyout. Delaying the payments will not put MGM-Pathe into default on the debt because a 30-day grace period on payments is permitted. But Moody's Investors Service Inc., one of the big debt-rating companies, immediately raised a red flag, announcing it was downgrading some MGM-Pathe debt ratings. Payment will be delayed from Dec. 15 until Jan. 11 on two junk bond issues underwritten by the now-defunct Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. When the bonds were issued, MGM-UA was owned by Kirk Kerkorian, who sold it last month to Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications. The company resulting from the merger is MGM-Pathe. MGM-Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons said the payment was delayed primarily because the company already was burdened this fiscal quarter with incidental costs of the MGM-UA $1.3 billion buyout, including relocations and layoffs. MGM-Pathe's statement also cited ``higher than anticipated MGM-UA payables.'' Spokeswoman Cecelia Wilkinson said two to three times the normal amount of monthly bills had been allowed to accumulate before Parretti took over, and he wanted to pay the vendors as soon as possible. Asked about the downgraded debt rating, Parsons said the company was merely exercising its rights under the debt agreement and did not ``understand why there's the downgrading.''

DOC.HEAD: German Company Charged With Not Telling FDA Drug Killed Patients
DOC.TEXT: A German manufacturer of an anti-depressant drug that was sold worldwide said Wednesday it will plead guilty to charges that it waited too long to notify U.S. regulators that the medication killed two patients in Europe. Hoechst AG marketed the drug nomifensine in the United States under the name Merital and voluntarily pulled it from shelves in 1986. The charges were filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Newark against Hoechst and its former research director, Rainer Zapf, who will not be extradited to the United States, prosecutors said. The company's U.S. subsidiary Hoechst-Roussel Pharmaceuticals Inc., based in Somerville, was not charged. A court date for the plea has not been set. U.S. Attorney Michael Chertoff said the case marked the first time a foreign drug maker has been prosecuted for failing to inform the U.S. Food and Drug Administration of adverse drug reactions that occurred outside the United States. More than 14 million people in 96 countries used the anti-depressant from its introduction in the early 1970s to its approval for use in the United States in December 1984, the company said. Hoechst began marketing the drug in the United States in July 1985. Charges were filed because Hoechst waited until 1986 to inform the FDA of a 1984 nomifensine-related death in France and a 1981 death in Italy, authorities said. Hoechst pulled the drug from the market after it noticed an increase in hemolytic anemia in certain users, a potentially fatal form of leukemia. The two patients in Europe died from hemolytic anemia associated with the drug, according to court papers. Andrea Stine, a spokeswoman for the company, said she did not know how widely the drug was used in the United States. She said Hoechst recorded $5 million in U.S. sales from the anti-depressant. FDA attorney Rick Blumber said Hoechst acted properly when it reported another death associated with the drug in Europe in April 1985. He said the anti-depressant was relabeled as a result of that fatality.

DOC.HEAD: Multimedia Expects Improved Results Despite Economic Slowdown
DOC.TEXT: Multimedia Inc. said Wednesday strength in its cable television and entertainment businesses has more than offset the adverse impact of a soft advertising market on its newspaper and broadcasting businesses. Chairman and Chief Executive Walter Bartlett said the company's revenue and income from continuing operations should be higher this year than in 1989 and show improvement again in 1991. Bartlett's upbeat review of the Greenville, S.C.-based media company's prospects at the 18th annual PaineWebber media outlook conference contrasted with a number of gloomy industry forecasts expressed earlier this week. ``Multimedia will be up this year and will be up again next year,'' he told the securities analysts. Robert E. Hamby Jr., treasurer and chief financial officer, said the company should meet analysts' earnings forecasts of $3.80 to $3.90 a share this year excluding a previously-disclosed writeoff of 25 cents a share. The company earned $3.11 a share in 1989. Multimedia owns 14 daily and 43 non-daily newspapers including papers in Greenville, S.C., Asheville, N.C., and Montgomery, Ala.; four TV stations and eight radio stations. It has applied for Federal Communications Commission approval of the purchase of a 51 percent interest in a fifth TV station. Bartlett said the slump in retail advertising has kept pressure on growth in newspaper and broadcasting revenue, which may continue into next year until the economy improves. But he said this has been outweighed by improved results in its cable TV system operations, which claim 347,000 subscribers, and in entertainment operations, which include production of the syndicated daily talk shows Donahue and Sally Jessy Raphael. The chairman said he expects to boost ad rates at its newspapers by 6 percent to 7 percent next year and by 5 percent to 6 percent in cable TV. Bartlett said the company has $375 million available for acquisitions, but said it is in no rush to spend it. He said the company recently passed up a chance to buy a television station offered at eight times its annual cash flow. ``We are pleased to have the money in our hip pocket if opportunities arise,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Feds: $38 Million in Deposits Diverted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES in last graf, All four, with appearances in court. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The first major Florida indictments growing out of the savings and loan crisis charged Wednesday that bank officers funded illegal campaign contributions and diverted $38 million in deposits to cover losses on speculative investments. ``Had there been a mask and gun involved, we almost could have called this bank robbery,'' said FBI agent William Gavin. Three ex-officers of the failed Fort Lauderdale-based Commonwealth Savings and Loan and an investment broke were named in two indictments carrying potential prison sentences of 15 to 256 years. Prosecutors charge the former executives' acts were a significant reason for Commonwealth's failure in July 1989 after the thrift absorbed a $33 million loss. The S&L remains under the control of the Resolution Trust Corp. Depositors were largely protected against losses by federal regulations, but taxpayers will be stuck with Commonwealth debts. ``These individuals defraud the American public, these individuals defraud the investors and the bank, these individuals defraud the taxpayers in this kind of behavior,'' U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said in announcing the indictments. ``The taxpaying public is having to cover a horrendous loss.'' The indictments charge that money set aside by a Catholic charity, a construction union and other institutional investors was diverted from the purchase of certificates of deposit to secret accounts used to conceal losses on trades controlled by ex-Treasurer Jason Chapnick. The accounts were credited with fake interest payments to lull depositors into the belief that their investments were prospering, prosecutors said. Bogus monthly brokerage-house statements, $11 million in unrecorded Treasury bill sales, fake letters of credit and false reports to independent auditors were part of the scheme to keep anyone from discovering the diversions, the indictment charged. The criminal investigation was prompted by reports from Commonwealth and regulators before the thrift failed, said Lehtinen, who called S&L fraud ``the largest crisis that the country faces.'' Chapnick, brother of Commonwealth Chairman Barry Chapnick, also was accused of converting $1.5 million to his personal use, including $700,000 to repay personal debts. A tax-perjury charge covers his federal income tax returns. Barry Chapnick is mentioned in the indictment as the one who selected the candidates for political contributions, but he was not charged in the indictment itself. Lehtinen cautioned against making much of the omission because the investigation is continuing. The probe was led by two prosecutors hired specifically to root out S&L fraud under federal bailout legislation, Lehtinen said. The additional staff is concentrating primarily on Commonwealth and on Miami's failed CenTrust Savings, which has not yet been charged. ``The scope of savings and loan fraud in South Florida in general and the inability to staff the investigations here and nationwide properly does impede some of the investigations,'' Lehtinen said. The expanded staff has been assigned to ``CenTrust, Commonwealth and a few other known investigations, leaving many other investigations in the district extremely short of either FBI or U.S. attorney manpower, but not CenTrust or Commonwealth.'' The fraud conspiracy indictment named: Jason Chapnick, 42, of Fort Lauderdale, former vice president and treasurer; Kenneth Fletcher, 41, of Davie, ex-president of Commonwealth's securities trading subsidiary Commvest; and investment broker Herbert Leslie Kalbach, 46, of Fort Lauderdale. Felix Adams, 41, of Bushnell, former executive vice president and assistant secretary, was accused in a separate indictment of misapplying Commonwealth funds on the political donations. Employee contributions allegedly were reimbursed by Commonwealth. Charges and potential sentences are: Chapnick, 52 counts, 256 years in prison, $12.5 million fine; Fletcher, 32 counts, 160 years, $8 million fine; Kalbach, three counts, 15 years, $750,000 fine; and Adams, six counts, 30 years, $1.5 million fine. All four appeared Wednesday afternoon before U.S. Magistrate Lurana Snow in Fort Lauderdale, where the grand jury issued the indictments. Adams pleaded innocent, and arraignments were delayed until Thursday for Chapnick and Friday for Fletcher and Kalbach.

DOC.HEAD: GM Planning New Plant in Eastern Germany
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp., which already has a modest vehicle assembly agreement in the former East Germany, will build a new assembly plant in the region, a GM executive said Wednesday. Vice Chairman Jack Smith said the $675 million plant in Eisenach will build 150,000 small Opel cars a year. Production is to begin in the fall of 1992. GM has a joint manufacturing venture in Eisenach that began building Opel Vectra midsize cars Oct. 5. Its target production is 10,000 vehicles a year, considered very low volume. GM has been the most aggressive of the Big Three in moving into the former Communist nations of Eastern Europe. Among its ventures are dealer networks in Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEAD: Continental's Creditors Meet to Organize Panel
DOC.TEXT: Creditors of Continental Airlines, which has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of bankruptcy laws, met Wednesday to begin discussing their strategies for dealing with Continental's attempts to reorganize. The creditors met for several hours in Wilmington, Del., where the company was incorporated, but broke up without selecting a chairman or general counsel, said Chris Matthews of Ameritrust Texas, which is acting as trustee for individual bondholders. The meeting likely will resume Thursday, he said. Continental Airlines filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Dec. 3, blaming the high cost of fuel since Iraq invaded Kuwait and its mounting debt. Service for passengers has continued normally.

DOC.NOTE:
Eds: Columbia Savings & Loan Association filed a $6 billion civil lawsuit against former junk bond financier Michael Milken in federal court in Los Angeles. The failed thrift accused Milken, nine other Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. officials and more than 100 Drexel-sponsored partnerships of coercive and manipulative junk bond sales. A story, AM-Columbia-Milken, is being expedited.
^The AP

DOC.HEAD: Companies Reach Chip Royalty Pact
DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc. and Toshiba Corp. of Japan reached a 10-year cross-licensing agreement covering a broad class of TI's microchip technology, Texas Instrument announced. Terms of the agreement, which replaces a 5-year accord expiring at the end of the year, were not disclosed. The payments will be based on worldwide sales of Toshiba semiconductors. Toshiba is the first of several semiconductor manufacturers in negotiations with TI to reach an agreement. The companies, whose licensing agreements expire at the end of the year, include most of the nine semiconductor manufacturers TI sued for patent infringement in 1986. The lawsuit also named Fujitsu Ltd., Hitachi Ltd., Oki Electric Industry Co., Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., NEC Corp., Mitsubishi Electric Corp. and Sharp Corp. of Japan, and Samsung Co. of South Korea. TI officials said in a news release that the new agreement ``reinforces TI's belief that it has the opportunity to earn a significant ongoing stream of royalty revenues from its worldwide patent portfolio.'' Analysts say the deal could net the Dallas-based company hundreds of millions of dollars. TI holds basic patents on the integrated circuit, the memory chip and other semiconductor technology. In recent years, the company has been aggressively enforcing its semiconductor patents, suing U.S. and foreign manufacturers it believes are using its technology without paying royalties.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Down As OPEC Ponders Crude Glut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3 pvs with 2 new grafs to ADD that prices now lowest since day after the invasion. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `With supply ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices dropped about $1 per barrel on the futures market Wednesday, as OPEC ministers wrestled with a potential glut of crude and demand by U.S. refineries tapered off. Light sweet crude for next-month delivery settled at $25.35 per barrel, its lowest level since Aug. 3, the day after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Contracts for January delivery finished down $1.06. Later months also traded lower. Despite the latest fall and an overall bearish mood among oil traders over the past two weeks, crude has seemed unwilling to give up a remnant ``war premium'' of around $5 a barrel in recent sessions on the New York Mercantile Exchange. With supply strong and demand weakening, oil traders said prices would likely have fallen below $20 per barrel recently without the lingering threat of a war in the Persian Gulf. But Iraq's insistence that it will keep oil-rich Kuwait has kept crude above $25 per barrel. The market ``seems to want to include at least a $5 to $6 premium while this incredible military standoff occurs,'' said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. Crude staged a brief rally Wednesday as traders responded to a continued diplomatic stalemate between U.S. and Iraqi officials over a date when Secretary of State James A. Baker III should go to Baghdad to discuss the crisis. The United States wants the meeting to occur in early January, but Iraq insistson waiting until just before Jan. 15. The U.N. Security Council has given Iraq until that date to either get out of Kuwait or face a possible military strike. But the market was more intently focused on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting in Vienna. OPEC ministers were warned their gushing crude production could lead to an oil glut and falling prices when the Gulf crisis ends, but they appeared reluctant to quickly cut output and lift slipping prices. Traders in New York were also put in a bearish mood by the weekly American Petroleum Institute report, issued Tuesday evening, which indicated the nation's refinery utilization had dropped from 88 percent of capacity to 83 percent of capacity in the past week. That means demand for crude oil will be down, experts said. ``When that many refineries decide to cut runs, they don't shift those dials every day or every week, so it's pretty structurally bearish,'' said Christian Gohler, an oil broker with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. As crude fell, futures prices for refined petroleum products also took a dive. Home heating oil dropped 3.05 cents to 74.63 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in January. Unleaded gasoline fell 2.30 cents to 64.49 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in January. Natural gas, which is not threatened by the possibility of war in the Middle East, dropped 8.1 cents to $2.204 per 1,000 cubic feet on contracts for January delivery.

DOC.HEAD: Accounting Firm Settles with Regulators on Silverado Charges
DOC.NOTE: EdS: SUBS grafs 16-17 pvs, `If Coopers ... savings industry,' to CLARIFY that hearing could have resulted in orders to firm and that Bush could be barred from both banking and thrift industries. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand, charged by federal regulators with making a faulty audit of a failed Colorado savings and loan, has agreed to tighten its auditing procedures, the government announced Wednesday. The Office of Thrift Supervision said its settlement with Coopers & Lybrand was its first major enforcement action against a big accounting firm. Experts have noted that accountants played an important role in the $500 billion savings and loan scandal, but until now regulators have focused their attention mainly on S&L operators and directors. The charges against Coopers & Lybrand stemmed from its 1986 audit of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver, whose board of directors included President Bush's son Neil. The collapse of Silverado in December 1988 is expected to cost taxpayers $1 billion. The Office of Thrift Supervision had accused Coopers & Lybrand and Arthur L. Knight, who headed the firm's team that handled the Silverado audit, of, among other things: -Accepting an unjustified understatement of Silverado's allowance for loan losses on its $1.3 billion loan portfolio. -Relying on appraisers' judgments that were not justified by market conditions or by financial statements applying to the properties behind the loans. -Not following accounting principles. The loan loss allowance should have been $35 million higher, the Ofice of Thrift Supervision said. The auditors ``did not possess the expertise required to properly complete the Silverado audit,'' the office asserted in a legal brief released with its announcement. ``This is a significant case for OTS, for those who provide professional services to insured institutions and for the public,'' said Timothy Ryan, director of the office, in a written statement. ``It says loud and clear that we hold accountants, lawyers and other professionals accountable for their actions, just as we do S&L directors and officers.'' In its settlement, the accounting firm agreed to meet a number of auditing requirements over the next five years. In addition, Knight agreed not to audit any insured savings institutions. ``In today's emotional and super-charged environment Coopers & Lybrand decided as a prudent business matter not to incur the expense, aggravation and substantial publicity that would have been associated with fighting the Office of Thrift Supervision,'' the firm's general counsel, Harris J. Amhowitz, said in a statement of his own. Amhowitz's statement indicated that Coopers & Lybrand believes its Silverado audit was not faulty. ``During the relevant 1986-87 period, the firm conducted several hundred audits of savings institutions with no indication of any endemic audit failures,'' the statement said. ``The GAO's report to Congress regarding audits by various accounting firms of failed savings assocations expressed no criticism of Coopers & Lybrand's audits.'' Coopers & Lybrand agreed, among other things, to ensure that employees on S&L audits are competent, and to comply with accounting principles for those audits. If Coopers & Lybrand had not settled the charges, it could have been required to participate in a public administrative hearing. That hearing could have resulted in orders to the firm to do, or stop doing, certain things. Neil Bush has been charged with conflict of interest in not fully disclosing his business ties with two big Silverado borrowers. The thrift agency is seeking an administrative order against Bush, an oil and gas developer, that could lead to barring him from the banking and savings industries. Bush, 35, has denied any wrongdoing. Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson is expected to recommend by Jan. 2 what sanctions, if any, should be taken against Bush. Bush and other former Silverado directors, as well as the thrift's law firm, have been charged with negligence in a $200 million lawsuit filed in September by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Claim 1 Million Combined Circulation
With AM-Daily News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Newsday sold ...,' to correct date strike began to Oct. 25, sted Oct. 28. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The combined circulations of Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, and offspring New York Newsday exceeded 1 million Sunday for the first time, the joint publisher said Wednesday. Newsday sold 600,000 copies and New York Newsday sold 400,000, publisher Robert M. Johnson said. Circulation has surged since a strike at the rival Daily News began Oct. 25. ``This is a milestone in our publishing history and something that we can all be proud of as the pinnacle of our 50th anniversary,'' Johnson said. Before the Daily News strike began, Sunday circulation had been 562,000 for Newsday and 150,000 for New York Newsday. Since the strike, the five-day average daily circulation of New York Newsday has increased from 221,000 to just under 350,000. Newsday's weekday editions have risen from a prestrike 492,000 to almost 525,000. Newsday was founded in 1940. New York Newsday, with a separate editorial staff, began publishing in 1985. Both are owned by Times Mirror Inc.

DOC.HEAD: T. Boone Pickens' Mesa Looks To Change Debt
DOC.TEXT: Mesa Limited Partnership, led by investor T. Boone Pickens, is working on a second transaction to repay 95 percent of its bank debt, a spokesman said Wednesday. The deal, coupled with the sale of natural gas properties finalized last week, will ``significantly strengthen the balance sheet,'' said Sidney Tassin, who works with general partner Pickens on Mesa's financial transactions. Mesa has been looking for ways to repay $1 billion in short-term bank debt. Its cash flow has been hobbled by low natural gas prices. Tassin said a broker is looking for buyers for Mesa's debt through a so-called private placement. American Banker reported Tuesday that Mesa hopes to raise $600 million through the placement. The funds raised would be used to repay Mesa's bank debt, Tassin said. The result would be debt that could be repaid over a longer period of time, 15 to 20 years, he said. Mesa incurred debt through the purchase of natural gas properties, which are long-term assets. Repayment of the new debt will match with the life of Mesa's natural gas assets, Tassin said. Mesa has also eliminated some of its debt through the sale of assets. The partnership last week finalized an agreement to sell about 13 percent of its reserves to Houston-based Seagull Energy Corp. The transaction will trim about $350 million from Mesa's debt. Its completion hinges on Seagull obtaining financial commitments. After the deal is closed, which is expected to be early next year, Mesa's primary interests will be in the Hugoton field of southwest Kansas, the West Panhandle field of Texas, the San Juan Basin of New Mexico and in the Gulf of Mexico. The private placement and sale to Seagull will repay about $950 million of Mesa's $1 billion in bank debt. Mesa's debt for more than 10 years has been secured by its prize properties in the Hugoton field. Mesa earlier this year decided not to pay common or preferred dividends to partners because of the lower cash flow. That left Pickens, who is compensated with 1 percent of Mesa's cash distribution, without a regular salary.

DOC.HEAD: Hilton Stock Shoots Up on Report of Buyout Interest
DOC.TEXT: Hilton Hotels Corp. stock shot up $6.67{ to $42.12{ a share Wednesday on a report that an investor group was mulling a $75 per share offer for the hotel-gaming concern. Trading volume was more than 2.5 million shares - 10 times the normal trading for Hilton on the New York Stock Exchange. A spokesman for the hotel-casino concern said no one had approached it about a buyout. Hilton had put itself up for sale and the stock hit an all-time high of $115.50 in summer 1989. The company took itself off the market last March after entertaining offers, including some from Japanese companies, that came in lower than expected. That decision, along with weak earnings, worries about the travel business and the Persian Gulf crisis, sent the stock to as low as $27 in recent months. Hilton spokesman James Galbraith cited a televised report Tuesday night by financial commentator Dan Dorfman as the reason for the big jump in Hilton's share price. Dorfman said some Japanese investors were included in the interested group. Michael Mueller, an analyst who follows hotel and gaming companies for Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco, noted that Hilton's stock price had been on the rise before the report. ``I turned positive on these stocks when the oil prices went down and it looked like there might be peace in the Gulf,'' Mueller said. Although the Japanese have recently bought such ``trophy'' properties as the Pebble Beach golf resorts and MCA Inc., Mueller said he was skeptical about the chances of getting financing for a bid such as described by Dorfman in today's tight credit markets. ``That would be a $4.5 billion transaction,'' Mueller said. ``It would be very tough right now to finance a real estate-hotel transaction of that kind.''

DOC.HEAD: Merc, Board of Trade Lower Circuit Breakers on Two Stock Index Futures
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade said they would implement new maximum daily price limits on two stock index futures contracts starting Thursday. The daily limit on the S&P 500 futures contract at the Merc will be narrowed from 30 points - roughly equivalent to 250 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average - to 20 points - equivalent to about 150 Dow points, the Merc said Wednesday. The daily limit on the MMI futures contract at the Board of Trade will be narrowed from 50 points - equivalent to about 250 Dow Points - to 30 points, equivalent to about 150 Dow points, the Merc said. All other price limits, also known as circuit breakers, remain at current levels, the world's two largest commodities exchanges said in a statement. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has approved the new price limits, which were proposed by the governing boards of each exchange in September, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Founder of Herman Miller Furniture Company Dies at 99
DOC.TEXT: Dirk Jan DePree, who founded Herman Miller Inc. and turned it into the second-largest U.S. office furniture company, has died. DePree died Monday night in a Holland rest home at age 99. DePree founded Zeeland-based Herman Miller in 1923, buying Star Furniture Co. with the help of his father-in-law, for whom the new company was named. DePree served as general manager until 1949 and president until 1962, when he was named chairman. The company is the second largest of its kind after Steelcase Inc. of Grand Rapids. DePree, a Zeeland native, was not a designer, but the company became known for hiring now-famous industry names such as Gilbert Rohde, Charles Eames and Robert Probst. Herman Miller furniture has been featured at the New York Museum of Modern Art and the Smithsonian Institution. During DePree's tenure, the company produced the ``House of Tomorrow'' for the 1934 World's Fair, the modular wall storage system, molded plywood and plastic chairs of the 1940s, and the stacking chairs of the 1950s. Earlier this year, DePree was named to the American National Business Hall of Fame, which recognized his development in the 1950s of a ``humanistic'' approach to the work place, including participatory management, profit sharing and employee incentives. The publicly held, Fortune 500 company has been named one of the ``10 most admired'' companies by the magazine. DePree served nearly 10 years as pastor of Ventura Baptist Church in Zeeland. He also served as international president of the Gideons Society. DePree's son, Hugh, is president emeritus of the company and another son, Max, is chairman. His other surviving children are Merle Schaap of Lansing and Betty Van Kley of Zeeland.
